def.en: Your #abdomen# is the part of your body below your chest where your stomach and intestines are.
def.exmp: He was suffering from pains in his abdomen.

def.en: #Abatement# means a reduction in the strength or power of something or the reduction of it.
def.exmp: ...the abatement of carbon dioxide emissions. ...noise abatement.

def.en: If someone in authority #abolishes# a system or practice, they formally put an end to it.
def.exmp: The following year Parliament voted to abolish the death penalty for murder. The whole system should be abolished.

def.en: If things #abound#, or if a place #abounds# #with# things, there are very large numbers of them.
def.exmp: Stories abound about when he was in charge. Venice abounds in famous hotels. The book abounds with close-up images from space.

def.en: If you go #abroad#, you go to a foreign country, usually one which is separated from the country where you live by an ocean or a sea.
def.exmp: I would love to go abroad this year, perhaps to the South of France. ...public opposition here and abroad. He will stand in for Mr Goh when he is abroad. About 65 per cent of its sales come from abroad. There'll still be a feeling abroad that this change has to be recognised.

def.en: An #abrupt# change or action is very sudden, often in a way which is unpleasant.
def.exmp: Rosie's idyllic world came to an abrupt end when her parents' marriage broke up. The recession brought an abrupt halt to this happiness. His abrupt departure is bound to raise questions. He stopped abruptly and looked my way. He was abrupt to the point of rudeness. Cross was a little taken aback by her abrupt manner. 'Good night, then,' she said abruptly. I think Simon was hurt by your abruptness this afternoon.

def.en: If something #absorbs# a liquid, gas, or other substance, it soaks it up or takes it in.
def.exmp: Plants absorb carbon dioxide from the air and moisture from the soil. Refined sugars are absorbed into the bloodstream very quickly. A household radiator absorbs energy in the form of electric current and releases it in the form of heat. The Colonial Office was absorbed into the Foreign Office. ...an economy capable of absorbing thousands of immigrants. ...footwear which does not absorb the impact of the foot striking the ground. The banks would be forced to absorb large losses. We can't absorb those costs. It absorbed vast amounts of capital that could have been used for investment. It might help if campaigning didn't absorb so much time and money. Too often he only absorbs half the information in the manual. We closed our offices at 2:00 p.m. to give employees time to absorb the bad news. ...a second career which absorbed her more completely than her acting ever had.

def.en: An #abstract# idea or way of thinking is based on general ideas rather than on real things and events.
def.exmp: ...abstract principles such as justice. It's not a question of some abstract concept. ...the faculty of abstract reasoning. It is hard to think abstractly in these conditions. ...abstract words such as glory, honor, and courage. ...a modern abstract painting. ...a licence to abstract water from the River Axe. The author has abstracted poems from earlier books.

def.en: If you say that something is #absurd#, you are criticizing it because you think that it is ridiculous or that it does not make sense.
def.exmp: It is absurd to be discussing compulsory redundancy policies for teachers. I've known clients of mine go to absurd lengths, just to avoid paying me a few pounds. That's absurd. Parkinson had a sharp eye for the absurd. Prices were still absurdly low, in his opinion. Absurdly, it makes shoppers overpay farmers to grow too much food. I find myself growing increasingly angry at the absurdity of the situation. ...the absurdities of fashionable childcare methods.

def.en: An #abundance# #of# something is a large quantity of it.
def.exmp: The area has an abundance of wildlife. Food was in abundance.

def.en: Something that is #abundant# is present in large quantities.
def.exmp: There is an abundant supply of cheap labour. Birds are abundant in the tall vegetation.

def.en: #Academy# is sometimes used in the names of schools and colleges, especially those specializing in particular subjects or skills, or private high schools in the United States.
def.exmp: ...the Royal Academy of Music. ...her experience as a police academy instructor. ...the American Academy of Psychotherapists. The British Academy of Film and Television Arts.

def.en: #Accessories# are items of equipment that are not usually essential, but which can be used with or added to something else in order to make it more efficient, useful, or decorative.
def.exmp: ...an exclusive range of hand-made bedroom and bathroom accessories. She was charged with being an accessory to the embezzlement of funds. Forster established the essentiality of minerals as accessory food factors required for maintaining life.

def.en: An #accidental# event happens by chance or as the result of an accident, and is not deliberately intended.
def.exmp: The jury returned a verdict of accidental death. His hand brushed against hers; it could have been either accidental or deliberate. A policeman accidentally killed his two best friends with a single bullet. A special locking system means the door cannot be opened accidentally.

def.en: If someone or something #is acclaimed#, they are praised enthusiastically.
def.exmp: She has been acclaimed for the TV drama 'Prime Suspect'. He was acclaimed as England's greatest modern painter. The group's debut album was immediately acclaimed a hip hop classic. She has published six highly acclaimed novels. Angela Bassett has won critical acclaim for her excellent performance. All this equipment has received international acclaim from the specialist hi-fi press.

def.en: If a building or space can #accommodate# someone or something, it has enough room for them.
def.exmp: The school in Poldown was not big enough to accommodate all the children. The CD-ROMS will accommodate the works of all English poets from 600 to 1900. ...a hotel built to accommodate guests for the wedding of King Alfonso. Students are accommodated in homes nearby. The roads are built to accommodate gradual temperature changes. The way that American history is taught may change in order to accommodate some more of those cultures. He has never put an arm around his wife to accommodate photographers. He's already altered several of the proposals in his economic plan to accommodate demands of special interests. Some animal and plant species cannot accommodate to the rapidly changing conditions. She walked slowly to accommodate herself to his pace.

def.en: #Accommodation# is used to refer to buildings or rooms where people live or stay.
def.exmp: The government will provide temporary accommodation for up to three thousand people. Prices start at £2,095 per person, including flights, hotel accommodation and various excursions. Rates are higher for deluxe accommodations. The school occupies split-site accommodation on the main campus. Some trains carry bicycles, but accommodation is restricted so a reservation is essential. His instinct would be to seek a new accommodation with the nationalists. Religions, to survive, must make accommodations with the larger political structures that nurture them.

def.en: An #accord# between countries or groups of people is a formal agreement, for example to end a war.
def.exmp: ...a fitting way to celebrate the peace accord. His predecessor was accorded an equally tumultuous welcome. The government accorded him the rank of Colonel. The treatment accorded to a United Nations official was little short of insulting. Such an approach accords with the principles of socialist ideology. ...scientific evidence that did not fully accord with the facts uncovered by the police.

def.en: You use #accordingly# to introduce a fact or situation which is a result or consequence of something that you have just referred to.
def.exmp: We have a different background, a different history. Accordingly, we have the right to different futures. The workforce have recently been calling for their working hours to be reduced. Many companies have accordingly switched to a five-day week. It is a difficult job and they should be paid accordingly. The new government will make a judgment about its interests and act accordingly.

def.en: If you have an #account# with a bank or a similar organization, you have an arrangement to leave your money there and take some out when you need it.
def.exmp: Some banks make it difficult to open an account. I had two accounts with Natwest, a savings account and a current account. Biggart Donald, the Glasgow-based marketing agency, has won two Edinburgh accounts. He kept detailed accounts. ...an account book. He gave a detailed account of what happened on the fateful night. According to police accounts, Mr and Mrs Hunt were found dead on the floor of their kitchen. This basic utilitarian model gives a relatively unsophisticated account of human behaviour. Science, on Weber's account, is an essentially value-free activity. The opening day of the battle was, nevertheless, accounted a success. ...homosexuals, whose sexual behaviour is still accounted sinful by the church.

def.en: An # account# is a detailed record of all the money that a business or a person receives and spends.
def.exmp: In double entry bookkeeping, every debit or credit in the #account# is also represented as a credit or debit somewhere else. Unless we make an adjustment to lower the original cost figure shown in the #accounts#, we will be overstating the value of the asset.

def.en: An # account# is a record kept by a business of invoices and payments for a customer.
def.exmp: The check for $8000 was an immediate payment on #account# of the agreed price for the house. We have gained some new clients to offset the old clients, but we've probably lost more #accounts# than we've gained.

def.en: An # account# is a regular client or customer, such as a firm or trader buying goods or supplies on credit.
def.exmp: New #account# applications require information to be filled out first by the potential customer, then by the company for quotation, and then back to the customer for final signature. We have gained some new clients to offset the old clients, but we've probably lost more #accounts# than we've gained.

def.en: An #accountant# is a person whose job is to keep financial accounts.
When you #accumulate# things or when they #accumulate#, they collect or are gathered over a period of time.
def.exmp: Households accumulate wealth across a broad spectrum of assets. Lead can accumulate in the body until toxic levels are reached.

def.en: The #accuracy# #of# information or measurements is their quality of being true or correct, even in small details.
def.exmp: We cannot guarantee the accuracy of these figures. ...weapons that could fire with accuracy at targets 3,000 yards away. Every bank pays close attention to the speed and accuracy of its staff.

def.en: #Accurate# information, measurements, and statistics are correct to a very detailed level.
def.exmp: Police have stressed that this is the most accurate description of the killer to date. This may provide a quick and accurate way of monitoring the amount of carbon dioxide in the air. Quartz timepieces are very accurate, to a minute or two per year. The test can accurately predict what a bigger explosion would do. Joseph Stalin gave an accurate assessment of the utility of nuclear weapons. They were accurate in their prediction that he would change her life drastically. What many people mean by the word 'power' could be more accurately described as 'control'. Marks were given for accurate spelling and punctuation. ...his maliciously accurate imitation of Hubert de Burgh. The rifle was extremely accurate. The pilots, however, were not as accurate as they should be. ...the technology to aim bombs accurately from aircraft.

def.en: If you #accuse# someone #of# doing something wrong or dishonest, you say or tell them that you believe that they did it.
def.exmp: He was accusing my mum of having an affair with another man. Talk things through in stages. Do not accuse or apportion blame. Her assistant was accused of theft and fraud by the police. All seven charges accused him of lying in his testimony. The accused men have been given relatively light sentences.

def.en: If you #ache# or a part of your body #aches#, you feel a steady, fairly strong pain.
def.exmp: Her head was throbbing and she ached all over. My leg still aches when I sit down. The weary walkers soothed their aching feet in the sea. You feel nausea and aches in your muscles. Poor posture can cause neck ache, headaches and breathing problems. She still ached for the lost intimacy and sexual contact of marriage. But Spain was a country aching to get away from its past. It was quite an achievement to keep smiling when his heart must have been aching. You also feel an overwhelming ache for support from others which you cannot put into words.

def.en: An #acid# is a chemical substance, usually a liquid, which contains hydrogen and can react with other substances to form salts.
def.exmp: ...citric acid. Acids in the stomach destroy the virus. These shrubs must have an acid, lime-free soil. ...the acidity of rainwater. These wines may taste rather hard and somewhat acid. ...a finely balanced wine with ripe acidity and soft fruit flavours. This comedy of contemporary manners is told with compassion and acid humour. 'You don't know how to be a mother and you never did,' she said acidly.

def.en: If you #acknowledge# a fact or a situation, you accept or admit that it is true or that it exists.
def.exmp: Naylor acknowledged, in a letter to the judge, that he was a drug addict. Belatedly, the government has acknowledged the problem. There is an acknowledged risk of lung cancer from radon. He is also acknowledged as an excellent goal-keeper. Some of the clergy refused to acknowledge the new king's legitimacy. The army sent me a postcard acknowledging my request. He saw her but refused to even acknowledge her. Doran stuck his head out of the window to acknowledge the cheering. She never even acknowledged the man who opened the door for her. He acknowledged the applause with a small bow.

def.en: If you #acquaint# someone #with# something, you tell them about it so that they know it.
def.exmp: ...efforts to acquaint the public with their rights under the new law. I want to acquaint myself with your strengths and weaknesses.

def.en: An #acquaintance# is someone who you have met and know slightly, but not well.
def.exmp: The proprietor was an old acquaintance of his. I have a large circle of friends and acquaintances engaged in photography. ...a writer who becomes involved in a real murder mystery through his acquaintance with a police officer. On first acquaintance she is cool and slightly distant. They had little or no acquaintance with philosophy or history.

def.en: If you #acquire# something, you buy or obtain it for yourself, or someone gives it to you.
def.exmp: General Motors acquired a 50% stake in Saab for about $400m. I recently acquired some wood from a holly tree. She was sitting in her newly-acquired wheelchair. I've never acquired a taste for wine. Having read the book, she will be able to pass on the acquired knowledge to trainee teachers. He has acquired a reputation as this country's premier solo violinist.

def.en: If a company or business person makes an #acquisition#, they buy another company or part of a company.
def.exmp: ...the acquisition of a profitable paper recycling company. ...the number of mergers and acquisitions made by Europe's 1,000 leading firms. How did you go about making this marvellous acquisition then? ...the President's recent acquisition of a helicopter. From her wardrobe Laura took her latest acquisition, a bright red dress. ...language acquisition.

def.en: An # acquisition# is the act of buying another company or part of a company.
def.exmp: The company has said it will now explore other opportunities for expansion, and it is expected to use the proceeds from the deal to help finance another #acquisition#. A management buyout is the #acquisition# of a company by its management team, assisted by external or other financing. #An acquisition# is the act of buying another company or part of a company.

def.en: An #acre# is an area of land measuring 4840 square yards or 4047 square metres.
def.exmp: The property is set in two acres of land.

def.en: An #acrobat# is an entertainer who performs difficult physical acts such as jumping and balancing, especially in a circus.
If a device or process #is# #activated#, something causes it to start working.
def.exmp: Video cameras with night vision can be activated by movement. ...a voice-activated computer. A computer controls the activation of an air bag.

def.en: Someone who is #active# moves around a lot or does a lot of things.
def.exmp: Having an active youngster about the house can be quite wearing. ...a long and active life. ...the tragedy of an active mind trapped by failing physical health. ...a chance for fathers to play a more active role in childcare. I am an active member of the Conservative Party. He is active on Tyler's behalf. They actively campaigned for the vote. Companies need to take active steps to increase exports. ...active discouragement from teachers. They have never been actively encouraged to take such risks. ...the White House says the president is not actively considering such a move. Guerrilla groups are active in the province. ...animals which are active at night. ...men who are sexually active. ...molten lava from an active volcano. The active ingredient in some of the mouthwashes was simply detergent.

def.en: You use #actual# to emphasize that you are referring to something real or genuine.
def.exmp: The segments are filmed using either local actors or the actual people involved. Officials admit the actual number of AIDS victims is much higher than statistics reflect. She had compiled pages of notes, but she had not yet gotten down to doing the actual writing. The exercises in this chapter can guide you, but it will be up to you to do the actual work.

def.en: You can use #acute# to indicate that an undesirable situation or feeling is very severe or intense.
def.exmp: The war has aggravated an acute economic crisis. The report has caused acute embarrassment to the government. The labour shortage is becoming acute. ...a patient with acute rheumatoid arthritis. ...an acute case of dysentery. In the dark my sense of hearing becomes so acute. Into her nineties, her thinking remained acute and her character forceful. His relaxed exterior hides an extremely acute mind. Everything he writes demonstrates the acuteness of his intelligence.

def.en: An #addict# is someone who takes harmful drugs and cannot stop taking them.
def.exmp: He's only 24 years old and a drug addict. She is a TV addict and watches as much as she can.

def.en: An #addition# #to# something is a thing which is added to it.
def.exmp: This is a fine book; a worthy addition to the Cambridge Encyclopedia series. This plywood addition helps to strengthen the structure. It was completely refurbished in 1987, with the addition of a picnic site. ...simple addition and subtraction problems.

def.en: #Additional# things are extra things apart from the ones already present.
def.exmp: The U.S. is sending additional troops to the region. The insurer will also have to pay the additional costs of the trial.

def.en: If something is #adequate#, there is enough of it or it is good enough to be used or accepted.
def.exmp: One in four people worldwide are without adequate homes. The old methods weren't adequate to meet current needs. The western diet should be perfectly adequate for most people. Many students are not adequately prepared for higher education. I speak the language adequately.

def.en: If you #adhere# #to# a rule or agreement, you act in the way that it says you should.
def.exmp: All members of the association adhere to a strict code of practice. She adhered to the strict Islamic dress code. He urged them to adhere to the values of Islam which defend the dignity of man. Small particles adhere to the seed. This sticky compound adheres well on this surface.

def.en: If one thing is #adjacent# #to# another, the two things are next to each other.
def.exmp: He sat in an adjacent room and waited. The schools were adjacent but there were separate doors. ...offices adjacent to the museum.

def.en: If one room, place, or object #adjoins# another, they are next to each other.
def.exmp: Fields adjoined the garden and there were no neighbours. We waited in an adjoining office.

def.en: #Admission# is permission given to a person to enter a place, or permission given to a country to enter an organization.
def.exmp: Students apply for admission to a particular college. Poland and Czechoslovakia have vigorously pursued admission to the European Community. ...an increase in hospital admissions of children. Each school sets its own admissions policy. Gates open at 10.30am and admission is free. The admission price is $8 for adults. By his own admission, he is not playing well. She wanted some admission of guilt from her father.

def.en: If you #admit# that something bad, unpleasant, or embarrassing is true, you agree, often unwillingly, that it is true.
def.exmp: I am willing to admit that I do make mistakes. Up to two thirds of 14 to 16 year olds admit to buying drink illegally. I'd be ashamed to admit feeling jealous. None of these people will admit responsibility for their actions. 'Actually, most of my tennis is at club level,' he admitted. She was admitted to hospital with a soaring temperature. He was admitted yesterday for treatment of blood clots in his lungs. He was admitted to the Academie Culinaire de France. The Parachute Regiment could be forced to admit women. Embassy security personnel refused to admit him or his wife. Journalists are rarely admitted to the region.

def.en: #Adolescent# is used to describe young people who are no longer children but who have not yet become adults.
def.exmp: It is important that an adolescent boy should have an adult in whom he can confide. He spent his adolescent years playing guitar in the church band. ...adolescent rebellion. Young adolescents are happiest with small groups of close friends.

def.en: If you #adopt# a new attitude, plan, or way of behaving, you begin to have it.
def.exmp: Parliament adopted a resolution calling for the complete withdrawal of troops. Pupils should be helped to adopt a positive approach to the environment. ...the adoption of Japanese management practices by British manufacturing. There are hundreds of people desperate to adopt a child. The adopted child has the right to see his birth certificate. A social worker is appointed to interview the prospective adopters. They gave their babies up for adoption. The majority of adoptions are successful. I tried to adopt a curled-up position to avoid damaging my limbs. Podulski had joined the U.S. Navy as an aviator, adopting a new country and a new profession. ...their adopted home in England. He has adopted the accent of a Second World War newscaster. The girl was uncertain what to do, or what tone of voice to adopt.

def.en: If you #adore# someone, you feel great love and admiration for them.
def.exmp: She adored her parents and would do anything to please them. My mother adores bananas and eats two a day. I adore good books and the theatre.

def.en: To #advance# means to move forward, often in order to attack someone.
def.exmp: Reports from Chad suggest that rebel forces are advancing on the capital. The water is advancing at a rate of 5cm a day. ...a picture of a man throwing himself before an advancing tank. Medical technology has advanced considerably. Japan has advanced from a rural, feudal society to an urban, industrial power. I advanced him some money, which he would repay on our way home. The bank advanced $1.2 billion to help the country with debt repayments. She was paid a £100,000 advance for her next two novels. Too much protein in the diet may advance the ageing process. The country's election commission has advanced the date of parliamentary elections by three days. When not producing art of his own, Oliver was busy advancing the work of others. Many theories have been advanced as to why some women suffer from depression. An important set of ideas have been advanced by the biologist Rupert Sheldrake. ...an advance on enemy positions. The defences are intended to obstruct any advance by tanks and other vehicles. Mark had for some time been making advances towards her. She rejected his advances during the trip to Cannes. Air safety has not improved since the dramatic advances of the 1970s. Their progress at work was mirrored by their children's educational advance. This could be an advance on the present situation. They don't normally give any advance notice about which building they're going to inspect. The event received little advance publicity. The 20-strong advance party will be followed by another 600 soldiers as part of U.N. relief efforts.

def.en: If you# advance# money for promised goods or services, you pay the money before the goods or services are provided.
def.exmp: A syndicate #advanced# the money to pay for the construction. The subcontractor's severe cost overruns made it necessary for the company to #advance# cash to ensure completion of the project. If you #advance# money for promised goods or services, you pay the money before the goods or services are provided.

def.en: In the Christian church, #Advent# is the period between Advent Sunday, the Sunday closest to the 30th of November, and Christmas Day.
#The# #advent# #of# an important event, invention, or situation is the fact of it starting or coming into existence.
def.exmp: ...the leap forward in communication made possible by the advent of the mobile phone. The advent of war led to a greater austerity. Deptford had come alive with the advent of the new priest at St Paul's.

def.en: If someone has an #adventure#, they become involved in an unusual, exciting, and rather dangerous journey or series of events.
def.exmp: I set off for a new adventure in the United States on the first day of the new year. Their cultural backgrounds gave them a spirit of adventure. ...a feeling of adventure and excitement. The group has adventured as far as the Austrian alps.

def.en: An #adverb# is a word such as 'slowly', 'now', 'very', 'politically', or 'fortunately' which adds information about the action, event, or situation mentioned in a clause.
#Adverse# decisions, conditions, or effects are unfavourable to you.
def.exmp: The police said Mr Hadfield's decision would have no adverse effect on the progress of the investigation. Despite the adverse conditions, the road was finished in just eight months. Price changes must not adversely affect the living standards of the people.

def.en: If you give someone #advice#, you tell them what you think they should do in a particular situation.
def.exmp: Don't be afraid to ask for advice about ordering the meal. Your community officer can give you advice on how to prevent crime in your area. Take my advice and stay away from him! Most foreign nationals have now left the country on the advice of their governments.

def.en: If you tell someone that #it# is #advisable# #to# do something, you are suggesting that they should do it, because it is sensible or is likely to achieve the result they want.
def.exmp: Because of the popularity of the region, it is advisable to book hotels or camp sites in advance. It is generally not advisable for expectant mothers to travel by air after the 28th week of pregnancy. I have doubts about the advisability of surgery in this case.

def.en: If you #advise# someone #to# do something, you tell them what you think they should do.
def.exmp: The minister advised him to leave as soon as possible. Herbert would surely advise her how to approach the bank. I would strongly advise against it. Doctors advised that he should be transferred to a private room. ...an officer who advises undergraduates on money matters. A family doctor will be able to advise on suitable birth control. ...the decision requiring police to advise suspects of their rights. I think it best that I advise you of my decision to retire. Candidates in India are advised to submit their applications through the overseas student office in London. Residents are advised not to put their rubbish bags on the pavement outside their houses.

def.en: If you #advocate# a particular action or plan, you recommend it publicly.
def.exmp: Mr Williams is a conservative who advocates fewer government controls on business. ...the tax policy advocated by the Opposition. He was a strong advocate of free market policies and a multi-party system. ...advocates for the homeless. Animal rights advocates argue that zoos are really animal prisons and very often cruel.

def.en: You talk about #aerial# attacks and #aerial# photographs to indicate that people or things on the ground are attacked or photographed by people in aeroplanes.
def.exmp: Weeks of aerial bombardment had destroyed factories and highways. Patterns that are invisible on the ground can be the most striking part of an aerial photograph. The film begins with an aerial view of the Great Basin of Nevada. The seagulls swirled in aerial combat over the barges. ...a saucer-shaped satellite television aerial. ...the radio aerials of taxis and cars.

def.en: An #aeroplane# is a vehicle with wings and one or more engines that enable it to fly through the air.
#Aesthetic# is used to talk about beauty or art, and people's appreciation of beautiful things.
def.exmp: ...products chosen for their aesthetic appeal as well as their durability and quality. He responded very strongly to the aesthetic of this particular work. There is nothing aesthetically pleasing about this bridge.

def.en: If an event or a series of events has been mentioned and you want to talk about it again, you can refer to it as #the affair#.
def.exmp: The government has mishandled the whole affair. The affair began when customs officials inspected a convoy of 60 tankers. The industry minister described the affair as 'an absolute scandal'. ...the damage caused to the CIA and FBI in the aftermath of the Watergate affair. ...confidential Bank of England documents relating to the BCCI affair. Michael said that his planned 10-day visit would be a purely private affair. Breakfast will be a cheerless affair for the Prime Minister this morning. All their beds were distinctive; Mac's was an iron affair with brass knobs. He tried dividing it into two bundles, tying them to his walking stick, and slinging the whole affair across his back. She was having an affair with someone at work. He does not want to interfere in the internal affairs of another country. With more details, here's our foreign affairs correspondent. He was rational and consistent in the conduct of his affairs. The unexpectedness of my father's death meant that his affairs were not entirely in order. If you wish to make a fool of yourself, that is your affair. If they want to stay and fight, then I guess that's their affair.

def.en: If something #affects# a person or thing, it influences them or causes them to change in some way.
def.exmp: Nicotine adversely affects the functioning of the heart and arteries. More than seven million people have been affected by drought. ...the worst-affected areas of Somalia. Arthritis is a crippling disease which affects people all over the world. The divorce affected Jim deeply. Gregor loved his sister, and her loss clearly still affects him. He listened to them, affecting an amused interest. Ms. Redgrave affects a heavy Italian accent.

def.en: If you regard someone or something with #affection#, you like them and are fond of them.
def.exmp: She thought of him with affection. She had developed quite an affection for the place. ...trying to win their affection. The distant object of his affections is Caroline. Jack Russell has a special place in the affections of the cricketing public. ...her fear of being replaced in his affections.

def.en: An #affiliate# is an organization which is officially connected with another, larger organization or is a member of it.
def.exmp: ...twelve companies, including three affiliates of a Texas oil firm. The World Chess Federation has affiliates in around 120 countries. All youth groups will have to affiliate to the National Youth Agency. The Government will not allow the staff association to affiliate with outside unions. He said he wanted to affiliate with a U.S. firm because he needed 'expert advice and counsel in legal affairs'.

def.en: If you #affirm# that something is true or that something exists, you state firmly and publicly that it is true or exists.
def.exmp: The House of Lords affirmed that the terms of a contract cannot be rewritten retrospectively. ...a speech in which he affirmed a commitment to lower taxes. 'This place is a dump,' affirmed Miss T. The ministers issued an affirmation of their faith in the system. Everything I had accomplished seemed to affirm that opinion. The high turnout was an affirmation of the importance that the voters attached to the election.

def.en: If you are #affluent#, you have a lot of money.
def.exmp: Cigarette smoking used to be commoner among affluent people. ...the affluent neighborhoods of Malibu. The diet of the affluent has not changed much over the decades.

def.en: If you #cannot afford# something, you do not have enough money to pay for it.
def.exmp: My parents can't even afford a new refrigerator. The arts should be available to more people at prices they can afford. We couldn't afford to buy a new rug. We can't afford to wait. The country could not afford the luxury of an election. This affords us the opportunity to ask questions about how the systems might change. It was a cold room, but it afforded a fine view of the Old City. ...the protection afforded by the police.

def.en: An #agency# is a business which provides a service on behalf of other businesses.
def.exmp: We had to hire maids through an agency. ...a successful advertising agency. ...the government agency which monitors health and safety at work in Britain. Webster is retiring as head of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA).

def.en: An # agency# is a group of people who sell and manage insurance contracts.
def.exmp: As an independent insurance #agency#, we help you find insurance solutions tailored to your individual needs. We are an independent #agency# with many insurance carriers offering quality auto insurance coverage. #An agency# is a group of people who sell and manage insurance contracts.

def.en: An #agent# is a person who looks after someone else's business affairs or does business on their behalf.
def.exmp: You are buying direct, rather than through an agent. ...a written declaration by someone, authorizing another person to act as his agent. All these years he's been an agent for the East. In many societies young men regard themselves as highly active, the agents of change, shapers of the world. ...the bleaching agent in white flour. ...fibrinogen, a blood clotting agent.

def.en: A substance that has a particular effect or is used for a particular purpose can be referred to as a particular kind of # agent#.
def.exmp: The type of emulsion produced depends on the solubility of the emulsifying #agent#. A suspending #agent# is used to keep a drug in suspension and prevent it settling. A substance that has a particular effect or is used for a particular purpose can be referred to as a particular kind of #agent#.

def.en: If someone or something #aggravates# a situation, they make it worse.
def.exmp: Stress and lack of sleep can aggravate the situation. He would only aggravate the injury by rubbing it. What aggravates you most about this country? You don't realise how aggravating you can be. I just couldn't take the aggravation.

def.en: An #aggressive# person or animal has a quality of anger and determination that makes them ready to attack other people.
def.exmp: Some children are much more aggressive than others. These fish are very aggressive. Aggressive behaviour is a sign of emotional distress. They'll react aggressively. Her aggressiveness made it difficult for him to explain his own feelings. He is respected as a very aggressive and competitive executive. The Zambian game is much more aggressive than European soccer. ...countries noted for aggressively pursuing energy efficiency.

def.en: If people #agitate# #for# something, they protest or take part in political activity in order to get it.
def.exmp: The women who worked in these mills had begun to agitate for better conditions. At least seventy students were injured in the continuing agitation against the decision. All you need to do is gently agitate the water with a finger or paintbrush. Its molecules can be agitated by microwave energy. Temperature is a measure of the agitation of the molecules of matter. The thought of them getting her possessions when she dies agitates her.

def.en: #Agony# is great physical or mental pain.
def.exmp: A new machine may save thousands of animals from the agony of drug tests. She called out in agony. As a young man he suffered agonies of religious doubt.

def.en: If something is #agreeable#, it is pleasant and you enjoy it.
def.exmp: ...workers in more agreeable and better paid occupations. ...an agreeable surprise. At first we chatted agreeably about his trips to London and Paris. The sisters were agreeably surprised to find out that the King of Spain had been their rescuer. ...sharing a bottle of wine with an agreeable companion. I've gone out of my way to be agreeable to his friends. She was agreeable to the project. If you are agreeable, my husband's office will make all the necessary arrangements. ...a solution that would be agreeable to all.

def.en: An #agreement# is a formal decision about future action which is made by two or more countries, groups, or people.
def.exmp: It looks as though a compromise agreement has now been reached. The two countries signed an agreement to jointly launch satellites. ...a new defence agreement between Greece and the United States. The two men had not reached agreement on any issues. But instead of ending in agreement, the talks broke up in acrimony at the end of the week. The judge kept nodding in agreement. There was general agreement that every effort should be made to prevent the war from spreading. The clinic doctor will then write to your GP to get his agreement. Many other surveys have produced results essentially in agreement with these figures.

def.en: An # agreement# is a plan or a decision that two or more people have made.
def.exmp: Under the #agreement#, all domestic accounts would be cut across the board by 0.3 percent. He has now signed a binding #agreement# to sell his 82 percent stake in the company. #An agreement# is a plan or a decision that two or more people have made.

def.en: #Agriculture# is farming and the methods that are used to raise and look after crops and animals.
def.exmp: The Ukraine is strong both in industry and agriculture. The monsoon has now covered almost all of the agriculturally important north-west of India.

def.en: An #aircraft# is a vehicle which can fly, for example an aeroplane or a helicopter.
def.exmp: The return flight of the aircraft was delayed. At least three military aircraft were destroyed.

def.en: An #airline# is a company which provides regular services carrying people or goods in aeroplanes.
def.exmp: ...the Dutch national airline KLM.

def.en: An #aisle# is a long narrow gap that people can walk along between rows of seats in a public building such as a church or between rows of shelves in a supermarket.
def.exmp: He started down the centre aisle. ...the frozen food aisle. He was in no hurry to walk down the aisle.

def.en: #Alarm# is a feeling of fear or anxiety that something unpleasant or dangerous might happen.
def.exmp: The news was greeted with alarm by MPs. She sat up in alarm. The moves reflect growing alarm over recent events. We could not see what had alarmed him. He heard the alarm go off. ...an extremely sophisticated alarm system. The other man rang the alarm bell.

def.en: If you are #alert#, you are paying full attention to things around you and are able to deal with anything that might happen.
def.exmp: We all have to stay alert. He had been spotted by an alert neighbour. The drug improved mental alertness. The bank is alert to the danger. Due to a security alert, this train will not be stopping at Oxford Circus. He wanted to alert people to the activities of the group. I was hoping he'd alert the police.

def.en: #Alien# means belonging to a different country, race, or group, usually one you do not like or are frightened of.
def.exmp: He said they were opposed to the presence of alien forces in the region. His work offers an insight into an alien culture. Such an attitude is alien to most businessmen. Both women had hired illegal aliens for child care. When war broke out, he was interned as an enemy alien.

def.en: If you #allege# #that# something bad is true, you say it but do not prove it.
def.exmp: She alleged that there was rampant drug use among the male members of the group. The accused is alleged to have killed a man. It was alleged that the restaurant discriminated against black customers.

def.en: If you #alleviate# pain, suffering, or an unpleasant condition, you make it less intense or severe.
def.exmp: Nowadays, a great deal can be done to alleviate back pain. ...the problem of alleviating mass poverty. Their energies were focussed on the alleviation of the refugees' misery.

def.en: An #alliance# is a group of countries or political parties that are formally united and working together because they have similar aims.
def.exmp: The two parties were still too much apart to form an alliance. What will be the effect of the alliance between IBM and Apple? They are now in a position to govern the state in alliance with either the Free Democrats or the Green Party.

def.en: If one item or share of something #is allocated# #to# a particular person or #for# a particular purpose, it is given to that person or used for that purpose.
def.exmp: Tickets are limited and will be allocated to those who apply first. The 1985 federal budget allocated $7.3 billion for development programmes. Our plan is to allocate one member of staff to handle appointments.

def.en: If you # allocate# funds, you divide up or distribute them.
def.exmp: Costs relating to the purchase of materials may be #allocated# according to the number of purchase transactions which have occurred. The government will #allocate# some money in the budget each year to service this debt. If you #allocate# funds, you divide up or distribute them.

def.en: An #allowance# is money that is given to someone, usually on a regular basis, in order to help them pay for the things that they need.
def.exmp: He lives on a single parent's allowance of £70 a week. She gets an allowance for looking after Lillian. ...those earning less than the basic tax allowance. Most of our flights have a baggage allowance of 44lbs per passenger.

def.en: An #alloy# is a metal that is made by mixing two or more types of metal together.
def.exmp: Bronze is an alloy of copper and tin. The company produces titanium alloy.

def.en: An # alloy# is a metal which is not pure because other elements have been added to it.
def.exmp: Melting aluminum with a small amount of copper produces the #alloy# duralumin. Like other copper #alloys#, Cu-Ni alloys possess excellent mechanical properties at low temperatures. #An alloy# is a metal which is not pure because other elements have been added to it.

def.en: A country's #ally# is another country that has an agreement to support it, especially in war.
def.exmp: Washington would not take such a step without its allies' approval. The United States is a close ally of South Korea. He is a close ally of the Prime Minister. She will regret losing a close political ally. He will have no choice but to ally himself with the new movement.

def.en: If one thing is #alongside# another thing, the first thing is next to the second.
def.exmp: He crossed the street and walked alongside Central Park. Much of the industry was located alongside rivers. He waited several minutes for a car to pull up alongside. He had worked alongside Frank and Mark and they had become friends. Men aged 60 are fighting alongside young boys. Her self-confidence will develop alongside her technique. Alongside the Job Creation Programme they launched a Work Experience Programme.

def.en: An #alphabet# is a set of letters usually presented in a fixed order which is used for writing the words of a particular language or group of languages.
def.exmp: The modern Russian alphabet has 31 letters. By two and a half he knew the alphabet.

def.en: When you #alternate# two things, you keep using one then the other.
def.exmp: Her aggressive moods alternated with gentle or more co-operative states. The three acts will alternate as headliners throughout the tour. Now you just alternate layers of that mixture and eggplant. The band alternated romantic love songs with bouncy dance numbers. ...an imaginative novel, with alternating chapters presenting each partner's point of view. The alternation of sun and snow continued for the rest of our holiday. They were streaked with alternate bands of colour. He could alternately bully and charm people. She became alternately angry and calm. Lesley had agreed to Jim going skiing in alternate years. His group was forced to turn back and take an alternate route. ...alternate forms of medical treatment. In most jurisdictions, twelve jurors and two alternates are chosen. The six food groups include grain products, vegetables, fruits, milk and milk products, meats and meat alternates, and a miscellaneous group. ...an alternate lifestyle.

def.en: If something is at a particular #altitude#, it is at that height above sea level.
def.exmp: The aircraft had reached its cruising altitude of about 39,000 feet. The following day I ran my first race at high altitude.

def.en: You use #altogether# to emphasize that something has stopped, been done, or finished completely.
def.exmp: When Artie stopped calling altogether, Julie found a new man. His tour may have to be cancelled altogether. Clinical test results are certainly encouraging - 10 per cent of wrinkles disappear altogether. The choice of language is altogether different. Today's celebrations have been altogether more sedate. This wine has an altogether stronger, more pronounced flavour than their other white wines. We were not altogether sure that the comet would miss the Earth. The fashion business, he claims, not altogether convincingly, is more real than the film business. 'I'm not altogether a fool,' she said gruffly. Altogether, it was a delightful town garden, peaceful and secluded. Britain has a dozen warships in the area, with a total of five thousand military personnel altogether. Altogether seven inmates escaped by scaling a wall and climbing down scaffolding.

def.en: a silvery, lightweight, easily worked, metallic chemical element that resists corrosion and is found abundantly, but only in combination: symbol, Al; at.
#Aluminum# is a lightweight metal used, for example, for making cooking equipment and aircraft parts.
def.exmp: ...aluminum cans.

def.en: # Aluminum# is a chemical element that is used in alloy form to make a lightweight metal, used, for example, for vehicle bodywork.
def.exmp: The cars will have lightweight #aluminum# bodies to improve the power to weight ratio, giving better acceleration. The traditional #aluminum# windshield surround has been replaced by a chunky, black steel frame. The car features a body manufactured almost entirely from #aluminum#, making it 40 percent lighter than a similar steel body.

def.en: Someone who is #ambitious# has a strong desire to be successful, rich, or powerful.
def.exmp: Chris is so ambitious, so determined to do it all. He's a very ambitious lad and he wants to play at the highest level. The ambitious project was completed in only nine months. Their goal was extraordinarily ambitious. Its trade and industrial policies should be used more ambitiously. He is working on his life story, ambitiously planned as a 50-volume work.

def.en: If you #amend# something that has been written such as a law, or something that is said, you change it in order to improve it or make it more accurate.
def.exmp: The president agreed to amend the constitution and allow multi-party elections. 'You must admit that the man has got charm,' said Nicolson. 'Glamour,' amended Wells. ...the amended version of the Act.

def.en: Someone who is #amiable# is friendly and pleasant to be with.
def.exmp: She had been surprised at how amiable and polite he had seemed. We chatted amiably about old friends.

def.en: If something happens #amid# noises or events of some kind, it happens while the other things are happening.
def.exmp: A senior leader cancelled a trip to Britain yesterday amid growing signs of a possible political crisis. Children were changing classrooms amid laughter and shouts. ...a tiny bungalow amid clusters of trees.

def.en: If there is an #ample# amount of something, there is enough of it and usually some extra.
def.exmp: There'll be ample opportunity to relax, swim and soak up some sun. The design of the ground floor created ample space for a good-sized kitchen. They have been amply rewarded with huge salaries. ...a young mother with a baby resting against her ample bosom.

def.en: An #amplifier# is an electronic device in a radio or stereo system which causes sounds or signals to get louder.
An # amplifier# is an electrical circuit that produces an output that is larger than the input.
def.exmp: #An amplifier# is a basic signal processing unit that increases the power of an audio signal. As #an amplifier# simply magnifies what it is given, it will amplify the noise as well as the signal. #An amplifier# is an electrical circuit that produces an output that is larger than the input.

def.en: If you #amplify# a sound, you make it louder, usually by using electronic equipment.
def.exmp: This landscape seemed to trap and amplify sounds. The music was amplified with microphones. 'This is the police,' came the amplified voice from the helicopter. ...a voice that needed no amplification. The mist had been replaced by a kind of haze that seemed to amplify the heat. Her anxiety about the world was amplifying her personal fears about her future. ...that amplification of the elements in his character that made him able to dominate her.

def.en: If something #amuses# you, it makes you want to laugh or smile.
def.exmp: The thought seemed to amuse him. Their antics never fail to amuse. I need distractions. I need to amuse myself so I won't keep thinking about things. Put a selection of baby toys in his cot to amuse him if he wakes early.

def.en: If one thing is an #analogue# #of# another, it is similar in some way.
def.exmp: No model can ever be a perfect analogue of nature itself. The analogue signals from the video tape are converted into digital code.

def.en: If you make or draw an #analogy# #between# two things, you show that they are similar in some way.
def.exmp: It is probably easier to make an analogy between the courses of the planets, and two trains travelling in the same direction.

def.en: #Analytic# means the same as analytical.
An #anecdote# is a short, amusing account of something that has happened.
def.exmp: Pete was telling them an anecdote about their mother. He has a talent for recollection and anecdote. The image of the fox as a pest is grossly exaggerated in anecdote and folklore.

def.en: #Angels# are spiritual beings that some people believe are God's servants in heaven.
def.exmp: Thank you a thousand times, you're an angel. Poppa thought her an angel. He was such an angel to put up with it.

def.en: An # angel# is an investor who uses their own funds to provide capital for a startup.
def.exmp: Venture capitalists will not touch the space industry but, increasingly, #angel# investors are playing a role. A business #angel# can provide both finance and business expertise to an investee company. #An angel# is an investor who uses their own funds to provide capital for a startup.

def.en: An #angle# is the difference in direction between two lines or surfaces.
def.exmp: The boat is now leaning at a 30 degree angle. ...the angle of the blade. ...brackets to adjust the steering wheel's angle. Thanks to the angle at which he stood, he could just see the sunset. His face will be discreetly concealed by camera angles. We had to do the scene over and over again, from different angles. He was considering the idea from all angles. It sounds as if he's just angling for sympathy. You can open the slats for a bright light or angle them for more shade. The path angled downhill and northwards. He drove down the long, steeply angled driveway.

def.en: #Anguish# is great mental suffering or physical pain.
def.exmp: A cry of anguish burst from her lips. Mark looked at him in anguish.

def.en: An #anniversary# is a date which is remembered or celebrated because a special event happened on that date in a previous year.
def.exmp: Vietnam is celebrating the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of Ho Chi Minh.

def.en: If someone or something #annoys# you, it makes you fairly angry and impatient.
def.exmp: Try making a note of the things which annoy you. It annoyed me that I didn't have time to do more reading. It just annoyed me to hear him going on.

def.en: If you remain #anonymous# when you do something, you do not let people know that you were the person who did it.
def.exmp: You can remain anonymous if you wish. An anonymous benefactor stepped in to provide the prize money. ...anonymous phone calls. Both mother and daughter, who have requested anonymity, are doing fine. The latest photographs were sent anonymously to the magazine's Paris headquarters. Of course, that would have to be by anonymous vote. He claims many more people would support him in the anonymity of a voting booth. ...the most anonymous part of north-west Washington. It's nice to stay in a home rather than in an anonymous holiday villa. ...the anonymity of the rented room.

def.en: #Ants# are small crawling insects that live in large groups.
def.exmp: Ants swarmed up out of the ground and covered her shoes and legs.

def.en: The #antennae# of something such as an insect or crustacean are the two long, thin parts attached to its head that it uses to feel things with.
An # antenna# is a device or a piece of wire that sends and receives radio signals.
def.exmp: The car's CD player has an AM/FM radio with a telescoping #antenna# and station presets. The three #antennae# mounted on his car boost the reception of his wireless network. A retractable #antenna# on the hood of the car gives improved radio reception.

def.en: An # antenna# is a system of conductors that radiates and/or receives electromagnetic waves.
def.exmp: A radio station pulses current through #an antenna# at the frequency it has been assigned, producing radio waves that propagate out from the antenna. One of the unique functions of the meter is for tuning the transmitter for maximum power output and matching to the #antenna#. #An antenna# is a system of conductors that radiates and/or receives electromagnetic waves.

def.en: If you #anticipate# an event, you realize in advance that it may happen and you are prepared for it.
def.exmp: At the time we couldn't have anticipated the result of our campaigning. It is anticipated that the equivalent of 192 full-time jobs will be lost. Officials anticipate that rivalry between leaders of the various drug factions could erupt into full scale war. What Jeff did was to anticipate my next question. Do you expect your partner to anticipate your needs? In the 50s, Rauschenberg anticipated the conceptual art movement of the 80s.

def.en: An #antique# is an old object such as a piece of china or furniture which is valuable because of its beauty or rarity.
def.exmp: ...a genuine antique. ...antique silver jewellery. He finds material at auctions, antique shops and flea markets.

def.en: #Anxiety# is a feeling of nervousness or worry.
def.exmp: Her voice was full of anxiety. Many editorials express their anxieties about the economic chaos in the country.

def.en: If you are #anxious# #to# do something or #anxious# #that# something should happen, you very much want to do it or very much want it to happen.
def.exmp: Both the Americans and the Russians are anxious to avoid conflict in South Asia. He is anxious that there should be no delay. Those anxious for reform say that the present system is too narrow. The foreign minister admitted he was still anxious about the situation in the country. A friend of mine is a very anxious person. They are waiting anxiously to see who will succeed him. The Prime Minister faces anxious hours before the votes are counted tomorrow night.

def.en: #Anyhow# means the same as anyway.
def.exmp: ...her long legs which she displayed all anyhow getting in and out of her car.

def.en: You use #anyway# or #anyhow# to indicate that a statement explains or supports a previous point.
def.exmp: I'm certain David's told you his business troubles. Anyway, it's no secret that he owes money. Mother certainly won't let him stay with her and anyhow he wouldn't. I don't know why I settled on Aberdeen, but anyway I did. I wasn't qualified to apply for the job really but I got it anyhow. Mary Ann doesn't want to have children. Not right now, anyway. What do you want from me, anyway? Where the hell was Bud, anyhow? I was told to go to Reading for this interview. It was a very amusing affair. Anyhow, I got the job. 'I've got a terrible cold.'—'Have you? Oh dear. Anyway, so you're not going to go away this weekend?' 'Anyway, I'd better let you have your dinner. Give our love to Francis. Bye.' 'Anyhow, thanks a lot. Bye bye.'

def.en: An #apartment# is a set of rooms for living in, usually on one floor of a large building.
def.exmp: Christina has her own apartment, with her own car. ...bleak cities of concrete apartment blocks. ...the private apartments of the Prince of Wales at St James's Palace.

def.en: If something #appals# you, it disgusts you because it seems so bad or unpleasant.
def.exmp: His ignorance appals me. My wife now looks like her mother, which appals me.

def.en: The #apparatus# of an organization or system is its structure and method of operation.
def.exmp: For many years, the country had been buried under the apparatus of the regime. ...a massive bureaucratic apparatus. One of the boys had to be rescued by firemen wearing breathing apparatus.

def.en: An #apparent# situation, quality, or feeling seems to exist, although you cannot be certain that it does exist.
def.exmp: I was a bit depressed by our apparent lack of progress. There is at last an apparent end to the destructive price war. It has been apparent that in other areas standards have held up well. The presence of a star is already apparent in the early film.

def.en: If you #appeal# #to# someone #to# do something, you make a serious and urgent request to them.
def.exmp: The Prime Minister appealed to young people to use their vote. He will appeal to the state for an extension of unemployment benefits. The United Nations has appealed for help from the international community. He has a message from King Fahd, believed to be an appeal for Arab unity. Romania's government issued a last-minute appeal to him to call off his trip. ...an appeal to save a library containing priceless manuscripts. This is not another appeal for famine relief. He said they would appeal against the decision. We intend to appeal the verdict. Maguire has appealed to the Supreme Court to stop her extradition. Heath's appeal against the sentence was later successful. The jury agreed with her, but she lost the case on appeal. On the other hand, the idea appealed to him. The range has long appealed to all tastes. Its new title was meant to give the party greater public appeal. Johnson's appeal is to people in all walks of life.

def.en: When someone makes an #appearance# at a public event or in a broadcast, they take part in it.
def.exmp: It was the president's second public appearance to date. Keegan made 68 appearances in two seasons for Southampton, scoring 37 times. She used to be so fussy about her appearance. He had the appearance of a college student. A flat-roofed extension will add nothing to the value or appearance of the house. The sudden appearance of a few bags of rice could start a riot. ...last Christmas, when there'd been the welcome appearance of Cousin Fred. Flowering plants were making their first appearance, but were still a rarity. Fears are growing of a cholera outbreak following the appearance of a number of cases in the city. We tried to meet both children's needs without the appearance of favoritism or unfairness. The U.S. president risked giving the appearance that the U.S. was taking sides.

def.en: Your #appendix# is a small closed tube inside your body which is attached to your digestive system.
def.exmp: ...a burst appendix.

def.en: Your #appetite# is your desire to eat.
def.exmp: He has a healthy appetite. Symptoms are a slight fever, headache and loss of appetite. ...his appetite for success. ...Americans' growing appetite for scandal. She gave him just enough information to whet his appetite.

def.en: When a group of people #applaud#, they clap their hands in order to show approval, for example when they have enjoyed a play or concert.
def.exmp: The audience laughed and applauded. Every person stood to applaud his unforgettable act of courage. He should be applauded for his courage. This last move can only be applauded. She applauds the fact that they are promoting new ideas.

def.en: #Applause# is the noise made by a group of people clapping their hands to show approval.
def.exmp: They greeted him with thunderous applause. ...a round of applause.

def.en: An #appliance# is a device or machine in your home that you use to do a job such as cleaning or cooking.
def.exmp: He could also learn to use the vacuum cleaner, the washing machine and other household appliances. ...Maytag, one of America's biggest domestic appliance manufacturers. These advances were the result of the intellectual appliance of science.

def.en: An # appliance# is an item of equipment that uses current, and is not an electric light unit or an independent motor.
def.exmp: For safety, a ground wire is often connected between the individual electrical #appliances# in the house and the main electric switchboard or fusebox. These wire wound variable resistors are fitted in various circuits of electrical #appliances# and have the ability to withstand temperatures and varying voltages. An #appliance# is an item of equipment that uses current, and is not an electric light unit or an independent motor.

def.en: Something that is #applicable# #to# a particular situation is relevant to it or can be applied to it.
def.exmp: What is a reasonable standard for one family is not applicable for another. Appraisal has traditionally been seen as most applicable to those in management and supervisory positions. It should include a review of energy usage and, where applicable, the production and disposal of waste. Piaget himself wrote relatively little about the applicability of his theories to education.

def.en: An #application# #for# something such as a job or membership of an organization is a formal written request for it.
def.exmp: His application for membership of the organisation was rejected. ...Turkey's application to join the European Community. Applications should be submitted as early as possible. Tickets are available on application. Students learned the practical application of the theory they had learned in the classroom. Simon's book provides a succinct outline of artificial intelligence and its application to robotics. ...his immense talent, boundless energy and unremitting application. With repeated applications of weedkiller, the weeds were overcome.

def.en: The # application# of a medical preparation, or an # application# of it, is an act or instance of bringing it into contact with a surface.
def.exmp: Cases of rheumatism are treated by the #application# of this ointment. Make sure the skin is clean before the #application# of the cream. #An application# of a medical preparation is an act or instance of bringing it into contact with a surface.

def.en: If you make an #appraisal# #of# something, you consider it carefully and form an opinion about it.
def.exmp: What is needed in such cases is a calm appraisal of the situation. Self-appraisal is never easy. Staff problems should be addressed through training and appraisals. ...an appraisal of your financial standing.

def.en: An # appraisal# is a professional examination of real or personal property to determine its market value.
def.exmp: An independent #appraisal# of the company's real estate holdings values those assets at about $1.1 billion. The company commissioned #appraisals# of the land value, and the timber value. #An appraisal# is a professional examination of real or personal property to determine its market value.

def.en: If you #appreciate# something, for example a piece of music or good food, you like it because you recognize its good qualities.
def.exmp: Anyone can appreciate our music. In time you'll appreciate the beauty and subtlety of this language. She never really appreciated the depth and bitterness of the Irish conflict. He appreciates that co-operation with the media is part of his professional duties. Peter stood by me when I most needed it. I'll always appreciate that. Thanks, lads. I appreciate it. I'd appreciate it if you wouldn't mention it. They don't have any confidence that houses will appreciate in value.

def.en: Something that is #appropriate# is suitable or acceptable for a particular situation.
def.exmp: It is appropriate that Irish names dominate the list. Dress neatly and attractively in an outfit appropriate to the job. The teacher can then take appropriate action. Dress appropriately and ask intelligent questions. It's entitled, appropriately enough, 'Art for the Nation'. He wonders about the appropriateness of each move he makes. Several other newspapers have appropriated the idea. The land was simply appropriated by the rulers. Senator Lugar is skeptical that Congress will appropriate more funding for this purpose.

def.en: An #apt# remark, description, or choice is especially suitable.
def.exmp: The words of this report are as apt today as in 1929. ...an apt description of the situation. ...the beach in the aptly named town of Oceanside. She was apt to raise her voice and wave her hands about. This type of weather is apt to be more common in winter.

def.en: If you describe an action, rule, or decision as #arbitrary#, you think that it is not based on any principle, plan, or system.
def.exmp: Arbitrary arrests and detention without trial were common. The victims were not chosen arbitrarily. He is horrified by the apparent arbitrariness by which she sets the prices.

def.en: An #arch# is a structure that is curved at the top and is supported on either side by a pillar, post, or wall.
def.exmp: Don't arch your back, keep your spine straight. 'Oh really?' he said, arching an eyebrow. I gazed up at the domed ceiling arching overhead. Both of them looked at him with that curious, slightly amused and even arch expression. She looked at me rather archly. Their attempts to be casual have so far just looked arch or patronising. 'You can't fool me,' Shirley said archly.

def.en: An #architect# is a person who designs buildings.
def.exmp: ...Merrick Denton-Thompson, the landscape architect for Hampshire county council. ...Paul Andreu, chief architect of French railways. ...Russia's chief architect of economic reform.

def.en: If a situation or problem #arises#, it begins to exist or people start to become aware of it.
def.exmp: ...if a problem arises later in the pregnancy. The birds also attack crops when the opportunity arises. ...an overwhelming sense of guilt arising from my actions. The charges arise out of a long-running fraud enquiry by Merseyside police. Heavy Metal music really arose in the late 60s. He arose at 6:30 a.m. as usual. When I arose from the chair, my father and Eleanor's father were in deep conversation. Arise, Sir William. ...the flat terrace, from which arises the cubic volume of the house.

def.en: If something #arouses# a particular reaction or attitude in people, it causes them to have that reaction or attitude.
def.exmp: We left in the daytime so as not to arouse suspicion. ...the deep public anger you have aroused. There is nothing like a long walk to arouse the appetite. He aroused her mothering instincts. Some men are aroused when their partner says erotic words to them. Some men feel that they get most sexually aroused in the morning. Being stroked by a partner is usually more arousing than stroking yourself. He apologized, saying this subject always aroused him. About two o'clock, we were aroused from our sleep by a knocking at the door.

def.en: If you #arrange# an event or meeting, you make plans for it to happen.
def.exmp: She arranged an appointment for Friday afternoon at four-fifteen. This time it was a friend ringing to try to arrange a fishing trip in Scotland. The Russian leader threw the carefully arranged welcome into chaos. I've arranged to see him on Friday morning. It was arranged that the party would gather for lunch in the Royal Garden Hotel. He had arranged for the boxes to be stored until they could be collected. I will arrange for someone to take you round. The hotel manager will arrange for a baby-sitter. I've arranged your hotels for you. Transport is not included but can be arranged. When she has a little spare time she enjoys arranging dried flowers. He started to arrange the books in piles. A number of seats have been arranged in front of the painting. The songs were arranged by another well-known bass player, Ron Carter.

def.en: An #array# #of# different things or people is a large number or wide range of them.
def.exmp: As the deadline approached she experienced a bewildering array of emotions. A dazzling array of celebrities are expected at the Mayfair gallery to see the pictures. There was an impressive array of pill bottles stacked on top of the fridge. We visited the local markets and saw wonderful arrays of fruit and vegetables. ...methods which can be used to create an ordered array of molecules within materials. The image is then stored on the computer hard disk as a vast array of black or white dots.

def.en: Someone who is #arrogant# behaves in a proud, unpleasant way towards other people because they believe that they are more important than others.
def.exmp: He was so arrogant. That sounds arrogant, doesn't it? ...an air of arrogant indifference. At times the arrogance of those in power is quite blatant. Later, Simpson arrogantly claimed: 'We won't lose another game.'

def.en: #Arteries# are the tubes in your body that carry blood from your heart to the rest of your body.
def.exmp: ...patients suffering from blocked arteries. Clarence Street was one of the north-bound arteries of the central business district. ...the point where the Ohio River, itself a great artery, joins the Mississippi.

def.en: If you describe someone as #articulate#, you mean that they are able to express their thoughts and ideas easily and well.
def.exmp: She is an articulate young woman. The child was unable to offer an articulate description of what she had witnessed. To start a revolution, you need discipline, incisiveness and articulacy. The president has been accused of failing to articulate an overall vision in foreign affairs. He articulated each syllable carefully.

def.en: #Artificial# objects, materials, or processes do not occur naturally and are created by human beings, for example using science or technology.
def.exmp: ...a wholefood diet free from artificial additives, colours and flavours. The city is dotted with small lakes, natural and artificial. He did not want his life to be prolonged by artificial means. ...artificially sweetened lemonade. ...drugs which artificially reduce heart rate. Even in the artificial environment of an office, our body rhythms continue to affect us. Removed from the artificial atmosphere of the fashion show, high-fashion clothes often look cheap and silly. ...another example of the capriciousness and artificiality of our adversarial system of justice. ...state subsidies that have kept retail prices artificially low. The voice was patronizing and affected, the accent artificial. ...the novel's use of homosexuality to suggest the artificiality of all relationships in that nervous city. The meat was chewy and the sauce was glutinous and tasted artificial. ...complaints that their tinned peas were an artificial shade of green.

def.en: If you #ascend# a hill or staircase, you go up it.
def.exmp: Mrs Clayton had to hold Lizzie's hand as they ascended the steps. Then we ascend steeply through forests of rhododendron. A number of staircases ascend from the cobbled streets onto the ramparts. ...an ascending spiral path leading to a tower. Keep the drill steady while it ascends and descends. Nott and Dickinson set a new altitude record when they ascended 55,900 feet in their balloon. ...the same year he ascended to power. Before ascending to the bench, she was a lawyer in a large New York firm. ...a few years before Sixtus V ascended the papal throne. Mobutu ascended through the ranks, eventually becoming commander of the army. They move freely from one department to another as they ascend the civil service ladder. ...the belief that the souls of the faithful and virtuous would ascend to heaven. The story ascends from a gothic tragedy to a miraculous fairy-tale.

def.en: If you #ascertain# the truth about something, you find out what it is, especially by making a deliberate effort to do so.
def.exmp: Through doing this, the teacher will be able to ascertain the extent to which the child understands what he is reading. Once they had ascertained that he was not a spy, they agreed to release him. Take time to ascertain what services your bank is providing, and at what cost.

def.en: If someone is #ashamed#, they feel embarrassed or guilty because of something they do or they have done, or because of their appearance.
def.exmp: I felt incredibly ashamed of myself for getting so angry. She was ashamed that she looked so shabby. I'm a lesbian and I'm not ashamed about it. I've never told this to anyone, but it's true, I was terribly ashamed of my mum. Women are often ashamed to admit they are being abused.

def.en: Someone or something that comes #ashore# comes from the sea onto the shore.
def.exmp: Oil has come ashore on a ten mile stretch to the east of Plymouth. Once ashore, the vessel was thoroughly inspected.

def.en: An #aspect# of something is one of the parts of its character or nature.
def.exmp: Climate and weather affect every aspect of our lives. He was interested in all aspects of the work here. Monroe described the financial aspect as crucial. The house had a south-west aspect. Our journey had taken on a new aspect. The countryside was no longer familiar. The snowy street, like the church, assumed a dumb, lifeless aspect.

def.en: If you #aspire to# something such as an important job, you have a strong desire to achieve it.
def.exmp: ...people who aspire to public office. They aspired to be gentlemen, though they fell far short of the ideal.

def.en: An #assault# by an army is a strong attack made on an area held by the enemy.
def.exmp: The rebels are poised for a new assault on the government garrisons. Most U.S. soldiers welcomed the ground assault when the order was finally given. ...a high-powered assault rifle. The attack is one of a series of savage sexual assaults on women in the university area. At the police station, I was charged with assault. The gang assaulted him with iron bars. She may have been sexually assaulted by her killer. He leveled a verbal assault against his Democratic opponents.

def.en: When people #assemble# or when someone #assembles# them, they come together in a group, usually for a particular purpose such as a meeting.
def.exmp: There wasn't even a convenient place for students to assemble between classes. Thousands of people, mainly Zulus, assembled in a stadium in Thokoza. He has assembled a team of experts to handle queries. The assembled multitude cheered and whistled as the political leaders arrived. Greenpeace managed to assemble enough boats to waylay the ship at sea. She had been trying to assemble the bomb when it went off in her arms. He is assembling evidence concerning a murder.

def.en: An #assembly# is a large group of people who meet regularly to make decisions or laws for a particular region or country.
def.exmp: ...the campaign for the first free election to the National Assembly. ...an assembly of party members from the Russian republic. ...an assembly of women Olympic gold-medal winners. He waited until complete quiet settled on the assembly. The U.S. Constitution guarantees free speech, freedom of assembly and equal protection. They were accused of unlawful assembly. By 9, the juniors are in the hall for assembly. ...a long room with a stage at one end for assemblies. For the rest of the day, he worked on the assembly of an explosive device. ...workers at Sao Paolo's car assembly plants.

def.en: # Assembly# is the process of putting parts together to make a machine or other product.
def.exmp: All the components were made and ready for #assembly#. The apparatus comes in kit form for ease of #assembly#. #Assembly# is the process of putting parts together to make a machine or other product.

def.en: When you #assess# a person, thing, or situation, you consider them in order to make a judgment about them.
def.exmp: Our correspondent has been assessing the impact of the sanctions. The test was to assess aptitude rather than academic achievement. It would be a matter of assessing whether she was well enough to travel. Ask them to send you information on how to assess the value of your belongings. What's the property's assessed value?

def.en: If you #assign# a piece of work #to# someone, you give them the work to do.
def.exmp: When I taught, I would assign a topic to children which they would write about. Later in the year, she'll assign them research papers. When teachers assign homework, students usually feel an obligation to do it. The selling broker is then required to assign a portion of the commission to the buyer broker. He assigned her all his land in Ireland. I was assigned to Troop A of the 10th Cavalry. Did you choose Russia or were you simply assigned there? Each of us was assigned a minder, someone who looked after us. Under Mr. Harel's system, each business must assign a value to each job. Assign the letters of the alphabet their numerical values–A equals 1, B equals 2, etc.

def.en: An #assignment# is a task or piece of work that you are given to do, especially as part of your job or studies.
