def.exmp: The assessment for the course involves written assignments and practical tests. An Australian division scheduled for assignment to Greece was ordered to remain in Egypt.

def.en: When people such as immigrants #assimilate# #into# a community or when that community #assimilates# them, they become an accepted part of it.
def.exmp: There is every sign that new Asian-Americans are just as willing to assimilate. His family tried to assimilate into the white and Hispanic communities. The Vietnamese are trying to assimilate themselves and become Americans. French Jews generally had been assimilated into the nation's culture. They promote social integration and assimilation of minority ethnic groups into the culture. I was speechless, still trying to assimilate the enormity of what he'd told me. This technique brings life to instruction and eases assimilation of knowledge.

def.en: If you #assist# someone, you help them to do a job or task by doing part of the work for them.
def.exmp: Julia was assisting him to prepare his speech. The family decided to assist me with my chores. Dr Amid was assisted by a young Asian nurse. The public is urgently requested to assist police in tracing this man. Foreign Office officials assisted with transport and finance problems. The Authority will provide a welfare worker to assist you. ...a chemical that assists in the manufacture of proteins. Here are some good sources of information to assist you in making the best selection. Salvage operations have been greatly assisted by the good weather conditions.

def.en: If you give someone #assistance#, you help them do a job or task by doing part of the work for them.
def.exmp: Since 1976 he has been operating the shop with the assistance of volunteers. She can still come downstairs with assistance but she's very weak. Any assistance you could give the police will be greatly appreciated. Employees are being offered assistance in finding new jobs. ...a viable programme of economic assistance. We shall offer you assistance with legal expenses up to $5,000. The translations were carried out with the assistance of a medical dictionary.

def.en: If you #associate# someone or something #with# another thing, the two are connected in your mind.
def.exmp: Through science we've got the idea of associating progress with the future. Rap groups have been barred from large musical events because they are associated with vandalism. I haven't been associated with the project over the last year. The press feels the need to associate itself with the green movement. What would they think if they knew that they were associating with a murderer? They disapproved of her dancing at discos and associating with homosexuals. ...the restaurant owner's business associates. Mr Lin is associate director of the Institute. She applied for associate membership last year. ...an associate professor of political science.

def.en: An #association# is an official group of people who have the same job, aim, or interest.
def.exmp: ...the British Olympic Association. Research associations are often linked to a particular industry. ...the company's six-year association with retailer J.C. Penney Co. Blyth's association with the sea began in 1966. The association between the two companies stretches back thirty years. He has a shelf full of things, each of which has associations for him. Black was considered inappropriate because of its associations with death.

def.en: If you give someone an #assurance# #that# something is true or will happen, you say that it is definitely true or will definitely happen, in order to make them feel less worried.
def.exmp: He would like an assurance that other forces will not move into the territory that his forces vacate. He will have been pleased by Marshal Yazov's assurance of the armed forces' loyalty. Masur led the orchestra with assurance. The E.U. is now acquiring greater assurance and authority. ...endowment assurance.

def.en: If you #assure# someone #that# something is true or will happen, you tell them that it is definitely true or will definitely happen, often in order to make them less worried.
def.exmp: He hastened to assure me that there was nothing traumatic to report. 'Are you sure the raft is safe?' she asked anxiously. 'Couldn't be safer,' Max assured her confidently. Government officials recently assured Hindus of protection. Last night's resounding victory over Birmingham City has virtually assured them of promotion. Ways must be found to assure our children a decent start in life.

def.en: #Astronomy# is the scientific study of the stars, planets, and other natural objects in space.
If you #attain# something, you gain it or achieve it, often after a lot of effort.
def.exmp: Jim is halfway to attaining his pilot's licence. ...attaining a state of calmness and confidence.

def.en: In the United States, an #attorney# or #attorney at law# is a lawyer.
def.exmp: ...a prosecuting attorney.

def.en: If you #attribute# something #to# an event or situation, you think that it was caused by that event or situation.
def.exmp: Women tend to attribute their success to external causes such as luck. People were beginning to attribute superhuman qualities to him. There's usually a lot of attribution of evil intent to those who have different views. This, and the remaining frescoes, are not attributed to Giotto. ...a Madonna and Child attributed to Pietro Lorenzetti. Cruelty is a normal attribute of human behaviour. He has every attribute you could want and could play for any team.

def.en: An #auction# is a public sale where goods are sold to the person who offers the highest price.
def.exmp: Lord Salisbury bought the picture at auction in London some years ago. Britain's two main auction houses, Sotheby's and Christies, have been involved in valuing the works. Eight drawings by French artist Jean Cocteau will be auctioned next week. The airline plans to auction its international routes to former competitors. We'll auction them for charity.

def.en: When an accountant #audits# an organization's accounts, he or she examines the accounts officially in order to make sure that they have been done correctly.
def.exmp: Each year they audit our accounts and certify them as being true and fair. The bank first learned of the problem when it carried out an internal audit.

def.en: An # audit# is an inspection of business accounts that is carried out by an accountant in order to make sure that they are correct.
def.exmp: Accountants have conducted an #audit# of the company, and uncovered the accounting discrepancies. The regulator would reserve the right to declare a bank solvent after an #audit#. An #audit# is an inspection of business accounts that is carried out by an accountant in order to make sure that they are correct.

def.en: When an accountant # audits# business accounts, he or she examines them officially in order to make sure that they are correct.
def.exmp: Each year they #audit# our accounts and certify them as being true and fair. The company's taxes for the years involved in the controversy are currently being #audited#. def.en: An #auditorium# is the part of a theatre or concert hall where the audience sits.
def.exmp: The Albert Hall is a huge auditorium.

def.en: To #augment# something means to make it larger, stronger, or more effective by adding something to it.
def.exmp: While searching for a way to augment the family income, she began making dolls. The augmentation of the army began along traditional lines.

def.en: #August# is the eighth month of the year in the Western calendar.
def.exmp: The world premiere took place in August 1956. The trial will resume on 22 August. This August has been the wettest for four years.

def.en: Someone or something that is #august# is dignified and impressive.
def.exmp: Being so near the august person of the Empress, he was overcome with awe. ...the august surroundings of the Liberal Club.

def.en: Someone's #aunt# is the sister of their mother or father, or the wife of their uncle.
def.exmp: She wrote to her aunt in America. It was a present from Aunt Vera.

def.en: #Aural# means related to the sense of hearing.
def.exmp: He became famous as an inventor of astonishing visual and aural effects.

def.en: An #authentic# person, object, or emotion is genuine.
def.exmp: ...authentic Italian food. She has authentic charm whereas most people simply have nice manners. They have to look authentic. There are factors, however, that have cast doubt on the statue's authenticity. Consumers are increasingly interested in the authentically exotic tastes. The enamel gives new brass an authentically tarnished finish. ...patterns for making authentic frontier-style clothing. The team decided to try and replicate the missing curtains as authentically as possible. I had obtained the authentic details about the birth of the organization. The book authentically and intimately describes the small details of her daily life. The film's authenticity of detail has impressed critics.

def.en: #The# #authorities# are the people who have the power to make decisions and to make sure that laws are obeyed.
def.exmp: This provided a pretext for the authorities to cancel the elections. The prison authorities have been criticised for not moving more quickly to end the protest by inmates. ...the Health Education Authority. Any alterations had to meet the approval of the local planning authority. Local police chiefs should re-emerge as figures of authority and reassurance in their areas. The judge had no authority to order a second trial. He had no natural authority and no capacity for imposing his will on others. The prison governor has refused to let him go, saying he must first be given authority from his own superiors. He's universally recognized as an authority on Russian affairs.

def.en: #Autonomy# is the control or government of a country, organization, or group by itself rather than by others.
def.exmp: Activists stepped up their demands for local autonomy last month. Each of the area managers enjoys considerable autonomy in the running of his own area.

def.en: An #auxiliary# is a person who is employed to assist other people in their work.
def.exmp: Nursing auxiliaries provide basic care, but are not qualified nurses. The government's first concern was to augment the army and auxiliary forces. ...an auxiliary motor. ...auxiliary fuel tanks. The restaurant is operated by the Palo Alto Auxiliary for the benefit of the Lucile Salter Packard Children's Hospital.

def.en: If you #avail# #yourself of# an offer or an opportunity, you accept the offer or make use of the opportunity.
def.exmp: Guests should feel at liberty to avail themselves of your facilities.

def.en: If you #avert# something unpleasant, you prevent it from happening.
def.exmp: Talks with the teachers' union over the weekend have averted a strike. A fresh tragedy was narrowly averted yesterday. He avoids any eye contact, quickly averting his gaze when anyone approaches. He kept his eyes averted.

def.en: An #award# is a prize or certificate that a person is given for doing something well.
def.exmp: ...the Booker prize, Britain's top award for fiction. She presented a bravery award to schoolgirl Caroline Tucker. ...workmen's compensation awards. ...this year's average pay award for teachers of just under 8%. She was awarded the prize for both films. For his dedication the Mayor awarded him a medal of merit. We have awarded the contract to a British shipyard. A High Court judge had awarded him £6 million damages.

def.en: #Aviation# is the operation and production of aircraft.
#Awe# is the feeling of respect and amazement that you have when you are faced with something wonderful and often rather frightening.
def.exmp: She gazed in awe at the great stones. His fellow officers regarded him with awe as some sort of genius. She filled me with a sense of awe. I am still awed by David's courage. The crowd listened in awed silence.

def.en: If you say that someone or something is #awful#, you dislike that person or thing or you think that they are not very good.
def.exmp: We met and I thought he was awful. I couldn't stand London! Bloody awful place. ...an awful smell of paint. Even if the weather's awful there's lots to do. Jeans look awful on me. The programme's awfulness has ensured it is talked about. Her injuries were massive. It was awful. Some of their offences are so awful they would chill the blood. I hardly slept at all and felt pretty awful. I looked awful and felt quite shaky. I've got an awful lot of work to do. The caramel looks awfully good. 'I'm awfully sorry,' she told him regretfully. Would you mind awfully waiting a bit, I'll be back right away. Gosh, you're awful pretty. You know, 10 years sounds like an awful long time.

def.en: An #awkward# situation is embarrassing and difficult to deal with.
def.exmp: I was the first to ask him awkward questions but there'll be harder ones to come. There was an awkward moment as couples decided whether to stand next to their partners. There was an awkwardly long silence. ...an awkwardly timed meeting. It was small but heavy enough to make it awkward to carry. Full-size tripods can be awkward, especially if you're shooting a low-level subject. The autoexposure button is awkwardly placed under the lens release button. Amy made an awkward gesture with her hands. He fell awkwardly and went down in agony clutching his right knee. He lay beside her awkwardly, propped on an elbow. Women frequently say that they feel awkward taking the initiative in sex. He was rather awkward with his godson. 'This is Malcolm,' the girl said awkwardly, to fill the silence. He displayed all the awkwardness of adolescence. She's got to an age where she is being awkward.

def.en: An #axe# is a tool used for cutting wood.
def.exmp: Community projects are being axed by hard-pressed social services departments. St Bartholomew's is one of four London hospitals facing the axe.

def.en: An #axis# is an imaginary line through the middle of something.
A #bachelor# is a man who has never married.
Your #background# is the kind of family you come from and the kind of education you have had.
def.exmp: Moulded by his background, he could not escape the traditional role of strict father. She came from a working-class background. His background was in engineering. The background to the current troubles is provided by the dire state of the country's economy. The meeting takes place against a background of continuing political violence. ...background information. I kept hearing the sound of applause in the background. ...police sirens wailing in the background. The background music was provided by an accordion player. ...roses patterned on a blue background. Paint the background tones lighter and the colours cooler.

def.en: #Bacterium# is the singular of bacteria.
A #badge# is a piece of metal or cloth which you wear to show that you belong to an organization or support a cause.
def.exmp: Being a Communist was a badge of honour for thousands of trade union activists.

def.en: #Badminton# is a game played by two or four players on a rectangular court with a high net across the middle.
#Bait# is food which you put on a hook or in a trap in order to catch fish or animals.
def.exmp: He baited his hook with pie. The boys dug pits and baited them so that they could spear their prey. ...baited lures. Service stations use petrol as a bait to lure motorists into the restaurants and other facilities. Television programmes are essentially bait to attract an audience for advertisements. He delighted in baiting his mother.

def.en: Someone who is #bald# has little or no hair on the top of their head.

The bald truth is he's just not happy. 'The leaders are outdated,' he stated baldly. 'They don't relate to young people.'

def.en: A #balloon# is a small, thin, rubber bag that you blow air into so that it becomes larger and rounder or longer.
def.exmp: She popped a balloon with her fork. They are to attempt to be the first to circle the Earth non-stop by balloon. In London, the use of the Tube has ballooned. The budget deficit has ballooned to $25 billion.

def.en: A #ballot# is a secret vote in which people select a candidate in an election, or express their opinion about something.

They succeeded in putting Perot's name on the ballot in Florida. The union said they will ballot members on whether to strike. International observers say the balloting was fair.

def.en: A #band# is a small group of musicians who play popular music such as jazz, rock, or pop.
def.exmp: He was a drummer in a rock band. Local bands provide music for dancing. Bands played German marches. Bands of government soldiers, rebels and just plain criminals have been roaming some neighborhoods. ...a small but growing band of Japanese companies taking their first steps into American publishing. Almost all hospitals use a wrist-band of some kind with your name and details on it. ...bands of natural vegetation between strips of crops. A band of light glowed in the space between floor and door. Surgeons placed a metal band around the knee cap to help it knit back together. ...a strong band of flat muscle tissue. For an initial service, a 10 megahertz-wide band of frequencies will be needed. ...a new tax band of 20p in the pound on the first £2,000 of taxable income. They appear to rule out some of the ideas that have been mentioned–banding the tax so higher earners would pay more. ...a banding system based on property values. The choice will be between a flat-rate or a banded charge.

def.en: A #bandage# is a long strip of cloth which is wrapped around a wounded part of someone's body to protect or support it.
def.exmp: We put some ointment and a bandage on his knee. His chest was swathed in bandages. Apply a dressing to the wound and bandage it. ...a bandaged hand. I bandaged the leg up and gave her aspirin for the pain.

def.en: A #bang# is a sudden loud noise such as the noise of an explosion.

All up and down the street the windows bang shut. The wind banged a door somewhere. We could bang on the desks and shout till they let us out. There is no point in shouting or banging the table. She banged his dinner on the table. He banged down the telephone. She'd fainted and banged her head. He hurried into the hall, banging his shin against a chair in the darkness. ...a nasty bang on the head. I didn't mean to bang into you. Various men kept banging into me in the narrow corridor. My bangs were cut short, but the rest of my hair was long. ...bang in the middle of the track. For once you leave bang on time for work.

def.en: A #bank# is an institution where people or businesses can keep their money.

def.en: The #banks# #of# a river, canal, or lake are the raised areas of ground along its edge.

def.en: When an aircraft #banks#, one of its wings rises higher than the other, usually when it is changing direction.

def.en: A # bank# is a place or organization that looks after people's money.

def.en: People or organizations that go #bankrupt# do not have enough money to pay their debts.

def.en: A #banner# is a long strip of cloth with something written on it.

def.en: A #banquet# is a grand formal dinner.
def.exmp: Last night he attended a state banquet at Buckingham Palace.

def.en: A #bar# is a place where you can buy and drink alcoholic drinks.
def.exmp: ...Devil's Herd, the city's most popular country-western bar. ...the Brass Nickel Bar. I'll see you in the bar later. On the ship there are video lounges, a bar and a small duty-free shop. Michael was standing alone by the bar when Brian rejoined him. He leaned forward across the bar. ...a brick building with bars across the ground floor windows. ...a crowd throwing stones and iron bars. What is your favourite chocolate bar? ...a bar of soap. ...a two-bar electric fire with a frayed flex. For added safety, bar the door to the kitchen. def.en: If a part of your body is #bare#, it is not covered by any clothing.

def.en: A #barrier# is something such as a rule, law, or policy that makes it difficult or impossible for something to happen or be achieved.

def.en: In America, #baseball# is a game played by two teams of nine players.

Any such thing would be bitterly opposed by most of the world's democracies. ...a bitterly fought football match. The rift within the organization reflects the growing bitterness of the dispute. She is said to be very bitter about the way she was sacked. His long life was marked by bitter personal and political memories. 'And he sure didn't help us,' Grant said bitterly. ...the party bureaucrats who bitterly resented their loss of power. I still feel bitterness and anger towards the person who knocked me down. I think the decision was a bitter blow from which he never quite recovered. A great deal of bitter experience had taught him how to lose gracefully. The statement was greeted with bitter disappointment by many of the other delegates. I was bitterly disappointed to have lost yet another race so near the finish. Outside, a bitter east wind was accompanied by flurries of snow. ...after spending a night in the bitter cold. It's been bitterly cold here in Moscow. The leaves taste rather bitter. ...as the wine ages, losing its bitter harshness, and becoming softer and smoother. ...a pint of bitter.

def.en: Something that is #bizarre# is very odd and strange.
def.exmp: The game was also notable for the bizarre behaviour of the team's manager. You know, that book you lent me is really bizarre. She dressed bizarrely. Bizarrely, death is not a disqualification for voting although non-attendance at party meetings is.

def.en: #Blackmail# is the action of threatening to reveal a secret about someone, unless they do something you tell them to do, such as giving you money.
def.exmp: It looks like the pictures were being used for blackmail. Opponents accused him of blackmail and extortion. The tactics employed can range from overt bullying to subtle emotional blackmail. He told her their affair would have to stop, because Jack Smith was blackmailing him. The government insisted that it would not be blackmailed by violence. I thought he was trying to blackmail me into saying whatever he wanted. The nasty thing about a blackmailer is that his starting point is usually the truth.

def.en: The #blade# of a knife, axe, or saw is the edge, which is used for cutting.
def.exmp: Many of these tools have sharp blades, so be careful.

def.en: A #blanket# is a large square or rectangular piece of thick cloth, especially one which you put on a bed to keep you warm.
def.exmp: The mud disappeared under a blanket of snow. Cold damp air brought in the new year under a blanket of fog. It seems as if the blanket of depression is in some way necessary to help them blot out the even greater pain of real life. A blanket of silence descended. More than a foot of snow blanketed parts of Michigan. With a thick mist now blanketing the trees, I got thoroughly lost. There's already a blanket ban on foreign unskilled labour in Japan. ...the blanket coverage of the Barcelona Olympics.

def.en: A # blanket# is a large square or rectangular piece of thick cloth, especially one that you put on a bed to keep you warm.
def.exmp: Extra #blankets# and soft pillows are provided for your comfort. If you are cold, you can ask for an extra #blanket# on your bed. Sheets and #blankets# must be tucked in at the corners of the beds.

def.en: A #blast# is a big explosion, especially one caused by a bomb.
def.exmp: 250 people were killed in the blast. There is a risk that toxic chemicals might be blasted into the atmosphere. ...a terrible accident in which his left arm was blasted off by some kind of a bomb. Earlier two holes were blasted into the ship's hull to let water out and stabilise the ferry. The explosion which followed blasted out the external supporting wall of her flat. Their work was taken up with boring and blasting rock with gelignite. They're using dynamite to blast away rocks to put a road in. Three miles away there was a salvo of blasting in the quarry. ...a son who blasted his father to death after a life-time of bullying. Alan Barnett, 28, was blasted with a sawn-off shotgun in Oldham on Thursday. ...the man who killed Nigel Davies with a shotgun blast. The police were reported to have blasted their way into the house using explosives. One armoured column attempted to blast a path through a barricade of buses and trucks. Blasting cold air over it makes the water evaporate. A blizzard was blasting great drifts of snow across the lake. Blasts of cold air swept down from the mountains. ...drivers who do not blast their horns. The sound of western music blasted as she entered. The buzzer suddenly responded in a long blast of sound. Ramsay blasted the ball into the back of the net. He may try to blast his way out of trouble, playing attacking shots to balls he would not normally contemplate hitting. Football: Taylor blasts Beck. The Department of Health and a top immunologist have blasted a report in last week's Sunday Times. Cricket: Blast for Ormrod. Blast! I can't do anything with this. Making the album was a real blast.

def.en: A # blast# is a shock wave from an explosion.
def.exmp: The #blast# is produced by ignition of a vapor cloud. The #blast# produced by an explosion interacts with any objects in its path. A #blast# is a shock wave from an explosion.

def.en: When a fire #blazes#, it burns strongly and brightly.
def.exmp: Three people died as wreckage blazed, and rescuers fought to release trapped drivers. The log fire was blazing merrily. ...a blazing fire. Two firemen were hurt in a blaze which swept through a tower block last night. The gardens blazed with colour. I wanted the front garden to be a blaze of colour. He got to his feet and his dark eyes were blazing with anger. Eva stood up and indignation blazed in her eyes. His eyes blazed intently into mine. Miss Turner turned blazing eyes on the victim. He was arrested in a blaze of publicity. ...the sporting career that began in a blaze of glory. Guns were blazing, flares going up and the sky was lit up all around. She took the gun and blazed away with calm and deadly accuracy.

def.en: If a situation is #bleak#, it is bad, and seems unlikely to improve.
def.exmp: The immediate outlook remains bleak. Many predicted a bleak future. The continued bleakness of the American job market was blamed. The island's pretty bleak. ...bleak inner-city streets. The weather can be quite bleak on the coast. His face was bleak. Alberg gave him a bleak stare. 'There is nothing left,' she says bleakly.

def.en: If you #blend# substances together or if they #blend#, you mix them together so that they become one substance.
def.exmp: Blend the butter with the sugar and beat until light and creamy. Blend the ingredients until you have a smooth cream. Put the soap and water in a pan and leave to stand until they have blended. Most whiskies are blended whiskies. The public areas offer a subtle blend of traditional charm with modern amenities. ...a blend of wine and sparkling water. He makes up his own blends of flour. You could paint the walls and ceilings the same colour so they blend together. ...the picture, furniture and porcelain collections that blend so well with the house itself. His 'cosmic vision' is to blend Christianity with 'the wisdom of all world religions'. ...a band that blended jazz, folk and classical music.

def.en: When someone such as a priest #blesses# people or things, he asks for God's favour and protection for them.
def.exmp: ...asking for all present to bless this couple and their loving commitment to one another. 'Bless you, Eva,' he whispered. God bless and thank you all so much.

def.en: Someone who is #blind# is unable to see because their eyes are damaged.
def.exmp: I started helping him run the business when he went blind. How would you explain colour to a blind person? He was a teacher of the blind. Early diagnosis and treatment can usually prevent blindness. The sun hit the windscreen, momentarily blinding him. Her mother groped for the back of the chair, her eyes blind with tears. Lettie groped blindly for the glass. David's good looks and impeccable manners had always made her blind to his faults. All the time I was blind to your suffering. ...blindness in government policy to the very existence of the unemployed. He never allowed his love of Australia to blind him to his countrymen's faults. ...her blind faith in the wisdom of the Church. Lesley yelled at him with blind, hating rage. He tried to overtake three cars on a blind corner and crashed head-on into a lorry. I remembered a huddle of stone buildings with blind walls.

def.en: A #bloom# is the flower on a plant.
def.exmp: ...the sweet fragrance of the white blooms. Harry carefully picked the bloom. This plant blooms between May and June. ...the scent of night-blooming flowers. Not many economies bloomed in 1990, least of all gold exporters like Australia. She bloomed into an utterly beautiful creature. The skin loses its youthful bloom.

def.en: #Blossom# is the flowers that appear on a tree before the fruit.
def.exmp: The cherry blossom came out early in Washington this year. ...the blossoms of plants, shrubs and trees. Why do some people take longer than others to blossom? What began as a local festival has blossomed into an international event. ...the blossoming relationship between Israel and Eastern Europe. ...the blossoming of British art, pop and fashion. Rain begins to fall and peach trees blossom.

def.en: A #blouse# is a kind of shirt worn by a girl or woman.
When a wind or breeze #blows#, the air moves.
def.exmp: A chill wind blew at the top of the hill. We woke to find a gale blowing outside. The wind blew her hair back from her forehead. Strong winds blew away most of the dust. Her cap fell off in the street and blew away. Sand blew in our eyes. The bushes and trees were blowing in the wind. Danny rubbed his arms and blew on his fingers to warm them. Take a deep breath and blow. He picked up his mug and blew off the steam. He blew a ring of blue smoke. The whistle blew and the train slid forward. A guard was blowing his whistle. He took out a handkerchief and blew his nose. The can exploded, wrecking the kitchen and bathroom and blowing out windows. Rival gunmen blew the city to bits. The dramatic World Motor Sports Council meeting in Paris blew the championship wide open as Schumacher was also docked six points. Someone took an inappropriate use of words on my part and tried to blow it into a major controversy. Before you blow it all on a luxury cruise, give a little thought to the future. My brother lent me some money and I went and blew the lot. He has almost certainly blown his chance of touring India this winter. ...the high-risk world of real estate, where one careless word could blow a whole deal. Oh you fool! You've blown it! The fuse blew as he pressed the button. A lorry blew a tyre and careered into them. The car tyre blew. A tyre blew out when the coach was on its way.

def.en: If someone receives a #blow#, they are hit with a fist or weapon.
def.exmp: He went off to hospital after a blow to the face. When the marriage finally broke up it was obviously a terrible blow to Soames. That ruling comes as a blow to environmentalists. His death dealt a severe blow to the army's morale.

def.en: A #blueprint# #for# something is a plan or set of proposals that shows how it is expected to work.
def.exmp: The country's president will offer delegates his blueprint for the country's future. ...the blueprint of a new plan of economic reform. ...a blueprint of the whole place, complete with heating ducts and wiring. The documents contain a blueprint for a nuclear device. The offspring contain a mixture of the genetic blueprint of each parent. DNA is the genetic material inside every cell that carries the blueprints for everything from hair color to the risk of cancer.

def.en: A #blunder# is a stupid or careless mistake.
def.exmp: I think he made a tactical blunder by announcing it so far ahead of time. No doubt I had blundered again. You're a blundering fool. People wanted to know how they had blundered into war, and how to avoid it in future. He had blundered into the table, upsetting the flowers.

def.en: If you are #blunt#, you say exactly what you think without trying to be polite.
def.exmp: She is blunt about her personal life. She told the industry in blunt terms that such discrimination is totally unacceptable. 'I don't believe you!' Jeanne said bluntly. To put it bluntly, he became a pain. His bluntness got him into trouble. One of them had been struck 13 times over the head with a blunt object. The constant repetition of violence has blunted the human response to it. Our appetite was blunted by the beer.

def.en: A #blur# is a shape or area which you cannot see clearly because it has no distinct outline or because it is moving very fast.
def.exmp: Out of the corner of my eye I saw a blur of movement on the other side of the glass. Her face is a blur. This creates a spectrum of colours at the edges of objects which blurs the image. If you move your eyes and your head, the picture will blur. ...blurred black and white photographs. ...her belief that scientists are trying to blur the distinction between 'how' and 'why' questions. The evidence is blurred by central banks' reluctance to reveal their blunders. The line between fact and fiction is becoming blurred. Her eyes, behind her glasses, began to blur. Sweat ran from his forehead into his eyes, blurring his vision. ...visual disturbances like eye-strain and blurred vision.

def.en: When you #blush#, your face becomes redder than usual because you are ashamed or embarrassed.
def.exmp: 'Hello, Maria,' he said, and she blushed again. I blushed scarlet at my stupidity. 'The most important thing is to be honest,' she says, without the trace of a blush.

def.en: A #board# is a flat, thin, rectangular piece of wood or plastic which is used for a particular purpose.
def.exmp: ...a chopping board. ...a draughts board. Dr Tinsley had five pieces on the board against Chinook's four. He wrote a few more notes on the board. The floor was draughty bare boards. Arthur wants to put his recommendation before the board at a meeting tomorrow. ...the agenda for the September 12 board meeting. The Scottish Tourist Board said 33,000 Japanese visited Scotland last year. ...the U.S. National Transportation Safety Board. I boarded the plane bound for England. Free room and board are provided for all hotel staff.

def.en: If someone #boasts# about something that they have done or that they own, they talk about it very proudly, in a way that other people may find irritating or offensive.
def.exmp: Witnesses said Furci boasted that he took part in killing them. Carol boasted about her costume. He's boasted of being involved in the arms theft. We remember our mother's stern instructions not to boast. It is the charity's proud boast that it has never yet turned anyone away. He was asked about earlier boasts of a quick victory. The houses will boast the latest energy-saving technology. Frommen says his country boasts a healthy economy.

def.en: Someone who is #bold# is not afraid to do things which involve risk or danger.
def.exmp: Amrita becomes a bold, daring rebel. In 1960 this was a bold move. Poland was already making bold economic reforms. You can and must act boldly and confidently. Don't forget the boldness of his economic programme. I don't feel I'm being bold, because it's always been natural for me to just speak out about whatever disturbs me. 'You should do it,' the girl said, boldly. ...bold flowers in various shades of red, blue or white. ...bold, dramatic colours. The design is pretty startling and very boldly coloured. Each picture is shown in colour on one page and as a bold outline on the opposite page.

def.en: A #bolt# is a long metal object which screws into a nut and is used to fasten things together.
def.exmp: The safety belt is easy to fit as there's no need to bolt it to seat belt anchorage points. Bolt the components together. The doors were bolted on. ...a wooden bench which was bolted to the floor. I heard the sound of a bolt being slowly and reluctantly slid open. He reminded her that he would have to lock and bolt the kitchen door after her. ...the heavy bolted doors . The pig rose squealing and bolted. I made some excuse and bolted for the exit. Being under stress can cause you to miss meals, eat on the move, or bolt your food. Back then I could bolt down three or four burgers and a pile of French fries. Suddenly a bolt of lightning crackled through the sky. ...bolts of black silk. If the soil dries out the plants may bolt.

def.en: A # bolt# is a pin with parallel threads and a flat end, used for fastening parts together and often secured with a nut.
def.exmp: Make sure the parts to be joined together are securely held with nuts and #bolts#. Loosen the nut from the #bolt# by turning it repeatedly. A #bolt# is a pin with parallel threads and a flat end, used for fastening parts together and often secured with a nut.

def.en: A #bond# #between# people is a strong feeling of friendship, love, or shared beliefs and experiences that unites them.
def.exmp: The experience created a very special bond between us. ...the bond that linked them. Belinda was having difficulty bonding with the baby. They all bonded while writing graffiti together. What had bonded them instantly and so completely was their similar background. The players are bonded by a spirit that is rarely seen in an English team. They expect bonding to occur naturally. ...the strong bond between church and nation. There are tangible signs that the republic's successfully breaking its bonds with Moscow. Freed from the bonds of convention and the fear of what others may think, the mind responds with new solutions. We must, somehow, find a way to loosen the bonds of tradition. The superglue may not create a bond with some plastics. The molecule contains four carbon atoms arranged in a ring with a triple bond between two of them. Diamond may be strong in itself, but it does not bond well with other materials. In graphite sheets, carbon atoms bond together in rings. Strips of wood are bonded together and moulded by machine. Most of it will be financed by government bonds. ...the recent sharp decline in bond prices.

def.en: A # bond# is a certificate issued to investors when a government or company borrows money from them.
def.exmp: The new credit, which the country will raise through issuing #bonds# to participating bank creditors, could total as much as $1.2 billion. #Bond# prices strengthened yesterday as investors began to suspect that the Federal Reserve has once again eased credit policy. A #bond# is a certificate issued to investors when a government or company borrows money from them.

def.en: A # bond# is a certificate issued to investors when a government or company borrows money from them.
def.exmp: The new credit, which the country will raise through issuing #bonds# to participating bank creditors, could total as much as $1.2 billion. #Bond# prices strengthened yesterday as investors began to suspect that the Federal Reserve has once again eased credit policy. A #bond# is a certificate issued to investors when a government or company borrows money from them.

def.en: Your #bones# are the hard parts inside your body which together form your skeleton.
def.exmp: Many passengers suffered broken bones. Stephen fractured a thigh bone. The body is made up primarily of bone, muscle, and fat. She scooped the chicken bones back into the stewpot. Make sure that you do not pierce the skin when boning the chicken thighs. The boned fish is so easy to serve. ...a small, expensive pocketknife with a bone handle.

def.en: If there is a #boom# in the economy, there is an increase in economic activity, for example in the amount of things that are being bought and sold.
def.exmp: An economic boom followed, especially in housing and construction. The 1980s were indeed boom years. ...the cycle of boom and bust which has damaged us for 40 years. The boom in the sport's popularity has meant more calls for stricter safety regulations. Public transport has not been able to cope adequately with the travel boom. By 1988 the economy was booming. Sales are booming. It has a booming tourist industry. 'Ladies,' boomed Helena, without a microphone, 'we all know why we're here tonight.' Thunder boomed like battlefield cannons over Crooked Mountain. Music boomed out from loudspeakers. A megaphone boomed out, 'This is the police.' He turned his sightless eyes their way and boomed out a greeting. The stillness of night was broken by the boom of a cannon.

def.en: A financial # boom# is an increase in economic activity with rapid growth and rising prices.
def.exmp: China's economic #boom# has produced a growing hunger for energy that only foreign supplies can satisfy. Investment advisers are predicting #a boom# in oil stocks because an oil shortage is developing. A financial #boom# is an increase in economic activity with rapid growth and rising prices.

def.en: If one thing #boosts# another, it causes it to increase, improve, or be more successful.
def.exmp: It wants the government to take action to boost the economy. The move is designed to boost sales during the peak booking months of January and February. It would get the economy going and give us the boost that we need. The proposal received a boost on Sunday when The New York Times endorsed it in a leading article. We need a big win to boost our confidence. Do what you can to give her confidence and boost her morale. It did give me a boost to win such a big event.

def.en: A #booth# is a small area separated from a larger public area by screens or thin walls where, for example, people can make a telephone call or vote in private.
def.exmp: I called her from a public phone booth near the entrance to the bar. In Darlington, queues formed at some polling booths. They sat in a corner booth, away from other diners.

def.en: If someone or something #bores# you, you find them dull and uninteresting.
def.exmp: Dickie bored him all through the meal with stories of the Navy. Life in the country bores me. There is every reason why I shouldn't enjoy his company–he's a bore and a fool. It's a bore to be sick, and the novelty of lying in bed all day wears off quickly. Get the special drill bit to bore the correct-size hole for the job. His eyes bored into her, paralysing her, robbing her of movement. Her eyes seemed to bore a hole in mine.

def.en: The # bore# is the internal diameter of the cylinder of an engine or pump.
def.exmp: The engine is a three-liter unit with an 83 x 90mm #bore# and stroke. The four-cylinder, four-stroke engine has a #bore# of 80 mm. The thin-wall cylinders were used to achieve the 2.8-liter displacement with a 92-mm #bore#.

def.en: The # bore# is the cylinder wall of an engine.
If you # bore# a hole in something, you make a deep round hole in it using a special tool.
If you # bore# a cylinder in an engine, you increase the size of the cylinder bore to accept the piston, and so increase displacement.
A # bore# is a circular hole in a material produced by drilling, turning, or drawing.
def.exmp: Drill a #bore# of 100mm diameter into the workpiece. The eyebolt is threaded into a #bore# in the metal. A #bore# is a circular hole in a material produced by drilling, turning, or drawing.

def.en: A woman's breasts are sometimes referred to as her #bosom# or her #bosoms#.
def.exmp: ...a large young mother with a baby resting against her ample bosom. Joan was delighted to welcome her boyfriend into the bosom of her large, close-knit family. They were bosom friends. Sakota was her cousin and bosom pal.

def.en: A #bottle# is a glass or plastic container in which drinks and other liquids are kept.
def.exmp: There were two empty beer bottles on the table. He was pulling the cork from a bottle of wine. ...Victorian scent bottles. He had drunk half a bottle of whisky. This is a large truck which has equipment to automatically bottle the wine. ...bottled water. Gary was holding a bottle to the baby's lips. Did she do things like bottling fruit or making jam? ...bottled plums. But will anyone have the bottle to go through with it?

def.en: When an object such as a ball #bounces# or when you #bounce# it, it moves upwards from a surface or away from it immediately after hitting it.
def.exmp: I bounced a ball against the house. My father would burst into the kitchen bouncing a football. ...a falling pebble, bouncing down the eroded cliff. They watched the dodgem cars bang and bounce. The wheelchair tennis player is allowed two bounces of the ball. Your arms and legs need protection from light bouncing off glass. They work by bouncing microwaves off solid objects. Her long black hair bounced as she walked. Then I noticed the car was bouncing up and down as if someone were jumping on it. The wind was bouncing the branches of the big oak trees. She lets us do anything, even bounce on our beds. Patsy had picked up the baby and was bouncing him on her knee. Moira bounced into the office. It was good to bounce ideas off another mind. Let's bounce a few ideas around. Attempts have been made to bounce member states into decisions with major financial implications. Our only complaint would be if the cheque bounced. His bank wrongly bounced cheques worth £75,000.

def.en: #Bound# is the past tense and past participle of bind.
def.exmp: There are bound to be price increases next year. If you are topless in a public place, this sort of thing is bound to happen. I'll show it to Benjamin. He's bound to know. We'll have more than one child, and one of them's bound to be a boy. We are as tightly bound to the people we dislike as to the people we love. Economic growth is still bound to the issues of poverty, social justice and conservation. The ship was bound for Italy. ...a Russian plane bound for Berlin. ...a Texas-bound oil freighter. ...homeward-bound commuters.

def.en: #Bounds# are limits which normally restrict what can happen or what people can do.
def.exmp: Changes in temperature occur slowly and are constrained within relatively tight bounds. ...a forceful personality willing to go beyond the bounds of convention. ...the bounds of good taste. Kirgizia is bounded by Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan and Tajikistan. ...the trees that bounded the car park. ...the park, bounded by two busy main roads and a huge housing estate. Our lives are bounded by work, family and television. He bounded up the steps and pushed the bell of the door. The dog came bounding back with the stick for Richard to throw again. She leaps in one bound onto her pony's back for a speedy canter around the ring. With one bound Jack was free. The shares bounded ahead a further 11p to 311p. The economy isn't bounding back as fast as people expected.

def.en: The #boundary# #of# an area of land is an imaginary line that separates it from other areas.
def.exmp: ...the Bow Brook which forms the western boundary of the wood. Drug traffickers operate across national boundaries. The boundaries between history and storytelling are always being blurred and muddled. ...extending the boundaries of press freedom.

def.en: When you #bow# #to# someone, you briefly bend your body towards them as a formal way of greeting them or showing respect.
def.exmp: They bowed low to Louis and hastened out of his way. He bowed slightly before taking her bag. I gave a theatrical bow and waved. The Colonel bowed his head and whispered a prayer of thanksgiving. She stood still, head bowed, hands clasped in front of her. Some shops are bowing to consumer pressure and stocking organically grown vegetables. Parliament has bowed to the demand for a referendum next year. ...their determination not to be bowed in the face of the allied attacks. I am bowed down by my sins.

def.en: The front part of a ship is called #the# #bow# or #the# #bows#.
def.exmp: The waves were about five feet now, and the bow of the boat was leaping up and down. ...the sight of that magnificent ship lit up from bow to stern. ...spray from the ship's bows.

def.en: A #bow# is a knot with two loops and two loose ends that is used in tying shoelaces and ribbons.
def.exmp: Add a length of ribbon tied in a bow. Some of the raiders were armed with bows and arrows.

def.en: Your #bowels# are the tubes in your body through which digested food passes from your stomach to your anus.
def.exmp: ...deep in the bowels of the earth. Lyn went off into the dark bowels of the building.

def.en: A #bowl# is a round container with a wide uncovered top.
def.exmp: Put all the ingredients into a large bowl. Your dog should have his own bowls for food and water. ...a bowl of soup. He smacked the bowl of his pipe into his hand. ...the toilet bowl. Everyone wanted to bowl, hence everyone wanted to open a bowling alley. I can't see the point of bowling a ball like that. He bowled so well that we won two matches. Watkins hit 16 before being bowled by Ambrose. He was bowled out first ball. Veronica looked at him, smiling, as they bowled along. It felt just like old times, to bowl down Knightsbridge. ...the Crystal Palace Bowl. ...the Rose Bowl. ...the Fiesta college football bowl.

def.en: #Bowling# is a game in which you roll a heavy ball down a narrow track towards a group of wooden objects and try to knock down as many of them as possible.
def.exmp: I go bowling for relaxation.

def.en: If a country, group, or person #boycotts# a country, organization, or activity, they refuse to be involved with it in any way because they disapprove of it.
def.exmp: The main opposition parties are boycotting the elections. Opposition leaders had called for a boycott of the vote. ...the lifting of the economic boycott against Israel.

def.en: If you #brace# #yourself for# something unpleasant or difficult, you prepare yourself for it.
def.exmp: He braced himself for the icy plunge into the black water. She braced herself, as if to meet a blow. Elaine braced herself against the dresser and looked in the mirror. He braced his back against the wall. He braced his shoulders as the snow slashed across his face. Overhead, the lights showed the old timbers, used to brace the roof. ...a brace of bottles of Mercier Rose champagne. ...a few brace of grouse. He wore leg braces after polio in childhood. She wears a neck brace.

def.en: If you say that someone or something is in a particular #bracket#, you mean that they come within a particular range, for example a range of incomes, ages, or prices.
def.exmp: ...a 33% top tax rate on everyone in these high-income brackets. Do you fall outside that age bracket? Fix the beam with the brackets and screws. ...adjustable wall brackets. The Magi, Bramins, and Druids were bracketed together as men of wisdom. Austrian wine styles are often bracketed with those of northern Germany. The prices in brackets are special rates for the under 18s. My annotations appear in square brackets.

def.en: #Brakes# are devices in a vehicle that make it go slower or stop.
def.exmp: The brakes began locking. A seagull swooped down in front of her car, causing her to slam on the brakes. He heard tires squeal as the car braked to avoid a collision. She braked sharply to avoid another car. He lit a cigarette and braked the car slightly. She braked to a halt and switched off. Illness had put a brake on his progress. You can take the financial brakes off in June.

def.en: # Brakes# are devices in a vehicle that make it go slower or stop.
def.exmp: Parts of the #brake# that may need replacement include linings and calipers. The car tends to skid from the rear if the #brakes# are applied hard. The #brakes# failed and her car accelerated out of control.

def.en: When a vehicle or its driver # brakes#, or when a driver # brakes# a vehicle, the driver makes it slow down or stop by using the brakes.
def.exmp: He heard tires squeal as the car #braked# to avoid a collision. She was forced to #brake# sharply as the other car cut in front of her. He #braked# to a halt and switched off the ignition.

def.en: A #brand# of a product is the version of it that is made by one particular manufacturer.
def.exmp: Winston is a brand of cigarette. I bought one of the leading brands. ...a supermarket's own brand. The British brand of socialism was more interested in reform than revolution. I was instantly branded as a rebel. The company has been branded racist by some of its own staff. The U.S. administration recently branded him a war criminal. The owner couldn't be bothered to brand the cattle. A brand was a mark of ownership burned into the hide of an animal with a hot iron.

def.en: A # brand# is a name, trademark, or other symbol which distinguishes a product or manufacturer from others in the market, for example Coca Cola, Apple, or Ford.
def.exmp: The company's objective is to become the leading Internet-based music media company and to create a global #brand#. Goods at the mid to low end of the market have reported poor sales in recent trading statements, while luxury #brands# are still turning huge profits. def.en: #Brandy# is a strong alcoholic drink.

def.en: # Brandy# is a strong alcoholic drink.
def.exmp: Always offer guests a #brandy# after dinner. They have a glass of #brandy# after their evening meal. Spirits like whiskey and #brandy# are too strong for me to drink.

def.en: #Brass# is a yellow-coloured metal made from copper and zinc.

def.en: The #breadth# #of# something is the distance between its two sides.

def.en: A woman's #breasts# are the two soft, round parts on her chest that can produce milk to feed a baby.
def.exmp: She wears a low-cut dress which reveals her breasts. As my newborn cuddled at my breast, her tiny fingers stroked my skin. She was slim and muscular and full-breasted. He struck his breast in a dramatic gesture. The verse rose up to fire his breast with inspiration. The battle roared; a sound calculated to arouse the sublimest emotions in the breast of the soldier. The cock's breast is tinged with chestnut. ...flocks of red-breasted parrots. He moved out from beneath an awning, reaching for something inside the breast of his overcoat. He reached into his breast pocket for his cigar case. ...a chicken breast with vegetables. ...breast of lamb.

def.en: A #breed# of a pet animal or farm animal is a particular type of it.
def.exmp: ...rare breeds of cattle. Certain breeds are more dangerous than others. He lived alone, breeding horses and dogs. He used to breed dogs for the police. These dogs are bred to fight. There is potential for selective breeding for better yields. Frogs will usually breed in any convenient pond. The area now attracts over 60 species of breeding birds. During the breeding season the birds come ashore. If they are unemployed it's bound to breed resentment. Violence breeds violence. Sue is one of the new breed of British women squash players who are making a real impact. The new breed of walking holidays puts the emphasis on enjoyment, not endurance. I had found that rare breed of man who was not afraid of committing himself.

def.en: A #breeze# is a gentle wind.

Making the pastry is a breeze if you have a food processor.

def.en: A #bribe# is a sum of money or something valuable that one person offers or gives to another in order to persuade him or her to do something.
def.exmp: He was being investigated for receiving bribes. He was accused of bribing a senior bank official. The government bribed the workers to be quiet.

def.en: #Bricks# are rectangular blocks of baked clay used for building walls, which are usually red or brown.

def.en: A #bride# is a woman who is getting married or who has just got married.
A #briefcase# is a case used for carrying documents in.
A #brisk# activity or action is done quickly and in an energetic way.
def.exmp: Taking a brisk walk can often induce a feeling of well-being. The horse broke into a brisk trot. Eve walked briskly down the corridor to her son's room. With determined briskness, Amy stood up and put their cups back on the tray. Vendors were doing a brisk trade in souvenirs. Its sales had been brisk since July. A trader said gold sold briskly on the local market. ...a typically brisk winter's day on the South Coast. The breeze was cool, brisk and invigorating. The Chief summoned me downstairs. He was brisk and businesslike. She is noted for her brisk handling of business. 'Anyhow,' she added briskly, 'it's none of my business.' He felt her familiar briskness, and he knew that it was all over.

def.en: An object or substance that is #brittle# is hard but easily broken.
def.exmp: Pine is brittle and breaks. ...the dry, brittle ends of the hair. These incidents suggest the peace in Northern Ireland is still brittle. This may help to undermine the brittle truce that currently exists. ...Noel Coward's brittle comedy of bad manners. Myrtle gave a brittle laugh.

def.en: A # brittle# material breaks or splits easily.
def.exmp: This steel is too #brittle# to make propeller blades because it might break whilst rotating. Because the coke is so #brittle#, it can crack just from a heat cycle. #A brittle# material breaks or splits easily.

def.en: Something that is #broad# is wide.
def.exmp: His shoulders were broad and his waist narrow. The hills rise green and sheer above the broad river. ...a broad expanse of green lawn. He greeted them with a wave and a broad smile. Charles grinned broadly. A broad range of issues was discussed. ...a broad coalition of workers, peasants, students and middle class professionals. This gives children a more broadly based education. The term Wissenschaft has a much broader meaning than the English word 'science'. ...restructuring in the broad sense of the word. We define education very broadly and students can study any aspect of its consequences for society. The agreement won broad support in the U.S. Congress. ...a film with broad appeal. The new law has been broadly welcomed by road safety organisations. These documents provided a broad outline of the Society's development. In broad terms, this means that the closer you live to a school, the more likely it is that your child will get a place there. There are, broadly speaking, three ways in which this is done. Broadly, it makes connections between ideas about healing and how they link to plants. They've been giving broad hints about what to expect. He hinted broadly that he would like to come. ...a Briton who spoke in a broad Yorkshire accent.

def.en: A #brochure# is a magazine or thin book with pictures that gives you information about a product or service.
def.exmp: ...travel brochures.

def.en: #Bronze# is a yellowish-brown metal which is a mixture of copper and tin.

def.en: A #brook# is a small stream.

def.en: A #broom# is a kind of brush with a long handle.

def.en: Something that is #brown# is the colour of earth or of wood.

There were many gorgeous females busy browning themselves. ...a slim brown man with a speckled turban. ...brown bread. ...spicy tomato sauce served over a bed of brown rice. def.en: If you #browse# in a shop, you look at things in a fairly casual way, in the hope that you might find something you like.
def.exmp: I stopped in several bookstores to browse. She browsed in an up-market antiques shop. I'm just browsing around. ...a browse around the shops. ...sitting on the sofa browsing through the TV pages of the paper. There are plenty of biographies for him to browse over. Try browsing around in the network bulletin boards. ...the three red deer stags browsing 50 yards from my lodge on the fringes of the forest.

def.en: A #bruise# is an injury which appears as a purple mark on your body, although the skin is not broken.
def.exmp: How did you get that bruise on your cheek? She was treated for cuts and bruises. I had only bruised my knee. Some people bruise more easily than others. I escaped with severely bruised legs. Choose a warm, dry day to cut them off the plants, being careful not to bruise them. ...bruised tomatoes and cucumbers. Be sure to store them carefully as they bruise easily. ...bruises on the fruit's skin. The government will be severely bruised by yesterday's events. Their egos are so easily bruised. ...the bruising experience of near-bankruptcy.

def.en: A #brush# is an object which has a large number of bristles or hairs fixed to it.
def.exmp: We gave him paint and brushes. Stains are removed with buckets of soapy water and scrubbing brushes. ...a hair brush. Have you brushed your teeth? She brushed the powder out of her hair. Using a small brush, he brushed away the fine sawdust. I gave it a quick brush with my hairbrush. Take a sheet of filo pastry and brush it with melted butter. He brushed his hair back with both hands. She brushed away tears as she spoke of him. He brushed the snow off the windshield. Something brushed against her leg. I felt her dark brown hair brushing the back of my shoulder. She knelt and brushed her lips softly across Michael's cheek. My father would burst into the kitchen, brushing past my mother. He brushed by with a perfunctory wave to the crowd. My first brush with a headmaster came six years ago. It is his third brush with the law in less than a year. ...the trauma of a brush with death. The corporation is fighting to survive its second brush with bankruptcy. ...the brush fire that destroyed nearly 500 acres. ...a meadow of low brush and grass.

def.en: A #brutal# act or person is cruel and violent.
def.exmp: He was the victim of a very brutal murder. ...the brutal suppression of anti-government protests. Jensen is a dangerous man, and can be very brutal and reckless. Her real parents had been brutally murdered. It was refreshing to talk about themselves and their feelings with brutal honesty. He took an anguished breath. He had to be brutal and say it. The talks had been brutally frank. 'Lotte Bruckner is dead.' It came out more brutally than Brand had intended. The dip in prices this summer will be brutal. The afternoon sun had been brutal. The 20th century brought brutal change to some countries. The early-morning New York air can be brutally cold.

def.en: A #bucket# is a round metal or plastic container with a handle attached to its sides.

def.en: A #bud# is a small pointed lump that appears on a tree or plant and develops into a leaf or flower.
def.exmp: Rosanna's favourite time is early summer, just before the buds open. The leaves were budding on the trees below. You heard what the boss said, bud.

def.en: Your #budget# is the amount of money that you have available to spend.
def.exmp: She will design a fantastic new kitchen for you–and all within your budget. Someone had furnished the place on a tight budget. This year's budget for AIDS prevention probably won't be much higher. The hospital obviously needs to balance the budget each year. ...his readiness to raise taxes as part of an effort to cut the budget deficit. The Chancellor could use the Budget to bring in taxation reforms. ...other indirect tax changes announced in the Budget. The company has budgeted $10 million for advertising. The movie is only budgeted at $10 million. I'm learning how to budget. We have continued to exercise caution in our budgeting for the current year. Cheap flights are available from budget travel agents from £240.

def.en: The # budget# of an organization is its financial situation, considered as the difference between the money that it expects to receive and the money that it expects to spend over a particular period.
def.exmp: The final effect of all the planning is reflected in the statement of planned financial position at the close of the #budget# period. The #budget# for the financial year was originally planned to bring down the fiscal deficit to around 5 percent of the GDP. The #budget# of an organization is its financial situation, considered as the difference between the money that it expects to receive and the money that it expects to spend over a particular period, usually a financial year.

def.en: A # budget# is the total amount of money allocated for a particular purpose during a particular period of time.
def.exmp: The company's R&D #budget#, which is about $125 million this year, may have to be doubled in a few years. Last year the company launched a new product with only 25 percent of its advertising #budget# allocated to TV. #A budget# is the total amount of money allocated for a particular purpose during a particular period of time.

def.en: If you # budget#, you allocate certain amounts of money to particular things and do not spend any more.
def.exmp: The stress of debt can be overcome by people learning how to #budget#. Children need to understand that they are part of the economics of the family, and should learn how to #budget# and make decisions. If you #budget#, you allocate certain amounts of money to particular things and do not spend any more.

def.en: If you # budget# a certain amount of money # for# something, you decide that you can spend that amount.
def.exmp: The company has #budgeted# $10 million for advertising. The country has #budgeted# $1.7 billion for wheat subsidies this year. If you #budget# a certain amount of money for something, you decide that you can spend that amount.

def.en: A #buffet# is a meal of cold food that is displayed on a long table at a party or public occasion.
def.exmp: ...a buffet lunch. A cold buffet had been laid out in the dining-room. We sat in the station buffet sipping tea. Their plane had been severely buffeted by storms. Storms swept the country, closing roads, buffeting ferries and killing as many as 30 people. ...the buffetings of the winds. The whole of Africa had been buffeted by social and political upheavals.

def.en: A #bulb# is the glass part of an electric lamp, which gives out light when electricity passes through it.
def.exmp: The stairwell was lit by a single bulb. ...tulip bulbs.

def.en: You can refer to something's #bulk# when you want to emphasize that it is very large.
def.exmp: The truck pulled out of the lot, its bulk unnerving against the dawn. ...the shadowy bulk of an ancient barn. Bannol lowered his bulk carefully into the chair. Despite his bulk he moved lightly on his feet. The bulk of the text is essentially a review of these original documents. The vast bulk of imports and exports are carried by sea. They come from all over the world, though the bulk is from the Indian subcontinent. Buying in bulk is more economical than shopping for small quantities. ...bulk purchasing.

def.en: A #bull# is a male animal of the cow family.
def.exmp: ...a massive bull elephant with huge tusks. I think it's a load of bull. The press couldn't deal with that so they made up all this bull.

def.en: A # bull# is a person who buys shares of stock when they expect the price to rise in order to make a profit by selling the shares again after a short time.
def.exmp: Undeterred, the #bulls# predict further gains in the months ahead as investors sniff out unrealized potential. #A bull# expects the market or markets to go up. #A bull# is a person who buys shares of stock when they expect the price to rise in order to make a profit by selling the shares again after a short time.

def.en: A #bulletin# is a short news report on the radio or television.
def.exmp: ...the early morning news bulletin. At 3.30 p.m. a bulletin was released announcing that the president was out of immediate danger.

def.en: A #bully# is someone who uses their strength or power to hurt or frighten other people.
def.exmp: I fell victim to the office bully. He's a coward and a bully who confuses physical strength with manhood. I wasn't going to let him bully me. I asked her if she was bullied by the other children. ...schoolchildren who were victims of bullying. We think an attempt to bully them into submission would be counterproductive. She used to bully me into doing my schoolwork. The government says it will not be bullied by the press.

def.en: If you #bump# into something or someone, you accidentally hit them while you are moving.
def.exmp: They stopped walking and he almost bumped into them. There was a jerk as the boat bumped against something. He bumped his head on the low beams of the house. Small children often cry after a minor bump. I felt a little bump and I knew instantly what had happened. The child took five steps, and then sat down with a bump. She fell against our coffee table and got a large bump on her forehead. The truck hit a bump and bounced. We left the road, and again bumped over the mountainside. The aircraft bumped along erratically without gathering anything like sufficient speed.

def.en: A #bunch# #of# people is a group of people who share one or more characteristics or who are doing something together.
def.exmp: My neighbours are a bunch of busybodies. We were a pretty inexperienced bunch of people really. The players were a great bunch. He had left a huge bunch of flowers in her hotel room. Lili had fallen asleep clutching a fat bunch of grapes. George took out a bunch of keys and went to work on the complicated lock. We did a bunch of songs together. I'd like to adopt a multi-racial child. In fact, I'd love a whole bunch. She clutches the sides of her skirt until it bunches around her waist.

def.en: A #bundle# #of# things is a number of them that are tied together or wrapped in a cloth or bag so that they can be carried or stored.
def.exmp: She produced a bundle of notes and proceeded to count out one hundred and ninety-five pounds. He gathered the bundles of clothing into his arms. I have about 20 year's magazines tied up in bundles. I remember Mickey as a bundle of fun, great to have around. Life at high school wasn't a bundle of laughs, either. He confessed to having been a bundle of nerves. The profession offers a bundle of benefits, not least of which is extensive training. He was bundled into a car and driven 50 miles to a police station. He was bundled in and arrested as soon as he was airborne. It's cheaper to buy software bundled with a PC than separately.

def.en: If you # bundle# one product with another to attract business, you give away a relatively cheap item to customers when you sell them a more expensive one.
def.exmp: Sellers often #bundle# several of their products at a reduced price. Own-brand shampoo and conditioner has been #bundled# and further discounted with a BOGO offer. If you #bundle# one product with another to attract business, you give away a relatively cheap item to customers when you sell them a more expensive one.

def.en: A #bureau# is an office, organization, or government department that collects and distributes information.
def.exmp: ...the Federal Bureau of Investigation. ...the Citizens' Advice Bureau. ...the Wall Street Journal's Washington bureau.

def.en: A #bureaucracy# is an administrative system operated by a large number of officials.
def.exmp: State bureaucracies can tend to stifle enterprise and initiative. People usually complain about having to deal with too much bureaucracy.

def.en: A #burglar# is a thief who enters a house or other building by force.
def.exmp: Burglars broke into their home.

def.en: If something #bursts# or if you #burst# it, it suddenly breaks open or splits open and the air or other substance inside it comes out.
def.exmp: The driver lost control when a tyre burst. It is not a good idea to burst a blister. ...a flood caused by a burst pipe. A dam burst and flooded their villages. Monsoons caused the river to burst its banks. The door burst open and an angry young nurse appeared. Gunmen burst into his home and opened fire. Rachel burst out as the door was flung open again. He burst onto the fashion scene in the early 1980s. He almost burst with pride when his son John began to excel at football. He thought his heart would burst with grief. Hundreds of fireworks burst simultaneously in midair. Every now and then you hear some bombs bursting. ...a burst of machine-gun fire. It is easier to cope with short bursts of activity than with prolonged exercise. The current flows in little bursts.

def.en: A #bush# is a large plant which is smaller than a tree and has a lot of branches.

def.en: A # bush# is a thin metal tube that fits into a hole or covers a part in order to guide the movement of a part or reduce friction.

A #bush# is a thin metal tube that fits into a hole or covers a part in order to guide the movement of a part or reduce friction.

def.en: A #butcher# is a shopkeeper who cuts up and sells meat.

def.en: #Butter# is a soft yellow substance made from cream.

def.en: If you #bypass# someone or something that you would normally have to get involved with, you ignore them, often because you want to achieve something more quickly.

Small veins are removed from the leg and used to bypass the blocked up stretch of coronary arteries. def.en: A # bypass# is a way of diverting a flow of fluid around a system.

def.en: A #cabbage# is a round vegetable with white, green or purple leaves that is usually eaten cooked.

def.en: A #cabin# is a small room in a ship or boat.

def.en: A #cabinet# is a cupboard used for storing things such as medicine or alcoholic drinks or for displaying decorative things in.

def.en: A #cable# is a thick wire, or a group of wires inside a rubber or plastic covering, which is used to carry electricity or electronic signals.

def.en: A # cable# is a conducting wire or wires separated and surrounded by a dielectric substance or insulation.
def.exmp: In urban areas an underground #cable# is used to deliver power to buildings. A transmission line is a #cable# for carrying an electrical signal from one place to another. A #cable# is a conducting wire or wires separated and surrounded by a dielectric substance or insulation.

def.en: A #cage# is a structure of wire or metal bars in which birds or animals are kept.
def.exmp: I hate to see birds in cages.

def.en: A # cage# is a device that fits into a rolling bearing and keeps the right amount of space between its individual rollers or balls.

Enclosing the balls or rollers of bearings in a #cage# prevents them from rubbing against each other and causing additional friction. def.en: # Cake# or a # cake# is the solid or semisolid substance that remains in a filter.

def.en: #Calcium# is a soft white element which is found in bones and teeth, and also in limestone, chalk, and marble.
#Calories# are units used to measure the energy value of food.

def.en: A # calorie# is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 gram of water through 1° centigrade.

A current of 1 ampere maintained for 1 second in a 1-ohm resistor produces 0.239 #calorie# of heat. #A calorie# is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 gram of water through 1° centigrade.

def.en: A #campaign# is a planned set of activities that people carry out over a period of time in order to achieve something such as social or political change.

We are campaigning for law reform. Mr Burns has actively campaigned against a hostel being set up here. They have been campaigning to improve the legal status of women. def.en: A #campus# is an area of land that contains the main buildings of a university or college.
def.exmp: ...during a rally at the campus. Private automobiles are not allowed on campus.

def.en: A #canal# is a long, narrow stretch of water that has been made for boats to travel along or to bring water to a particular area.
def.exmp: ...the Grand Union Canal. ...Venetian canals and bridges. ...delaying the food's progress through the alimentary canal.

def.en: A #candle# is a stick of hard wax with a piece of string called a wick through the middle.

def.en: A #cannon# is a large gun, usually on wheels, which used to be used in battles.

def.en: A #canoe# is a small, narrow boat that you move through the water using a stick with a wide end called a paddle.

def.en: A #cap# is a soft, flat hat with a curved part at the front which is called a peak.
def.exmp: ...a dark-blue baseball cap. ...a frontier guard in olive-grey uniform and a peaked cap. Rees, 32, has been capped for England 23 times. ...England's most capped rugby union player. Mark Davis will win his first cap for Wales in Sunday's Test match against Australia. The only new cap is Llanelli's 20-year-old left-wing Wayne Proctor. The Secretary of State for Environment has the power to cap councils which spend excessively. Nearly half of all local councils face being capped. Between 70 and 80 councils face significant spending cuts or capping next year. She unscrewed the cap of her water bottle and gave him a drink. They had capped the roof with plywood. ...homemade scones capped with cream. The unrest capped a weekend of right-wing attacks on foreigners. def.en: A # cap# is a protective cover or seal, especially one that closes off an end or a tip.
def.exmp: The #caps# of medicine bottles must be kept firmly closed. Unscrew the #cap# of the bottle and pour all the contents into a beaker. A #cap# is a protective cover or seal, especially one that closes off an end or a tip.

def.en: To # cap# a well is to seal it off.
def.exmp: On March 24, 1980, the company #capped# the well by inserting cement plugs. For some months the gas was allowed to flow freely and then the well was #capped# with cement. To #cap# a well is to seal it off.

def.en: Your #capacity# #for# something is your ability to do it, or the amount of it that you are able to do.
def.exmp: Our capacity for giving care, love and attention is limited. Her mental capacity and temperament are as remarkable as his. ...people's creative capacities. ...the amount of spare capacity in the economy. Bread factories are working at full capacity. def.en: The # capacity# of an engine is its size or power, expressed in Europe as cubic centimeters or liters, and in the US as cubic inches.
The # capacity# of a container such as a fuel tank is its volume, or the amount of liquid it can hold, measured in units such as quarts or gallons.
def.exmp: The new model has increased fuel tank #capacity#, and will run for more than 150 miles between fill-ups. This car has a fuel tank #capacity# of 9.9 gallons. Engineers have improved the brakes, increased the fuel tank #capacity#, and made the car generally lighter.

def.en: The # capacity# of a generating unit, generating station, or other electrical apparatus is the maximum load that it can carry.
def.exmp: Power transmission lines have enough #capacity# to carry very large currents. The electricity system must have sufficient reserve #capacity# that the system can accommodate prolonged equipment shutdowns without significant interruption of electricity supply. The #capacity# of a generating unit, generating station, or other electrical apparatus is the maximum load that it can carry.

def.en: A #cape# is a large piece of land that sticks out into the sea from the coast.

def.en: #Capitalism# is an economic and political system in which property, business, and industry are owned by private individuals and not by the state.

def.en: A #capsule# is a very small tube containing powdered or liquid medicine, which you swallow.

def.en: A # capsule# is a small, soluble case of gelatine containing a dose of medicine.
def.exmp: Some people find #capsules# easier to swallow than hard tablets. Gelatin #capsules# dissolve easily and release the medicine into the stomach. A #capsule# is a small, soluble case of gelatine containing a dose of medicine.

def.en: A #captive# person or animal is being kept imprisoned or enclosed.
