We all performed action songs, sketches and dances before a captive audience of parents and patrons. Airlines consider business travellers a captive market.

def.en: A # captive# is an insurance company set up by a commercial company to write the parent company's own insurances and obtain access to the reinsurance market.

Owning #a captive# is a means of arranging for self-insurance, with coverage for very large losses being arranged by the company by means of reinsurance. #A captive# is an insurance company set up by a commercial company to write the parent company's own insurances and obtain access to the reinsurance market.

def.en: If you #capture# someone or something, you catch them, especially in a war.
def.exmp: The guerrillas shot down one aeroplane and captured the pilot. The whole town celebrated when two tanks were captured. King Arthur himself captures the beast and cuts off its head. The Russians now appear ready to capture more territory from the Chechens. ...the murders of fifteen thousand captured Polish soldiers. ...the final battles which led to the army's capture of the town. def.en: If you #caress# someone, you stroke them gently and affectionately.

def.en: The #cargo# of a ship or plane is the goods that it is carrying.

def.en: A #casualty# is a person who is injured or killed in a war or in an accident.

def.en: A #catastrophe# is an unexpected event that causes great suffering or damage.
def.exmp: From all points of view, war would be a catastrophe. If the world is to avoid environmental catastrophe, advanced economies must undergo a profound transition.

def.en: If people or things are divided into #categories#, they are divided into groups in such a way that the members of each group are similar to each other in some way.

def.en: In British English, to #cater for# a group of people means to provide all the things that they need or want.

def.en: If something #ceases#, it stops happening or existing.

def.en: A #celebrity# is someone who is famous, especially in areas of entertainment such as films, music, writing, or sport.

def.en: To # cement# something is to fix or stick it using a type of cement.

def.en: A #cemetery# is a place where dead people's bodies or their ashes are buried.
A #census# is an official survey of the population of a country that is carried out in order to find out how many people live there and to obtain details of such things as people's ages and jobs.
A #cent# is a small unit of money worth one hundredth of some currencies, for example the dollar and the euro.
def.exmp: A cup of rice which cost thirty cents a few weeks ago is now being sold for up to one dollar. We haven't got a cent.

def.en: #Centigrade# is a scale for measuring temperature, in which water freezes at 0 degrees and boils at 100 degrees.

def.en: A #centimetre# is a unit of length in the metric system equal to ten millimetres or one-hundredth of a metre.

def.en: #Cereal# or #breakfast cereal# is a food made from grain.

def.en: #Certainty# is the state of being definite or of having no doubts at all about something.

A general election became a certainty three weeks ago. ...the certainty of more violence and bloodshed. I began to realize the certainty of freezing to death if I remained where I was. There are no certainties in modern Europe. The collapse of old certainties is reshaping the political parties.

def.en: If someone in an official position #certifies# something, they officially state that it is true.

Exmp: A charge controller takes the energy from your solar panels and #charges# a battery.
def.exmp: 'Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs', the 1937 Disney classic, has lost none of its original charm. The house had its charms, not the least of which was the furniture that came with it. You can't force–or even charm–him into behaving differently if he doesn't want to. ...charming his way into the British Embassy in Teheran. He charmed his way out of trouble. def.en: A #charter# is a formal document describing the rights, aims, or principles of an organization or group of people.

def.en: If you #chase# someone, or #chase# #after# them, you run after them or follow them quickly in order to catch or reach them.

Police said he was arrested without a struggle after a car chase through the streets of Biarritz. In Wales, 14 people are chasing every job. There are too many schools chasing too few pupils. ...publishers and booksellers chasing after profits from high-volume sales. They took an invincible lead in the chase for the championship. I'm not very good at flirting or chasing women. 'I was always chasing after unsuitable men,' she says. The chase is always much more exciting than the conquest anyway. Many farmers will then chase you off their land quite aggressively. Angry demonstrators chased him away. His single-minded pursuit of European union helped chase Mrs Thatcher from power. They chased down the stairs into the narrow, dirty street. ...chasing about late at night in search of life's necessities. ...bear robes, mountain lion hides, and other trophies of the chase. ...the Champion Hunter Chase.

def.en: A #chef# is a cook in a restaurant or hotel.
A # chef# is a cook in a restaurant or hotel.
def.exmp: Our #chef# is famous for her delicious cooking. The talented #chefs# in the restaurant can prepare a variety of dishes. The #chefs# have experience of cooking in a busy hotel kitchen.

def.en: A #chemist# or a #chemist's# is a shop where drugs and medicines are sold or given out, and where you can buy cosmetics and some household goods.

def.en: #Chemistry# is the scientific study of the structure of substances and of the way that they react with other substances.

If the supply of vitamins and minerals in the diet is inadequate, this will result in changes in body chemistry. ...the extraordinary chemistry between Ingrid and Bogart. def.en: If you #cherish# something such as a hope or a pleasant memory, you keep it in your mind for a long period of time.

He genuinely loved and cherished her. The previous owners had cherished the house. He described the picture as his most cherished possession. These people cherish their independence and sovereignty. Freud called into question some deeply-cherished beliefs.

def.en: #Cherries# are small, round fruit with red skins.

Your #chest# is the top part of the front of your body where your ribs, lungs, and heart are.

def.en: When you #chew# food, you use your teeth to break it up in your mouth so that it becomes easier to swallow.

One girl was chewing gum. He chews tobacco constantly. He chewed his lower lip nervously. They pause and chew their pencils. def.en: The #chief# of an organization is the person who is in charge of it.
def.exmp: ...a commission appointed by the police chief. ...Putin's chief of security. ...Sitting Bull, chief of the Sioux tribes of the Great Plains. ...the chief test pilot. Financial stress is well established as a chief reason for divorce. The job went to one of his chief rivals.

def.en: When you #chill# something or when it #chills#, you lower its temperature so that it becomes colder but does not freeze.
def.exmp: Chill the fruit salad until serving time. These doughs can be rolled out while you wait for the pastry to chill. ...a glass of chilled champagne. The marble floor was beginning to chill me. An exposed garden may be chilled by cold winds. Wade placed his chilled hands on the radiator. The boulder sheltered them from the chilling wind. There was a coldness in her that chilled him. Some films chill you to the marrow of your bones. The violence used against the students sent a chill through Indonesia. He smiled, an odd, dreamy smile that sent chills up my back. He caught a chill while performing at a rain-soaked open-air venue. ...chill winds, rain and choppy seas. September is here, bringing with it a chill in the mornings. ...the cold chill of the night.

def.en: A #chimney# is a pipe through which smoke goes up into the air, usually through the roof of a building.
def.exmp: This gas fire doesn't need a chimney.

def.en: Your #chin# is the part of your face that is below your mouth and above your neck.
def.exmp: ...a double chin. He rubbed the gray stubble on his chin.

def.en: #Chips# are long, thin pieces of potato fried in oil or fat and eaten hot, usually with a meal.
def.exmp: I had fish and chips in a cafe. Frank Browne shook more sauce over his chips. ...a package of onion-flavored potato chips. It contains real chocolate chips. He was burning wood chips to make charcoal. Teichler's eyes gleamed like chips of blue glass. The washbasin had a small chip. The blow chipped the woman's tooth. Steel baths are lighter but chip easily. The wagon's paint was badly chipped on the outside. They drank out of chipped mugs. He put the pile of chips in the centre of the table and drew a card. The information could be used as a bargaining chip to extract some parallel information from Britain. He was not expected to be released because he was considered a valuable chip in this game.

def.en: # Chips# are small pieces of material that come off the surface of a workpiece when it is being cut.
def.exmp: When cutting metal, make sure that the #chips# clear properly and do not scratch the surface of the metal. #Chips# are pieces of metal removed from a workpiece by cutting tools or by an abrasive medium. #Chips# are small pieces of material that come off the surface of a workpiece when it is being cut.

def.en: A # chip# is the finished integrated circuit.
def.exmp: A microprocessor is a small #chip# part to control functions of a digital system like a music player, electronic calculator, or computer. Memory modules are computer #chips# used to add memory to a computer. A #chip# is the finished integrated circuit.

def.en: When you #choke# or when something #chokes# you, you cannot breathe properly or get enough air into your lungs.
def.exmp: The coffee was almost too hot to swallow and made him choke for a moment. A small child could choke on the doll's hair. Dense smoke swirled and billowed, its rank fumes choking her. The girl choked to death after breathing in smoke. Within minutes the hall was full of choking smoke. The men pushed him into the entrance of a nearby building where they choked him with his tie. The village's roads are choked with traffic. His pond has been choked by the fast-growing weed.

def.en: The # choke# in a vehicle is a device that reduces the amount of air going into the engine and makes it easier to start the engine or run it in cold weather.
def.exmp: A #choke# gets the engine firing right, with the right air/fuel mixture and lets it warm up without being too rich or too lean. The #choke# circuit restricts the flow of air through the carburetor, thus increasing the percentage of fuel mixed with that air to help the engine start and warm up. Almost all American cars use a butterfly valve-type #choke#, placed near the carburetor's air inlet.

def.en: A # choke# is a device for reducing the flow of a fluid in a pipe or tube.
def.exmp: The #choke# on a motorcycle restricts the amount of air that is mixed with the gas. #A choke# is a device that restricts the flow of air at the entrance of the carburetor. #A choke# is a device for reducing the flow of a fluid in a pipe or tube.

def.en: A # choke# is a device which controls the flow rate of a fluid in a pipe.
def.exmp: The well flow is controlled with a #choke#. #Chokes# are used to control the rate of flow of the drilling mud out of the hole. A #choke# is a device which controls the flow rate of a fluid in a pipe.

def.en: A # choke# is a coil of low resistance and high inductance that is used in electrical circuits to pass low frequency or direct currents while stopping the higher frequency alternating currents.
def.exmp: Inductors called #chokes# are used as parts of filters in power supplies or to block alternating current signals from passing through a circuit. #Chokes# are inductors used to eliminate alternating current above a certain frequency. A #choke# is a coil of low resistance and high inductance that is used in electrical circuits to pass low frequency or direct currents while stopping the higher frequency alternating currents.

def.en: If you #chop# something, you cut it into pieces with strong downward movements of a knife or an axe.
def.exmp: Chop the butter into small pieces. Chop the onions very finely. Visitors were set to work chopping wood. ...chopped tomatoes. ...grilled lamb chops.

def.en: If you # chop# food, you cut it into pieces with strong, downward movements of a knife.
def.exmp: #Chop# the butter into small pieces. Finely #chop# the onions and garlic with a sharp knife. I used a kitchen knife to #chop# the tomatoes into large pieces.

def.en: A #chorus# is a part of a song which is repeated after each verse.
def.exmp: Caroline sang two verses and the chorus of her song. Everyone joined in the chorus. The chorus was singing 'The Ode to Joy'. ...the Hallelujah Chorus. Students played the lesser parts and sang in the chorus. The government is defending its economic policies against a growing chorus of criticism. 'Hi,' they chorused. He was greeted with a rousing chorus of Happy Birthday. 'All the best,' called the other typists in chorus.

def.en: #Christ# is one of the names of Jesus, whom Christians believe to be the son of God and whose teachings are the basis of Christianity.
def.exmp: ...the teachings of Christ. He looked at her watch. 'Christ! We only have three minutes!'

def.en: A #Christian# is someone who follows the teachings of Jesus Christ.
def.exmp: He was a devout Christian. Last week there were clashes during protests by Christians and Muslims. ...the Christian Church. ...the Christian faith. ...Christian areas of Beirut. Most of my friends are Christian.

def.en: #Christmas# is a Christian festival when the birth of Jesus Christ is celebrated.
def.exmp: The day after Christmas is generally a busy one for retailers. Merry Christmas, Mom. During the Christmas holidays there's a tremendous amount of traffic between the Northeast and Florida. He'll be in the hospital over Christmas, so we'll be spending our Christmas Day there.

def.en: A #chronic# illness or disability lasts for a very long time.
def.exmp: ...chronic back pain. Most of them were chronically ill. Anyone who does not believe that smoking is an addiction has never been a chronic smoker. ...a chronic worrier. One cause of the artist's suicide seems to have been chronic poverty. There is a chronic shortage of patrol cars in this police district. Research and technology are said to be chronically underfunded.

def.en: A #church# is a building in which Christians worship.
def.exmp: ...one of Britain's most historic churches. ...St Helen's Church. I didn't see you in church on Sunday. ...co-operation with the Church of Scotland. Church leaders said he was welcome to return. ...the separation of church and state.

def.en: An electrical #circuit# is a complete route which an electric current can flow around.
def.exmp: Any attempts to cut through the cabling will break the electrical circuit. He joined the professional circuit. It's a common problem, the one I'm asked about most when I'm on the lecture circuit. She made a slow circuit of the room.

def.en: A # circuit# is a system for cycling (=moving in a repeated way) a bulk solid through a process to reduce its size.
def.exmp: The feedstock is pumped around in a #circuit# until the required degree of size reduction is achieved. The material is continually returned to the #circuit# for further size reduction. A #circuit# is a system for cycling a bulk solid through a process to reduce its size.

def.en: An electrical # circuit# is the complete path crossed by an electric current.
def.exmp: When distributing three-phase electric power, a fourth or neutral cable is run in the street distribution to provide a complete #circuit# to each house. An ampere is the unit of measurement of electrical current produced in a #circuit# by 1 volt acting through a resistance of 1 ohm. An electrical #circuit# is the complete path crossed by an electric current.

def.en: Something that is #circular# is shaped like a circle.
def.exmp: ...a circular hole twelve feet wide and two feet deep. Place your hands on your shoulders and move your elbows up, back, and down, in a circular motion. Both sides of the river can be explored on this circular walk. The proposal has been widely publicised in BBC-TV press information circulars sent to 1,800 newspapers.

def.en: If a piece of writing #circulates# or #is circulated#, copies of it are passed round among a group of people.
def.exmp: The document was previously circulated in New York at the United Nations. Public employees, teachers and liberals are circulating a petition for his recall. This year anonymous leaflets have been circulating in Beijing. ...an inquiry into the circulation of 'unacceptable literature'. Rumours were already beginning to circulate that the project might have to be abandoned. I deeply resented those sort of rumours being circulated at a time of deeply personal grief. ...a virus which circulates via the bloodstream and causes ill health in a variety of organs. Cooking odours can circulate throughout the entire house. The north pole is warmer than the south and the circulation of air around it is less well contained. ...the principle of free circulation of goods. Let me get you something to drink, then I must circulate.

def.en: The #circumference# of a circle, place, or round object is the distance around its edge.
def.exmp: ...a scientist calculating the Earth's circumference. The island is 3.5 km in circumference. Cut the salmon into long strips and wrap it round the circumference of the bread.

def.en: A #circus# is a group that consists of clowns, acrobats, and animals which travels around to different places and performs shows.
def.exmp: My real ambition was to work in a circus. ...circus performers. My dad took me to the circus. It could well turn into some kind of a media circus. ...the travelling circus of political journalists. ...Piccadilly Circus.

def.en: If you #cite# something, you quote it or mention it, especially as an example or proof of what you are saying.
def.exmp: She cites a favourite poem by George Herbert. He cites just one example. I am merely citing his reaction as typical of British industry. Spain was cited as the most popular holiday destination. They cited Alex's refusal to return to the marital home. Three admirals and a top Navy civilian will be cited for failing to act on reports of sexual assaults. The judge ruled a mistrial and cited the prosecutors for outrageous misconduct.

def.en: You use #civil# to describe events that happen within a country and that involve the different groups of people in it.
def.exmp: ...civil unrest. ...the U.S. civil aviation industry. They were married on August 9 in a civil ceremony in Venice. ...Jewish civil and religious law. ...a United Nations covenant on civil and political rights. As visitors, the least we can do is be civil to the people in their own land. The man nodded civilly to Sharpe, then consulted a notebook. ...civility to underlings.

def.en: In a military situation, a #civilian# is anyone who is not a member of the armed forces.
def.exmp: The safety of civilians caught up in the fighting must be guaranteed. ...the country's civilian population. ...civilian casualties. ...a soldier in civilian clothes.

def.en: To #civilize# a person or society means to educate them and improve their way of life.
def.exmp: ...a comedy about a man who tries to civilise a woman–but she ends up civilising him. It exerts a civilizing influence on mankind.

def.en: If you say that someone #claims# #that# something is true, you mean they say that it is true but you are not sure whether or not they are telling the truth.
def.exmp: He claimed that it was all a conspiracy against him. A man claiming to be a journalist threatened to reveal details about her private life. 'I had never received one single complaint against me,' claimed the humiliated doctor. He claims a 70 to 80 per cent success rate. He repeated his claim that the people of Trinidad and Tobago backed his action. He rejected claims that he had affairs with six women. An underground organisation has claimed responsibility for the bomb explosion. He was too modest to claim the credit. Now they are returning to claim what was theirs. Rival claims to Macedonian territory caused conflict in the Balkans. Zhuang claimed the record in 54.64 seconds. Steffi Graf claimed a fourth Wimbledon title in 1992. She'd no claims on him now. He was surrounded by people, all with claims on his attention. There is already a long list of people claiming her attention. Some 25 per cent of the people who are entitled to claim State benefits do not do so. John had taken out redundancy insurance but when he tried to claim, he was refused payment. They intend to claim for damages against the three doctors. ...the office which has been dealing with their claim for benefit. Last time we made a claim on our insurance they paid up really quickly. The union claimed a pay rise worth four times the rate of inflation. They are making substantial claims for improved working conditions. Electricity workers have voted for industrial action in pursuit of a pay claim. The civil war claimed the life of a U.N. interpreter yesterday. Heart disease is the biggest killer, claiming 180,000 lives a year.

def.en: A # claim# is a request to an insurance company for payment of a sum of money according to the terms of an insurance policy.
def.exmp: Over the course of 30 or 40 years there may be only a handful of times you need to make an insurance #claim#. Your employer is responsible for all issues related to your employment and your #claim# for workers' compensation. A #claim# is a request to an insurance company for payment of a sum of money according to the terms of an insurance policy.

def.en: A # claim# is a sum of money demanded from an insurance company according to the terms of an insurance policy.
def.exmp: The employer assumes all or part of the responsibility for paying the health insurance #claims# of the employees. A deductible is an amount deducted from an insurance #claim#. A #claim# is a sum of money demanded from an insurance company according to the terms of an insurance policy.

def.en: If you # claim# money from an insurance company, you ask for payment of costs relating to a loss or damage for which you have insurance cover.
def.exmp: If you #claim# for damage or loss to your insured property which occurs after your building has not been occupied for 60 consecutive days, an additional compulsory excess is payable. The notice must specify the amount #claimed# or the facts that will enable the insurer to determine the amount. If you #claim# money from an insurance company, you ask for payment of costs relating to a loss or damage for which you have insurance cover.

def.en: The #clarity# of something such as a book or argument is its quality of being well explained and easy to understand.
def.exmp: ...the ease and clarity with which the author explains difficult technical and scientific subjects. In business circles he is noted for his flair and clarity of vision. This remarkable technology provides far greater clarity than conventional x-rays. The first thing to strike me was the amazing clarity of the water.

def.en: When people #clash#, they fight, argue, or disagree with each other.
def.exmp: A group of 400 demonstrators clashed with police. Behind the scenes, Parsons clashed with almost everyone on the show. The United States and Israel clashed over demands for a U.N. investigation into the killings. There have been a number of clashes between police in riot gear and demonstrators. Don't make any policy decisions which clash with official company thinking. Here, morality and good sentiments clash headlong. Inside government, there was a clash of views. The detective changed his holiday dates when his flight was brought forward and it now clashed with the trial. The red door clashed with the soft, natural tones of the stone walls. So what if the colours clashed? Lewis has recently recovered his fitness and will clash with Christie in the 4x100m relay. The two sides will clash there only if Chelsea beat Sunderland in their quarter-final replay. Australia's rugby union team for the return clash with New Zealand is weakened by injury. The golden bangles on her arms clashed and jingled. ...a noise like the clash of cymbals.

def.en: If you #clasp# someone or something, you hold them tightly in your hands or arms.
def.exmp: She clasped the children to her. He paced the corridor, hands clasped behind his back. With one last clasp of his hand, she left him and went to her usual chair. ...the clasp of her handbag.

def.en: A #classic# example of a thing or situation has all the features which you expect such a thing or situation to have.
def.exmp: The debate in the mainstream press has been a classic example of British hypocrisy. His first two goals were classic cases of being in the right place at the right time. It was a classic of interrogation: first the bully, then the kind one who offers sympathy. ...the classic children's film Huckleberry Finn. ...a classic study of the American penal system. The record won a gold award and remains one of the classics of modern popular music. ...a film classic. As I grow older, I like to reread the classics regularly. Wear classic clothes which feel good and look good. These are classic designs which will fit in well anywhere. ...a Classics degree.

def.en: A #classification# is a division or category in a system which divides things into groups or types.
def.exmp: Its tariffs cater for four basic classifications of customer.

def.en: # Classification# is the separation of larger particles from smaller ones.
def.exmp: #Classification# is used for fine particles that cannot be efficiently screened. #Classification# involves the separation of mixtures of minerals into two or more products on the basis of the velocity with which mineral grains fall through a fluid medium. #Classification# is the separation of larger particles from smaller ones.

def.en: A #clause# is a section of a legal document.
def.exmp: He has a clause in his contract which entitles him to a percentage of the profits. ...a compromise document sprinkled with escape clauses. ...a complaint alleging a breach of clause 4 of the code.

def.en: The #claws# of a bird or animal are the thin, hard, curved nails at the end of its feet.
def.exmp: The cat tried to cling to the edge by its claws. The wolf clawed at the tree and howled the whole night. His fingers clawed at Blake's wrist. He stumbled, clawed wildly at the air and fell backwards into the water. Some did manage to claw their way up iron ladders to the safety of the upper deck. Gino clawed his way out of underworld obscurity to become a millionaire hotelier. She should take her claws out of Tom and let him get on with his life.

def.en: #Clay# is a kind of earth that is soft when it is wet and hard when it is dry.
def.exmp: ...the heavy clay soils of Cambridgeshire. As the wheel turned, the potter shaped and squeezed the lump of clay into a graceful shape. ...a little clay pot. Most tennis is played on hard courts, but a substantial amount is played on clay. He was a clay-court specialist who won Wimbledon five times.

def.en: The #clergy# are the official leaders of the religious activities of a particular group of believers.
def.exmp: These proposals met opposition from the clergy.

def.en: A #clerk# is a person who works in an office, bank, or law court and whose job is to look after the records or accounts.
def.exmp: She was offered a job as an accounts clerk with a travel firm. ...a hotel clerk. Gene clerked at the auction. He clerked for the chief justice of the Supreme Court.

def.en: A #cliff# is a high area of land with a very steep side, especially one next to the sea.
def.exmp: The car rolled over the edge of a cliff.

def.en: The #climax# #of# something is the most exciting or important moment in it, usually near the end.
def.exmp: For Pritchard, reaching an Olympics was the climax of her career. It was the climax to 24 hours of growing anxiety. The last golf tournament of the European season is building up to a dramatic climax. The demonstration climaxed two weeks of strikes. They've just finished a sell-out U.K. tour that climaxed with a three-night stint at Brixton Academy. Often, a man can enjoy making love but may not be sufficiently aroused to climax.

def.en: If you #cling# #to# someone or something, you hold onto them tightly.
def.exmp: Another man was rescued as he clung to the riverbank. She had to cling onto the door handle until the pain passed. They hugged each other, clinging together under the lights. He appears determined to cling to power. Another minister clung on with a majority of only 18. Japan's productivity has overtaken America in some industries, but elsewhere the United States has clung on to its lead. His sodden trousers were clinging to his shins. ...clinging black garments. Her glass had bits of orange clinging to the rim. I was terrified he would leave me, so I was clinging to him. She was anxious not to appear clinging. They know scholars reject their legend, but they still cling to their belief. They're clinging to the past.

def.en: A #clinic# is a building where people go to receive medical advice or treatment.
def.exmp: ...a family planning clinic.

def.en: A #clip# is a small device, usually made of metal or plastic, that is specially shaped for holding things together.
def.exmp: She took the clip out of her hair. He clipped his safety belt to a fitting on the deck. He clipped his cufflinks neatly in place. ...an electronic pen which clips to the casing. His flashlight was still clipped to his belt. ...an historical film clip of Lenin speaking. ...a clip from the movie 'Shane'. I saw an old man out clipping his hedge. He had already clipped his hair close to the skull. Give hedges a last clip. Kids in his neighborhood clipped his picture from the newspaper and carried it around. The lorry clipped the rear of a tanker and then crashed into a second truck. The boy was later given a clip round the ear by his father. Boardman finished in 1hr 43mins, clipping 49 seconds from his own course record.

def.en: A #cloak# is a long, loose, sleeveless piece of clothing which people used to wear over their other clothes when they went out.
def.exmp: Today most of England will be under a cloak of thick mist. Preparations for the wedding were made under a cloak of secrecy. ...the decision to cloak major tourist attractions in unsightly hoardings. A fire could have been deliberately started to cloak small coordinated troop movements. The beautiful sweeping coastline was cloaked in mist.

def.en: When something is moving #clockwise#, it is moving in a circle in the same direction as the hands on a clock.
def.exmp: He told the children to start moving clockwise around the room. Gently swing your right arm in a clockwise direction.

def.en: A #closet# is a piece of furniture with doors at the front and shelves inside, which is used for storing things.
def.exmp: He is a closet Fascist. ...closet misogyny.

def.en: A # closet# is a very small room for storing things, especially one without windows.
def.exmp: The #closet# in the suite is large, with plenty of room for clothes. Fetch the pan and brush from the broom #closet#. The #closets# are not tall enough to hang long clothes in.

def.en: A #clue# #to# a problem or mystery is something that helps you to find the answer to it.
def.exmp: Geneticists in Canada have discovered a clue to the puzzle of why our cells get old and die. How a man shaves may be a telling clue to his age. The vital clue to the killer's identity was his nickname, Peanuts.

def.en: A #clumsy# person moves or handles things in a careless, awkward way, often so that things are knocked over or broken.
def.exmp: I'd never seen a clumsier, less coordinated boxer. Unfortunately, I was still very clumsy behind the wheel of the jeep. The rooks flew clumsily towards their nests. Ben's biggest problem is clumsiness. The action seemed a clumsy attempt to topple the Janata Dal government. He denied the announcement was clumsy and insensitive. If the matter were handled clumsily, it could cost Miriam her life. I was ashamed at my clumsiness and insensitivity. The keyboard is a large and clumsy instrument as far as portable computers are concerned. It was a clumsy looking aeroplane.

def.en: A #cluster# #of# people or things is a small group of them close together.
def.exmp: ...clusters of men in formal clothes. There's no town here, just a cluster of shops, cabins and motels at the side of the highway. The passengers clustered together in small groups. The children clustered around me.

def.en: If you #clutch# #at# something or #clutch# something, you hold it tightly, usually because you are afraid or anxious.
def.exmp: I staggered and had to clutch at a chair for support. She was clutching a photograph. Tony fell into the clutches of an attractive American who introduced him to drugs. Stojanovic escaped their clutches by jumping from a moving vehicle. Laura let out the clutch and pulled slowly away down the drive. ...the second clutch of eggs. The party has attracted a clutch of young southern liberals. ...a clutch of songs about adolescent experiences.

def.en: The # clutch# in a vehicle is a mechanism which connects the engine with the gearbox to make the vehicle move, and disconnects them to allow a driver to change gear.
A # clutch# is a device that locks two parts of a mechanism together and transfers power between them.
def.exmp: #Clutches# control whether automobiles transmit engine power to the gearbox. If the engine is running with the #clutch# engaged and the transmission in neutral, the engine spins the input shaft of the transmission, but no power is transmitted to the wheels. A #clutch# is a device that locks two parts of a mechanism together and transfers power between them.

def.en: #Coal# is a hard black substance that is extracted from the ground and burned as fuel.
def.exmp: Gas-fired electricity is cheaper than coal. Today, oil and natural gas have replaced coal and wood in most areas. The iron teakettle was hissing splendidly over live coals. It is important to get the coals white-hot before you start cooking.

def.en: A #coalition# is a government consisting of people from two or more political parties.
def.exmp: Since June the country has had a coalition government. It took five months for the coalition to agree on and publish a medium-term economic programme. He had been opposed by a coalition of about 50 civil rights, women's and Latino organizations.

def.en: #Coarse# things have a rough texture because they consist of thick threads or large pieces.
def.exmp: ...a jacket made of very coarse cloth. ...a beach of coarse sand. ...coarsely-ground black pepper. The soldiers did not bother to moderate their coarse humour in her presence. The women laughed coarsely at some vulgar joke. The coarseness of her cursing amazed the workmen.

def.en: #Cocaine# is a powerful drug which some people take for pleasure, but which they can become addicted to.
A #cock# is an adult male chicken.
def.exmp: The cock was announcing the start of a new day. ...a cock pheasant. He paused and cocked his head as if listening. The Brigadier thought about this for a moment, head cocked to one side. He suddenly cocked an ear and listened. All ears were cocked for the footsteps on the stairs. His hands were too weak to cock his revolver.

def.en: #Cognitive# means relating to the mental process involved in knowing, learning, and understanding things.
def.exmp: As children grow older, their cognitive processes become sharper. ...Vygotsky's theory of cognitive development.

def.en: If something is #coherent#, it is well planned, so that it is clear and sensible and all its parts go well with each other.
def.exmp: He has failed to work out a coherent strategy for modernising the service. The President's policy is perfectly coherent. The campaign was widely criticised for making tactical mistakes and for a lack of coherence. The government has to convince voters it is proceeding coherently toward its goals. He's so calm when he answers questions in interviews. I wish I could be that coherent. She lost consciousness and when she came round she still lacked coherence and focus. He talked coherently.

def.en: Something that is #cohesive# consists of parts that fit together well and form a united whole.
def.exmp: 'Daring Adventures' from '86 is a far more cohesive and successful album. Huston had assembled a remarkably cohesive and sympathetic cast. They had no group cohesiveness. They were in competition with each other all the time.

def.en: A #coil# #of# rope or wire is a length of it that has been wound into a series of loops.
def.exmp: Tod shook his head angrily and slung the coil of rope over his shoulder. The steel arrives at the factory in coils. Pythons kill by tightening their coils so that their victim cannot breathe. He turned off the water and began to coil the hose. Louisa was dancing, spinning by herself, her skirt flying out and coiling around her feet. A huge rattlesnake lay coiled on the blanket. Once we have the wire, we can coil it up into the shape of a spring. Her hair was coiled up on top of her head.

def.en: A # coil# is a twisted tube for carrying a fluid, which is used inside a vessel but has entry and exit points outside the vessel.
def.exmp: The refrigerant is circulated through the #coil# of the evaporative condenser. The high velocity of the coolant through the #coil# ensures usefully high heat transfer rates. A #coil# is a twisted tube for carrying a fluid, which is used inside a vessel but has entry and exit points outside the vessel.

def.en: A # coil# consists of several loops of conductor that may be round a central ferrous core.
def.exmp: The #coil# used to be central to supplying high voltage to a car's sparking plugs. An inductor is a circuit element consisting of a #coil# of wire wound on a core material made of ferrous or non-ferrous material. A #coil# consists of several loops of conductor that may be round a central ferrous core.

def.en: If one event #coincides# #with# another, they happen at the same time.
def.exmp: The exhibition coincides with the 50th anniversary of his death. Although his mental illness had coincided with his war service it had not been caused by it. The beginning of the solar and lunar years coincided every 13 years. The kids' views on life don't always coincide, but they're not afraid of voicing their opinions. ...a case in which public and private interests coincide. He gave great encouragement to his students, especially if their passions happened to coincide with his own.

def.en: A #coincidence# is when two or more similar or related events occur at the same time by chance and without any planning.
def.exmp: Mr. Berry said the timing was a coincidence and that his decision was unrelated to Mr. Roman's departure. ...a string of amazing coincidences. The premises of Chabert and Sons were situated by the river and, by coincidence, not too far away from where Eric Talbot had met his death.

def.en: #Coke# is a solid black substance that is produced from coal and is burned as a fuel.
def.exmp: ...a coke-burning stove.

def.en: # Coke# is a fuel that is made by the carbonization of fossil fuels.
def.exmp: By-products of this conversion of coal to #coke# include coal tar, ammonia, light oils, and coal gas. #Coke# is prepared from bituminous coals by pyrolysis or dry distillation. #Coke# is a fuel that is made by the carbonization of fossil fuels.

def.en: When one person or group #collaborates# #with# another, they work together, especially on a book or on some research.
def.exmp: He collaborated with his son Michael on the English translation of a text on food production. The government is urging Japan's firms to collaborate with foreigners. ...a place where professionals and amateurs collaborated in the making of music. The two men met and agreed to collaborate. He was accused of having collaborated with the secret police.

def.en: If a building or other structure #collapses#, it falls down very suddenly.
def.exmp: A section of the Bay Bridge had collapsed. The roof collapsed in a roar of rock and rubble. Most of the deaths were caused by landslides and collapsing buildings. Governor Deukmejian called for an inquiry into the freeway's collapse. His business empire collapsed under a massive burden of debt. This system has collapsed in most countries where it ruled. The rural people have been impoverished by a collapsing economy. The coup's collapse has speeded up the drive to independence. Their economy is teetering on the brink of collapse. He collapsed following a vigorous exercise session at his home. It's commonplace to see people collapsing from hunger in the streets. A few days after his collapse he was sitting up in bed. She arrived home exhausted and barely capable of showering before collapsing on her bed. He plunged 300ft to the ground when his parachute collapsed. He was rushed to hospital last week after suffering a collapsed lung.

def.en: The #collar# of a shirt or coat is the part which fits round the neck and is usually folded over.
def.exmp: His tie was pulled loose and his collar hung open. ...a coat with a huge fake fur collar. As Kerr fled towards the exit, Boycott collared him at the ticket barrier. Beattie managed to collar Atkins in a hallway. Bernard was once collared by an aggressive stranger in Soho.

def.en: A # collar# is a ring or tube that fits onto a shaft or rod, for example to prevent a part from coming off the end of a shaft.
def.exmp: There's a metal #collar# around the shaft that prevents it from being pulled out. Threaded shaft #collars# lock securely by fully slotting into the threads of the shaft. A #collar# is a ring or tube that fits onto a shaft or rod, for example to prevent a part from coming off the end of a shaft.

def.en: If two or more moving people or objects #collide#, they crash into one another.
def.exmp: Two trains collided head-on in north-eastern Germany early this morning. Racing up the stairs, he almost collided with Daisy. He collided with a pine tree near the North Gate. The aims of the negotiators in New York again seem likely to collide with the aims of the warriors in the field. In the next two years, Nasser regularly collided with the different Western powers, who refused to arm him. What happens when the two interests collide will make a fascinating spectacle.

def.en: A #collision# occurs when a moving object crashes into something.
def.exmp: They were on their way to the Shropshire Union Canal when their van was involved in a collision with a car. I saw a head-on collision between two aeroplanes. It's the collision of disparate ideas that alters one's perspective. The play represents the collision of three generations.

def.en: A #colonel# is a senior officer in an army, air force, or the marines.
def.exmp: This particular place was run by an ex-Army colonel. ...Colonel Edward Staley.

def.en: #Colonial# means relating to countries that are colonies, or to colonialism.
def.exmp: ...the 31st anniversary of Jamaica's independence from British colonial rule. ...the colonial civil service. ...a group of ex-colonials. ...the white colonial houses on the north side of the campus. I sat on the Colonial bench that was just to the left of the office doorway.

def.en: A #colony# is a country which is controlled by a more powerful country.
def.exmp: In France's former North African colonies, anti-French feeling is growing. Puerto Rico, though it calls itself a Commonwealth, is really a self-governing American colony. In 1932, he established a school and artists' colony in Stone City, Iowa. ...a penal colony. ...industrial colonies. Many of our troops and officers were scattered around the world in the service of His Majesty in the colonies. On the eve of the Revolution, the colonies produced thirty thousand tons of crude iron a year. The Shetlands are famed for their colonies of sea birds. The caterpillars feed in large colonies.

def.en: A #column# is a tall, often decorated cylinder of stone which is built to honour someone or forms part of a building.
def.exmp: ...a London landmark, Nelson's Column in Trafalgar Square. The explosion sent a column of smoke thousands of feet into the air. There were reports of columns of military vehicles appearing on the streets. We had stupidly been looking at the wrong column of figures. In The Dictionary of Quotations, there are no fewer than one and a half columns devoted to 'kiss'. His name features frequently in the social columns of the tabloid newspapers. She also writes a regular column for the Times Educational Supplement.

def.en: A # column# is a tall, vertical vessel which separates substances by gravity, usually for distillation.
def.exmp: Within refineries there are several other, smaller distillation towers called #columns#, designed to separate specific and unique products. Separation of the oxide and the organic byproducts is accomplished by distillation in two #columns#. #A column# is a tall, vertical vessel which separates substances by gravity, usually for distillation.

def.en: A #comb# is a flat piece of plastic or metal with narrow pointed teeth along one side, which you use to tidy your hair.
def.exmp: Salvatore combed his hair carefully. Her reddish hair was cut short and neatly combed. Officers combed the woods for the murder weapon. They fanned out and carefully combed the temple grounds. Eight policemen then spent two years combing through the evidence.

def.en: #Combat# is fighting that takes place in a war.
def.exmp: Over 16 million men had died in combat. Yesterday saw hand-to-hand combat in the city. ...combat aircraft. It was the end of a long combat. Congress has criticised new government measures to combat crime.

def.en: A #combination# #of# things is a mixture of them.
def.exmp: ...a fantastic combination of colours. ...the combination of science and art.

def.en: If you #combine# two or more things or if they #combine#, they exist together.
def.exmp: The Church has something to say on how to combine freedom with responsibility. If improved education is combined with other factors dramatic results can be achieved. Relief workers say it's worse than ever as disease and starvation combine to kill thousands. A stagnant economy combined with a surge in the number of teenagers is likely to have contributed to rising crime levels in the U.S. David Jacobs was given the job of combining the data from these 19 studies into one giant study. Combine the flour with 3 tablespoons water to make a paste. Carbon, hydrogen and oxygen combine chemically to form carbohydrates and fats. Combined with other compounds, they created a massive dynamite-type bomb. Their system seems to combine the two ideals of strong government and proportional representation. ...a clever, far-sighted lawyer who combines legal expertise with social concern. Her tale has a consciously youthful tone and storyline, combined with a sly humour. It is possible to combine a career with being a mother. He will combine the two jobs over the next three years. ...an announcement by Steetley and Tarmac of a joint venture that would combine their operations. Different states or groups can combine to enlarge their markets. ...Veba, an energy-and-chemicals combine that is Germany's fourth-biggest company.

def.en: To #commemorate# an important event or person means to remember them by means of a special action, ceremony, or specially-created object.
def.exmp: One room contained a gallery of paintings commemorating great moments in baseball history. The 200th anniversary of Mozart's death is being commemorated around the world with concerts featuring his work. ...the 50th Anniversary Commemoration of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. ...a service of commemoration. ...a march in commemoration of Malcolm X.

def.en: When something #commences# or you #commence# it, it begins.
def.exmp: The academic year commences at the beginning of October. They commenced a systematic search. The hunter knelt beside the animal carcass and commenced to skin it.

def.en: If you #commend# someone or something, you praise them formally.
def.exmp: I commended her for that action. I commend Ms. Orth on writing such an informative article. The book was widely commended for its candour. The reports commend her bravery. His actions were commended by the Jury. The Company received a commendation from the Royal Society of Arts. I can commend it to him as a realistic course of action. The Rousseau model commended itself to a lot of early socialists.

def.en: #Commerce# is the activities and procedures involved in buying and selling things.
def.exmp: They have made their fortunes from industry and commerce.

def.en: If you #commission# something or #commission# someone #to# do something, you formally arrange for someone to do a piece of work for you.
def.exmp: The Ministry of Agriculture commissioned a study into low-input farming. You can commission them to paint something especially for you. ...specially commissioned reports. Our china can be bought off the shelf or by commission. He approached John Wexley with a commission to write the screenplay of the film. ...Government-commissioned research. Just a few days ago, I finished a commission. The salesmen work on commission only. He also got a commission for bringing in new clients. Travel agents charge 1 per cent commission on sterling cheques. Sellers pay a fixed commission fee. The authorities have been asked to set up a commission to investigate the murders. ...the Press Complaints Commission. If a person uses a gun in the commission of a crime, then he should be given an additional penalty. He accepted a commission as a naval officer. He was commissioned as second lieutenant in the Air Force. Only commissioned officers qualify for the Military Cross.

def.en: # Commission# is payment of part of the revenues or profits from a sale or deal that is paid to the person who arranged or facilitated the deal.
def.exmp: Travel agents charge 1 percent #commission# on tickets. The salespeople work on #commission# only. #Commission# is payment of part of the revenues or profits from a sale or deal that is paid to the person who arranged or facilitated the deal.

def.en: # Commission# is payment to a broker of part of the profits from a sale.
def.exmp: Travel agents charge 1 percent #commission# on tickets. The salespeople work on #commission# only. #Commission# is payment to a broker of part of the profits from a sale.

def.en: If an insurance company pays # commission# to an intermediary, they pay them a fee for selling an insurance policy.
def.exmp: Insurance agents are paid #a commission# on a homeowner's insurance policy which is a percentage of the premium. An agent may be employed by a particular insurance company to sell insurance policies on its behalf and handle claims, receiving #a commission# on sales. If an insurance company pays #commission# to an intermediary, they pay them a fee for selling an insurance policy.

def.en: # Commission# is payment of part of the revenues or profits from a sale or deal that is paid to the person who arranged or facilitated the deal.
A #committee# is a group of people who meet to make decisions or plans for a larger group or organization that they represent.
def.exmp: ...a committee of ministers. ...an elected Management Committee who serve the Association on a voluntary basis. ...the Committee for Safety in Medicine. My reasons were stated in writing and circulated to all committee members.

def.en: A #commodity# is something that is sold for money.
def.exmp: The government increased prices on several basic commodities like bread and meat.

def.en: A # commodity# is an item that is traded on the market, such as wheat, gold, silver, oil, coffee, or sugar.
def.exmp: The corporation provided $150 million to finance the exports of various #commodities# and food goods including cotton and tobacco. #Commodities# widely traded on exchanges around the world are agricultural products and raw materials such as oil and copper. A #commodity# is an item that is traded on the market, such as wheat, gold, silver, oil, coffee, or sugar.

def.en: #The Commonwealth# is an organization consisting of the United Kingdom and most of the countries that were previously under its rule.
def.exmp: ...the Commonwealth of Australia. ...the Commonwealth of Independent States, which replaced the Soviet Union. ...a commonwealth of nations without economic borders.

def.en: #Communism# is the political belief that all people are equal and that workers should control the means of producing things.
def.exmp: ...the ultimate triumph of communism in the world.

def.en: If you #commute#, you travel a long distance every day between your home and your place of work.
def.exmp: Mike commutes to London every day. McLaren began commuting between Paris and London. He's going to commute. The number of commuters to London has dropped by 100,000. ...a commuter train. The average Los Angeles commute is over 60 miles a day. His death sentence was commuted to life imprisonment. Prison sentences have been commuted.

def.en: If you # commute# an annuity, you pay it at one time instead of in installments.
def.exmp: Retirement annuities are taxed as earned income, but part of the benefits can be #commuted# to a tax free lump sum. If you leave the plan before age 55, you may take a deferred pension or transfer the #commuted# value of your pension to another retirement arrangement. If you #commute# an annuity, you pay it at one time instead of in installments.

def.en: #Compact# things are small or take up very little space.
def.exmp: ...my compact office in Washington. ...the new, more compact Czech government. The very compactness of the cottage made it all the more snug and appealing. He was compact, probably no taller than me. He looked physically very powerful, athletic in a compact way. The Smith boy was compacting the trash. The soil settles and is compacted by the winter rain. ...a pile of compacted earth. Regular forking of beds and borders relieves the compaction caused by rain.

def.en: A # compact# is a porous solid that is made by pressing a powder.
def.exmp: A slowly increasing force is exerted on the powder #compact# and the point at which failure occurs determines the tensile strength. Metal powders may be pressed into #compacts# using a number of different techniques. #A compact# is a porous solid that is made by pressing a powder.

def.en: A #companion# is someone who you spend time with or who you are travelling with.
def.exmp: Fred had been her constant companion for the last six years of her life. I asked my travelling companion what he thought of the situation in Algeria.

def.en: Something that is #comparable# to something else is roughly similar, for example in amount or importance.
def.exmp: ...paying the same wages to men and women for work of comparable value. Farmers were meant to get an income comparable to that of townspeople. The risk it poses is comparable with smoking just one cigarette every year. ...to assess a number of comparably qualified students. The rises are the result of a comparability study. In other comparable countries real wages increased much more rapidly. By contrast, the comparable figure for the Netherlands is 16 per cent. Published rates are not always directly comparable. The result is a lack of comparability between the accounts of similar companies.

def.en: You use #comparative# to show that you are judging something against a previous or different situation.
def.exmp: ...those who manage to reach the comparative safety of Fendel. The task was accomplished with comparative ease. ...a comparatively small nation. ...children who find it comparatively easy to make and keep friends. ...a comparative study of the dietary practices of people from various regions of India. ...a professor of English and comparative literature. The comparative of 'pretty' is 'prettier'.

def.en: When you make a #comparison#, you consider two or more things and discover the differences between them.
def.exmp: ...a comparison of the British and German economies. Its recommendations are based on detailed comparisons between the public and private sectors. There are no previous statistics for comparison. It is demonstrably an unfair comparison. He finds the comparison of insect wings with a sailing boat useful up to a point. The comparison of her life to a sea voyage simplifies her experience.

def.en: A #compartment# is one of the separate spaces into which a railway carriage is divided.
def.exmp: On the way home we shared our first-class compartment with a group of businessmen. I put a bottle of champagne in the freezer compartment. ...the secret compartment of my jewel box.

def.en: #Compassion# is a feeling of pity, sympathy, and understanding for someone who is suffering.
def.exmp: Elderly people need time and compassion from their physicians.

def.en: If things, for example systems, ideas, and beliefs, are #compatible#, they work well together or can exist together successfully.
def.exmp: Free enterprise, he argued, was compatible with Russian values and traditions. Marriage and the life I live just don't seem compatible. National courts can freeze any law while its compatibility with European legislation is being tested. Mildred and I are very compatible. She's interested in the things that interest me. In a large city you're almost certain to find a physician with whom you are compatible and feel comfortable. As a result of their compatibility, Haig and Fraser were able to bring about wide-ranging reforms.

def.en: If a situation, a rule, or a person #compels# you #to# do something, they force you to do it.
def.exmp: ...the introduction of legislation to compel cyclists to wear a helmet. Leonie's mother was compelled to take in washing to help support her family. Local housing authorities have been compelled by the housing crisis to make offers of sub-standard accommodation.

def.en: To #compensate# someone #for# money or things that they have lost means to pay them money or give them something to replace that money or those things.
def.exmp: The official promise to compensate people for the price rise clearly hadn't been worked out properly. To ease financial difficulties, farmers could be compensated for their loss of subsidies. The company agreed to keep up high levels of output in order to compensate for supplies lost. She would then feel guilt for her anger and compensate by doing even more for the children. MPs say it is crucial that a system is found to compensate for inflation. The pluses more than compensated for the inconveniences involved in making the trip. People who sense that they are inferior have to compensate, and often over-compensate by way of outward achievement. No supportive words could ever compensate for the pain of being separated from her children for 10 years.

def.en: #Compensation# is money that someone who has experienced loss or suffering claims from the person or organization responsible, or from the state.
def.exmp: He received one year's salary as compensation for loss of office. There should be compensation for British farmers hit by the slump in demand. The Court ordered Dr Williams to pay £300 compensation and £100 costs after admitting assault. Helen gained some compensation for her earlier defeat by winning the final open class. Despite a reduction in earnings there are compensations in moving to the north-east where the quality of life is excellent. The toy glider she left him as a Christmas present was no compensation for her absence.

def.en: # Compensation# is money that someone who has experienced inconvenience, loss, or suffering claims from the person or organization responsible, or from the state.
def.exmp: He has to pay $6,960 #compensation# for the damage he caused. The basic award is calculated in the same way as redundancy #compensation# on each full year of service in various brackets. #Compensation# is money that someone who has experienced inconvenience, loss, or suffering claims from the person or organization responsible, or from the state.

def.en: If one thing #complements# another, it goes well with the other thing and makes its good qualities more noticeable.
def.exmp: Nutmeg, parsley and cider all complement the flavour of these beans well. There will be a written examination to complement the practical test. We complement one another perfectly. The green wallpaper is the perfect complement to the old pine of the dresser. Political knowledge is a necessary complement to science in approaching solutions to these problems. Each ship had a complement of around a dozen officers and 250 men. Not one house on the Close still had its full complement of windows.

def.en: A #complication# is a problem or difficulty that makes a situation harder to deal with.
def.exmp: The age difference was a complication to the relationship. An added complication is the growing concern for the environment. Blindness is a common complication of diabetes. He died of complications from a heart attack.

def.en: A #compliment# is a polite remark that you say to someone to show that you like their appearance, appreciate their qualities, or approve of what they have done.
def.exmp: You can do no harm by paying a woman compliments. 'Well done, Cassandra,' Crook said. She blushed, but accepted the compliment with good grace. They complimented me on the way I looked each time they saw me. Firstly I compliment you on most of your excellent Spring issue of 'Triangle'. We consider it a compliment to be called 'conservative'. It's obvious he's worried about us and I'm taking it as a compliment. My compliments to the chef. Give my compliments to your lovely wife when you write home.

def.en: If someone or something #complies# #with# an order or set of rules, they are in accordance with what is required or expected.
def.exmp: The commander said that the army would comply with the ceasefire. Some beaches had failed to comply with European directives on bathing water. There are calls for his resignation, but there is no sign yet that he will comply.

def.en: The #components# of something are the parts that it is made of.
def.exmp: Enriched uranium is a key component of a nuclear weapon. The management plan has four main components. They were automotive component suppliers to motor manufacturers. Gorbachev failed to keep the component parts of the Soviet Union together. Polish workers will now be making component parts for Boeing 757s.

def.en: The things that something #is composed# #of# are its parts or members.
def.exmp: The force would be composed of troops from NATO countries. Protein molecules compose all the complex working parts of living cells. They agreed to form a council composed of leaders of the rival factions. Vivaldi composed a large number of very fine concertos. Cale also uses electronic keyboards to compose. He started at once to compose a reply to Anna. The document composed in Philadelphia transformed the confederation of sovereign states into a national government. Anthony dismounted with his camera and walked away from the walls to compose a shot. The drawing is beautifully composed. She quickly composed herself as the car started off. Then he composed his features, took Godwin's hand awkwardly and began to usher him from the office.

def.en: A #composite# object or item is made up of several different things, parts, or substances.
def.exmp: Galton devised a method of creating composite pictures in which the features of different faces were superimposed over one another. Spain is a composite of diverse traditions and people.

def.en: A # composite# is a mixture of two materials, one of which makes the other stronger.
def.exmp: The commonest #composites# in current use are plastics, reinforced by glass or carbon fibers. Fiber-reinforced plastic is #a composite# made of a polymer matrix reinforced with fibers. #A composite# is a mixture of two materials, one of which makes the other stronger.

def.en: When you talk about the #composition# of something, you are referring to the way in which its various parts are put together and arranged.
def.exmp: Television has transformed the size and social composition of the audience at great sporting occasions. Forests vary greatly in composition from one part of the country to another. Mozart's compositions are undoubtedly amongst the world's greatest. He taught the piano, organ and composition. The course is designed to help students with colour and composition. These plays are arranged in their order of composition.

def.en: A #compound# is an enclosed area of land that is used for a particular purpose.
def.exmp: Police fired on them as they fled into the embassy compound. ...a military compound. Organic compounds contain carbon in their molecules. Honey is basically a compound of water, two types of sugar, vitamins and enzymes. ...a tall shrub with shiny compound leaves. ...the compound microscope. Additional bloodshed and loss of life will only compound the tragedy. The problem is compounded by the medical system here.

def.en: A # compound# is a mixture of substances producing another substance.
def.exmp: Fluorocarbons are #compounds# consisting of fluorine and carbon. Set up a reaction of iron and sulfur to form a chemical #compound#. A #compound# is a mixture of substances producing another substance.

def.en: Something that is #comprehensive# includes everything that is needed or relevant.
def.exmp: The Rough Guide to Nepal is a comprehensive guide to the region. ...Birmingham's inner-city comprehensives. She taught French at Cheam Comprehensive in South London. He left comprehensive school at the age of 16. ...Rushcliffe Comprehensive School.

def.en: A # comprehensive# motor insurance policy provides protection against most risks, including third-party liability, fire, theft, and damage.
When you #compress# something or when it #compresses#, it is pressed or squeezed so that it takes up less space.
def.exmp: Poor posture, sitting or walking slouched over, compresses the body's organs. Air will compress but the brake fluid won't. The compression of the wood is easily achieved. He never understood how to organize or compress large masses of material. All those three books are compacted and compressed into one book. The four debates will be compressed into an unprecedentedly short eight-day period. Some courses such as engineering had to be compressed. Sore throats may be relieved by cold compresses.

def.en: A # compress# is a soft pad of gauze or other material applied with pressure to a part of the body to control hemorrhage or to supply heat, cold, moisture, or medication to alleviate pain or reduce infection.
def.exmp: Hold a #compress# on the cut to stop the bleeding. Apply a cold #compress# to the bite to reduce the pain and swelling. A #compress# is a soft pad of gauze or other material applied with pressure to a part of the body to control hemorrhage or to supply heat, cold, moisture, or medication to alleviate pain or reduce infection.

def.en: If you say that something #comprises# or #is comprised of# a number of things or people, you mean it has them as its parts or members.
def.exmp: The special cabinet committee comprises Mr Brown, Mr Mandelson, and Mr Straw. The exhibition comprises 50 oils and watercolours. The task force is comprised of congressional leaders, cabinet heads and administration officials. A crowd comprised of the wives and children of scientists staged a demonstration. ...the multitude of ideas, ambitions and regrets that comprises the culture of Russia today. Women comprise 44% of hospital medical staff.

def.en: A #compromise# is a situation in which people accept something slightly different from what they really want, because of circumstances or because they are considering the wishes of other people.
def.exmp: Encourage your child to reach a compromise between what he wants and what you want. Be ready and willing to make compromises between your needs and those of your partner. The government's policy of compromise is not universally popular. The government has compromised with its critics over monetary policies. 'Nine,' said I. 'Nine thirty,' tried he. We compromised on 9.15. Israel had originally wanted $1 billion in aid, but compromised on the $650 million. ...members of the government who have compromised themselves by co-operating with the emergency committee. He would rather shoot himself than compromise his principles.

def.en: If something is #compulsory#, you must do it or accept it, because it is the law or because someone in a position of authority says you must.
def.exmp: In East Germany learning Russian was compulsory. Many young men are trying to get away from compulsory military conscription. Five of the company's senior managers have been made compulsorily redundant.

def.en: Your #comrades# are your friends, especially friends that you share a difficult or dangerous situation with.
def.exmp: Unlike so many of his comrades he survived the war. The Party's authority, comrades, will be put to a serious test.

def.en: If you #conceal# something, you cover it or hide it carefully.
def.exmp: Frances decided to conceal the machine behind a hinged panel. Five people were arrested for carrying concealed weapons. Robert could not conceal his relief. She knew at once that he was concealing something from her. ...a pair of carved Indian doors which conceal a built-in cupboard. The hat concealed her hair.

def.en: If you #concede# something, you admit, often unwillingly, that it is true or correct.
def.exmp: Bess finally conceded that Nancy was right. 'Well,' he conceded, 'I do sometimes mumble a bit.' Mr. Chapman conceded the need for Nomura's U.S. unit to improve its trading skills. The government conceded the right to establish independent trade unions. Facing total defeat in Vietnam, the French subsequently conceded full independence to Laos. A strike by some ten thousand bank employees has ended after the government conceded some of their demands. They conceded four goals to Leeds United. Luton conceded a free kick on the edge of the penalty area. Reiner, 56, has all but conceded the race to his rival. Alain Prost finished third and virtually conceded the world championship. Airtours conceded defeat in its attempt to take control of holiday industry rival Owners Abroad. He happily conceded the election.

def.en: If you cannot #conceive# #of# something, you cannot imagine it or believe it.
def.exmp: I just can't even conceive of that quantity of money. He was immensely ambitious but unable to conceive of winning power for himself. The ancients conceived the Earth as afloat in water. We conceive of the family as being in a constant state of change. Elvis conceived of himself as a ballad singer. She had conceived the idea of a series of novels. He conceived of the first truly portable computer in 1968. Women, he says, should give up alcohol before they plan to conceive. About one in six couples has difficulty conceiving. A mother who already has non-identical twins is more likely to conceive another set of twins.

def.en: #Concern# is worry about a situation.
def.exmp: The group has expressed concern about reports of political violence in Africa. The move follows growing public concern over the spread of the disease. As the militants gather, there is concern that the protest might again run out of control. There is no cause for concern. The growing number of people seeking refuge in Thailand is beginning to concern Western aid agencies. It concerned her that Bess was developing a crush on Max. I've been concerned about you lately. We're naturally concerned for our daughter's safety. Academics and employers are deeply concerned that students are not sufficiently prepared mathematically for university courses. ...a phone call from a concerned neighbor. His concern was that people would know that he was responsible. Unemployment was the electorate's main concern. ...a story that illustrates how dangerous excessive concern with safety can be. Feminism must address issues beyond the concerns of middle-class whites. Without her care and concern, he had no chance at all. He had only gone along out of concern for his two grandsons. I didn't concern myself with politics. He would concern himself solely with the plight of the hostages. The agency is more concerned with making arty ads than understanding its clients' businesses. The bulk of the book concerns Sandy's two middle-aged children. Chapter 2 concerns itself with the methodological difficulties. Randolph's work was exclusively concerned with the effects of pollution on health. It was just a little unfinished business from my past, and it doesn't concern you at all. It's a very stressful situation for everyone concerned. I believe he was concerned in all those matters you mention. The technical aspects were the concern of the Army. I would be glad to get rid of them myself. But that is not our concern. If not a large concern, Queensbury Nursery was at least a successful one.

def.en: You use #concerning# to indicate what a question or piece of information is about.
def.exmp: For more information concerning the club contact I. Coldwell. ...various questions concerning pollution and the environment. It is particularly concerning that he is working for non-British companies while advising on foreign policy.

def.en: A #concert# is a performance of music.
def.exmp: ...a short concert of piano music. I've been to plenty of live rock concerts. ...a new concert hall.

def.en: If you make a #concession# #to# someone, you agree to let them do or have something, especially in order to end an argument or conflict.
def.exmp: The King made major concessions to end the confrontation with his people. The government has granted concessions to three private telephone companies. ...tax concessions for mothers who stay at home with their children. Open daily; admission £1.10 with concessions for children and OAPs.

def.en: An individual or business operating a # concession# within another business's premises has been granted a license to run a subsidiary business on those premises.
def.exmp: A local butcher operates a #concession# in the large general food store. The company won the #concession# for 7 new stores at the airport. An individual or business operating a #concession# within another business's premises has been granted a license to run a subsidiary business on those premises.

def.en: In a department store, a # concession# is a business with a license or contract to operate another business within the store.
def.exmp: The company is an established #concession# in a busy mid-market ladies fashion retailer at the local mall. The retailer has 26 stores, #concessions# in 15 department stores and a presence in 8 stores through other partnerships. In a department store, a #concession# is a business with a license or contract to operate another business within the store.

def.en: Something that is #concise# says everything that is necessary without using any unnecessary words.
def.exmp: Burton's text is concise and informative. Whatever you are writing make sure you are clear, concise, and accurate. He'd delivered his report clearly and concisely. ...Sotheby's Concise Encyclopedia of Porcelain.

def.en: If you #condemn# something, you say that it is very bad and unacceptable.
def.exmp: Political leaders united yesterday to condemn the latest wave of violence. Graham was right to condemn his players for lack of ability, attitude and application. ...a document that condemns sexism as a moral and social evil. He was condemned to life imprisonment. ...appeals by prisoners condemned to death. Their lack of qualifications condemned them to a lifetime of boring, usually poorly-paid work. He felt condemned to being alone. Mark was condemned to do most of the work. State officials said the court's ruling clears the way for proceedings to condemn buildings in the area.

def.en: If you #condense# something, especially a piece of writing or speech, you make it shorter, usually by including only the most important parts.
def.exmp: We have learnt how to condense serious messages into short, self-contained sentences. The English translation may have been condensed into a single more readable book. Water vapour condenses to form clouds. The compressed gas is cooled and condenses into a liquid. As the air rises it becomes colder and moisture condenses out of it.

def.en: When you #conduct# an activity or task, you organize it and carry it out.
def.exmp: I decided to conduct an experiment. He said they were conducting a campaign against democrats across the country. The council conducted a survey of the uses to which farm buildings are put. Also up for discussion will be the conduct of free and fair elections. The Conservative Party did not in the main disagree with Bevin's conduct of foreign policy. The way he conducts himself reflects on the party and will increase criticisms against him. Most people believe they conduct their private and public lives in accordance with Christian morality. For Europeans, the law is a statement of basic principles of civilised conduct. He has trouble understanding that other people judge him by his conduct. Dennis had recently begun a successful career conducting opera in Europe. Solti will continue to conduct here and abroad. At the Curtis Institute he studied conducting with Fritz Reiner. Water conducts heat faster than air. He asked if he might conduct us to the ball which was to bring the proceedings to an end.

def.en: A #conductor# is a person who stands in front of an orchestra or choir and directs its performance.
A # conductor# is the first casing string that is put into a well.
def.exmp: The well is begun by setting the first casing string, known as the #conductor#, to a depth depending on soil conditions. The #conductor# is the first string that is cemented to the top and is equipped with the casing head and blowout prevention equipment. A #conductor# is the first casing string that is put into a well.

def.en: A # conductor# is a wire, cable, rod, tube, or bus bar designed for electrical current to pass.
def.exmp: When a direct current supply is connected to the #conductor#, it is seen to move. When we get shocked we are usually in contact with the ground, an appliance or fixture, or something else that makes a good return #conductor#. #A conductor# is a wire, cable, rod, tube, or bus bar designed for electrical current to pass.

def.en: When you #confer# #with# someone, you discuss something with them in order to make a decision.
def.exmp: He conferred with Hill and the others in his office. His doctors conferred by telephone and agreed that he must get away from his family for a time. The constitution also confers large powers on Brazil's 25 constituent states. An honorary doctorate of law was conferred on him by Newcastle University in 1976. Never imagine that rank confers genuine authority.

def.en: A #conference# is a meeting, often lasting a few days, which is organized on a particular subject or to bring together people who have a common interest.
