def.exmp: The President summoned all the state governors to a conference on education. ...the Conservative Party conference. Last weekend the Roman Catholic Church in Scotland held a conference, attended by 450 delegates. They sat down at the dinner table, as they always did, before the meal, for a conference. Her employer was in conference with two lawyers and did not want to be interrupted.

def.en: If someone #confesses# to doing something wrong, they admit that they did it.
def.exmp: He had confessed to seventeen murders. Her husband confessed to having had an affair. I had expected her to confess that she only wrote these books for the money. Most rape victims confess a feeling of helplessness. Ray changed his mind, claiming that he had been forced into confessing. 'I played a very bad match,' he confessed. You just go to the church and confess your sins. Once we have confessed our failures and mistakes to God, we should stop feeling guilty.

def.en: If you have #confidence# #in# someone, you feel that you can trust them.
def.exmp: I have every confidence in you. This has contributed to the lack of confidence in the police. His record on ceasefires inspires no confidence. The band is on excellent form and brimming with confidence. I always thought the worst of myself and had no confidence whatsoever. I can say with confidence that such rumours were totally groundless. We told you all these things in confidence. Even telling Lois seemed a betrayal of confidence. Gregory shared confidences with Carmen.

def.en: Information that is #confidential# is meant to be kept secret or private.
def.exmp: She accused them of leaking confidential information about her private life. We'll take good care and keep what you've told us strictly confidential, Mr. Lane. People can phone in the knowledge that any information they give will be treated confidentially. ...the confidentiality of the client-solicitor relationship. 'Look,' he said in a confidential tone, 'I want you to know that me and Joey are cops.'. His face suddenly turned solemn, his voice confidential. Nash hadn't raised his voice, still spoke rather softly, confidentially.

def.en: To #confine# something #to# a particular place or group means to prevent it from spreading beyond that place or group.
def.exmp: Health officials have successfully confined the epidemic to the Tabatinga area. The U.S. will soon be taking steps to confine the conflict. He did not confine himself to the one language. Yoko had largely confined her activities to the world of big business. His genius was not confined to the decoration of buildings. The woman will be confined to a mental institution. He announced that the army and police had been confined to barracks. The movie is set entirely within the confines of the abandoned factory. ...the wild grass and weeds that grew in the confines of the grandstand. ...away from the confines of the British class system. I can't stand the confines of this marriage.

def.en: #Conflict# is serious disagreement and argument about something important.
def.exmp: Try to keep any conflict between you and your ex-partner to a minimum. Employees already are in conflict with management over job cuts. The two companies came into conflict. ...the anguish of his own inner conflict. ...talks aimed at ending four decades of conflict. The National Security Council has met to discuss ways of preventing a military conflict. There is a conflict between what they are doing and what you want. Do you feel any conflict of loyalties? The two objectives are in conflict. Personal ethics and professional ethics sometimes conflict. He held firm opinions which usually conflicted with my own. There are conflicting reports about the identity of the hostage. ...three powers with conflicting interests.

def.en: If something #conforms# #to# something such as a law or someone's wishes, it is of the required type or quality.
def.exmp: The Night Rider lamp has been designed to conform to new British Standard safety requirements. The meat market can continue only if it is radically overhauled to conform with strict European standards. Many children who can't or don't conform are often bullied. He did not feel obliged to conform to the rules that applied to ordinary men. We conformed with social and family expectations. I am well aware that we all conform to one stereotype or another. Like most 'peacetime wars' it did not conform to preconceived ideas.

def.en: If you #are confronted# #with# a problem, task, or difficulty, you have to deal with it.
def.exmp: She was confronted with severe money problems. Ministers underestimated the magnitude of the task confronting them. We are learning how to confront death. NATO countries have been forced to confront fundamental moral questions. I was confronted with an array of knobs, levers, and switches. She pushed her way through the mob and confronted him face to face. They don't hesitate to open fire when confronted by police. The candidates confronted each other during a televised debate. She had decided to confront Kathryn with what she had learnt. I could not bring myself to confront him about it. His confronting me forced me to search for the answers.

def.en: #Congress# is the elected group of politicians that is responsible for making the law in the United States.
def.exmp: We want to cooperate with both the administration and Congress.

def.en: A #congress# is a large meeting that is held to discuss ideas and policies.
def.exmp: A lot has changed after the party congress. ...a congress of coal miners.

def.en: A #conjunction# #of# two or more things is the occurrence of them at the same time or place.
def.exmp: ...the conjunction of two events. ...a conjunction of religious and social factors.

def.en: If one country or group of people #conquers# another, they take complete control of their land.
def.exmp: During 1936, Mussolini conquered Abyssinia. Early in the eleventh century the whole of England was again conquered by the Vikings. I was certain that love was quite enough to conquer our differences. He has never conquered his addiction to smoking. ...the first man in history to conquer Everest.

def.en: #Conquest# is the act of conquering a country or group of people.
def.exmp: He had led the conquest of southern Poland in 1939. After the Norman Conquest the forest became a royal hunting preserve. Jerusalem has seen endless conquests and occupations. He had realized that Britain could not have peace unless she returned at least some of her former conquests. Despite his conquests, he remains lonely and isolated. ...men who boast about their sexual conquests to all their friends. Pushkin was a womaniser whose conquests included everyone from prostitutes to princesses. The conquest of inflation has been the Government's overriding economic priority for nearly 15 years. ...the conquest of cancer.

def.en: #Conscience# is doing what you believe is right even though it might be unpopular, difficult, or dangerous.
def.exmp: He refused for reasons of conscience to sign a new law legalising abortion. ...the law on freedom of conscience and religious organizations. I'm so glad he had a pang of conscience. They have shown a ruthless lack of conscience.

def.en: Someone who is #conscientious# is very careful to do their work properly.
def.exmp: We are generally very conscientious about our work. Virginia was still struggling to be a conscientious and dedicated mother. He studied conscientiously and enthusiastically.

def.en: #Consecutive# periods of time or events happen one after the other without interruption.
def.exmp: The Cup was won for the third consecutive year by the Toronto Maple Leafs. Photographs taken at the same time on two consecutive sunny days can be quite different from one another. ...a CD player which plays six CDs consecutively.

def.en: A #consensus# is general agreement among a group of people.
def.exmp: The consensus amongst the world's scientists is that the world is likely to warm up over the next few decades. The question of when the troops should leave would be decided by consensus.

def.en: If you give your #consent# #to# something, you give someone permission to do it.
def.exmp: At approximately 11:30 p.m., Pollard finally gave his consent to the search. Can my child be medically examined without my consent? He finally consented to go. He asked Ginny if she would consent to a small celebration after the christening. I was a little surprised when she consented.

def.en: The #consequences# #of# something are the results or effects of it.
def.exmp: Her lawyer said she understood the consequences of her actions and was prepared to go to jail. An economic crisis may have tremendous consequences for our global security.

def.en: #Consequently# means as a result.
def.exmp: Grandfather Dingsdale had sustained a broken back while working in the mines. Consequently, he spent the rest of his life in a wheelchair. Relations between the two companies had, consequently, never been close.

def.en: #Considerable# means great in amount or degree.
def.exmp: To be without Pearce would be a considerable blow. Doing it properly makes considerable demands on our time. Vets' fees can be considerable, even for routine visits. Children vary considerably in the rate at which they learn these lessons. Their dinner parties had become considerably less formal.

def.en: Someone who is #considerate# pays attention to the needs, wishes, or feelings of other people.
def.exmp: I think he's the most charming, most considerate man I've ever known. I've always understood one should try and be considerate of other people. He treats everyone equally and considerately.

def.en: Something that #consists of# particular things or people is formed from them.
def.exmp: Breakfast consisted of porridge served with butter. Her crew consisted of children from Devon and Cornwall. His work as a consultant consisted in advising foreign companies on the siting of new factories. ...Baudelaire's idea that genius consists in the ability to summon up childhood.

def.en: Someone who is #consistent# always behaves in the same way, has the same attitudes towards people or things, or achieves the same level of success in something.
def.exmp: Becker has never been the most consistent of players anyway. ...his consistent support of free trade. It's something I have consistently denied. Jones and Armstrong maintain a consistently high standard. This result is consistent with the findings of Garnett & Tobin. New goals are not always consistent with the existing policies. These are clear consistent policies which we are putting into place.

def.en: If you #consolidate# something that you have, for example power or success, you strengthen it so that it becomes more effective or secure.
def.exmp: The question is: will the junta consolidate its power by force? Brydon's team-mate Martin Williamson consolidated his lead in the National League when he won the latest round. But change brought about the growth and consolidation of the working class. Even if not total, the Romans' hold was sufficient for them to begin the task of consolidation. Judge Charles Schwartz is giving the state 60 days to disband and consolidate Louisiana's four higher-education boards. IBM, which consolidated some operations last summer, has made clear that it needs to continue to streamline them. This consolidation meant having to reduce the numerical strength of the Army. Further consolidations in the industry could follow.

def.en: If someone or something is #conspicuous#, people can see or notice them very easily.
def.exmp: The most conspicuous way in which the old politics is changing is in the growing use of referendums. You may feel tearful in situations where you feel conspicuous. Britain continues to follow U.S. policy in this and other areas where American policies have most conspicuously failed. Johnston's name was conspicuously absent from the list.

def.en: #Conspiracy# is the secret planning by a group of people to do something illegal.
def.exmp: Seven men, all from Bristol, admitted conspiracy to commit arson. He believes there probably was a conspiracy to kill President Kennedy in 1963. It's all part of a conspiracy to dispense with the town centre all together and move everything out to Meadowhall. There was no evidence to link the brigade to any conspiracy against Mr Bush.

def.en: A #constituent# is someone who lives in a particular constituency, especially someone who is able to vote in an election.
def.exmp: Caffeine is the active constituent of drinks such as tea and coffee. ...a plan to split the company into its constituent parts and sell them separately. ...the leaders of Russia's constituent republics.

def.en: If something #constitutes# a particular thing, it can be regarded as being that thing.
def.exmp: Testing patients without their consent would constitute a professional and legal offence. The vote hardly constitutes a victory. What constitutes abuse? Volunteers constitute more than 95% of The Center's work force. ...the four companies constituting the Aramco partnership. On 6 July a People's Revolutionary Government was constituted. The accused will appear before a specially-constituted military tribunal.

def.en: The #constitution# of a country or organization is the system of laws which formally states people's rights and duties.
def.exmp: The king was forced to adopt a new constitution which reduced his powers. ...the American Constitution. The club's constitution prevented women from becoming full members. He must have an extremely strong constitution. I've always had the constitution of an ox.

def.en: To #constrain# someone or something means to limit their development or force them to behave in a particular way.
def.exmp: Women are too often constrained by family commitments and by low expectations. How can we produce top-class engineers when universities are constrained to offer salaries that can only attract mediocre staff? It's the capacity of those roads which is going to constrain the amount of travel by car that can take place. These will be very constrained budgets designed to get the deficit down.

def.en: If you #consume# something, you eat or drink it.
def.exmp: Many people experienced a drop in their cholesterol levels when they consumed oat bran. ...serving chocolate ice-creams for the children to consume in the kitchen. Some of the most efficient refrigerators consume 70 percent less electricity than traditional models. ...plans which will consume hours of time and deplete your cash reserves. ...oil-consuming countries. It is very space-consuming. ...the fire which consumed the dwelling. The memories consumed him.

def.en: The #consumption# of fuel or natural resources is the amount of them that is used or the act of using them.
def.exmp: The laws have led to a reduction in fuel consumption in the U.S.. ...a tax on the consumption of non-renewable energy resources. Most of the wine was unfit for human consumption. The average daily consumption of fruit and vegetables is around 200 grams. Excessive alcohol consumption is clearly bad. Recycling the waste from our increased consumption is better than burning it. The production and consumption of goods and services is the ultimate aim of all economic endeavour.

def.en: A #container# is something such as a box or bottle that is used to hold or store things in.
def.exmp: ...the plastic containers in which fish are stored and sold. ...stainless steel or glass containers.

def.en: If something #is contaminated# #by# dirt, chemicals, or radiation, they make it dirty or harmful.
def.exmp: Have any fish been contaminated in the Arctic Ocean? ...vast tracts of empty land, much of it contaminated by years of army activity. Nuclear weapons plants across the country are heavily contaminated with toxic wastes. More than 100,000 people could fall ill after drinking contaminated water. The contamination of the sea around Capri may be just the beginning.

def.en: If you #contemplate# an action, you think about whether to do it or not.
def.exmp: For a time he contemplated a career as an army medical doctor. She contemplates leaving for the sake of the kids. As he lay in his hospital bed that night, he cried as he contemplated his future. That makes it difficult to contemplate the idea that the present policy may not be sustainable. It is a place of quiet contemplation. He contemplated his hands, still frowning. He was lost in the contemplation of the landscape for a while.

def.en: #Contemporary# things are modern and relate to the present time.
def.exmp: She writes a lot of contemporary music for people like Whitney Houston. Perhaps he should have a more updated look, a more contemporary style. Only the names are ancient; the characters are modern and contemporary. ...drawing upon official records and the reports of contemporary witnesses. Like most of my contemporaries, I grew up in a vastly different world. ...a glossary of musical terms found in Shakespeare and his contemporaries.

def.en: If you have #contempt# #for# someone or something, you have no respect for them or think that they are unimportant.
def.exmp: He has contempt for those beyond his immediate family circle. I hope voters will treat his advice with the contempt it deserves. Mr. Kelly was sentenced to six months in prison for contempt.

def.en: If you have to #contend with# a problem or difficulty, you have to deal with it or overcome it.
def.exmp: It is time, once again, to contend with racism. American businesses could soon have a new kind of lawsuit to contend with. The government contends that he is fundamentalist. 'You were just looking,' contends Samantha. 'I was the one doing all the work.' ...the two main groups contending for power. ...with 10 U.K. construction yards contending with rivals from Norway, Holland, Italy and Spain. ...a binding political settlement between the contending parties.

def.en: A #continent# is a very large area of land, such as Africa or Asia, that consists of several countries.
def.exmp: She loved the African continent. Dinosaurs evolved when most continents were joined in a single land mass. Its shops are among the most stylish on the Continent.

def.en: A #contract# is a legal agreement, usually between two companies or between an employer and employee, which involves doing work for a stated sum of money.
def.exmp: The company won a prestigious contract for work on Europe's tallest building. He was given a seven-year contract with an annual salary of $150,000. You can contract with us to deliver your cargo. The Boston Museum of Fine Arts has already contracted to lease part of its collection to a museum in Japan. Blood is only expelled from the heart when it contracts. New research shows that an excess of meat and salt can contract muscles. ...the contraction and expansion of blood vessels. Foods and fluids are mixed in the stomach by its muscular contractions. The manufacturing economy contracted in October for the sixth consecutive month. He contracted AIDS from a blood transfusion. Ovarian cancer is the sixth most common cancer contracted by women. She contracted a formal marriage to a British ex-serviceman. The convictions resulted in the local crime bosses putting a contract on him. The police advised her to get out of town because there was a contract on her life.

def.en: A # contract# is an official agreement between two or more companies or people, in which each party has rights and obligations.
def.exmp: They recently signed #a contract# with a major food company to supply a billion aluminum food cans. Producers are refusing to sign long-term #contracts# because they expect higher prices. A #contract# is an official agreement between two or more companies or people, in which each party has rights and obligations.

def.en: If you #contradict# someone, you say that what they have just said is wrong, or suggest that it is wrong by saying something different.
def.exmp: She dared not contradict him. His comments appeared to contradict remarks made earlier in the day by the chairman. He often talks in circles, frequently contradicting himself and often ends up saying nothing. Her version contradicted the Government's claim that they were shot after being challenged. The result seems to contradict a major U.S. study reported last November. Mr Grant feels that the cut-backs contradict the Government's commitment to better educational standards.

def.en: If you describe an aspect of a situation as a #contradiction#, you mean that it is completely different from other aspects, and so makes the situation confused or difficult to understand.
def.exmp: ...the contradictions between her private life and the public persona. The performance seemed to me unpardonable, a contradiction of all that the Olympics is supposed to be. The militants see no contradiction in using violence to bring about a religious state.

def.en: A #contrast# is a great difference between two or more things which is clear when you compare them.
def.exmp: ...the contrast between town and country. The two visitors provided a startling contrast in appearance. Silk was used with wool for contrast. The boy's room is a complete contrast to the guest room. ...a country of great contrasts. She contrasted the situation then with the present crisis. Contrast that approach with what goes on in most organizations. In this section we contrast four possible broad approaches. Johnson's easy charm contrasted sharply with the prickliness of his boss. Paint the wall in a contrasting colour. ...a television with brighter colours, better contrast, and digital sound.

def.en: If you #contrive# an event or situation, you succeed in making it happen, often by tricking someone.
def.exmp: The oil companies were accused of contriving a shortage of gasoline to justify price increases. We therefore had to contrive a very large black-out curtain. The orchestra contrived to produce some of its best playing for years. They somehow contrived to lose tens of thousands of applications.

def.en: If you describe something or someone as #controversial#, you mean that they are the subject of intense public argument, disagreement, or disapproval.
def.exmp: Immigration is a controversial issue in many countries. ...Morton's controversial book, 'Diana, Her True Story.'. The changes are bound to be controversial. ...the controversial 19th century politician Charles Parnell. More controversially, he claims that these higher profits cover the cost of finding fresh talent. David Hirst was controversially sent off on his European debut for Sheffield Wednesday last night.

def.en: #Controversy# is a lot of discussion and argument about something, often involving strong feelings of anger or disapproval.
def.exmp: The proposed cuts have caused considerable controversy. ...a fierce political controversy over human rights abuses.

def.en: A #convention# is a way of behaving that is considered to be correct or polite by most people in a society.
def.exmp: It's just a social convention that men don't wear skirts. Despite her wish to defy convention, she had become pregnant and married at 21. We go offstage and come back for the convention of the encore. ...the stylistic conventions of Egyptian art. ...the U.N. convention on climate change. ...the Geneva convention. ...the annual convention of the Society of Professional Journalists. ...the Republican convention.

def.en: Someone who is #conventional# has behaviour or opinions that are ordinary and normal.
def.exmp: ...a respectable married woman with conventional opinions. People still wore their hair short and dressed conventionally. ...the risks and drawbacks of conventional family planning methods. These discs hold more than 400 times as much information as a conventional computer floppy disk. Organically-grown produce does not differ greatly in appearance from conventionally-grown crops. We must reduce the danger of war by controlling nuclear, chemical and conventional arms.

def.en: You say #conversely# to indicate that the situation you are about to describe is the opposite or reverse of the one you have just described.
def.exmp: In real life, nobody was all bad, nor, conversely, all good.

def.en: #Conversion# is the act or process of changing something into a different state or form.
def.exmp: ...the conversion of disused rail lines into cycle routes. A loft conversion can add considerably to the value of a house. ...his conversion to Christianity. It's hard to trust the President's conversion.

def.en: In a refinery, # conversion# is cracking and rearranging the molecules in crude oil.
def.exmp: Catalytic cracking is similar to thermal cracking except that catalysts facilitate the #conversion# of the heavier molecules into lighter products. Cracking is #a conversion# method which is used to convert heavier, lower value hydrocarbons into lighter, higher value ones. In a refinery, #conversion# is cracking and rearranging the molecules in crude oil.

def.en: To #convey# information or feelings means to cause them to be known or understood by someone.
def.exmp: When I returned home, I tried to convey the wonder of this machine to my husband. In every one of her pictures she conveys a sense of immediacy. He also conveyed his views and the views of the bureaucracy. The railway company extended a branch line to Brightlingsea to convey fish direct to Billingsgate.

def.en: If someone #is convicted# #of# a crime, they are found guilty of that crime in a law court.
def.exmp: In 1977 he was convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment. There was insufficient evidence to convict him. ...a convicted drug dealer.

def.en: A #conviction# is a strong belief or opinion.
def.exmp: It is our firm conviction that a step forward has been taken. Their religious convictions prevented them from taking up arms. 'We shall, sir,' said Thorne, with conviction. He will appeal against his conviction. The man was known to the police because of previous convictions.

def.en: A #cop# is a policeman or policewoman.
def.exmp: Frank didn't like having the cops know where to find him.

def.en: If you #cope# #with# a problem or task, you deal with it successfully.
def.exmp: It was amazing how my mother coped with bringing up three children on less than three pounds a week. The problems were an annoyance, but we managed to cope. Never before has the industry had to cope with war and recession at the same time. She has had to cope with losing all her previous status and money. New blades have been designed to cope with the effects of dead insects. The country's prisons are filled with drug-takers, and cannot cope with the numbers. The speed of economic change has been so great that the tax-collecting system has been unable to cope.

def.en: #Copper# is reddish-brown metal that is used to make things such as coins and electrical wires.
def.exmp: Chile is the world's largest producer of copper. ...a copper mine. His hair has reverted back to its original copper hue. ...your friendly neighbourhood copper.

def.en: #Cord# is strong, thick string.
def.exmp: The door had been tied shut with a length of nylon cord. ...gilded cords and tassels. ...electrical cord. We used so many lights that we needed four extension cords. He had bare feet, a T-shirt and cords on. ...a pair of cord trousers.

def.en: #Cordial# means friendly.
def.exmp: He had never known him to be so chatty and cordial. He said the two countries had close and cordial relations. They all greeted me very cordially and were eager to talk about the new project. Egypt wants to solve the problem in an atmosphere of cordiality. ...fruit cordials.

def.en: #Corn# is used to refer to crops such as wheat and barley.
def.exmp: ...fields of corn. He filled the barn to the roof with corn. ...rows of corn in an Iowa field.

def.en: If one thing #correlates# #with# another, there is a close similarity or connection between them, often because one thing causes the other.
def.exmp: Obesity correlates with increased risk for hypertension and stroke. The political opinions of spouses correlate more closely than their heights. The loss of respect for British science is correlated to reduced funding. At the highest executive levels earnings and performance aren't always correlated. Attempts to correlate specific language functions with particular parts of the brain have not advanced very far. Lieutenant Ryan closed his eyes, first mentally viewing the different crime scenes, then correlating the data.

def.en: If one thing #corresponds# #to# another, there is a close similarity or connection between them.
def.exmp: Racegoers will be given a number which will correspond to a horse running in a race. A 22 per cent increase in car travel corresponds with a 19 per cent drop in cycle mileage per person. The two maps of London correspond closely. Her expression is concerned but her body-language does not correspond. March and April sales this year were up 8 per cent on the corresponding period in 1992. ...the inexorable rise in Britain's fortunes and the corresponding decline of France as an international power. She still corresponds with American friends she met in Majorca nine years ago. We corresponded regularly.

def.en: #Correspondence# is the act of writing letters to someone.
def.exmp: The judges' decision is final and no correspondence will be entered into. His interest in writing came from a long correspondence with a close college friend. He always replied to his correspondence. She virtually never mentions him in her correspondence or notebooks. In African languages there is a close correspondence between sounds and letters. ...correspondences between Eastern religions and Christianity.

def.en: A #correspondent# is a newspaper or television journalist, especially one who specializes in a particular type of news.
def.exmp: ...our Diplomatic Correspondent, Mark Brayne.

def.en: A #corridor# is a long passage in a building or train, with doors and rooms on one or both sides.
def.exmp: East Prussia and the rest of Germany were separated, in 1919, by the Polish Corridor.

def.en: A # corridor# is a long passage in a building, with doors and rooms on one or both sides.
def.exmp: There are doors on both sides of the #corridor#. I ran down the #corridor# towards the elevator. The restaurant is at the end of the #corridor# on the right.

def.en: If metal or stone #corrodes#, or #is corroded#, it is gradually destroyed by a chemical or by rust.
def.exmp: He has devised a process for making gold wires which neither corrode nor oxidise. Engineers found the structure had been corroded by moisture. Acid rain destroys trees and corrodes buildings. The investigators found that the underground pipes were badly corroded. Suffering was easier to bear than the bitterness he felt corroding his spirit. He warns that corruption is corroding Russia.

def.en: Someone who is #corrupt# behaves in a way that is morally wrong, especially by doing dishonest or illegal things in return for money or power.
def.exmp: ...to save the nation from corrupt politicians of both parties. ...corrupt police officers. He had accused three opposition members of corrupt practices. ...several government officials charged with acting corruptly. It is sad to see a man so corrupted by the desire for money and power. ...warning that television will corrupt us all. Cruelty depraves and corrupts. Some of the finer type-faces are corrupted by cheap, popular computer printers. They can ensure that traditional cuisines are not totally corrupted by commercial practices. ...corrupted data.

def.en: #Cosmic# means occurring in, or coming from, the part of space that lies outside Earth and its atmosphere.
def.exmp: ...cosmic radiation. ...cosmic debris. ...the cosmic laws governing our world. ...humanity's place in the cosmic order of things.

def.en: If you say that something is #costly#, you mean that it costs a lot of money, often more than you would want to pay.
def.exmp: Having professionally-made curtains can be costly, so why not make your own? Psychometric tests can save organizations from grim and costly mistakes. This sort of scandal in international banking has been politically costly.

def.en: An actor's or performer's #costume# is the set of clothes they wear while they are performing.
def.exmp: Even from a distance the effect of his fox costume was stunning. The performers, in costume and make-up, were walking up and down backstage. In all, she has eight costume changes. ...men and women in eighteenth-century costume. In the colourful markets at Chincero and Pisac, women still wear their traditional costume. ...a lavish costume drama set in Ireland and the U.S. in the 1890s.

def.en: A house or room that is #cosy# is comfortable and warm.
def.exmp: Downstairs there's a breakfast room and guests can relax in the cosy bar. We took time to relax in the cosily-decorated drawing room. In the evening a log fire would provide cosiness. They like to make sure their guests are comfortable and cosy. He was settled cosily in the corner with an arm round Lynda. ...a cosy chat between friends. My mood this year is for a cosy, nice and thoroughly wholesome Christmas. ...chatting cosily with friends over coffee. ...the cosiness and solidity of family life.

def.en: A #cottage# is a small house, usually in the country.
def.exmp: They used to have a cottage in N.W. Scotland. My sister Yvonne also came to live at Ockenden Cottage with me.

def.en: #Cotton# is a type of cloth made from soft fibres from a particular plant.
def.exmp: ...a cotton shirt. ...a large cotton plantation in Tennessee. There's a needle and cotton there.

def.en: A #couch# is a long, comfortable seat for two or three people.
def.exmp: The new centre-right government's radical objectives are often couched in moderate terms. This time the proposal was couched as an ultimatum.

def.en: A #council# is a group of people who are elected to govern a local area such as a city or, in Britain, a county.
def.exmp: ...Cheshire County Council. The city council has voted almost unanimously in favour. ...David Ward, one of just two Liberal Democrats on the council. ...reports of local council meetings. There is a shortage of council housing. Council tenants around the country are planning a mass lobby of Parliament. ...the National Council for Civil Liberties. ...the Arts Council. ...community health councils. The permanent council of the Organization of American States meets today here in Washington. ...the Bundesbank's central council. President Najibullah said he would call a grand council of all Afghans. The president also meets ministers at inter-ministerial councils held at the Elysée Palace.

def.en: #Counsel# is advice.
def.exmp: He had always been able to count on her wise counsel. His parishioners sought his counsel and loved him. My advisers counselled me to do nothing. The prime minister was right to counsel caution about military intervention. ...a psychologist who counsels people with eating disorders. Crawford counsels her on all aspects of her career. Singleton's counsel said after the trial that he would appeal. The defence counsel warned that the judge should stop the trial.

def.en: In a place such as a shop or café, a #counter# is a long narrow table or flat surface at which customers are served.
def.exmp: ...those fellows we see working behind the counter at our local video rental store. ...the cosmetics counter. We were sitting on stools at the counter having coffee. The leadership discussed a plan of economic measures to counter the effects of such a blockade. Congestion could be countered by persuading more drivers to get on their bikes. Sears then countered by filing an antitrust lawsuit. ...NATO's traditional role as a counter to the military might of the Warsaw pact. Both of them had to counter fierce criticism. The union countered with letters rebutting the company's claims. The Prime Minister countered by stating that he had grave misgivings about the advice he had been given. 'But Peter, it's not that simple,' Goldstone countered in a firm voice. ...an answerphone with an LED display call counter.

def.en: Someone's or something's #counterpart# is another person or thing that has a similar function or position in a different place.
def.exmp: The Foreign Secretary telephoned his Italian counterpart to protest. The Finnish organization was very different from that of its counterparts in the rest of the Nordic region.

def.en: A #county# is a region of Britain, Ireland, or the USA which has its own local government.
def.exmp: He is living now in his mother's home county of Oxfordshire. Over 50 events are planned throughout the county.

def.en: A #coupon# is a piece of printed paper which allows you to pay less money than usual for a product, or to get it free.
def.exmp: Bring the coupon below to any Tecno store and pay just £10.99. ...a 50p money-off coupon. Send the coupon with a cheque for £18.50, made payable to 'Good Housekeeping'. He was filling in his pools coupon.

def.en: A # coupon# is a piece of printed paper which allows you to pay less money than usual for a product, or to get it free.
def.exmp: With the #coupon#, you get an entrée free. Please present this #coupon# at check-in to receive the special rate. Give the discount #coupon# to the waitperson, who will take 10% off your bill.

def.en: #Courtesy# is politeness, respect, and consideration for others.
def.exmp: ...a gentleman who behaves with the utmost courtesy towards ladies. He did not even have the courtesy to reply to my fax. By extending the courtesy of a phone call to my clients, I was building a personal relationship with them. At least if they're arguing, they're doing you the courtesy of being interested. Hugh and John were exchanging faintly barbed courtesies. A courtesy shuttle bus operates between the hotel and the town. ...a courtesy phone. The President paid a courtesy call on Emperor Akihito. Both were accorded the courtesy title of Lady. My title, by courtesy only, is the Honourable Amalia Lovell.

def.en: A #courtyard# is an open area of ground which is surrounded by buildings or walls.
def.exmp: They walked through the arch and into the cobbled courtyard.

def.en: Your #cousin# is the child of your uncle or aunt.
def.exmp: My cousin Mark helped me. We are cousins. Whereas West Germans drink wine, their Eastern cousins prefer Schnapps. The average European kitchen is smaller than its American cousin. ...misanthropy and its cousin racism.

def.en: A #cow# is a large female animal that is kept on farms for its milk.
def.exmp: He kept a few dairy cows. Dad went out to milk the cows. ...a herd of cows. ...a cow elephant. The government, far from being cowed by these threats, has vowed to continue its policy. ...cowing them into submission. By this time she was so cowed by the beatings that she meekly obeyed.

def.en: If you call someone a #coward#, you disapprove of them because they are easily frightened and avoid dangerous or difficult situations.
def.exmp: She accused her husband of being a coward.

def.en: A #crab# is a sea creature with a flat round body covered by a shell, and five pairs of legs with large claws on the front pair.
If something hard #cracks#, or if you #crack# it, it becomes slightly damaged, with lines appearing on its surface.
def.exmp: A gas main had cracked under my neighbour's garage and gas had seeped into our homes. Remove the dish from the oven, crack the salt crust and you will find the skin just peels off the fish. Thunder cracked in the sky. He cracked his fingers nervously. He cracked his head on the pavement and was knocked cold. Crack the eggs into a bowl. He has finally cracked the system after years of painstaking research. She's calm and strong, and she is just not going to crack. I had the conviction Larkin's nerve would crack and he'd squeeze the trigger in a reflex action. Some countries are showing signs of cracking under intense pressure from the United States. Her voice cracked and she began to cry. He cracked jokes and talked about beer and girls.

def.en: A #crack# is a very narrow gap between two things, or between two parts of a thing.
def.exmp: Kathryn had seen him through a crack in the curtains. He went to the door, opened it a crack, and listened. The plate had a crack in it. Hundreds of office buildings and homes developed large cracks in walls and ceilings. Suddenly there was a loud crack and glass flew into the car. 'Crack!'–The first shot rang out, hitting Paolo. I should love to have a crack at the Olympia title in my last year. She decided to head for the dormitory to take another crack at locating Blanche. When Paul made the crack about the 'famous girl detective', I began to suspect that he had it in for you. ...a crack undercover police officer. He is said to be a crack shot, despite weak vision in one eye.

def.en: A # crack# is a long thin hole with sharp ends in a material.
def.exmp: The failure started from #a crack# in one of the welds. To repair #a crack# in the tank you first need to know what caused it to crack. #A crack# is a long thin hole with sharp ends in a material.

def.en: A #cradle# is a baby's bed with high sides.
def.exmp: I dropped the receiver back in the cradle. He fixed the towing cradle round the hull. Mali is the cradle of some of Africa's richest civilizations. ...New York, the cradle of capitalism. I cradled her in my arms. He was sitting at the big table cradling a large bowl of milky coffee.

def.en: You can refer to a boat, a spacecraft, or an aircraft as a #craft#.
def.exmp: With great difficulty, the fisherman manoeuvred his small craft close to the reef. The troops are reported to have advanced nearly four miles since they were landed from naval craft on Sunday evening. ...the arts and crafts of the North American Indians. All kinds of traditional craft industries are preserved here. ...the craft of writing. Maurice Murphy, one of the country's leading classical trumpeters, learnt his craft with the Black Dyke Mills band. The windows would probably have been crafted in the latter part of the Middle Ages. Many delegates were willing to craft a compromise. The author extracts the maximum from every carefully-crafted scene in this witty tale. ...original, hand-crafted bags at affordable prices.

def.en: A #crane# is a large machine that moves heavy things by lifting them in the air.
def.exmp: The little prefabricated hut was lifted away by a huge crane. She craned her neck to get a better view. Children craned to get close to him. She craned forward to look at me.

def.en: When you #crawl#, you move forward on your hands and knees.
def.exmp: Don't worry if your baby seems a little reluctant to crawl or walk. I began to crawl on my hands and knees towards the door. As he tried to crawl away, he was hit in the shoulder. I watched the moth crawl up the outside of the lampshade. I crawled out of bed at nine-thirty. They had not foreseen the higher inflation in France when most of Western Europe was crawling out of recession. Hairpin turns force the car to crawl at 10 miles an hour in some places. The traffic on the approach road slowed to a crawl. This place is crawling with police. ...rock-hard earth littered with rubbish and crawling with vermin.

def.en: #Cream# is a thick yellowish-white liquid taken from milk.
def.exmp: ...strawberries and cream. ...cream of mushroom soup. Gently apply the cream to the affected areas. ...sun protection creams. ...cream silk stockings. ...a cream-coloured Persian cat. The Ball was attended by the cream of Hollywood society. ...the cream of Chicago's 200 jazz and blues clubs.

def.en: A # cream# is a semi-solid substance that you rub into your skin.
def.exmp: Apply a thin layer of antifungal #cream# to the rash until it is absorbed into the skin. Gently rub the medicated #cream# on the irritated areas of the skin. #A cream# is a semi-solid substance that you rub into your skin.

def.en: You can refer to any living thing that is not a plant as a #creature#, especially when it is of an unknown or unfamiliar kind.
def.exmp: Alaskan Eskimos believe that every living creature possesses a spirit. The garden is surrounded by a hedge in which many small creatures can live. They have been visited by creatures from outer space. She's charming, a sweet creature. I am not a vain creature. She was a creature of the emotions, rather than reason. We are not creatures of the Conservative government.

def.en: When people or animals #creep# somewhere, they move quietly and slowly.
def.exmp: Back I go to the hotel and creep up to my room. The rabbit creeps away and hides in a hole. Mist had crept in again from the sea. Insecurity might creep in. An increasing ratio of mistakes, perhaps induced by tiredness, crept into her game. ...a proposal that crept through unnoticed at the National Council in December. Now his other major works are creeping back into concert programmes. Their organisation has been subjected to creeping privatisation since 1981. The inflation rate has been creeping up to 9.5 per cent. The average number of students in each class is creeping up from three to four.

def.en: # Creep# is the tendency of a solid material to move or change shape slightly as a result of stress that continues for some time.
def.exmp: As the stress continues, the extension of the metal caused by #creep# eventually leads to failure. During #creep#, damage accumulates in the form of internal cavities. #Creep# is the tendency of a solid material to move or change shape slightly as a result of stress that continues for some time.

def.en: The #crew# of a ship, an aircraft, or a spacecraft is the people who work on and operate it.
def.exmp: The mission for the crew of the space shuttle Endeavour is essentially over. Despite their size, these vessels carry small crews, usually of around twenty men. The surviving crew members were ferried ashore. ...a two-man film crew making a documentary. A paramedic ambulance crew went to the accident scene but were unable to save Mrs Wilson. She was already a keen and experienced sailor, having crewed in both Merlin and Grayling. There were to be five teams of three crewing the boat. ...a fully-crewed yacht. ...the motley crew of failed and aspiring actors who comprised the 'distinguished guests'. This crew of killers and life-wreckers are headed by the mad but cunning Nino Brown.

def.en: #Cricket# is an outdoor game played between two teams.
def.exmp: During the summer term we would play cricket at the village ground. ...the Yorkshire County Cricket Club.

def.en: A person with a physical disability or a serious permanent injury is sometimes referred to as a #cripple#.
def.exmp: She has gone from being a healthy, fit, and sporty young woman to being a cripple. Mr Easton was seriously crippled in an accident and had to leave his job. He had been warned that another bad fall could cripple him for life. He heaved his crippled leg into an easier position. Howard wanted to be a popular singer, but stage fright crippled him. I'm not perfect but I'm also not emotionally crippled or lonely. Let's try to cripple their communications. A total cut-off of supplies would cripple the country's economy. The pilot was able to maneuver the crippled aircraft out of the hostile area.

def.en: A #crisis# is a situation in which something or someone is affected by one or more very serious problems.
def.exmp: Natural disasters have obviously contributed to the continent's economic crisis. The Italian political system has been judged to be in terminal crisis for decades. ...children's illnesses or other family crises. He's having a mid-life crisis. ...someone to turn to in moments of crisis.

def.en: Food that is #crisp# is pleasantly hard, or has a pleasantly hard surface.
def.exmp: Bake the potatoes for 15 minutes, till they're nice and crisp. ...crisp bacon. ...crisp lettuce. The pizza base retains its crispness without becoming brittle. ...crisply-fried onion rings. Cook the bacon until it begins to crisp. Spread breadcrumbs on a dry baking sheet and crisp them in the oven. ...a packet of crisps. ...cheese and onion potato crisps. ...a crisp autumn day. He wore a panama hat and a crisp white suit. I slipped between the crisp clean sheets. ...crisp banknotes. ...his crisply-pressed suit. ...crisp autumn leaves. He crunched through the crisp snow. 'Very well,' I said, adopting a crisp authoritative tone. 'I'm not a journalist,' said Mary Ann crisply.

def.en: A #criterion# is a factor on which you judge or decide something.
def.exmp: The most important criterion for entry is that applicants must design and make their own work. British defence policy had to meet three criteria if it was to succeed.

def.en: A #crow# is a large black bird which makes a loud, harsh noise.
def.exmp: The cock crows and the dawn chorus begins. Edwards is already crowing about his assured victory. We've seen them all crowing that the movement is dead. She was crowing with delight. 'I'm not sure I've ever driven a better lap,' crowed a delighted Irvine.

def.en: A #cruise# is a holiday during which you travel on a ship or boat and visit a number of places.
def.exmp: He and his wife were planning to go on a world cruise. The next stop on this cruise is likely to be in Cornwall. She wants to cruise the canals of France in a barge. During their summer holidays they cruised further afield to Normandy and Brittany. ...a 51ft cruising yacht. A black and white police car cruised past. Graf looked in awesome form as she cruised to an easy victory. ...gay men cruising on Clapham Common.

def.en: To #crush# something means to press it very hard so that its shape is destroyed or so that it breaks into pieces.
def.exmp: Andrew crushed his empty can. Their vehicle was crushed by an army tank. Peel and crush the garlic. ...crushed ice. The military operation was the first step in a plan to crush the uprising. ...in his bid to crush the rebels. ...the violent crushing of anti-government demonstrations. Listen to criticism but don't be crushed by it. We were at the front, crushed against the stage. Franklin and his thirteen-year-old son somehow got separated in the crush. Everywhere he went he was mobbed by a crush of fans. She had a crush on you, you know. I'd got over my schoolgirl crush.

def.en: The #crust# on a loaf of bread is the outside part.
def.exmp: As the water evaporates, a crust of salt is left on the surface of the soil. Earthquakes leave scars in the Earth's crust.

def.en: A #crystal# is a small piece of a substance that has formed naturally into a regular symmetrical shape.
def.exmp: ...salt crystals. ...ice crystals. ...a single crystal of silicon. ...a strand of crystal beads. Some of the finest drinking glasses are made from lead crystal. ...crystal glasses. ...an immense crystal chandelier. Get out your best china and crystal.

def.en: A # crystal# is a solid that has an atomic or molecular structural unit which is repeated throughout the solid.
def.exmp: Larger #crystals# have a smaller surface area to volume ratio, leading to a higher purity. The external geometry of a #crystal# is a result of the internal regular arrangements of atoms that it is built up from. A #crystal# is a solid that has an atomic or molecular structural unit which is repeated throughout the solid.

def.en: A #cucumber# is a long thin vegetable with a hard green skin and wet transparent flesh.
In the theatre or in a musical performance, a performer's #cue# is something another performer says or does that is a signal for them to begin speaking, playing, or doing something.
def.exmp: The actors not performing sit at the side of the stage in full view, waiting for their cues. I had never known him miss a cue. He read the scene, with Seaton cueing him. That was the cue for several months of intense bargaining. That was Nicholas's cue to ask for another chocolate chip cookie. Their youngest brother was nine when he picked up a cue for the first time.

def.en: If you #cultivate# land or crops, you prepare land and grow crops on it.
def.exmp: She also cultivated a small garden of her own. ...the few patches of cultivated land. ...the cultivation of fruits and vegetables. Farmers with many acres under cultivation profited. He has written eight books and has cultivated the image of an elder statesman. Cultivating a positive mental attitude towards yourself can reap tremendous benefits. ...the cultivation of a positive approach to life and health. Howe carefully cultivated Daniel C. Roper, the Assistant Postmaster General. Estonia has done much to cultivate the friendship of western European countries.

def.en: Someone who is #cunning# has the ability to achieve things in a clever way, often by deceiving other people.
def.exmp: These disturbed kids can be cunning. ...Mr Blair's cunning plan. They were cunningly disguised in golf clothes. ...one more example of the cunning of today's art thieves. He tackled the job with a great deal of imagination, skill and cunning.

def.en: A #cupboard# is a piece of furniture that has one or two doors, usually contains shelves, and is used to store things.
def.exmp: The kitchen cupboard was stocked with tins of soup and food.

def.en: If you #curb# something, you control it and keep it within limits.
def.exmp: ...advertisements aimed at curbing the spread of Aids. Inflation needs to be curbed in Russia. He called for much stricter curbs on immigration. He curbed his temper. You must curb your extravagant tastes.

def.en: If doctors or medical treatments #cure# an illness or injury, they cause it to end or disappear.
def.exmp: An operation finally cured his shin injury. Her cancer can only be controlled, not cured. MDT is an effective treatment and could cure all the leprosy sufferers worldwide. Almost overnight I was cured. Now doctors believe they have cured him of the disease. There is still no cure for a cold. Atkinson has been told rest is the only cure for his ankle injury. Private firms are willing to make large-scale investments to help cure Russia's economic troubles. We need to cure our environmental problems. Punishment can never be an effective cure for acute social problems. The magic cure for inflation does not exist. The experience was a detestable ordeal, and it cured him of any ambitions to direct again. He went to a clinic to cure his drinking and overeating. Legs of pork were cured and smoked over the fire. ...sliced cured ham.

def.en: When a polymer # cures# or you # cure# it, it sets, often with heat or pressure.
If you # cure# a substance, you treat or finish it chemically or physically.
def.exmp: The electron beam process is a suitable way to #cure# the product in this process because the electrons can penetrate the thick release film in order to reach the active ingredients in the coating being irradiated. The textile industry is ready to adopt ionizing irradiation as a technique to finish and #cure# fabrics. If you #cure# a substance, you treat or finish it chemically or physically.

def.en: If you # cure# rubber, you harden it by treating it with sulfur at a high temperature.
If you have #curls#, your hair is in the form of tight curves and spirals.
def.exmp: ...the little girl with blonde curls. A curl of black hair fell loosely across his forehead. Dry curly hair naturally for maximum curl and shine. She has hair that refuses to curl. Maria had curled her hair for the event. Afro hair is short and tightly curled. A thin curl of smoke rose from a rusty stove. ...curls of lemon peel. His fingers curled gently round her wrist. Raise one foot, curl the toes and point the foot downwards. She sat with her legs curled under her. Smoke was curling up the chimney. He curled the ball into the net. He wanted to curl into a tiny ball. The kitten was curled on a cushion on the sofa. In colder weather, your cat will curl up into a tight, heat-conserving ball. She curled up next to him. He was asleep there, curled up in the fetal position. The rose leaves have curled because of an attack by grubs. The corners of the lino were curling up. He curled his upper lip in a show of scepticism. She had a small, mean mouth that curled disapprovingly each time her husband wrote something in his diary.

def.en: The money used in a particular country is referred to as its #currency#.
def.exmp: Tourism is the country's top earner of foreign currency. More people favour a single European currency than oppose it. ...Western currencies. His theory of the social contract had wide currency in America. 'Loop' is one of those computer words that has gained currency in society.

def.en: A #curriculum# is all the different courses of study that are taught in a school, college, or university.
def.exmp: There should be a broader curriculum in schools for post-16-year-old pupils. Russian is the one compulsory foreign language on the school curriculum. ...the history curriculum.

def.en: If you #curse#, you use rude or offensive language, usually because you are angry about something.
def.exmp: I cursed and hobbled to my feet. He shot her an angry look and a curse. Grandma protested, but he cursed her and rudely pushed her aside. He cursed himself for having been so careless. So we set off again, cursing the delay, towards the west. She silently cursed her own stupidity. Maybe there is a curse on my family. He's been the object of a voodoo curse. Apathy is the long-standing curse of British local democracy. Summer colds are a terrible curse.

def.en: #Curtains# are large pieces of material which you hang from the top of a window.
def.exmp: Her bedroom curtains were drawn. The curtain rises toward the end of the Prelude. ...a curtain of cigarette smoke. Something dark disappeared behind the curtain of leaves.

def.en: A #curve# is a smooth, gradually bending line, for example part of the edge of a circle.
def.exmp: ...the curve of his lips. ...a curve in the road. Her spine curved. The track curved away below him. ...a knife with a slightly curving blade. A small, unobtrusive smile curved the cook's thin lips. The ball curved strangely in the air. Each firm will face a downward-sloping demand curve. Was it just a temporary blip on an otherwise healthy growth curve?

def.en: A #cushion# is a fabric case filled with soft material, which you put on a seat to make it more comfortable.
def.exmp: ...a velvet cushion. The company provides a styrofoam cushion to protect the tablets during shipping. The steering wheel has an energy absorbing rim to cushion the driver's head in the worst impacts. The suspension is designed to cushion passengers from the effects of riding over rough roads. They said Western aid was needed to cushion the blows of vital reform. The price rises will be cushioned by welfare benefits. The subsidies are designed to cushion farmers against unpredictable weather. Housing benefit provides a cushion against hardship.

def.en: Something that # cushions# a part or object when it hits something protects it by reducing the force of the impact.
def.exmp: The main function of springs is to #cushion# the impact of a load. The engine is #cushioned# against shock and vibration by rubber mountings. Something that #cushions# a part or object when it hits something protects it by reducing the force of the impact.

def.en: A # cushion# is a fabric case filled with soft material, which you put on a seat to make it more comfortable.
def.exmp: The chair and sofa have large comfortable #cushions#. I arranged some soft #cushions# on the chairs. The chairs have linen covers and silk #cushions# on top.

def.en: #Customary# is used to describe things that people usually do in a particular society or in particular circumstances.
def.exmp: It is customary to offer a drink or a snack to guests. At Christmas it was customary for the children to perform bits of poetry. They interrupted the customary one minute's silence with jeers and shouts. Marriages in medieval Europe were customarily arranged by the families. The king carried himself with his customary elegance. Yvonne took her customary seat behind her desk.

def.en: In computer technology, #cyberspace# refers to data banks and networks, considered as a place.
A #cylinder# is an object with flat circular ends and long straight sides.
def.exmp: ...a cylinder of foam. It was recorded on a wax cylinder. ...oxygen cylinders. ...a 2.5 litre, four-cylinder engine.

def.en: In an engine, a # cylinder# is a part with flat circular ends and long straight sides in which a piston moves backward and forward.
def.exmp: The carburetor heats the gas before it enters the engine #cylinder#. Both engines feature four valves per #cylinder# and a host of engineering improvements. With two sparking plugs in each of its four #cylinders#, the new engine produces 82bhp.

def.en: A # cylinder# is a cavity of circular cross-section that contains a moving piston, for example in an internal combustion engine.
def.exmp: The piston moves up in the #cylinder#, compressing the fuel as it goes. Fluid may be leaking out of the back side of the master #cylinder# where the piston assembly goes. A #cylinder# is a cavity of circular cross-section that contains a moving piston, for example in an internal combustion engine.

def.en: A #dairy# is a shop or company that sells milk and food made from milk, such as butter, cream, and cheese.
def.exmp: ...dairy produce. ...vitamins found in eggs, meat and dairy products. ...a small vegetable and dairy farm. ...the feeding of dairy cows.

def.en: A #dam# is a wall that is built across a river in order to stop the water flowing and to make a lake.
def.exmp: ...plans to build a dam on the Danube River. ...the Aswan Dam. ...plans to dam the nearby Delaware River. This reservoir was formed by damming the River Blith.

def.en: Something that is #damp# is slightly wet.
def.exmp: Her hair was still damp. ...the damp, cold air. She wiped the table with a damp cloth. There was damp everywhere and the entire building was in need of rewiring. Hillsden damped a hand towel and laid it across her forehead.

def.en: If you #dash# somewhere, you run or go there quickly and suddenly.
def.exmp: Suddenly she dashed down to the cellar. She dashed in from the garden. ...a 160-mile dash to hospital. Oh, Tim! I'm sorry but I have to dash. See you tomorrow night. Must dash now. Add a dash of balsamic vinegar. ...a story with a dash of mystery thrown in. ...A fake fur collar or cuff adds a dash of glamour to even the simplest style. She seized the doll and dashed it against the stone wall with tremendous force. The announcement dashed hopes of an early end to the crisis. They had their championship hopes dashed by a 3-1 defeat. He's in a dash to get Russia back into Europe. ...the dash to buy shares in internet companies. Dash it all. It's just not playing the game, is it? The Prince was driving with great fire and dash.

def.en: #Dawn# is the time of day when light first appears in the sky, just before the sun rises.
def.exmp: Nancy woke at dawn. We can only guess what went through the mind of a man who could look back to the dawn of powered flight. ...the dawn of the radio age. Throughout Europe a new railway age, that of the high-speed train, has dawned. A new era seemed to be about to dawn for the coach and his young team. Now there is a dawning realisation that drastic action is necessary. ...the dawning of the space age. Tettlinger uncovered his eyes in the first dawning of hope. When the great day dawned, the first concern was the weather. The next day dawned sombre and gloomy.

def.en: #Daylight# is the natural light that there is during the day, before it gets dark.
def.exmp: It was still daylight but all the cars had their headlights on. Lack of daylight can make people feel depressed. Quinn returned shortly after daylight yesterday morning.

def.en: If someone or something #dazzles# you, you are extremely impressed by their skill, qualities, or beauty.
def.exmp: George dazzled her with his knowledge of the world. The movie's special effects fail to dazzle. The dazzle of stardom and status attracts them. The sun, glinting from the pool, dazzled me. Kelly was dazzled by the lights. The sun's dazzle on the water hurts my eyes. ...a filter that can cut dazzle.

def.en: If something is #deadly#, it is likely or able to cause someone's death, or has already caused someone's death.
def.exmp: He was acquitted on charges of assault with a deadly weapon. ...a deadly disease currently affecting dolphins. Passive smoking can be deadly too. The authorities are looking into last week's deadly gas explosions. His mother's voice was one he knew; ice cold and deadly. The Duchess levelled a deadly look at Nikko. She finds these parties deadly. Broadcast news was accurate and reliable but deadly dull. The north wind was bitter and deadly cold. The United States had been deadly serious in its threat of military action. ...the deadly combination of low expectations and low achievement. It is here that most students fall into a subtle and deadly trap. The two became deadly enemies. That would make the competition between rival suppliers even deadlier. ...the fastest and deadliest bowlers in world cricket today.

def.en: A #dealer# is a person whose business involves buying and selling things.
def.exmp: ...an antique dealer. ...dealers in commodities and financial securities. They aim to clear every dealer from the street.

def.en: A # dealer# is a broker who can hold a position in the securities they sell.
def.exmp: #A dealer# trading shares charges a percentage of the dollar amount of the trade. Each #dealer# has a password that allows access to updated stock information. #A dealer# is a broker who can hold a position in the securities they sell.

def.en: A #dean# is an important official at a university or college.
def.exmp: She was Dean of the Science faculty at Sophia University. ...Alan Webster, former Dean of St Paul's. ...Aaron Copland, who was known as the dean of American composers.

def.en: When something such as a dead body, a dead plant, or a tooth #decays#, it is gradually destroyed by a natural process.
def.exmp: The bodies buried in the fine ash slowly decayed. The ground was scattered with decaying leaves. When not removed, plaque causes tooth decay and gum disease. ...decayed teeth. Popular cinema seems to have decayed. Congress has tried dozens of approaches to revitalize decaying urban and rural areas. There are problems of urban decay and gang violence.

def.en: #Deceit# is behaviour that is deliberately intended to make people believe something which is not true.
def.exmp: They have been involved in a campaign of deceit.

def.en: If you #deceive# someone, you make them believe something that is not true, usually in order to get some advantage for yourself.
def.exmp: He has deceived and disillusioned us all. If you can make the last 10 seconds exciting, you can deceive your audience into thinking it's been like that all along. Alcoholics are notorious for their ability to deceive themselves about the extent of their problem. His gentle, kindly appearance did not deceive me. The boys, if my eyes did not deceive me, were praying.

def.en: #December# is the twelfth and last month of the year in the Western calendar.
def.exmp: ...a bright morning in mid-December. Her baby was born on 4 December. The talks are due to be concluded this December.

def.en: A #decimal# system involves counting in units of ten.
def.exmp: ...the decimal system of metric weights and measures. In 1971, the 1p and 2p decimal coins were introduced in Britain. ...simple math concepts, such as decimals and fractions.

def.en: If a fact, action, or event is #decisive#, it makes it certain that there will be a particular result.
def.exmp: ...his decisive victory in the presidential elections. The election campaign has now entered its final, decisive phase. The meeting between Molotov, Bidault and Bevin was decisive. The plan was decisively rejected by Congress three weeks ago. He should give way to a younger, more decisive leader. 'I'll call for you at half ten,' she said decisively. His supporters admire his decisiveness.

def.en: A #deck# on a vehicle such as a bus or ship is a lower or upper area of it.
def.exmp: ...sitting on the top deck of the number 13 bus. ...a luxury liner with five passenger decks. She stood on the deck and waved. ...the tape deck in my car. I stuck a tape in the deck. Matt picked up the cards and shuffled the deck. A natural timber deck leads into the main room of the home. Villagers decked the streets with bunting. The house was decked with flowers. I hear you decked him and scared the hell out of his buddies.

def.en: If something #declines#, it becomes less in quantity, importance, or strength.
def.exmp: The number of staff has declined from 217,000 to 114,000. Hourly output by workers declined 1.3% in the first quarter. Union membership and union power are declining fast. ...a declining birth rate. He declined their invitation. The band declined to comment on the story. He offered the boys some coffee. They declined politely. There wasn't such a big decline in enrollments after all. ...Rome's decline in the fifth century. The first signs of economic decline became visible.

def.en: If you say that someone #has dedicated# themselves #to# something, you approve of the fact that they have decided to give a lot of time and effort to it because they think that it is important.
def.exmp: Back on the island, he dedicated himself to politics. Bessie has dedicated her life to caring for others. He's quite dedicated to his students. ...a company staffed by capable and dedicated people. We admire her dedication to the cause of humanity. To be successful takes hard work and dedication. She dedicated her first album to Woody Allen. This book is dedicated to the memory of my mother. The other day, in a little church near Brighton, a window was dedicated to the memory of the Revd. Michael Scott. The church is dedicated to St Mary of Bec. ...the dedication of the Holocaust Museum. Some 250 guests attended the dedication ceremony.

def.en: If you #deduce# something or #deduce# that something is true, you reach that conclusion because of other things that you know to be true.
def.exmp: Alison had cleverly deduced that I was the author of the letter. The date of the document can be deduced from references to the Civil War. She hoped he hadn't deduced the reason for her visit.

def.en: When you #deduct# an amount from a total, you subtract it from the total.
def.exmp: The company deducted this payment from his compensation. Up to 5% of marks in the exams will be deducted for spelling mistakes.

def.en: If something #is deemed# #to# have a particular quality or #to# do a particular thing, it is considered to have that quality or do that thing.
def.exmp: French and German were deemed essential. He says he would support the use of force if the U.N. deemed it necessary. I was deemed to be a competent shorthand typist.

def.en: A #deer# is a large wild animal that eats grass and leaves.
A #defect# is a fault or imperfection in a person or thing.
def.exmp: He was born with a hearing defect. ...a defect in the aircraft caused the crash. A report has pointed out the defects of the present system. He tried to defect to the West last year. He defected from the party in the late 1970s. ...a KGB officer who defected in 1963. ...the defection of at least sixteen Parliamentary deputies.

def.en: #Deficiency# #in# something, especially something that your body needs, is not having enough of it.
def.exmp: They did blood tests on him for signs of vitamin deficiency. There are serious deficiencies in the numbers of suitable aircraft. ...a serious deficiency in our air defence.

def.en: A #deficit# is the amount by which something is less than what is required or expected, especially the amount by which the total money received is less than the total money spent.
def.exmp: They're ready to cut the federal budget deficit for the next fiscal year. ...a deficit of 3.275 billion francs.

def.en: A # deficit# is a situation in which liabilities are greater than assets.
def.exmp: Cash in-flows and out-flows must be balanced against each other, with a surplus placed on the asset side or a #deficit# on the liability side. Slashing capital spending and selling off public assets reduce the budget #deficit# in the short term but do little to correct the underlying fiscal imbalance. A #deficit# is a situation in which liabilities are greater than assets.

def.en: A # deficit# is a situation in which expenses are greater than revenues during a particular accounting period.
def.exmp: You are running a #deficit# if you spend more money than you make. None of the companies reported a #deficit# during this prosperous period. A #deficit# is a situation in which expenses are greater than revenues during a particular accounting period.

def.en: If something such as a decision or an arrangement is #definite#, it is firm and clear, and unlikely to be changed.
def.exmp: It's too soon to give a definite answer. Her Royal Highness has definite views about most things. She made no definite plans for her future. We didn't have any definite proof. If you have any definite news of my husband, please let me know. The police had nothing definite against her. There has already been a definite improvement. That's a very definite possibility. Mary is very definite about this. Studying his face in the bathroom mirror he wished he had more definite features.

def.en: A #definition# is a statement giving the meaning of a word or expression, especially in a dictionary.
def.exmp: There is no general agreement on a standard definition of intelligence. My definition of a good hospice is one where some of the patients start feeling too good to die. Give your brows extra definition with Outdoor Girl's Eyebrow Pencil in Brown. The speakers criticised his new programme for lack of definition.

def.en: If you #defy# someone or something that is trying to make you behave in a particular way, you refuse to obey them and behave in that way.
def.exmp: This was the first (and last) time that I dared to defy my mother. Nearly eleven-thousand people have been arrested for defying the ban on street trading. I defy you to come up with one major accomplishment of the current Prime Minister. He looked at me as if he was defying me to argue. When the flowers open in spring they fill the night air with a fragrance that defies description. It's a devastating and barbaric act that defies all comprehension.

def.en: If you say that someone or something #degenerates#, you mean that they become worse in some way, for example weaker, lower in quality, or more dangerous.
def.exmp: Inactivity can make your joints stiff, and the bones may begin to degenerate. From then on the whole tone of the campaign began to degenerate. ...a very serious humanitarian crisis which could degenerate into a catastrophe. ...various forms of physical and mental degeneration. ...the degeneration of our political system. ...a group of degenerate computer hackers. ...the degenerate attitudes he found among some of his fellow officers.

def.en: A #delegate# is a person who is chosen to vote or make decisions on behalf of a group of other people, especially at a conference or a meeting.
def.exmp: He plans to delegate more authority to his deputies. How many of their activities can be safely and effectively delegated to less trained staff? Many employers find it hard to delegate. A key factor in running a business is the delegation of responsibility. Officials have now been delegated to start work on a draft settlement.

def.en: Something that is #delicate# is small and beautifully shaped.
def.exmp: He had delicate hands. ...an evergreen tree with large flame-coloured leaves and delicate blossom. She was a shy, delicately pretty girl with enormous blue eyes. Young haricot beans have a tender texture and a delicate, subtle flavour. The colours are delicate and shimmering. ...a soup delicately flavoured with nutmeg. Although the coral looks hard, it is very delicate. ...a washing machine catering for every fabric–even the most delicate. She was physically delicate and psychologically unstable. The European members are afraid of upsetting the delicate balance of political interests. This sensitive book tackles the delicate issue of adoption with care and simplicity. She turned to Mary Ann. 'This is kind of delicate. Would you excuse us for a moment?' Clearly, the situation remains delicately poised. ...a delicately-worded memo. ...a long and delicate operation carried out at a hospital in Florence. Each motion must be delicate and precise, involving tiny movements. She picked her way delicately over the rocks. ...the delicately embroidered sheets.

def.en: #Delight# is a feeling of very great pleasure.
def.exmp: Throughout the house, the views are a constant source of surprise and delight. Andrew roared with delight when he heard Rachel's nickname for the baby. To my great delight, it worked perfectly. Isn't she a delight? The aircraft was a delight to fly. Sampling the local cuisine is one of the delights of a holiday abroad. She has created a style of music that has delighted audiences all over the world. The report has delighted environmentalists. Generations of adults and children have delighted in the story. He delighted in sharing his love of birds with children.

def.en: To #demonstrate# a fact means to make it clear to people.
def.exmp: The study also demonstrated a direct link between obesity and mortality. You have to demonstrate that you are reliable. They are anxious to demonstrate to the voters that they have practical policies. He's demonstrated how a campaign based on domestic issues can move votes. Have they, for example, demonstrated a commitment to democracy? The government's going to great lengths to demonstrate its military might. 30,000 angry farmers demonstrated against possible cuts in subsidies. In the cities vast crowds have been demonstrating for change. Thousands of people demonstrated outside the parliament building. The BBC has just successfully demonstrated a new digital radio transmission system. He flew the prototype to West Raynham to demonstrate it to a group of senior officers. A style consultant will demonstrate how to dress to impress.

def.en: A #denial# of something is a statement that it is not true, does not exist, or did not happen.
def.exmp: Despite official denials, the rumours still persist. Denial of the Mafia's existence is nothing new. ...the denial of visas to international relief workers. This does not justify the denial of constitutional protection. With major life traumas, like losing a loved one, for instance, the mind's first reaction is denial. ...an addict who is in denial about his addiction.

def.en: If one thing #denotes# another, it is a sign or indication of it.
def.exmp: Red eyes denote strain and fatigue. There was a message waiting, denoting that someone had been here ahead of her. In figure 24 'D' denotes quantity demanded and 'S' denotes quantity supplied. In the Middle Ages the term 'drab' denoted a very simple type of woollen cloth which was used by peasants to make their clothes.

def.en: If you #denounce# a person or an action, you criticize them severely and publicly because you feel strongly that they are wrong or evil.
def.exmp: The letter called for trade union freedom and civil rights, but did not openly denounce the regime. German leaders denounced the attacks and pleaded for tolerance. Some 25,000 demonstrators denounced him as a traitor. ...informers who might denounce you at any moment.
