def.en: Something that is #dense# contains a lot of things or people in a small area.
def.exmp: Where Bucharest now stands, there once was a large, dense forest. Its fur is short, dense and silky. They thrust their way through the dense crowd. Java is a densely populated island. The fire struck a densely wooded area of Oakland. A dense column of smoke rose several miles into the air. ...a small dense star. His prose is vigorous and dense, occasionally to the point of obscurity. He's not a bad man, just a bit dense.

def.en: #Density# is the extent to which something is filled or covered with people or things.
def.exmp: ...a law which restricts the density of housing. The region has a very high population density. ...areas with high densities of immigrant populations. Jupiter's moon Io, whose density is 3.5 grams per cubic centimetre, is all rock.

def.en: # Density# is the quantity of mass per unit volume of a non-porous solid.
def.exmp: The #density# of lead is greater than that of polypropylene. The greater #density# of zinc results in a considerably smaller anode which is less susceptible to wave damage. #Density# is the quantity of mass per unit volume of a non-porous solid.

def.en: # Density# is a measure of a distributed mass per unit volume for porous solids or particle suspensions.
def.exmp: As well as the speed of the fluid and the average particle size, the erosion rate depends on the particle #density# in the flow. The #density# of a water vapor cloud depends on the number and size of particles per unit volume involved. #Density# is a measure of a distributed mass per unit volume for porous solids or particle suspensions.

def.en: #Dental# is used to describe things that relate to teeth or to the care and treatment of teeth.
def.exmp: You can get free dental treatment. ...the dental profession.

def.en: #Departure# or a #departure# is the act of going away from somewhere.
def.exmp: ...the President's departure for Helsinki. They hoped this would lead to the departure of all foreign forces from the country. The airline has more than 90 scheduled departures from here every day. This would inevitably involve his departure from the post of Prime Minister. Reihill's departure from the company is thought to follow disagreements with John Reihill Sr, who now controls the company. Taylor announced another departure from practice in that England will train at Wembley. Now she's written a novel which is not a mystery and is a considerable departure from her previous work.

def.en: To #depict# someone or something means to show or represent them in a work of art such as a drawing or painting.
def.exmp: ...a gallery of pictures depicting Nelson's most famous battles. Margaret Atwood's novel depicts a gloomy, futuristic America. Children's books often depict farmyard animals as gentle, lovable creatures.

def.en: A #deposit# is a sum of money which is part of the full price of something, and which you pay when you agree to buy it.
def.exmp: A £50 deposit is required when ordering, and the balance is due upon delivery. It is common to ask for the equivalent of a month's rent as a deposit. The Tory candidate lost his deposit. After 10 minutes the surplus material is washed away and any remaining deposit examined with ultra violet light. ...underground deposits of gold and diamonds. ...mineral deposits. Someone was seen depositing a packet. Fritz deposited a glass and two bottles of beer in front of Wolfe. Imagine if you were suddenly swept up and deposited in Morocco. How well could you cope with the language, the weather, the people, and so on? You are advised to deposit valuables in the hotel safe. The customer has to deposit a minimum of £100 monthly. The phosphate was deposited by the decay of marine microorganisms.

def.en: If you # deposit# money in a bank account, you put it there.
def.exmp: They arranged for the money to be #deposited# in a bank in Andorra. When he left the company, he #deposited# the checks into two unauthorized bank accounts. If you #deposit# money in a bank account, you put it there.

def.en: A # deposit# is a sum of money which you pay when you book a room at a hotel or guest house.
If someone or something #depresses# you, they make you feel sad and disappointed.
def.exmp: I must admit the state of the country depresses me. I know he is too optimistic but I don't want to depress him. The stronger U.S. dollar depressed sales.

def.en: If you #deprive# someone #of# something that they want or need, you take it away from them, or you prevent them from having it.
def.exmp: The disintegration of the Soviet Union deprived western intelligence agencies of their main enemies. They've been deprived of the fuel necessary to heat their homes.

def.en: The #depth# of something such as a river or hole is the distance downwards from its top surface, or between its upper and lower surfaces.
def.exmp: The smaller lake ranges from five to fourteen feet in depth. The depth of the shaft is 520 yards. Pour the vegetable oil into a frying pan to a depth of about 1cm. They were detected at depths of more than a kilometre in the sea. I am well aware of the depth of feeling that exists in Londonderry. 'Tough, isn't it?' was all she said, but Amy felt the depth of her unspoken sympathy. The country's leadership had underestimated the depth of the crisis. We felt at home with her and were impressed with the depth of her knowledge. It makes invaluable reading for anyone who wants to acquire a greater depth of understanding of the subject. White wines tend to gain depth of colour with age. The blue base gives the red paint more depth. All the paintings are startlingly dramatic as a result of their depth of field and colour. His music lacks depth. There are hidden depths in all of us. The ship vanished into the depths. ...the depths of the countryside. Somewhere in the depths of the pine forest an identical sound reverberated. I was in the depths of despair when the baby was sick. The country is in the depths of a recession. ...the depths of winter.

def.en: A #deputy# is the second most important person in an organization such as a business or government department.
def.exmp: ...Jack Lang, France's minister for culture, and his deputy, Catherine Tasca. ...the academy's deputy director, Vladimir Kudryatsev. The president appealed to deputies to approve the plan quickly.

def.en: If you #derive# something such as pleasure or benefit #from# a person or from something, you get it from them.
def.exmp: Mr Ying is one of those happy people who derive pleasure from helping others. Anna's strength is derived from her parents and her sisters. The word Easter derives from Eostre, the pagan goddess of spring.

def.en: If you #descend# or if you #descend# a staircase, you move downwards from a higher to a lower level.
def.exmp: Things are cooler and more damp as we descend to the cellar. She descended one flight of stairs. An uneasy calm descended on the area. A reverent hush descended on the multitude. 3,000 city officials descended on Capitol Hill to lobby for more money. Curious tourists and reporters from around the globe are descending upon the peaceful villages. Darkness has now descended and the moon and stars shine hazily in the clear sky. We're not going to descend to such methods. She's got too much dignity to descend to writing anonymous letters. He was ultimately overthrown and the country descended into chaos.

def.en: Someone's #descendants# are the people in later generations who are related to them.
def.exmp: They are descendants of the original English and Scottish settlers. ...Lord Cochrane and his descendants. His design was a descendant of a 1956 device. They are the descendants of plants imported by the early settlers.

def.en: A #descent# is a movement from a higher to a lower level or position.
def.exmp: Sixteen of the youngsters set off for help, but during the descent three collapsed in the cold and rain. ...the crash of an Airbus A300 on its descent into Kathmandu airport. On the descents, cyclists spin past cars, freewheeling downhill at tremendous speed. The only lasting solution lies in a political settlement. Without it, their descent into chaos will be guaranteed. ...his swift descent from respected academic to struggling small businessman. All the contributors were of African descent.

def.en: When someone #designs# a garment, building, machine, or other object, they plan it and make a detailed drawing of it from which it can be built or made.
def.exmp: They wanted to design a machine that was both attractive and practical. ...men wearing specially designed boots. We may be able to design a course to suit your particular needs. Computer security systems will be designed by independent technicians. A number of very well designed studies have been undertaken. He was a born mechanic with a flair for design. Most mobile robots are still in the design stage. She came to London in 1960 to study fashion design. These machines are constantly updated by improving the design of the computers. ...a new design of clock. The shoes were of good design and good quality. BMW is recalling 8,000 cars because of a design fault. They drew up the design for the house in a week. Their range of tableware is decorated with a blackberry design. Many pictures have been based on simple geometric designs. Is there some design in having him in the middle? The intelligence service conceived a grand design to assassinate the War Minister. This project is designed to help landless people. It's not designed for anyone under age eighteen.

def.en: When you #designate# someone or something #as# a particular thing, you formally give them that description or name.
def.exmp: ...a man interviewed in one of our studies whom we shall designate as E. There are efforts under way to designate the bridge a historic landmark. I live in Exmoor, which is designated as a national park. Some of the rooms were designated as offices. ...scholarships designated for minorities. Smoking is allowed in designated areas. Designate someone as the spokesperson. The President's designated successor is his son. Japan's Prime Minister-designate is completing his Cabinet today.

def.en: Something that is #desirable# is worth having or doing because it is useful, necessary, or popular.
def.exmp: Prolonged negotiation was not desirable. The crowd moved indoors for what were deemed the most desirable items. ...the desirability of democratic reform. ...the debate on the desirability of banning the ivory trade. ...the young women whom his classmates thought most desirable. ...Veronica's desirability.

def.en: A #desolate# place is empty of people and lacking in comfort.
def.exmp: ...a desolate landscape of flat green fields broken by marsh. Half-ruined, hardly a building untouched, it's a desolate place. He was desolate without her. Their inclination to wait and demand more resources desolated President Lincoln. I saw them walk away and felt absolutely desolated. They have maintained their optimism in the face of desolating subjugation.

def.en: If you #dispatch# someone to a place, you send them there for a particular reason.
def.exmp: He dispatched scouts ahead. The Italian government was preparing to dispatch 4,000 soldiers to search the island. The despatch of the task force is purely a contingency measure. The victory inspired him to dispatch a gleeful telegram to Roosevelt. Free gifts are dispatched separately so please allow 28 days for delivery. We have 125 cases ready for dispatch. ...this despatch from our West Africa correspondent. I was carrying dispatches from the ambassador. The fox takes his chance with a pack of hounds which may catch him and despatch him immediately. Amy sat outside in the sun while Gerald despatched his business. He feels we should act with despatch.

def.en: If you are #desperate#, you are in such a bad situation that you are willing to try anything to change it.
def.exmp: Troops are needed to help get food into Kosovo where people are in desperate need. Desperate with anxiety, Bob and Hans searched the whole house. He made a desperate attempt to hijack a plane. Thousands are desperately trying to leave their battered homes. They'd been married nearly four years and June was desperate to start a family. People are desperate for him to do something. He was a boy who desperately needed affection. India's United Nations ambassador said the situation is desperate. I decided not to abandon John when he was in such a desperate position.

def.en: If you #despise# something or someone, you dislike them and have a very low opinion of them.
def.exmp: I can never, ever forgive him. I despise him. She secretly despises his work. How I despised myself for my cowardice!

def.en: You use #despite# to introduce a fact which makes the other part of the sentence surprising.
def.exmp: Despite a thorough investigation, no trace of Dr Southwell has been found. The National Health Service has visibly deteriorated, despite increased spending. He was obviously distressed despite being unconscious. She will stand by husband, despite reports that he sent another woman love notes. Despite myself, Harry's remarks had caused me to stop and reflect.

def.en: #Dessert# is something sweet, such as fruit or a pudding, that you eat at the end of a meal.
def.exmp: She had homemade ice cream for dessert. I am partial to desserts that combine fresh fruit with fine pastry.

def.en: A # dessert# is something sweet, such as fruit, pastry, or ice cream, that you eat at the end of a meal.
A person's #destiny# is everything that happens to them during their life, including what will happen in the future, especially when it is considered to be controlled by someone or something else.
def.exmp: We are masters of our own destiny. It is my destiny one day to be king. Is it destiny that brings people together, or is it accident?

def.en: #Destruction# is the act of destroying something, or the state of being destroyed.
def.exmp: ...an international agreement aimed at halting the destruction of the ozone layer. ...weapons of mass destruction.

def.en: Something that is #destructive# causes or is capable of causing great damage, harm, or injury.
def.exmp: ...the awesome destructive power of nuclear weapons. Guilt can be very destructive. ...the size of armies and the destructiveness of their weapons. Power can be used creatively or destructively.

def.en: If you #detach# one thing #from# another that it is fixed to, you remove it.
def.exmp: Detach the white part of the application form and keep it. It is easy to detach the currants from the stems. There was an accident when the towrope detached from the car. It helps them detach themselves from their problems and become more objective. Alexis saw his father detach himself from the group and walk away down the hill by himself.

def.en: When people such as the police #detain# someone, they keep them in a place under their control.
def.exmp: The act allows police to detain a suspect for up to 48 hours. He was arrested and detained for questioning. Thank you. We won't detain you any further.

def.en: A #detective# is someone whose job is to discover what has happened in a crime or other situation and to find the people involved.
def.exmp: Detectives are appealing for witnesses who may have seen anything suspicious. She hired a private detective in an attempt to find her daughter. ...Detective Inspector Ian Mosley. ...Detective Nardosa of the New York City Police Department.

def.en: A #detector# is an instrument which is used to discover that something is present somewhere, or to measure how much of something there is.
def.exmp: ...a metal detector. ...fire alarms and smoke detectors.

def.en: A # detector# is an instrument to detect the unbalance in a bridge circuit.
def.exmp: The further down the chain toward the output that #a detector# is placed, the more effect the non-linear distortion will have on the detection function. The circuit acts as a phase #detector# by comparing the frequency of an oscillator with an incoming signal and then feeding back the output to keep the oscillator in phase with the incoming frequency. #A detector# is an instrument to detect the unbalance in a bridge circuit.

def.en: If something #deteriorates#, it becomes worse in some way.
def.exmp: There are fears that the situation might deteriorate into full-scale war. The weather conditions are deteriorating. Grant's health steadily deteriorated. ...concern about the rapid deterioration in relations between the two countries. ...the slow steady deterioration of a patient with Alzheimer's disease.

def.en: To #deviate# #from# something means to start doing something different or not planned, especially in a way that causes problems for others.
def.exmp: They stopped you as soon as you deviated from the script. He planned his schedule far in advance, and he didn't deviate from it. From very early on he believed a military revolution was necessary and he has never deviated from that ideological path.

def.en: If you #devise# a plan, system, or machine, you have the idea for it and design it.
def.exmp: We devised a scheme to help him. New long-range objectives must be devised.

def.en: #Dew# is small drops of water that form on the ground and other surfaces outdoors during the night.
def.exmp: The dew gathered on the leaves.

def.en: If someone or something #is diagnosed# #as# having a particular illness or problem, their illness or problem is identified.
def.exmp: The soldiers were diagnosed as having flu. Susan had a mental breakdown and was diagnosed with schizophrenia. In 1894 her illness was diagnosed as cancer. He could diagnose an engine problem simply by listening. This disorder is easily diagnosed but not so easily treated.

def.en: A #dial# is the part of a machine or instrument such as a clock or watch which shows you the time or a measurement that has been recorded.
def.exmp: The luminous dial on the clock showed five minutes to seven. The dials of most barometers are inscribed with weather terms. He turned the dial on the radio. The heat dial was set at 150 degrees. ...turning the dial on the phone. He lifted the phone and dialled her number. He dialled, and spoke briefly to the duty officer.

def.en: A #dialect# is a form of a language that is spoken in a particular area.
def.exmp: In the fifties, many Italians spoke only local dialect. They began to speak rapidly in dialect.

def.en: The #diameter# of a round object is the length of a straight line that can be drawn across it, passing through the middle of it.
def.exmp: ...a tube less than a fifth of the diameter of a human hair. ...a length of 22-mm diameter steel pipe. ...a tiny capsule, between 1 and 3 millimetres in diameter.

def.en: A #diamond# is a hard, bright, precious stone which is clear and colourless.
def.exmp: ...a pair of diamond earrings. ...a sphere made of diamond without impurity or flaw. Nicole loves wearing her diamonds, even with jeans and a white T-shirt. He formed his hands into the shape of a diamond. He drew the seven of diamonds. ...win the ace of clubs and play a diamond.

def.en: If you #dictate# something, you say or read it aloud for someone else to write down.
def.exmp: Sheldon writes every day of the week, dictating his novels in the morning. Everything he dictated was signed and sent out the same day. He had warned the West against trying to dictate to the Soviet Union. What right has one country to dictate the environmental standards of another? He cannot be allowed to dictate what can and cannot be inspected. What gives them the right to dictate to us what we should eat? The officers were more or less able to dictate terms to successive governments. The rules of court dictate that a defendant is entitled to all evidence which may help his case. The film's budget dictated a tough schedule. The way in which they dress is dictated by very rigid fashion rules. Of course, a number of factors will dictate how long an apple tree can survive. Circumstances dictated that they played a defensive rather than attacking game. Commonsense now dictates that it would be wise to sell a few shares. Their job is to ensure that the dictates of the Party are followed. We have followed the dictates of our consciences and have done our duty.

def.en: Your #diet# is the type and range of food that you regularly eat.
def.exmp: It's never too late to improve your diet. ...a healthy diet rich in fruit and vegetables. Poor diet and excess smoking will seriously damage the health of your hair. He was put on a diet of milky food. ...a special diet for children with high cholesterol. Have you been on a diet? You've lost a lot of weight. Diet and exercise will alter your shape. I've only lost sixteen pounds since I started this diet. I've been dieting ever since the birth of my fourth child. Most of us have dieted at some time in our lives. She has already lost around two stone through dieting. ...sugar-free diet drinks. ...diet margarine. The radio had fed him a diet of pop songs. People are rejecting this constant diet of despair.

def.en: If you #differentiate# #between# things or if you #differentiate# one thing #from# another, you recognize or show the difference between them.
def.exmp: A child may not differentiate between his imagination and the real world. At this age your baby cannot differentiate one person from another. ...distinctive policies that differentiate them from the other parties. The differentiation between the two product ranges will increase.

def.en: If something such as knowledge or information #is diffused#, or if it #diffuses# somewhere, it is made known over a wide area or to a lot of people.
def.exmp: Over time, the technology is diffused and adopted by other countries. ...an attempt to diffuse new ideas. As agriculture developed, agricultural ideas diffused across Europe. ...the development and diffusion of ideas. The arrival of letters from the Pope did nothing to diffuse the tension. Diffusing a light also reduces its power. The sun slid behind trees, its last light diffused by wintry branches. It allows nicotine to diffuse slowly and steadily into the bloodstream. It created a glowing centre of warmth that quickly diffused through my limbs. The moisture present in all foods absorbs the flavour of the smoke and eventually diffuses that flavour into its interior. There are data on the rates of diffusion of molecules. ...a diffuse community. A cold, diffuse light filtered in through the skylight. His writing is so diffuse and obscure that it is difficult to make out what it is he is trying to say.

def.en: If people or animals #dig#, they make a hole in the ground or in a pile of earth, stones, or rubbish.
def.exmp: They tried digging in a patch just below the cave. Dig a largish hole and bang the stake in first. Rescue workers are digging through the rubble in search of other victims. They dug for shellfish at low tide. Two men were standing by the freshly dug grave. He dug into his coat pocket for his keys. She digs the serving spoon into the moussaka. I grab George's arm and dig my nails into his flesh. He could feel the beads digging into his palm. Graham was standing there, his hands dug into the pockets of his baggy white trousers. The enquiry dug deeper into the alleged financial misdeeds of his government. He has been digging into the local archives. Much that is included in them has appeared in other published works, and one must dig hard for reliable new material. Occupants of the White House have exploited their office at key moments in an election campaign to dig themselves out of trouble. He's taken these measures to try and dig himself out of a hole. 'They play classic rock'n'roll,' states her boyfriend, 'My dad digs them too.'. I can dig it. I don't expect a band always to be innovative. He's an archaeologist and has been on a dig in Crete for the past year. Americans are always quick to have a dig at the British. She couldn't resist a dig at Dave after his unfortunate performance. Cassandra silenced him with a sharp dig in the small of the back. He went to London and lived in digs in Gloucester Road.

def.en: When food #digests# or when you #digest# it, it passes through your body to your stomach.
def.exmp: Do not undertake strenuous exercise for a few hours after a meal to allow food to digest. She couldn't digest food properly. Nutrients from the digested food can be absorbed into the blood. They learn well but seem to need time to digest information. She read everything, digesting every fragment of news. All this has upset me. I need time to digest it all. The organization publishes a regular digest of environmental statistics. ...the Middle East Economic Digest.

def.en: If someone behaves or moves with #dignity#, they are calm, controlled, and admirable.
def.exmp: ...her extraordinary dignity and composure. ...the sense of human dignity. ...the integrity and the dignity of our lives and feelings. If you were wrong, admit it. You won't lose dignity, but will gain respect. She still has her dignity.

def.en: A #dilemma# is a difficult situation in which you have to choose between two or more alternatives.
def.exmp: He was faced with the dilemma of whether or not to return to his country. The issue raises a moral dilemma.

def.en: Someone who is #diligent# works hard in a careful and thorough way.
def.exmp: Meyers is a diligent and prolific worker. The historical research was impressively diligent. The police are pursuing their inquiries with great diligence. The two sides are now working diligently to resolve their differences.

def.en: If a liquid #is diluted# or #dilutes#, it is added to or mixes with water or another liquid, and becomes weaker.
def.exmp: If you give your baby juice, dilute it well with cooled, boiled water. The liquid is then diluted. The poisons seeping from Hanford's contaminated land quickly dilute in the water. ...ditches dug for sewage dilution. ...a dilute solution of bleach. There was a clear intention to dilute black voting power. Serious attention is being given to diluting the value of personal tax allowances. ...a potentially devastating dilution of earnings per share.

def.en: #Dim# light is not bright.
def.exmp: She stood waiting, in the dim light. Below decks, the lights were dim. Two lamps burned dimly. He followed her into a dimly lit kitchen. ...the dimness of an early September evening. The room was dim and cool and quiet. I squinted to adjust my eyes to the dimness. Pete's torch picked out the dim figures of Bob and Chang. The shoreline could be dimly seen. It seems that the '60s era of social activism is all but a dim memory. Christina dimly recalled the procedure. I was dimly aware that dozens of curious people were looking at us. The prospects for a peaceful solution are dim. Dim the lighting–it is unpleasant to lie with a bright light shining in your eyes. The houselights dimmed. Dim your lights behind that car. Their economic prospects have dimmed. Forty eight years of marriage have not dimmed the passion between Bill and Helen. Her eyes dimmed with sorrow. The twinkle in his eyes was dimmed by tears. Their memory of what happened has dimmed. The intervening years had dimmed his memory.

def.en: When something #diminishes#, or when something #diminishes# it, it becomes reduced in size, importance, or intensity.
def.exmp: The threat of nuclear war has diminished. Federalism is intended to diminish the power of the central state. Universities are facing grave problems because of diminishing resources. This could mean diminished public support for the war. He never put her down or diminished her. He could no longer cope; he relied on me, and felt diminished by it.

def.en: When you #dine#, you have dinner.
def.exmp: He dines alone most nights. That night the two men dined at Wilson's club. They used to enjoy going out to dine.

def.en: If you #dip# something #in# a liquid, you put it into the liquid for a short time, so that only part of it is covered, and take it out again.
def.exmp: They dip the food into the sauce. Quickly dip the base in and out of cold water. One dip into the bottle should do an entire nail. She dipped a hand into the jar of sweets and pulled one out. Watch your fingers as you dip into the pot. Ask the children to guess what's in each container by dipping their hands in. Blake jumped in expertly; the boat dipped slightly under his weight. The sun dipped below the horizon. I noticed little things, a dip of the head, a twitch in the shoulder. The road dipped and rose again. ...a path which suddenly dips down into a tunnel. Where the road makes a dip, turn right. Their father was helping to dip the sheep. He digs potatoes and helps with the sheep dipping. ...sheep dip. Unemployment dipped to 6.9 per cent last month. The president became more cautious as his popularity dipped. ...the current dip in farm spending. Maybe we could just buy some dips. ...prawns with avocado dip. She flicked through a romantic paperback between occasional dips in the pool. He dipped his headlights as they came up behind a slow-moving van. This picture shows the view from a car using normal dipped lights. ...a chance to dip into a wide selection of books on Buddhism. Just when she was ready to dip into her savings, Greg hastened to her rescue.

def.en: #Dip.
#Diplomatic# means relating to diplomacy and diplomats.
def.exmp: ...before the two countries resume full diplomatic relations. Efforts are being made to avert war and find a diplomatic solution. These diplomatic skills led to her appointment as the President of the United Nations General Assembly. ...a growing sense of doubt that the conflict can be resolved diplomatically. The President made it clear he did not want to see the country diplomatically isolated. She is very direct. I tend to be more diplomatic, I suppose. 'Their sound is very interesting,' he says, diplomatically.

def.en: A #directory# is a book which gives lists of facts, for example people's names, addresses, and telephone numbers, or the names and addresses of business companies, usually arranged in alphabetical order.
def.exmp: ...a telephone directory. This option lets you create new files or directories. Yahoo is the oldest and best-known Web directory service.

def.en: If there is #dirt# on something, there is dust, mud, or a stain on it.
def.exmp: I started to scrub off the dirt. They all sit on the dirt in the dappled shade of a tree. I drove along the dirt road. The rooster chased me across the dirt floor of the barn. Steve was keen to get all the dirt he could on her. Both parties use computers to dig up dirt on their opponents.

def.en: A #disastrous# event has extremely bad consequences and effects.
def.exmp: ...the recent, disastrous earthquake. The effect on coffee prices has been disastrous for the producers. The vegetable harvest is disastrously behind schedule. Their scheme went disastrously wrong. England's cricketers have had another disastrous day. ...their disastrous performance in the general election of 1906. ...the company's disastrously timed venture into property development.

def.en: A #disc# is a flat, circular shape or object.
def.exmp: Most shredding machines are based on a revolving disc fitted with replaceable blades. I had slipped a disc and was frozen in a spasm of pain. This disc includes the piano sonata in C minor.

def.en: If you #discard# something, you get rid of it because you no longer want it or need it.
def.exmp: Read the manufacturer's guidelines before discarding the box. ...discarded cigarette butts.

def.en: If you can #discern# something, you are aware of it and know what it is.
def.exmp: You need a long series of data to be able to discern such a trend. It was hard to discern why this was happening. Below the bridge we could just discern a narrow, weedy ditch.

def.en: When someone #is discharged# #from# hospital, prison, or one of the armed services, they are officially allowed to leave, or told that they must leave.
def.exmp: He has a broken nose but may be discharged today. You are being discharged on medical grounds. ...the regulation that gay people should be discharged from the military. Five days later Henry discharged himself from hospital. He was given a conditional discharge and ordered to pay compensation. ...the quiet competence with which he discharged his many college duties. The goods will be sold for a fraction of their value in order to discharge the debt. The resulting salty water will be discharged at sea. The bird had trouble breathing and was discharging blood from the nostrils. They develop a fever and a watery discharge from their eyes. All discharges and disposals of radioactive waste from Springfields were within relevant limits. Lewis was tried for unlawfully and dangerously discharging a weapon.

def.en: # Discharge# is the flow of waste or product from a process.
def.exmp: The control of air pollution resulting from the #discharge# of sulfur dioxide into the atmosphere has become increasingly urgent. Other openings were provided at the top of the shell to allow #discharge# of the products of combustion into the air of the room. #Discharge# is the flow of waste or product from a process.

def.en: When a pump # discharges# a substance, it pushes it out.
def.exmp: Oil is #discharged# from the pump into the casing and out the wellhead. The volume of the fluid #discharged# from the pump is equal to the area of the plunger or piston. When a pump #discharges# a substance, it pushes it out.

def.en: Electrical # discharge# can occur by the release of the electric charge stored in a capacitor through an external circuit.
def.exmp: The #discharge# path was formed when a conductive liquid seeped into the plug-socket assembly. Capacitors may also have built-in #discharge# resistors to dissipate stored energy to a safe level within a few seconds after power is removed. Electrical #discharge# can occur by the release of the electric charge stored in a capacitor through an external circuit.

def.en: If you #disclose# new or secret information, you tell people about it.
def.exmp: Neither side would disclose details of the transaction. The company disclosed that he will retire in May.

def.en: If you # disclose# information to an insurer, you provide information about a risk that may be relevant when calculating the premium.
def.exmp: Please fully #disclose# all material facts that are relevant to the policy including any disease or claims made by you. If you #disclose# motoring convictions to an automobile insurer you will often have to pay an extra premium. If you #disclose# information to an insurer, you provide information about a risk that may be relevant when calculating the premium.

def.en: #Discourse# is spoken or written communication between people, especially serious discussion of a particular subject.
def.exmp: ...a tradition of political discourse. The Centre has a strong record of research in discourse analysis. ...our work on discourse and the way people talk to each other. Gates responds with a lengthy discourse on deployment strategy. He discoursed for several hours on French and English prose.

def.en: If you are #discreet#, you are polite and careful in what you do or say, because you want to avoid embarrassing or offending someone.
def.exmp: They were gossipy and not always discreet. He followed at a discreet distance. I took the phone, and she went discreetly into the living room. We were very discreet about the romance. She's making a few discreet inquiries with her mother's friends. Everyone tried discreetly to find out more about him. She wore discreet jewellery. ...stately houses, discreetly hidden behind great avenues of sturdy trees. The two rooms were relatively small and discreetly lit.

def.en: If there is a #discrepancy# #between# two things that ought to be the same, there is a noticeable difference between them.
def.exmp: ...the discrepancy between press and radio reports. ...major discrepancies in payments made to claimants in similar circumstances.

def.en: If you can #discriminate# #between# two things, you can recognize that they are different.
def.exmp: He is incapable of discriminating between a good idea and a terrible one. The device can discriminate between the cancerous and the normal cells. They believe the law discriminates against women. ...legislation which would discriminate in favour of racial minorities. The Commission for Racial Equality teaches organisations not to discriminate.

def.en: If you say that someone is #in# #disgrace#, you are emphasizing that other people disapprove of them and do not respect them because of something that they have done.
def.exmp: His vice president also had to resign in disgrace. She has brought disgrace upon womankind. The way the sales were handled was a complete disgrace. The national airline is a disgrace. Republican leaders called him a disgrace to the party. What went on was a scandal. It was a disgrace to Britain. I have disgraced my family's name. I've disgraced myself by the actions I've taken.

def.en: If you are #in# #disguise#, you are not wearing your usual clothes or you have altered your appearance in other ways, so that people will not recognize you.
def.exmp: You'll have to travel in disguise. He was wearing that ridiculous disguise. She's adopted so many disguises her own mother wouldn't recognize her. She disguised herself as a man so she could fight on the battlefield. The extremists entered the building disguised as medical workers. I was heavily disguised. He made no attempt to disguise his agitation. Their healthy image disguises the fact that they are highly processed foods. I played along, and disguised my voice. This is lust thinly disguised as love.

def.en: #Disgust# is a feeling of very strong dislike or disapproval.
def.exmp: He spoke of his disgust at the incident. A look of disgust came over his face. I threw the book aside in disgust. He disgusted many with his boorish behaviour.

def.en: #Dismay# is a strong feeling of fear, worry, or sadness that is caused by something unpleasant and unexpected.
def.exmp: Local councillors have reacted with dismay and indignation. Lucy discovered to her dismay that she was pregnant. The ministers expressed dismay at the continued practice of ethnic cleansing. Meg looked up at her in dismay. The committee was dismayed by what it had been told. The thought that she was crying dismayed him. He was dismayed at the cynicism of the youngsters. He was dismayed to find that his hands were shaking.

def.en: If you #dismiss# something, you decide or say that it is not important enough for you to think about or consider.
def.exmp: Mr Wakeham dismissed the reports as speculation. I would certainly dismiss any allegations of impropriety by the Labour Party. I wouldn't dismiss it out of hand. I dismissed him from my mind. 'It's been a lovely day,' she said, dismissing the episode. ...the power to dismiss civil servants who refuse to work. The military commander has been dismissed. Two more witnesses were called, heard and dismissed. The hired carriage was dismissed. An American judge yesterday dismissed murder charges against Dr Jack Kevorkian. ...their attempt to have the case against them dismissed.

def.en: A #disorder# is a problem or illness which affects someone's mind or body.
def.exmp: ...a rare nerve disorder that can cause paralysis of the arms. ...a psychiatrist who specialises in eating disorders. He appeared to be suffering from a severe mental disorder and had served a term in prison. The emergency room was in disorder. Inside all was disorder: drawers fallen out, shoes and boots scattered. He called on the authorities to stop public disorder. There are other forms of civil disorder–most notably, football hooliganism.

def.en: A # disorder# is a mental or physical illness which prevents part of your body from working properly.
def.exmp: Depending on the medical condition, the insurer may shorten the benefit period to compensate for the medical #disorder#. Sleep #disorders# have been linked to an increased risk of injury due to falls and car accidents. #A disorder# is a mental or physical illness which prevents part of your body from working properly.

def.en: When something #disperses# or when you #disperse# it, it spreads over a wide area.
def.exmp: The oil appeared to be dispersing. The intense currents disperse the sewage. Because the town sits in a valley, air pollution is not easily dispersed. Police fired shots and used teargas to disperse the demonstrators. The crowd dispersed peacefully after prayers.

def.en: #Disposal# is the act of getting rid of something that is no longer wanted or needed.
def.exmp: ...methods for the permanent disposal of radioactive wastes. ...waste disposal sites.

def.en: Someone's #disposition# is the way that they tend to behave or feel.
def.exmp: The rides are unsuitable for people of a nervous disposition. He was a man of decisive action and an adventurous disposition. ...his friendly and cheerful disposition. This has given him a disposition to consider our traditions critically. They show no disposition to improvise or to take risks. ...to understand the buildings from the disposition of walls and entrances. Judge Stacks was appointed to oversee the disposition of funds.

def.en: A #dispute# is an argument or disagreement between people or groups.
def.exmp: They have won previous pay disputes with the government. Negotiators failed to resolve the bitter dispute between the European Community and the United States over cutting subsides to farmers. He disputed the allegations. Nobody disputed that Davey was clever. Some economists disputed whether consumer spending is as strong as the figures suggest. Russia and Ukraine have been disputing the ownership of the fleet. Fishermen from Bristol disputed fishing rights with the Danes. ...a disputed border region.

def.en: If you #disregard# something, you ignore it or do not take account of it.
def.exmp: He disregarded the advice of his executives. Critics say he allowed the police and security forces to disregard human rights. Whoever planted the bomb showed a total disregard for the safety of the public.

def.en: If someone or something #disrupts# an event, system, or process, they cause difficulties that prevent it from continuing or operating in a normal way.
def.exmp: Anti-war protesters disrupted the debate. The drought has severely disrupted agricultural production.

def.en: When something #dissipates# or when you #dissipate# it, it becomes less or becomes less strong until it disappears or goes away completely.
def.exmp: The tension in the room had dissipated. He wound down the windows to dissipate the heat. ...heat dissipation. He is dissipating his time and energy on too many different things. Her father had dissipated her inheritance. ...the dissipation of my wealth.

def.en: If a substance #dissolves# in liquid or if you #dissolve# it, it becomes mixed with the liquid and disappears.
def.exmp: Heat gently until the sugar dissolves. Dissolve the salt in a little boiled water. The committee has been dissolved. The King agreed to dissolve the present commission. The present assembly will be dissolved on April 30th. Kaifu threatened to dissolve the Parliament and call an election. The marriage was dissolved in 1976. His new-found optimism dissolved. Lenny still could not dissolve the nagging lump of tension in his chest.

def.en: If something is #distinct# #from# something else of the same type, it is different or separate from it.
def.exmp: Engineering and technology are disciplines distinct from one another and from science. This book is divided into two distinct parts. ...a banking industry with two distinctly different sectors. ...to impart a distinct flavor with a minimum of cooking fat. I distinctly heard the loudspeaker calling passengers for the Turin-Amsterdam flight. Now that Tony was no longer present, there was a distinct change in her attitude. I have distinct memories of him in his last years. I distinctly remember wishing I had not got involved. Being 6ft 3in tall has some distinct disadvantages! Another Cup marathon between the two sides is now a distinct possibility. His government is looking distinctly shaky.

def.en: A #distinction# #between# similar things is a difference.
def.exmp: There are obvious distinctions between the two wine-making areas. The distinction between craft and fine art is more controversial. Lewis emerges as a composer of distinction and sensitivity. ...pieces of furniture of distinction. The order was created in 1902 as a special distinction for eminent men and women. I did an M.A. at Liverpool University in Latin American Studies and got a distinction. He has the distinction of being regarded as the Federal Republic's greatest living writer.

def.en: If you can #distinguish# one thing #from# another or #distinguish# #between# two things, you can see or understand how they are different.
def.exmp: Could he distinguish right from wrong? Research suggests that babies learn to see by distinguishing between areas of light and dark. It is necessary to distinguish the policies of two successive governments. There is something about music that distinguishes it from all other art forms. The bird has no distinguishing features. There were cries, calls. He could distinguish voices. Over the next few years he distinguished himself as a leading constitutional scholar. They distinguished themselves at the Battle of Assaye.

def.en: If you #distort# a statement, fact, or idea, you report or represent it in an untrue way.
def.exmp: The media distorts reality; categorises people as all good or all bad. The minister has said his remarks at the weekend have been distorted. These figures give a distorted view of the significance for the local economy. A painter may exaggerate or distort shapes and forms. His size was persistently distorted by the cartoonists. This caused the sound to distort. Sound was becoming more and more distorted through the use of hearing aids.

def.en: If something #distracts# you or your attention #from# something, it takes your attention away from it.
def.exmp: Tom admits that playing video games sometimes distracts him from his homework. Don't let yourself be distracted by fashionable theories. A disturbance in the street distracted my attention.

def.en: #Distress# is a state of extreme sorrow, suffering, or pain.
def.exmp: Jealousy causes distress and painful emotions. Her mouth grew stiff with pain and distress. He expressed concern that the ship might be in distress. The constable received a distress call, and saw two youths attacking his colleague. The idea of Toni being in danger distresses him enormously. I did not want to frighten or distress the horse.

def.en: A #district# is a particular area of a town or country.
def.exmp: I drove around the business district. ...Nashville's shopping district. ...a summer holiday hike in the Lake District. Varieties of these crops have been collected from all around the district. ...the home of the governor of the district. ...the continuing support of Glasgow District Council. ...the district health authority.

def.en: If you #disturb# someone, you interrupt what they are doing and upset them.
def.exmp: I hope I'm not disturbing you. Find a quiet, warm, comfortable room where you won't be disturbed. I dream about him, dreams so vivid that they disturb me for days. He had been disturbed by the news of the attack on Hector Coyne. He'd placed his notes in the brown envelope. They hadn't been disturbed. She patted Mona, taking care not to disturb her costume. Neither Baker nor Levy seemed eager to disturb the cordial atmosphere by discussing more sensitive issues. What could possibly disturb such tranquility?

def.en: A #disturbance# is an incident in which people behave violently in public.
def.exmp: During the disturbance which followed, three Englishmen were hurt. ...the worst of last September's disturbances. The home would cause less disturbance to local residents than a school. The animals are very sensitive to disturbance and have never bred in captivity. Poor educational performance is related to emotional disturbance. ...the treatment of certain heart rhythm disturbances.

def.en: A #ditch# is a long narrow channel cut into the ground at the side of a road or field.
def.exmp: I decided to ditch the sofa bed. Unpopular policies such as unilateral disarmament were ditched. I can't bring myself to ditch him and start again. One American pilot was forced to ditch his jet in the Gulf. A survivor was knocked unconscious when the helicopter ditched.

def.en: If you #dive# #into# some water, you jump in head-first with your arms held straight above your head.
def.exmp: He tried to escape by diving into a river. She was standing by a pool, about to dive in. Joanne had just learnt to dive. Pat had earlier made a dive of 80 feet from the Chasm Bridge. Bezanik is diving to collect marine organisms. This sighting occurred during my dive to a sunken wreck off Sardinia. ...a pelican which had just dived for a fish. The shark dived down and swam under the boat. He was killed when his monoplane stalled and dived into the ground. Witnesses said the plane failed to pull out of a dive and smashed down in a field. They dived into a taxi. The cashier dived for cover when a gunman opened fire. He would dive under one obstacle, round another, and lightly step over a third. He made a sudden dive for Uncle Jim's legs to try to trip him up. She dived into her bag and brought out a folded piece of paper. If we cut interest rates, the pound would dive. Profits have dived from £7.7m to £7.1m. The shares dived 22p to 338p. Stock prices took a dive. We've played in all the little pubs and dives around Liverpool.

def.en: If a group or range of things is #diverse#, it is made up of a wide variety of things.
def.exmp: ...shops selling a diverse range of gifts. Society is now much more diverse than ever before. Jones has a much more diverse and perhaps younger audience.

def.en: A #diversion# is an action or event that attracts your attention away from what you are doing or concentrating on.
def.exmp: The robbers threw smoke bombs to create a diversion. The whole argument is a diversion. Finger painting is very messy but an excellent diversion. They turned back because of traffic diversions. ...the illegal diversion of profits from secret arms sales. ...the diversion of a ship to Lebanon with $8m worth of aluminium on board.

def.en: To #divert# vehicles or travellers means to make them follow a different route or go to a different destination than they originally intended.
def.exmp: ...Rainham Marshes, east London, where a new bypass will divert traffic from the A13. During the strike, ambulances will be diverted to private hospitals. We diverted a plane to rescue 100 passengers. She insists on diverting to a village close to the airport. The capital remained jammed with diverted traffic. The government is trying to divert more public funds from west to east. ...government departments involved in diverting resources into community care. He instructed switchboard staff to divert all Laura's calls to him. Customers will only incur additional call charges if the call is diverted outside the U.K.. They want to divert the attention of the people from the real issues. The President needed to divert attention away from his own economic record.

def.en: A #dividend# is the part of a company's profits which is paid to people who have shares in the company.
def.exmp: The first quarter dividend has been increased by nearly 4 per cent.

def.en: A # dividend# is an amount of a company's profits that is paid to people who own shares in the company.
def.exmp: The first quarter #dividend# has been increased by nearly 4 percent. The company's acquisitions will eventually result in higher #dividends# for shareholders. A #dividend# is an amount of a company's profits that is paid to people who own shares in the company.

def.en: A # dividend# is a sum of money from a company's net profits that is distributed to the holders of certain insurance policies.
def.exmp: A mutual insurance company is owned by its policyholders, and returns part of its profits to the policyholders as #dividends#. #Dividends# are cash payments credited to whole life policies generally as a percentage of current cash value. A #dividend# is a sum of money from a company's net profits that is distributed to the holders of certain insurance policies.

def.en: You use #divine# to describe something that is provided by or relates to a god or goddess.
def.exmp: He suggested that the civil war had been a divine punishment. ...divine inspiration. The law was divinely ordained. 'Isn't it divine?' she said. 'I wish I had the right sort of brooch to lend you for it.'. Darling how lovely to see you, you look simply divine. ...divinely glamorous singer Jeffrey McDonald. ...the child's ability to divine the needs of its parents and respond to them. From this he divined that she did not like him much. The only reason I was divining for water was because of the drought. ...a divining rod.

def.en: If you feel #dizzy#, you feel that you are losing your balance and are about to fall.
def.exmp: Her head still hurt, and she felt slightly dizzy and disoriented. He began to get dizzy spells. Her head spins dizzily as soon as she sits up. His complaint causes dizziness and nausea. She is famed for playing dizzy blondes. ...a charmingly dizzy great-grandmother. The sudden height dizzied her and she clung tightly. We're descending now at dizzying speed.

def.en: A #dock# is an enclosed area in a harbour where ships go to be loaded, unloaded, and repaired.
def.exmp: ...the loading dock. She headed for the docks, thinking that Ricardo might be hiding in one of the boats. What other ships are in dock here? The vessel docked at Liverpool in April 1811. Russian commanders docked a huge aircraft carrier in a Russian port. The aircraft carrier has been docked there since last month. The space shuttle Atlantis is scheduled to dock with Russia's Mir space station. They have docked a robot module alongside the orbiting space station. The shuttle will spend five days docked with Mir. The truck left the loading dock with hoses still attached. He had a house there and a dock and a little aluminum boat. What about the odd chance that you do put an innocent man in the dock? He threatens to dock her fee. To dock points would be wrong.

def.en: A #doctorate# is the highest degree awarded by a university.
def.exmp: He obtained his doctorate in Social Psychology.

def.en: A #domain# is a particular field of thought, activity, or interest, especially one over which someone has control, influence, or rights.
def.exmp: ...the great experimenters in the domain of art. This information should be in the public domain. ...the mighty king's domain.

def.en: A #dome# is a round roof.
def.exmp: ...the dome of St Paul's cathedral. ...the dome of the hill.

def.en: #Domestic# political activities, events, and situations happen or exist within one particular country.
def.exmp: ...over 100 domestic flights a day to 15 U.K. destinations. ...sales in the domestic market. Opportunities will improve as the company expands domestically and internationally. Domestically, he's going to make some compromises that he doesn't want to make. ...a plan for sharing domestic chores. ...domestic appliances. It was a scene of such domestic bliss. I was called out to attend a domestic dispute. She was kind and domestic and put her family before her part-time job. ...a domestic cat.

def.en: Someone or something that is #dominant# is more powerful, successful, influential, or noticeable than other people or things.
def.exmp: ...a change which would maintain his party's dominant position in Scotland. She was a dominant figure in the French film industry. Because it is carried by a dominant gene, an affected individual can expect about half of his or her children to inherit the illness.

def.en: To #dominate# a situation means to be the most powerful or important person or thing in it.
def.exmp: The book is expected to dominate the best-seller lists. ...countries where life is dominated by war. No single factor appears to dominate. ...the domination of the market by a small number of organizations. He denied that his country wants to dominate Europe. Women are no longer dominated by the men in their relationships. The countries of Eastern Europe immediately started to dominate. They had five centuries of domination by the Romans. It's one of the biggest buildings in this area, and it really dominates this whole place. ...its skyline dominated by the central mosque.

def.en: A #donkey# is an animal which is like a horse but which is smaller and has longer ears.
#Doom# is a terrible future state or event which you cannot prevent.
def.exmp: ...his warnings of impending doom. ...a wicked mermaid who lured sailors to their doom. Why are people so full of gloom and doom? Attendance figures had been steadily dropping, creating a mood of doom and discouragement among theatre directors. That argument doomed their marriage to failure.

def.en: A #doorway# is a space in a wall where a door opens and closes.
def.exmp: Hannah looked up to see David and another man standing in the doorway. We were escorted through a low doorway. ...homeless people sleeping in shop doorways.

def.en: A #dorm# is the same as a dormitory.
A #dose# #of# medicine or a drug is a measured amount of it which is intended to be taken at one time.
def.exmp: One dose of penicillin can wipe out the infection. She was born with a healthy dose of self-confidence. The West is getting a heavy dose of snow and rain today. The doctor fixed the rib, dosed him heavily with drugs, and said he would probably get better. I dosed myself with quinine. I dosed him up with Valium.

def.en: A # dose# # of# medicine or a drug is a measured amount of it which is intended to be taken at one time.
def.exmp: One #dose# of penicillin can wipe out the infection. Try to take your daily #dose# of the medicine at the same time each day. #A dose# of medicine or a drug is a measured amount of it which is intended to be taken at one time.

def.en: A #dove# is a bird that looks like a pigeon but is smaller and lighter in colour.
def.exmp: A clear split over tactics appears to be emerging between doves and hawks in the party.

def.en: #Downtown# places are in or towards the centre of a large town or city, where the shops and places of business are.
def.exmp: ...an office in downtown Chicago. By day he worked downtown for American Standard. You have to be downtown in a hurry. ...in a large vacant area of the downtown. ...Ardastra Gardens, a short taxi ride from downtown.

def.en: When you #doze#, you sleep lightly or for a short period, especially during the daytime.
def.exmp: For a while she dozed fitfully. After lunch I had a doze.

def.en: A #draft# is an early version of a letter, book, or speech.
def.exmp: I rewrote his rough draft, which was published under my name. I faxed a first draft of this article to him. ...a draft report from a major U.S. university. ...a draft law. He drafted a standard letter to the editors. The legislation was drafted by House Democrats. During the Second World War, he was drafted into the U.S. Army. He wasn't drafted for the war; he volunteered for the Navy. Extra police have been drafted into the town after the violence. The manager will make a special plea to draft the player into his squad as a replacement. ...his effort to avoid the draft. The money was payable by a draft drawn by the home. Ten days later Carmen received a bank draft for a plane ticket.

def.en: If you #drain# a liquid from a place or object, you remove the liquid by causing it to flow somewhere else.
def.exmp: Miners built the tunnel to drain water out of the mines. Now the focus is on draining the water. Springs and rivers that drain into lakes carry dissolved nitrates and phosphates. The water slowly drained away, down through the porous soil. Vast numbers of people have been mobilised to drain flooded land. The soil drains freely and slugs aren't a problem. Drain the pasta well, arrange on four plates and pour over the sauce. Wash the leeks thoroughly and allow them to drain. Tony built his own house and laid his own drains. ...storm drains. Pamela drained her glass and refilled it. Harry felt the colour drain from his face. Thacker's face drained of colour. Jock's face had been suddenly drained of all colour. His usually florid complexion seemed drained of colour. And then, suddenly, the euphoria began to drain away. She felt the tension drain out of her. The happiness and the excitement had been drained completely from her voice. My emotional turmoil had drained me. United left the pitch looking stunned and drained. This work is physically exhausting and emotionally draining. As his energy drained away, his despair and worry grew. I can help resolve conflicts that drain energy. He could rest only when he was too drained of energy to fret further. ...an ultra-modern printing plant, which has been a big drain on resources. Fraud trials are often complex and have become an expensive drain on the public purse. The state's finances have been drained by war. The company has steadily drained its cash reserves.

def.en: A # drain# is a hole in a bathtub or sink that allows the water to flow away.
def.exmp: The shower #drain# is blocked with hair. The stopper for the #drain# of the sink is missing. Chambermaids put the plug in the #drain# to indicate that they have cleaned the room.

def.en: A #dramatic# change or event happens suddenly and is very noticeable and surprising.
def.exmp: A fifth year of drought is expected to have dramatic effects on the California economy. This policy has led to a dramatic increase in our prison populations. At speeds above 50mph, serious injuries dramatically increase. He witnessed many dramatic escapes as people jumped from as high as the fourth floor. Their arrival was dramatic and exciting. He tipped his head to one side and sighed dramatically. ...a dramatic arts major in college. I had no thoughts of making a dramatic film. I was working in documentary.

def.en: If you have to take #drastic# action in order to solve a problem, you have to do something extreme and basic to solve it.
def.exmp: Drastic measures are needed to clean up the profession. He's not going to do anything drastic about economic policy. Elderly people are not in a position to make drastic changes at this stage of their life. ...a drastic reduction in the numbers of people dying. As a result, services have been drastically reduced.

def.en: A #drawback# is an aspect of something or someone that makes them less acceptable than they would otherwise be.
def.exmp: He felt the apartment's only drawback was that it was too small.

def.en: If you #dread# something which may happen, you feel very anxious and unhappy about it because you think it will be unpleasant or upsetting.
def.exmp: I'm dreading Christmas this year. I dreaded coming back, to be honest. I suffer badly from cold sores and dread them appearing on my wedding day. I'd been dreading that the birth would take a long time. She thought with dread of the cold winters to come. ...a more effective national policy to combat this dread disease. ...the dread phrase 'politically correct'.

def.en: When something #drifts# somewhere, it is carried there by the movement of wind or water.
def.exmp: We proceeded to drift on up the river. The climbing balloon drifted silently over the countryside. The waves became rougher as they drifted. We need to offer young people drifting into crime an alternative set of values. She and her husband drifted apart and, eventually, they divorced. There is a general sense that the country and economy alike are drifting. You've been drifting from job to job without any real commitment. ...the drift towards the cities. As rural factories shed labour, people drift towards the cities. Cool summer dance sounds are drifting from the stereo indoors. The snow, except where it drifted, was only calf-deep. The storm caused severe drifting. ...the white and drifted snow. ...a nine-foot snow drift. There was a drift of smoke above the trees. Grace was beginning to get his drift. Anybody who's listening will get the drift of what he was saying. I follow the drift of her conversation.

def.en: A # drift# is the degree to which a wellbore is not vertical.
def.exmp: The #drift# is the inclination of the wellbore from the vertical at the point of reference. The extent to which the wellbore deviates from a truly vertical line is commonly called the #drift# of the well. #A drift# is the degree to which a wellbore is not vertical.

def.en: A #drill# is a tool or machine that you use for making holes.
def.exmp: ...pneumatic drills. ...a dentist's drill. He drilled into the wall of Lili's bedroom. I drilled five holes at equal distance. There have been proposals to drill for more oil. The team is still drilling. Drilling is due to start early next year. The teacher runs them through a drill–the days of the week, the weather and some counting. He drills the choir to a high standard. ...stimulation rather than repetitive drilling. The Marines carried out a drill that included 18 ships and 90 aircraft. His hands were clasped behind him like a drill sergeant. ...a fire drill. ...air-raid drills. ...cotton drill. Sow the seeds in drills about 1/2in. deep and 12in. apart.

def.en: To # drill# is to use a tool to make a hole for a well, with the aim of finding oil, gas, or water.
def.exmp: An infilling well is a well #drilled# between known producing wells to exploit the reservoir better. Natural gas wells are wells #drilled# specifically for natural gas, and contain little or no oil. To #drill# is to use a tool to make a hole for a well, with the aim of finding oil, gas, or water.

def.en: When liquid #drips# somewhere, or you #drip# it somewhere, it falls in individual small drops.
def.exmp: Sit your child forward and let the blood drip into a tissue or on to the floor. Amid the trees the sea mist was dripping. The children kept dripping Coke on the carpets. A tap in the kitchen was dripping. Lou was dripping with perspiration. He was holding a cloth that dripped pink drops upon the floor. Drips of water rolled down the trousers of his uniform. I had a bad attack of pneumonia and spent two days in hospital on a drip. They were dazed by window displays dripping with diamonds and furs. His voice was dripping with sarcasm.

def.en: A #drought# is a long period of time during which no rain falls.
def.exmp: Drought and famines have killed up to two million people here. He told a press conference that Spain was suffering one of the worst droughts of the century.

def.en: When someone #drowns# or #is drowned#, they die because they have gone or been pushed under water and cannot breathe.
def.exmp: Forty-eight people have drowned after their boat capsized during a storm. A child can drown in only a few inches of water. Last night a boy was drowned in the river. He walked into the sea and drowned himself. Dolphins have sometimes been known to save drowning swimmers. We were drowning in data but starved of information. ...people who gradually find themselves drowning in debt. The potatoes were drowned in chilli. Clapping drowned the speaker's words for a moment. The conversation was drowned by the arrival of the taxi. Their cheers drowned out the protests of demonstrators. Her voice was drowned out by a loud crash.

def.en: A #drum# is a musical instrument consisting of a skin stretched tightly over a round frame.
def.exmp: ...an oil drum. ...a drum of chemical waste. He had found a drum of electric cable. He drummed his fingers on the leather top of his desk. Rain drummed on the roof of the car.

def.en: A # drum# is a hollow rotating part in a steam turbine or an axial compressor (= a compressor in which gas flows parallel with the rotation of the axis).
def.exmp: The blades in a steam turbine are fastened to a cylindrical #drum#. A rotary filter consists of a cylindrical #drum# covered with a perforated sieve which supports a filter cloth. #A drum# is a hollow rotating part in a steam turbine or an axial compressor.

def.en: Someone who is #drunk# has drunk so much alcohol that they cannot speak clearly or behave sensibly.
def.exmp: Stewart could not remember exactly why he had done it because he was so drunk. I got drunk and had to be carried home. He was arrested on suspicion of drunk driving. A drunk lay in the alley. They are currently drunk with success. I felt drunk with the excitement of life.

def.en: If you describe something as #dubious#, you mean that you do not consider it to be completely honest, safe, or reliable.
def.exmp: This claim seems to us to be rather dubious. Soho was still a highly dubious area. Those figures alone are a dubious basis for such a conclusion. Carter was dubiously convicted of shooting three white men in a bar. My parents were dubious about it at first but we soon convinced them. He eyed Coyne dubiously. Nagy has the dubious honour of being the first athlete to be banned in this way. El Salvador has earned the dubious distinction of having the worst soil erosion in continental America.

def.en: If an event is #due to# something, it happens or exists as a direct result of that thing.
def.exmp: The country's economic problems are largely due to the weakness of the recovery. If the trip is a success, a lot of this will be due to Mr Green's efforts. Due to the large volume of letters he receives Dave regrets he is unable to answer queries personally. Jobs could be lost in the defence industry due to political changes sweeping Europe. The results are due at the end of the month. The first price increases are due to come into force in July. Jason is currently in Britain to finish recording his second album which is due out in May. Mr Carter is due in London on Monday. ...customers who paid later than twenty days after the due date. After due consideration it was decided to send him away to live with foster parents. I do hope that people will make use of footpaths and treat them with due attention that is needed. I was sent a cheque for £1,525 and advised that no further pension was due. I've got some leave due to me and I was going to Tasmania for a fortnight. He had not taken a summer holiday that year but had accumulated the leave due him. The deputy chief inspector rang me up and said, 'Miss Smith, you know you are due for a move?'. He is not due for release until 2020. I reckon I'm due one of my travels. Only 18 of the U.N.'s 180 members had paid their dues by the January deadline. They headed due north. The Thames flows due south from Oxford, through the market town of Abingdon. ...a mining town 40 miles due east of Los Angeles.

def.en: If you describe someone or something as #dull#, you mean they are not interesting or exciting.
def.exmp: They are both nice people but can be rather dull. I felt she found me boring and dull. The documentary lasts for more than two-and-a-half hours, and there is scarcely a dull minute. They enjoy anything that breaks the dullness of their routine life. The body's natural rhythms mean we all feel dull and sleepy between 1 and 3pm. His eyes looked dully ahead. Did you notice any unusual depression or dullness of mind? The stamp was a dull blue colour. The street lamps gleamed dully through the night's mist. It's always dull and raining. The long whining whistle of a shell was followed by the dull boom of the explosion. The coffin closed with a dull thud. He heard his heart thump dully but more quickly. The pain, usually a dull ache, gets worse with exercise. I realized with a kind of dull shock that I didn't recognize a single name. His arm throbbed dully. Her eyes dulled and she gazed blankly. He can dull your senses with facts and figures. Share prices and trading have been dulled by worries over the war.

def.en: Someone who is #dumb# is completely unable to speak.
def.exmp: ...a young deaf and dumb man. We were all struck dumb for a minute. I shook my head dumbly, not believing him. I've met a lot of dumb people. The questions were set up to make her look dumb. I came up with this dumb idea. It's the media that's dumb. An expression of dumb recognition wiggled across her features.

def.en: If you #dump# something somewhere, you put it or unload it there quickly and carelessly.
def.exmp: We dumped our bags at the nearby Grand Hotel and hurried towards the market. He got my haversack from the cab and dumped it at my feet. The getaway car was dumped near a motorway tunnel. A million tonnes of untreated sewage is dumped into the sea. The government declared that it did not dump radioactive waste at sea. German law forbids the dumping of hazardous waste on German soil. ...companies that bring their rubbish straight to the dump. The walled garden was used as a dump. 'What a dump!' Christabel said, standing in the doorway of the youth hostel. Ministers believed it was vital to dump the poll tax before the election. It produces more than it needs, then dumps its surplus onto the world market. I thought he was going to dump me for another girl. She was dumped by her long-term lover after five years. I suggested that we not only dump the two companies, but that we also should ditch any other business not involved in soft drinks. I was sometimes dumped with my grandmother or left with highly unsuitable au pairs. He can't cope and dumps his two teenage boys on them to be looked after. It can take a couple of hours to dump a thousand telephone numbers into a 128k EPROM pack. All the data is then dumped into the main computer. ...a screen dump. He was a nice guy, Mona. He didn't dump on me.

def.en: If you #duplicate# something that has already been done, you repeat or copy it.
def.exmp: His task will be to duplicate his success overseas here at home. Scientists hope the work done in collaboration with other researchers may be duplicated elsewhere. Charles scored again, with an exact duplicate of his first goal. She found Ned alone in the photocopy room, duplicating some articles. ...a business which duplicates video and cinema tapes for the movie makers. I'm on my way to Switzerland, but I've lost my card. I've got to get a duplicate. He let himself in with a duplicate key. ...a duplicate copy of the loan contract.

def.en: Something that is #durable# is strong and lasts a long time without breaking or becoming weaker.
def.exmp: Bone china is strong and durable. Airlines recommend hard-sided cases for durability.

def.en: The #duration# #of# an event or state is the time during which it happens or exists.
def.exmp: He was given the task of protecting her for the duration of the trial. Courses are of two years' duration.

def.en: #Dusk# is the time just before night when the daylight has almost gone but when it is not completely dark.
def.exmp: We arrived home at dusk. She turned and disappeared into the dusk.

def.en: If one person or thing #is dwarfed# by another, the second is so much bigger than the first that it makes them look very small.
def.exmp: His figure is dwarfed by the huge red McDonald's sign. The U.S. air travel market dwarfs that of Britain. ...a white dwarf star. ...a red dwarf. ...dwarf shrubs.

def.en: If you #dwell# #on# something, especially something unpleasant, you think, speak, or write about it a lot or for quite a long time.
def.exmp: I'd rather not dwell on the past. They are concerned for the fate of the forest and the Indians who dwell in it. Shiva is a dark god; he dwells in the mountains and deserts.

def.en: A #dwelling# or a #dwelling place# is a place where someone lives.
def.exmp: Some 3,500 new dwellings are planned for the area. We hiked the Grand Canyon, exploring Indian cliff dwellings.

def.en: If you #dye# something such as hair or cloth, you change its colour by soaking it in a special liquid.
def.exmp: The women prepared, spun and dyed the wool. She had dyed black hair. ...bottles of hair dye.

def.en: An #eagle# is a large bird that lives by eating small animals.
#Earnest# people are very serious and sincere in what they say or do, because they think that their actions and beliefs are important.
def.exmp: Ella was a pious, earnest woman. His expression is as earnest when he smiles as when he is arguing. Despite their earnest efforts, they still struggle to win support. He was admired by many for his earnestness.

def.en: If you talk about the #ease of# a particular activity, you are referring to the way that it has been made easier to do, or to the fact that it is already easy to do.
def.exmp: For ease of reference, only the relevant extracts of the regulations are included. ...the camera's ease of use in manual mode. She lived a life of ease. Tensions had eased. The heavily falling snow had eased. I gave him some brandy to ease the pain. ...editorials calling for the easing of sanctions. I eased my way towards the door. She eased back into the chair and nodded. He eased his foot off the accelerator. Leaphorn eased himself silently upward. I eased open the door.

def.en: #Easter# is a Christian festival when Jesus Christ's return to life is celebrated.
def.exmp: 'Happy Easter,' he yelled. ...the first Easter morning. They usually have a walking holiday at Easter. She spends her Easter holidays taking groups of children to France. The government declared Easter Monday a public holiday.

def.en: When the tide or the sea #ebbs#, its level gradually falls.
def.exmp: When the tide ebbs it's a rock pool inhabited by crustaceans. ...the spring ebb tide. We decided to leave on the ebb at six o'clock next morning. ...as a man's physical strength ebbs. Were there occasions when enthusiasm ebbed? His little girl's life ebbed away. Their popular support is ebbing away.

def.en: If you say that someone is #eccentric#, you mean that they behave in a strange way, and have habits or opinions that are different from those of most people.
def.exmp: He is an eccentric character who likes wearing a beret and dark glasses. ...Mr Thomas, a businessman with eccentric views. On first impressions it would be easy to dismiss Jonathan as an eccentric. The painters were eccentrically dressed.

def.en: An # eccentric# is any circular component of a vehicle that rotates around an off-center axis.
def.exmp: The slide valves were worked by #eccentrics#, rods, and rocking links. When the #eccentric# rotates, the rocker arm moves the diaphragm up and down. The top end of the lever is connected to the control rod and the center is mounted on an #eccentric#, which is rotated by the accelerator pedal.

def.en: An # eccentric# component of a vehicle rotates around an off-center axis.
An #echo# is a sound which is caused by a noise being reflected off a surface such as a wall.
def.exmp: He listened and heard nothing but the echoes of his own voice in the cave. His feet echoed on the bare board floor. The bang came suddenly, echoing across the buildings, shattering glass. The room echoed. The corridor echoed with the barking of a dozen dogs. ...the bare stone floors and the echoing hall. Many phrases in the last two chapters echo earlier passages. Their views often echo each other. 'That was a truly delicious piece of pork,' he said. 'Yes, wasn't it?' echoed Penelope. I hear an echo of the thinking that got us into this mess in the first place. Political attacks work only if they find an echo with voters. The accident has echoes of past disasters.
