Pinks and beiges were chosen to echo the colours of the ceiling. The old fable continues to echo down the centuries.

def.en: An #eclipse# #of# the sun is an occasion when the moon is between the Earth and the sun, so that for a short time you cannot see part or all of the sun.
def.exmp: ...an eclipse of the sun. ...the solar eclipse on May 21st. ...the total lunar eclipse on 10 December. The gramophone had been eclipsed by new technology such as the compact disc. Of course, nothing is going to eclipse winning the Olympic title.

def.en: #Ecology# is the study of the relationships between plants, animals, people, and their environment, and the balances between these relationships.
def.exmp: ...a senior lecturer in ecology. ...the ecology of the rocky Negev desert in Israel. ...the extinction of the marshes' unique ecology. Global ecological efforts can easily be at odds with local ecologies.

def.en: Something that is #economical# does not require a lot of money to operate.
def.exmp: ...plans to trade in their car for something smaller and more economical. It is more economical to wash a full load. Services could be operated more efficiently and economically. ...ideas for economical housekeeping. His gestures were economical, his words generally mild. Burn's novel, vividly and economically written, is a sombre reflection on fame and its cost.

def.en: #Economics# is the study of the way in which money, industry, and trade are organized in a society.
def.exmp: He gained a first class Honours degree in economics. He is regarded as a committed supporter of a radical free-market economics policy. ...the economics of the third world.

def.en: If something is #edible#, it is safe to eat and not poisonous.
def.exmp: ...edible fungi.

def.en: #Editorial# means involved in preparing a newspaper, magazine, or book for publication.
def.exmp: He has been on the editorial staff of 'Private Eye' since 1963. I went to the editorial board meetings when I had the time. Rosie Boycott was not involved editorially with Virago. We are not about to change our editorial policy. Editorially, they never really became a unique distinct product. In an editorial, The Independent suggests the victory could turn nasty.

def.en: Something that is #effective# works well and produces the results that were intended.
def.exmp: The project looks at how we could be more effective in encouraging students to enter teacher training. Simple antibiotics are effective against this organism. ...an effective public transport system. ...the team roles which you believe to be necessary for the team to function effectively. Services need to be more effectively organised than they are at present. ...the effectiveness of computers as an educational tool. They have had effective control of the area since the security forces left. ...a restructuring that would have resulted in an effective increase on one of their most popular excursion fares. The new rules will become effective in the next few days.

def.en: If you make an #effort# #to# do something, you try very hard to do it.
def.exmp: He made no effort to hide his disappointment. Finding a cure requires considerable time and effort. ...his efforts to reform Italian research. Despite the efforts of the United Nations, the problem of drug traffic continues to grow. But a concerted effort has begun to improve the quality of the urban air. She took a deep breath and sat up slowly and with great effort. With an effort she contained her irritation. ...a famine relief effort in Angola. Even carrying the camcorder while hiking in the forest was an effort.

def.en: If you #eject# someone #from# a place, you force them to leave.
def.exmp: Officials used guard dogs to eject the protesters. He was ejected from a restaurant. ...the ejection of hecklers from the meeting. He aimed his rifle, fired a single shot, then ejected the spent cartridge. The pilot ejected from the plane and escaped injury.

def.en: You use #elaborate# to describe something that is very complex because it has a lot of different parts.
def.exmp: ...an elaborate research project. ...an elaborate ceremony that lasts for eight days. ...elaborate efforts at the highest level to conceal the problem. ...an elaborate management training scheme for graduates. It was clearly an elaborately planned operation. He is known for his elaborate costumes. ...elaborately costumed dolls. His task was to elaborate policies which would make a market economy compatible with a clean environment. ...the plan elaborated by the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. ...the elaboration of specific policies and mechanisms. A spokesman declined to elaborate on a statement released late yesterday. Would you care to elaborate?

def.en: When time #elapses#, it passes.
def.exmp: Forty-eight hours have elapsed since his arrest.

def.en: #Elastic# is a rubber material that stretches when you pull it and returns to its original size and shape when you let it go.
def.exmp: ...a piece of elastic. ...my plaid Bermuda shorts with the elastic waist. Beat it until the dough is slightly elastic. ...an elastic rope. ...an elastic interpretation of the rules of boxing. If export and import demand is elastic, then the change in trade volumes will operate to remove the surplus.

def.en: Your #elbow# is the part of your arm where the upper and lower halves of the arm are joined.
def.exmp: He slipped and fell, badly bruising an elbow. They also claim that the security team elbowed aside a steward. Mr Smith elbowed me in the face. Brand elbowed his way to the centre of the group of bystanders. Non-state firms gradually elbow aside the inefficient state-owned ones. Environmental concerns will elbow their way right to the top of the agenda.

def.en: #The# #elder# #of# two people is the one who was born first.
def.exmp: ...his elder brother. ...the elder of her two daughters. The young have no respect for their elders. ...tribal elders. He is now an elder of the village church.

def.en: You use #elderly# as a polite way of saying that someone is old.
def.exmp: ...an elderly couple. Many of those most affected are elderly. The elderly are a formidable force in any election. Some of those artillery pieces look a little elderly.

def.en: When people #elect# someone, they choose that person to represent them, by voting for them.
def.exmp: The people of the Philippines have voted to elect a new president. Manchester College elected him Principal in 1956. The country is about to take a radical departure by electing a woman as its new president. ...the country's democratically elected president. Those electing to smoke will be seated at the rear. ...the date when the president-elect takes office.

def.en: If you describe a person or thing as #elegant#, you mean that they are pleasing and graceful in appearance or style.
def.exmp: Patricia looked beautiful and elegant as always. ...an elegant restaurant. ...Princess Grace's understated elegance. The furniture managed to combine practicality with elegance. ...a tall, elegantly dressed man with a mustache. The document impressed me with its elegant simplicity. ...an elegantly simple idea.

def.en: When someone or something achieves a more important rank or status, you can say that they #are elevated# #to# it.
def.exmp: He was elevated to the post of prime minister. The Prime Minister is known to favour the elevation of more women to the Cabinet. After his elevation to the papacy, he reigned for two years. Don't elevate your superiors to superstar status. Emotional stress can elevate blood pressure. ...overweight individuals who have elevated cholesterol levels. Jack elevated the gun at the sky.

def.en: An #elevator# is a device that carries people up and down inside buildings.
An # elevator# is a device that carries people or goods up and down inside tall buildings.
Someone who is #eligible# #to# do something is qualified or able to do it, for example because they are old enough.
def.exmp: Almost half the population are eligible to vote in today's election. You could be eligible for a university scholarship. The rules covering eligibility for benefits changed in the 1980s. He's the most eligible bachelor in Japan.

def.en: Someone who is # eligible# # for# something or # to do# something is qualified or allowed to do it.
To #eliminate# something, especially something you do not want or need, means to remove it completely.
def.exmp: The Sex Discrimination Act has not eliminated discrimination in employment. Academic departments are being eliminated. If you think you may be allergic to a food or drink, eliminate it from your diet. ...the prohibition and elimination of chemical weapons. I was eliminated from the 400 metres in the semi-finals. If you are eliminated in the show-jumping then you are out of the complete competition. He declared war on the government and urged right-wingers to eliminate their opponents. The radio station claimed that 87,000 'reactionaries' had been eliminated.

def.en: You can refer to the most powerful, rich, or talented people within a particular group, place, or society as the #elite#.
def.exmp: ...a government comprised mainly of the elite. We have a political elite in this country. ...the elite troops of the President's bodyguard.

def.en: Speech or writing that is #eloquent# is well expressed and effective in persuading people.
def.exmp: I heard him make a very eloquent speech at that dinner. ...the eloquence of his prose. Jan speaks eloquently about her art. He was eloquent about his love of books. ...one particularly eloquent German critic. I wish I'd had the eloquence of Helmut Schmidt.

def.en: #Elsewhere# means in other places or to another place.
def.exmp: Almost 80 percent of the state's residents were born elsewhere. They were living rather well, in comparison with people elsewhere in the world. But if you are not satisfied then go elsewhere. Until the doctor arrived from elsewhere on the ward, Amy was in charge.

def.en: If you #embark# #on# something new, difficult, or exciting, you start doing it.
def.exmp: He's embarking on a new career as a writer. The government embarked on a programme of radical economic reform. They travelled to Portsmouth, where they embarked on the battle cruiser HMS Renown. Bob ordered brigade HQ to embark. Embarkation was scheduled for just after 4 pm.

def.en: If something or someone #embarrasses# you, they make you feel shy or ashamed.
def.exmp: His clumsiness embarrassed him. It embarrassed him that he had no idea of what was going on. The Republicans are trying to embarrass the president by thwarting his economic program. The Government has been embarrassed by the affair.

def.en: An #embassy# is a group of government officials, headed by an ambassador, who represent their government in a foreign country.
def.exmp: The American Embassy has already complained. Mr Cohen held discussions at the embassy with one of the rebel leaders.

def.en: If an object #embeds# #itself# in a substance or thing, it becomes fixed there firmly and deeply.
def.exmp: One of the bullets passed through Andrea's chest before embedding itself in a wall. The fossils at Dinosaur Cove are embedded in hard sandstones. There is glass embedded in the cut. This agreement will be embedded in a state treaty to be signed soon. I think that hatred of the other is deeply embedded in our society.

def.en: To #embody# an idea or quality means to be a symbol or expression of that idea or quality.
def.exmp: Jack Kennedy embodied all the hopes of the 1960s. For twenty-nine years, Checkpoint Charlie embodied the Cold War. That stability was embodied in the Gandhi family. The proposal has been embodied in a draft resolution. U.K. employment law embodies arbitration and conciliation mechanisms for settling industrial disputes. ...In the British system the executive is supposedly embodied by the Crown and the legislative by Parliament

def.en: If you #embrace# someone, you put your arms around them and hold them tightly, usually in order to show your love or affection for them.
def.exmp: Penelope came forward and embraced her sister. At first people were sort of crying for joy and embracing each other. He threw his arms round her and they embraced passionately. ...a young couple locked in an embrace. He embraces the new information age. The new rules have been embraced by government watchdog organizations. The marriage signalled James's embrace of the Catholic faith. ...a theory that would embrace the whole field of human endeavour.

def.en: To #emerge# means to come out from an enclosed or dark space such as a room or a vehicle, or from a position where you could not be seen.
def.exmp: Richard was waiting outside the door as she emerged. The postman emerged from his van soaked to the skin. ...holes made by the emerging adult beetle. There is growing evidence that the economy is at last emerging from recession. ...their plans to emerge from bankruptcy by February of next year. ...the growing corruption that has emerged in the past few years. It soon emerged that neither the July nor August mortgage repayment had been collected. The emerging caution over numbers is perhaps only to be expected. Mr Shevardnadze emerged as a major figure in the reform movement. Vietnam has emerged as the world's third-biggest rice exporter. New leaders have emerged. ...the new republic that emerged in October 1917. ...the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.

def.en: If you #emigrate#, you leave your own country to live in another country.
def.exmp: He emigrated to Belgium. They planned to emigrate. ...the huge emigration of workers to the West.

def.en: An #eminent# person is well-known and respected, especially because they are good at their profession.
def.exmp: ...an eminent scientist.

def.en: If something #emits# heat, light, gas, or a smell, it produces it and sends it out by means of a physical or chemical process.
def.exmp: The new device emits a powerful circular column of light. ...the amount of carbon dioxide emitted. Polly blinked and emitted a long, low whistle.

def.en: #Empirical# evidence or study relies on practical experience rather than theories.
def.exmp: There is no empirical evidence to support his thesis. ...empirically based research. They approached this part of their task empirically.

def.en: If a place or object #is enclosed# by something, the place or object is inside that thing or completely surrounded by it.
def.exmp: The rules state that samples must be enclosed in two watertight containers. Enclose the pot in a clear polythene bag. The surrounding land was enclosed by an eight foot wire fence. ...the enclosed waters of the Baltic. I have enclosed a cheque for £10. He tore open the creamy envelope that had been enclosed in the letter. The enclosed leaflet shows how Service Care can ease all your worries.

def.en: An #enclosure# is an area of land that is surrounded by a wall or fence and that is used for a particular purpose.
def.exmp: This enclosure was so vast that the outermost wall could hardly be seen.

def.en: If you #encounter# problems or difficulties, you experience them.
def.exmp: Every day of our lives we encounter stresses of one kind or another. Environmental problems they found in Poland were among the worst they encountered. Did you encounter anyone in the building? Renata wrote him that she had encountered her long-estranged father. The author tells of a remarkable encounter with a group of South Vietnamese soldiers. ...a sexual encounter. ...his first serious encounter with alcohol.

def.en: An #encyclopedia# is a book or set of books in which facts about many different subjects or about one particular subject are arranged for reference, usually in alphabetical order.
You say that someone #is endowed# #with# a particular desirable ability, characteristic, or possession when they have it by chance or by birth.
def.exmp: You are endowed with wealth, good health and a lively intellect. Herbs have been used for centuries to endow a whole range of foods with subtle flavours. The ambassador has endowed a $1 million public-service fellowships program.

def.en: #Endurance# is the ability to continue with an unpleasant or difficult situation, experience, or activity over a long period of time.
def.exmp: The exercise obviously will improve strength and endurance. ...his powers of endurance.

def.en: If you #endure# a painful or difficult situation, you experience it and do not avoid it or give up, usually because you cannot.
def.exmp: The company endured heavy financial losses. ...unbearable pain, which they had to endure in solitude because not even the doctors could get near them. Somehow the language endures and continues to survive. ...the start of an enduring friendship.

def.en: If people in authority #enforce# a law or a rule, they make sure that it is obeyed, usually by punishing people who do not obey it.
def.exmp: Until now, the government has only enforced the ban with regard to American ships. The measures are being enforced by Interior Ministry troops. They struggled to limit the cost by enforcing a low-tech specification. David is now living in Beirut again after an enforced absence.

def.en: If you #engage in# an activity, you do it or are actively involved with it.
def.exmp: I have never engaged in the drug trade. You can engage in croquet on the south lawn. They never learned skills to engage the attention of the others. They tried to engage him in conversation. We want to engage recognized leaders in discussion. She found it hard to engage with office life. She had vowed to go out of her way to engage with the Irish people at local community level. And she, too, suffers from a lack of critical engagement with the literary texts. We engaged the services of a recognised engineer. He had been able to engage some staff. Press the lever until you hear the catch engage. ...a lesson in how to engage the four-wheel drive. It could engage the enemy beyond the range of hostile torpedoes.

def.en: If you # engage# a clutch or a gear, you put the mechanism into operation.
An #engagement# is an arrangement that you have made to do something at a particular time.
def.exmp: He had an engagement at a restaurant in Greek Street at eight. ...business-related social engagements. I've broken off my engagement to Arthur. Announcing our engagement was a relief. I felt our engagement was quite an unhappy time. The constitution prohibits them from military engagement on foreign soil.

def.en: To #enlighten# someone means to give them more knowledge and greater understanding about something.
def.exmp: A few dedicated doctors have fought for years to enlighten the profession. If you know what is wrong with her, please enlighten me. ...an enlightening talk on the work done at the animal park. It can be an enormously enlightening and exciting experience.

def.en: If you #inquire# about something, you ask for information about it.
def.exmp: 'Is something wrong?' he enquired. 'Who are you?' he enquired of the first man. I rang up to inquire about train times. He inquired whether there had been any messages for him. He was so impressed that he inquired the young shepherd's name. Inspectors were appointed to inquire into the affairs of the company.

def.en: To #enrich# something means to improve its quality, usually by adding something to it.
def.exmp: An extended family enriches life in many ways. It is important to enrich the soil prior to planting. ...nutrient-enriched water. He will drain, rather than enrich, the country. Those who know how to use the system can enrich themselves at the expense of the very people who work for those companies. It was actually used for enriching uranium to weapons-grade levels.

def.en: If one thing #entails# another, it involves it or causes it.
def.exmp: Such a decision would entail a huge political risk. The changed outlook entails higher economic growth than was previously assumed. The job of a choreologist entails teaching dancers the technique and performance of dance movements. I'll never accept parole because that entails me accepting guilt.

def.en: An #enterprise# is a company or business, often a small one.
def.exmp: There are plenty of small industrial enterprises. ...the integration of farming enterprises. ...the first Director of such a novel enterprise. Horse breeding is indeed a risky enterprise. He is still involved in voluntary work promoting local enterprise. ...a national program of subsidies to private enterprise. ...the spirit of enterprise worthy of a free and industrious people. ...the group's lack of enterprise.

def.en: #Enthusiasm# is great eagerness to be involved in a particular activity which you like and enjoy or which you think is important.
def.exmp: The lack of enthusiasm for unification among most West Germans fills him with disappointment. Their skill, enthusiasm and running has got them in the team. Draw him out about his current enthusiasms and future plans.

def.en: If you are #enthusiastic# #about# something, you show how much you like or enjoy it by the way that you behave and talk.
def.exmp: Tom was very enthusiastic about the place. Bob Dole seemed less than enthusiastic about the proposed move. He knew much about pictures and fine furniture, and was an enthusiastic gardener. The announcement was greeted enthusiastically.

def.en: If you #are entitled# #to# something, you have the right to have it or do it.
def.exmp: If the warranty is limited, the terms may entitle you to a replacement or refund. They are entitled to first class travel. There are 23 Clubs throughout the U.S., and your membership entitles you to enjoy all of them. Chomsky's review is entitled 'Psychology and Ideology'. ...a performance entitled 'United States'.

def.en: An #entity# is something that exists separately from other things and has a clear identity of its own.
def.exmp: ...the earth as a living entity. North and South will remain separate entities within a commonwealth until the year 2000.

def.en: An # entity# is a business organization such as a corporation or partnership.
def.exmp: The company disclosed that it intends to convert its Information Systems subsidiary into a separate public #entity#. For shareholders, the benefits will accrue only if the company is divided into 2 separate #entities#. #An entity# is a business organization such as a corporation or partnership.

def.en: An #entrepreneur# is a person who sets up businesses and business deals.
An #envelope# is the rectangular paper cover in which you send a letter to someone through the post.
If you #envisage# something, you imagine that it is true, real, or likely to happen.
def.exmp: He envisages the possibility of establishing direct diplomatic relations in the future. He had never envisaged spending the whole of his working life in that particular job. Personally, I envisage them staying together.

def.en: If there is an #epidemic# #of# a particular disease somewhere, it affects a very large number of people there and spreads quickly to other areas.
def.exmp: A flu epidemic is sweeping through Moscow. ...a killer epidemic of yellow fever. ...an epidemic of serial killings. Drug experts say it could spell the end of the crack epidemic.

def.en: You can refer to an event or a short period of time as an #episode# if you want to suggest that it is important or unusual, or has some particular quality.
def.exmp: This episode is bound to be a deep embarrassment for Washington. Unfortunately it was a rather sordid episode of my life. The final episode will be shown next Sunday. ...people who'd suffered a third episode of depression in two years. The new drug lessens the severity of pneumonia episodes.

def.en: If you refer to a long period of time as an #epoch#, you mean that important events or great changes took place during it.
def.exmp: The birth of Christ was the beginning of a major epoch of world history. Two main glacial epochs affected both areas during the last 100 million years of Precambrian times.

def.en: An #equation# is a mathematical statement saying that two amounts or values are the same, for example 6x4=12x2.
def.exmp: The equation is simple: research breeds new products. The party fears the equation between higher spending and higher taxes. New plans have taken chance out of the equation.

def.en: #The equator# is an imaginary line around the middle of the Earth at an equal distance from the North Pole and the South Pole.
If one amount or value is #the# #equivalent# #of# another, they are the same.
def.exmp: The equivalent of two tablespoons of polyunsaturated oils is ample each day. Even the cheapest car costs the equivalent of 70 years' salary for a government worker. A unit is equivalent to a glass of wine or a single measure of spirits. They will react with hostility to the price rises and calls for equivalent wage increases are bound to be heard. ...the civil administrator of the West Bank and his equivalent in Gaza. ...the Red Cross emblem, and its equivalent in Muslim countries, the Red Crescent. ...a decrease of 10% in property investment compared with the equivalent period in 1991. His party has just suffered the equivalent of a near-fatal heart attack.

def.en: You can refer to a period of history or a long period of time as an #era# when you want to draw attention to a particular feature or quality that it has.
def.exmp: ...the nuclear era. ...the Reagan-Bush era. It was an era of austerity.

def.en: If people #erect# something such as a building, bridge, or barrier, they build it or create it.
def.exmp: Opposition demonstrators have erected barricades in roads leading to the parliament building. The building was erected in 1900-1901. We all unconsciously erect barriers against intimacy. Japanese proprietors are erecting a complex infrastructure of political influence throughout America. He erected a new doctrine of precedent. ...the whole edifice of free trade which has been erected since the Second World War. Stand reasonably erect, your arms hanging naturally. Her head was erect and her back was straight. ...the short, stiff, erect stems of almost bead-like blue flowers.

def.en: #Erosion# is the gradual destruction and removal of rock or soil in a particular area by rivers, the sea, or the weather.
def.exmp: As their roots are strong and penetrating, they prevent erosion. ...erosion of the river valleys. ...soil erosion. ...the erosion of confidence in world financial markets. ...an erosion of presidential power. ...the erosion of moral standards. ...a dramatic erosion of support for the program.

def.en: Beliefs, opinions, or methods that are #erroneous# are incorrect or only partly correct.
def.exmp: Some people have the erroneous notion that one can contract AIDS by giving blood. They have arrived at some erroneous conclusions. It had been widely and erroneously reported that Armstrong had refused to give evidence.

def.en: If a bad situation #escalates# or if someone or something #escalates# it, it becomes greater in size, seriousness, or intensity.
def.exmp: Both unions and management fear the dispute could escalate. The protests escalated into five days of rioting. Defeat could cause one side or other to escalate the conflict. The threat of nuclear escalation remains. ...a sudden escalation of violence.

def.en: An #escort# is a person who travels with someone in order to protect or guard them.
def.exmp: He arrived with a police escort shortly before half past nine. My sister needed an escort for a company dinner. I escorted him to the door. The vessel was escorted to an undisclosed port.

def.en: An #essay# is a short piece of writing on one particular subject written by a student.
def.exmp: We asked Jason to write an essay about his hometown and about his place in it. ...Thomas Malthus's essay on population. Sinclair essayed a smile but it could hardly have been rated as a success. His first essay in running a company was a notoriously tough undertaking.

def.en: The #essence# #of# something is its basic and most important characteristic which gives it its individual identity.
def.exmp: The essence of consultation is to listen to, and take account of, the views of those consulted. ...the essence of life. Others claim that Ireland's very essence is expressed through the language. ...a few drops of vanilla essence. ...exotic bath essences.

def.en: Something that is #essential# is extremely important or absolutely necessary to a particular subject, situation, or activity.
def.exmp: It was absolutely essential to separate crops from the areas that animals used as pasture. As they must also sprint over short distances, speed is essential. Jordan promised to trim the city budget without cutting essential services. The flat contained the basic essentials for bachelor life. Most authorities agree that play is an essential part of a child's development. In this trial two essential elements must be proven: motive and opportunity. ...the essentials of everyday life, such as eating and exercise. This has stripped the contest down to its essentials. ...the bare essentials.

def.en: An #estate# is a large area of land in the country which is owned by a person, family, or organization.
def.exmp: ...a shooting party on Lord Wyville's estate in Yorkshire. He used to live on the estate. His estate was valued at $150,000.

def.en: A person's # estate# is their property and money, especially everything that is left after they die.
def.exmp: A personal representative is appointed through the will of a deceased or by a court to settle the #estate# of someone who dies. A certified legal document, known as probate, must be in place to prove that a will is valid, thus allowing an executor to administer the #estate# of the deceased. A person's #estate# is their property and money, especially everything that is left after they die.

def.en: #Esteem# is the admiration and respect that you feel towards another person.
def.exmp: He is held in high esteem by colleagues in the construction industry. Their public esteem has never been lower. He said he retained immense regard and esteem for the prime minister. I greatly esteem your message in the midst of our hard struggle.

def.en: Something that is #eternal# lasts for ever.
def.exmp: Whoever believes in Him shall have eternal life. ...the quest for eternal youth. She is eternally grateful to her family for their support. The whole universe exists eternally in that one infinite being. In the background was that eternal hum. ...the eternal truths of the Indian subcontinent. ...the eternal question.

def.en: #Ethnic# means connected with or relating to different racial or cultural groups of people.
def.exmp: ...a survey of Britain's ethnic minorities. ...ethnic tensions. ...a predominantly young, ethnically mixed audience. There are still several million ethnic Germans in Russia. ...a large ethnically Albanian population. ...the original flavours of ethnic dishes. ...a magnificent range of ethnic fabrics.

def.en: To #evacuate# someone means to send them to a place of safety, away from a dangerous building, town, or area.
def.exmp: They were planning to evacuate the seventy American officials still in the country. Since 1951, 18,000 people have been evacuated from the area. ...the evacuation of the sick and wounded. An evacuation of the city's four-million inhabitants is planned for later this week. The fire is threatening about sixty homes, and residents have evacuated the area. Officials ordered the residents to evacuate. ...the mass evacuation of the Bosnian town of Srebrenica. Burning sulfur from the wreck has forced evacuations from the area.

def.en: If you #evade# something, you find a way of not doing something that you really ought to do.
def.exmp: By his own admission, he evaded taxes as a Florida real-estate speculator. Delegates accused them of trying to evade responsibility for the failures of the past five years. Mr Portillo denied he was evading the question. Too many companies, she says, are evading the issue. Under the pretence of lighting a candle, she evades him and disappears. She turned and gazed at the river, evading his eyes. He managed to evade capture because of the breakdown of a police computer. Happiness, which had been so elusive in Henry's life, still evaded him. When she sat down at her desk she found that the words evaded her.

def.en: If you #evaluate# something or someone, you consider them in order to make a judgment about them, for example about how good or bad they are.
def.exmp: They will first send in trained nurses to evaluate the needs of the individual situation. The market situation is difficult to evaluate. ...the opinions and evaluations of college supervisors. Evaluation is standard practice for all training arranged through the school.

def.en: When a liquid #evaporates#, or #is evaporated#, it changes from a liquid state to a gas, because its temperature has increased.
def.exmp: Moisture is drawn to the surface of the fabric so that it evaporates. The water is evaporated by the sun. High temperatures also result in high evaporation from the plants. The soothing, cooling effect is caused by the evaporation of the sweat on the skin. My anger evaporated and I wanted to cry. Your dreams always seem to evaporate, and nothing ever quite matches expectations. The project evaporated and Harry was left high and dry.

def.en: #The# #eve# #of# a particular event or occasion is the day before it, or the period of time just before it.
def.exmp: ...on the eve of his 27th birthday.

def.en: #Evidence# is anything that you see, experience, read, or are told that causes you to believe that something is true or has really happened.
def.exmp: Ganley said he'd seen no evidence of widespread fraud. There is a lot of evidence that stress is partly responsible for disease. To date there is no evidence to support this theory. The evidence against him was purely circumstantial. ...enough evidence for a successful prosecution. He's wise in other ways too, as evidenced by his reason for switching from tennis to golf. She was not calculating and evidenced no specific interest in money.

def.en: If something is #evident#, you notice it easily and clearly.
def.exmp: His footprints were clearly evident in the heavy dust. The threat of inflation is already evident in bond prices. ...the best-publicised cases of evident injustice. It was evident that she had once been a beauty. The cities are bombarded day after day in an evident effort to force their surrender.

def.en: When animals or plants #evolve#, they gradually change and develop into different forms.
def.exmp: The bright plumage of many male birds has evolved to attract females. Maize evolved from a wild grass in Mexico. ...when amphibians evolved into reptiles. ...a tiny airline which eventually evolved into Pakistan International Airlines. Popular music evolved from folk songs. As medical knowledge evolves, beliefs change. This was when he evolved the working method from which he has never departed.

def.en: If you #exaggerate#, you indicate that something is, for example, worse or more important than it really is.
def.exmp: He thinks I'm exaggerating. Don't exaggerate. Sheila admitted that she did sometimes exaggerate the demands of her job. Like many stories about him, it smacks of exaggeration. It would be an exaggeration to call the danger urgent. These figures exaggerate the loss of competitiveness. The dress exaggerates her wasp waist and enlarges her bosom.

def.en: If something #exceeds# a particular amount or number, it is greater or larger than that amount or number.
def.exmp: Its research budget exceeds $700 million a year. The demand for places at some schools exceeds the supply. His performance exceeded all expectations. He accepts he was exceeding the speed limit. I would be exceeding my powers if I ordered the march to be halted.

def.en: #Exceedingly# means very or very much.
def.exmp: We had an exceedingly good lunch. This was an exceedingly difficult decision to take. I have a case that troubles me exceedingly.

def.en: If someone #excels# #in# something or #excels# #at# it, they are very good at doing it.
def.exmp: Caine has always been an actor who excels in irony. Mary was a better rider than either of them and she excelled at outdoor sports. Academically he began to excel. I think Krishnan excelled himself in all departments of his game.

def.en: You use #exceptional# to describe someone or something that has a particular quality, usually a good quality, to an unusually high degree.
def.exmp: ...children with exceptional ability. His translation is exceptional in its poetic quality. He's an exceptionally talented dancer. The conditions under ground were exceptionally hot. ...if the courts hold that this case is exceptional. School governors have the discretion to allow parents to withdraw pupils in exceptional circumstances. Exceptionally, in times of emergency, we may send a team of experts. At your request we may agree, exceptionally, to work outside usual working hours.

def.en: An #excerpt# is a short piece of writing or music which is taken from a larger piece.
def.exmp: ...an excerpt from Tchaikovsky's Nutcracker. The readings you heard earlier were excerpted from a new oral history of Pearl Harbor.

def.en: An #excess# #of# something is a larger amount than is needed, allowed, or usual.
def.exmp: An excess of house plants in a small flat can be oppressive. Polyunsaturated oils are essential for health. Excess is harmful, however. After cooking the fish, pour off any excess fat. The major reason for excess weight is excess eating. She said she was sick of her life of excess. ...adolescent excess. ...the bloody excesses of warfare and empire-building. ...a letter demanding an excess fare of £20. Staff who have to travel farther can claim excess travel expenses. The company wanted £1,800 for a policy with a £400 excess for under-21s.

def.en: # Excess# is a stated contribution towards the cost of a claim that the policyholder has to pay.
def.exmp: The #excess# is the lump sum that you pay in the event of an accident. As a bigger #excess# reduces the financial risk carried by your insurer, your insurer is able to offer you a significantly lower premium. #Excess# is a stated contribution towards the cost of a claim that the policyholder has to pay.

def.en: If you describe the amount or level of something as #excessive#, you disapprove of it because it is more or higher than is necessary or reasonable.
def.exmp: ...the alleged use of excessive force by police. The government says that local authority spending is excessive. Managers are also accused of paying themselves excessively high salaries. Mum had started taking pills and drinking excessively.

def.en: Writers sometimes use #exclaim# to show that someone is speaking suddenly, loudly, or emphatically, often because they are excited, shocked, or angry.
def.exmp: 'He went back to the lab,' Iris exclaimed impatiently. He exclaims that it must be a typing error.

def.en: If you #exclude# someone #from# a place or activity, you prevent them from entering it or taking part in it.
def.exmp: The Academy excluded women from its classes. The army should be excluded from political life. Many of the youngsters feel excluded. They eat only plant foods, and take care to exclude animal products from other areas of their lives. In some schools, Christmas carols are being modified to exclude any reference to Christ. I cannot entirely exclude the possibility that some form of pressure was applied to the neck. ...the pathological evidence, which does not exclude suicide. This was intended to exclude the direct rays of the sun. They have spent $3 million building fences around the National Park to exclude such pests.

def.en: If you describe something as #exclusive#, you mean that it is limited to people who have a lot of money or who belong to a high social class, and is therefore not available to everyone.
def.exmp: He is already a member of Britain's most exclusive club. The City was criticised for being too exclusive and uncompetitive. ...a rising middle class, which objected to the exclusiveness of the traditional elite. ...a company with a reputation for exclusivity. Our group will have exclusive use of a 60-foot boat. Many of their cheeses are exclusive to our stores in Britain. Only 250 are to be sold in Europe, so exclusivity is guaranteed. He told the magazine in an exclusive interview: 'All my problems stem from drink'. Some papers thought they had an exclusive. All charges for service are exclusive of value added tax. Skiing weekends cost £58 (exclusive of travel and accommodation).

def.en: You can refer to a short journey as an #excursion#, especially if it is made for pleasure or enjoyment.
def.exmp: In Bermuda, Sam's father took him on an excursion to a coral barrier. We also recommend a full day optional excursion to the Upper Douro. Another pleasant excursion is Malaga, 18 miles away. ...Radio 3's latest excursion into ethnic music, dance and literature. The few excursions into stylistic experiment do not entirely come off.

def.en: To #execute# someone means to kill them as a punishment for a serious crime.
def.exmp: He was executed by lethal injection earlier today. One group claimed to have executed the American hostage. This boy's father had been executed for conspiring against the throne. Execution by lethal injection is scheduled for July 30th. We are going to execute our campaign plan to the letter. U.S. forces are fully prepared for the execution of any action once the order is given by the president. I executed the hairpin turn high on the sheer western face of the mountains. The landing was skilfully executed. Morris executed a suite of twelve drawings in 1978. A well-executed shot of a tall ship is a joy to behold. The ideas in the show's presentation were good, but failed in execution.

def.en: An #executive# is someone who is employed by a business at a senior level.
def.exmp: ...an advertising executive. ...Her husband is a senior bank executive. A successful job search needs to be as well organised as any other executive task. I don't envisage I will take an executive role, but rather become a consultant on merchandise and marketing. ...an executive briefcase. ...a chain of shops specialising in pricey executive toys. ...executive cars. He sits on the executive committee that manages Lloyds. Some executive members have called for his resignation. ...the executive of the National Union of Students. The government, the executive and the judiciary are supposed to be separate. The matter should be resolved by the executive branch of government.

def.en: If a person or thing #exemplifies# something such as a situation, quality, or class of things, they are a typical example of it.
def.exmp: The room's style exemplifies Conran's ideal of 'beauty and practicality'. ...the emotional expressiveness of modern dance as exemplified by the work of Martha Graham.

def.en: If someone or something is #exempt# #from# a particular rule, duty, or obligation, they do not have to follow it or do it.
def.exmp: Men in college were exempt from military service. Children under two years are exempt. The fund was in danger of losing its tax-exempt status. South Carolina claimed the power to exempt its citizens from the obligation to obey federal law. Companies with fifty-five or fewer employees would be exempted from the requirements. ...the exemption of employer-provided health insurance from taxation. ...new exemptions for students and the low-paid.

def.en: If someone or something #exerts# influence, authority, or pressure, they use it in a strong or determined way, especially in order to produce a particular effect.
def.exmp: He exerted considerable influence on the thinking of the scientific community on these issues. The cyst was causing swelling and exerting pressure on her brain. Youngsters get so absorbed that they don't realise how much they're exerting themselves. Do not exert yourself unnecessarily. He clearly found the physical exertion exhilarating. Thanks to the exertions of a few sensible and courageous men, the compromise was accepted.

def.en: If something #exhausts# you, it makes you so tired, either physically or mentally, that you have no energy left.
def.exmp: Don't exhaust him. He took to walking long distances in an attempt to physically exhaust himself. She was too exhausted and distressed to talk about the tragedy. It was an exhausting schedule she had set herself. We have exhausted all our material resources. They said that food supplies were almost exhausted. She and Chantal must have exhausted the subject of babies and clothes. ...the exhaust from a car engine. The city's streets are filthy and choked with exhaust fumes. ...the concentration of car exhausts in the Los Angeles area.

def.en: The # exhaust# of an engine consists of the waste gas that leaves it.
def.exmp: Notice the #exhaust# fumes coming from the back of the car. The four-stroke engine uses the piston's motion to draw in fuel and air and to force out the #exhaust# gasses. The #exhaust# of an engine consists of the waste gas that leaves it.

def.en: If someone is living #in# #exile#, they are living in a foreign country because they cannot live in their own country, usually for political reasons.
def.exmp: He is now living in exile in Egypt. He returned from exile earlier this year. ...after nearly six years of exile. During his exile, he also began writing books. His second wife, Hilary, had been widowed, then exiled from South Africa. They threatened to exile her in southern Spain. ...Haiti's exiled president. He has been exiled from the first team and forced to play in third team matches. Michael was exiled to the kitchen for supper. Rovers lost 4-1 and began their long exile from the First Division.

def.en: Something that is #exotic# is unusual and interesting, usually because it comes from or is related to a distant country.
def.exmp: ...brilliantly coloured, exotic flowers. She flits from one exotic location to another. ...exotically beautiful scenery.

def.en: An #expedition# is an organized journey that is made for a particular purpose such as exploration.
def.exmp: ...Byrd's 1928 expedition to Antarctica. Forty-three members of the expedition were killed. Caroline joined them on the shopping expeditions. ...a fishing expedition.

def.en: If someone #is expelled# #from# a school or organization, they are officially told to leave because they have behaved badly.
def.exmp: More than five-thousand secondary school students have been expelled for cheating. ...a boy expelled from school for making death threats to his teacher. An American academic was expelled from the country yesterday. They were told at first that they should simply expel the refugees. Daily brushing of the skin helps the skin expel toxins. As the lungs exhale this waste, gas is expelled into the atmosphere.

def.en: To #expend# something, especially energy, time, or money, means to use it or spend it.
def.exmp: Children expend a lot of energy and may need more high-energy food than adults.

def.en: #Expenditure# is the spending of money on something, or the money that is spent on something.
def.exmp: Policies of tax reduction must lead to reduced public expenditure. They should cut their expenditure on defence. An expenditure for clothing will qualify as a trade or business expense. The financial rewards justified the expenditure of effort.

def.en: #Expense# is the money that something costs you or that you need to spend in order to do something.
def.exmp: He's bought a specially big TV at vast expense so that everyone can see properly. To avoid extra expense and mess later on, try to decide on fittings before the plastering's finished. It was not a fortune but would help to cover household expenses. As a member of the International Olympic Committee her fares and hotel expenses were paid by the IOC. Can you claim this back on expenses?

def.en: If you # expense# an item, you treat it as an expense for bookkeeping or tax purposes.
def.exmp: Borrowing is not the only way to shield income against tax. Investment in many intangible assets can be #expensed# immediately. Research and development expenditures, including engineering costs, are #expensed# when incurred and amounted to $258.6 million in 2010. If you #expense# an item, you treat it as an expense for bookkeeping or tax purposes.

def.en: An # expense# is a cost involved in doing business.
def.exmp: All income and #expenses# must be itemized on the balance sheet. There are some doubts among the banks whether the company has enough cash flow to cover the heavy interest #expenses# from the acquisition. #An expense# is a cost involved in doing business.

def.en: If something is #expensive#, it costs a lot of money.
def.exmp: Wine's so expensive in this country. I get very nervous because I'm using a lot of expensive equipment. She was expensively dressed, with fine furs and jewels. They do a third-rate job very expensively.

def.en: An #experiment# is a scientific test which is done in order to discover what happens to something in particular conditions.
def.exmp: The astronauts are conducting a series of experiments to learn more about how the body adapts to weightlessness. ...a proposed new law on animal experiments. This question can be answered only by experiment. In 1857 Mendel started experimenting with peas in his monastery garden. The scientists have experimented on the tiny neck arteries of rats. The scientists have already experimented at each other's test sites. ...the ethical aspects of animal experimentation. When the experimenters repeated the tests on themselves, they observed an exactly opposite effect. As an experiment, we bought Ted a watch. ...the country's five year experiment in democracy. She needs plenty of room for experiment in her life. ...if you like cooking and have the time to experiment. He believes that students should be encouraged to experiment with bold ideas. Decentralization and experimentation must be encouraged. His stories about his sexual experimentation were more bravado than fact.

def.en: Something that is #experimental# is new or uses new ideas or methods, and might be modified later if it is unsuccessful.
def.exmp: ...an experimental air conditioning system. He tends to write bizarre and highly experimental pieces of music. The technique is experimental, but the list of its practitioners is growing. ...the main techniques of experimental science. ...the use of experimental animals. We have experimental and observational evidence concerning things which happened before and after the origin of life. ...an ecology laboratory, where communities of species can be studied experimentally under controlled conditions. The British Sports Minister is reported to be ready to argue for an experimental lifting of the ban. This system is being tried out experimentally at many universities. Before opening the front door he lifted the cases experimentally.

def.en: #Expertise# is special skill or knowledge that is acquired by training, study, or practice.
def.exmp: The problem is that most local authorities lack the expertise to deal sensibly in this market.

def.en: When something such as a contract, deadline, or visa #expires#, it comes to an end or is no longer valid.
def.exmp: He had lived illegally in the United States for five years after his visitor's visa expired. He endured excruciating agonies before he finally expired.

def.en: If an insurance policy # expires#, it is no longer valid.
def.exmp: At the end of the mortgage period the decreasing term insurance #expires#, leaving the base policy still in force. A renewal policy will be issued to replace #an expiring# policy. If an insurance policy #expires#, it is no longer valid.

def.en: Something that is #explicit# is expressed or shown clearly and openly, without any attempt to hide anything.
def.exmp: ...sexually explicit scenes in films and books. ...explicit references to age in recruitment advertising. The play was the first commercially successful work dealing explicitly with homosexuality. Their intention is not to become involved in explicitly political activities. When the book was published, the energy and explicitness caught the popular imagination. He was explicit about his intention to overhaul the party's internal voting system. She has been talking very explicitly about AIDS to these groups.

def.en: If you say that someone #is exploiting# you, you think that they are treating you unfairly by using your work or ideas and giving you very little in return.
def.exmp: Critics claim he exploited black musicians for personal gain. ...the plight of the exploited sugar cane workers. Extra payments should be made to protect the interests of the staff and prevent exploitation. The government and its opponents compete to exploit the troubles to their advantage. ...the exploitation of the famine by local politicians. You'll need a good aerial to exploit the radio's performance. Cary is hoping to exploit new opportunities in Europe. So you feel that your skills have never been fully appreciated or exploited? I think we're being very short sighted in not exploiting our own coal. ...the planned exploitation of its potential oil and natural gas reserves. His wartime exploits were later made into a film.

def.en: An #explosion# is a sudden, violent burst of energy, for example one caused by a bomb.
def.exmp: After the second explosion, all of London's main train and subway stations were shut down. Three people have been killed in a bomb explosion in northwest Spain. Bomb disposal experts blew up the bag in a controlled explosion. France has carried out an underground nuclear explosion on Mururoa Atoll in the South Pacific. The study also forecast an explosion in the diet soft-drink market. He explains that there was an explosion of courses through the 1960s. The spread of the suburbs has triggered a population explosion among America's deer. Every time they met, Myra anticipated an explosion. It was an explosion of anger against the practices of the occupying forces. They warned him that a referendum might cause an explosion in the country. ...the explosion of protest and violence sparked off by the killing of seven workers. There was an explosion of music.

def.en: An # explosion# is a very rapid combustion, with a sudden loud noise, that is damaging to internal combustion engines.
def.exmp: Ignition of unburned residual mixture is not likely to be the cause of #an explosion# in an engine cylinder. Excessive heating of the fuel, due to gasoline pipes being too near the engine, was the cause of the #explosion#. The loud knocking noise was due to a violent #explosion# in one of the engine's cylinders.

def.en: An # explosion# happens when a free gas expands very quickly, because of a chemical reaction that produces a gas, or because a container of pressurized gas ruptures.
def.exmp: If the oil has a high enough vapor pressure, a match could light the vapor before it reached the wick, possibly causing #an explosion#. #An explosion# is a sudden catastrophic release of energy, causing a pressure wave. #An explosion# happens when a free gas expands very quickly, because of a chemical reaction that produces a gas, or because a container of pressurized gas ruptures.

def.en: An #explosive# is a substance or device that can cause an explosion.
def.exmp: ...one-hundred-and-fifty pounds of Semtex explosive. There were traces of explosives in the bedroom. The explosive device was timed to go off at the rush hour. Highly explosive gas is naturally found in coal mines. Hydrogen is explosively flammable when mixed with oxygen. The explosive growth in casinos is one of the most conspicuous signs of Westernisation. These transactions grew explosively in the early 1980s. He appeared to be treating the potentially explosive situation with some sensitivity. Nobody knows what explosive arguments the future of Europe will bring. A referendum next year would coincide explosively with the election campaign. She was unpredictable, explosive, impulsive and easily distracted. He's inherited his father's explosive temper. 'Are you mad?' David asked explosively. He made a loud, explosive noise of disgust. ...an explosive drumbeat. The sound of her own chewing and swallowing were explosively loud.

def.en: #Exposure# #to# something dangerous means being in a situation where it might affect you.
def.exmp: Exposure to lead is known to damage the brains of young children. ...the potential exposure of people to nuclear waste. He was suffering from exposure and shock but his condition was said to be stable. At least two people died of exposure in Chicago overnight. ...the exposure of Anthony Blunt as a former Soviet spy. Their sporting reputation has suffered enormously from Johnson's exposure. All the candidates have been getting an enormous amount of exposure on television and in the press. Larger drawings tend to require two or three exposures to cover them. A tripod also lets you shoot long exposures at night. ...an exposure of 1/18sec at f/11. Against a deep blue sky or dark storm-clouds, you may need to reduce the exposure.

def.en: # Exposure# is the risk that a loss might occur.
def.exmp: Financial advice for small businesses can identify and maximize growth opportunities and minimize #exposure# to foreign currency fluctuations. Hedge funds employ innovative investment strategies to attain relatively high returns while simultaneously reducing #exposure# to market risk. #Exposure# is the risk that a loss might occur.

def.en: A company's # exposure# is the amount of a particular risk that it has.
def.exmp: Risk management involves analyzing all #exposures# to the possibility of loss to which a company might be subject, and determining how to handle these. It may be better to pass some risk to a reinsurance company as this will reduce the insurer's #exposure# to risk. A company's #exposure# is the amount of a particular risk that it has.

def.en: Something that is #exquisite# is extremely beautiful or pleasant, especially in a delicate way.
def.exmp: The Indians brought in exquisite beadwork to sell. Mr Zhang's photography is exquisite. ...her exquisite manners. ...exquisitely crafted dolls' houses. ...an exquisitely beautiful young woman. The words issuing from her lips gave exquisite pleasure as they flowed over him. She peeled it with exquisite care.

def.en: Something that is #extensive# covers or includes a large physical area.
def.exmp: ...an extensive tour of Latin America. When built, the palace and its grounds were more extensive than the city itself. Mark, however, needs to travel extensively with his varied business interests. Developments in South Africa receive extensive coverage in The Sunday Telegraph. ...the extensive research into public attitudes to science. The facilities available are very extensive. ...the extensively reported trial. All these issues have been extensively researched in recent years. The blast caused extensive damage, shattering the ground-floor windows. The security forces have extensive powers of search and arrest. Mr Marr makes extensive use of exclusively Scottish words. Hydrogen is used extensively in industry for the production of ammonia.

def.en: If you are talking about how great, important, or serious a difficulty or situation is, you can refer to #the# #extent# #of# it.
def.exmp: The government itself has little information on the extent of industrial pollution. Growing up with him soon made me realise the extent of his determination. The full extent of the losses was disclosed yesterday. Their commitment was only to maintain the extent of forests, not their biodiversity.

def.en: The #exterior# of something is its outside surface.
def.exmp: In one ad the viewer scarcely sees the car's exterior. The exterior of the building was elegant and graceful. According to Mandy, Pat's tough exterior hides a shy and sensitive soul. The exterior walls were made of pre-formed concrete. ...the oven's exterior surfaces.

def.en: #External# is used to indicate that something is on the outside of a surface or body, or that it exists, happens, or comes from outside.
def.exmp: ...a much reduced heat loss through external walls. ...internal and external allergic reactions. Vitamins can be applied externally to the skin. ...externally imposed conditions. ...the commissioner for external affairs. ...Jamaica's external debt. ...the republic's external borders. ...protecting the value of the mark both internally and externally. ...a reaction to external events. Such events occur only when the external conditions are favorable.

def.en: A species of animal or plant that is #extinct# no longer has any living members, either in the world or in a particular place.
def.exmp: It is 250 years since the wolf became extinct in Britain. ...the bones of extinct animals. If the current trend continues, black farmers in the United States may be extinct by the end of this decade. Herbalism had become an all but extinct skill in the Western world. Its tallest volcano, long extinct, is Olympus Mons.

def.en: If you #extinguish# a fire or a light, you stop it burning or shining.
def.exmp: It took about 50 minutes to extinguish the fire. The lights are extinguished as soon as the news conference is over. The message extinguished her hopes of Richard's return.

def.en: To #extract# a substance means to obtain it from something else, for example by using industrial or chemical processes.
def.exmp: ...the traditional method of pick and shovel to extract coal. Citric acid can be extracted from the juice of oranges, lemons, limes or grapefruit. ...looking at the differences in the extracted DNA. Petroleum engineers plan and manage the extraction of oil. He extracted a small notebook from his hip pocket. Patterson went straight to the liquor cabinet and extracted a bottle of Scotch. She reached into the wardrobe and extracted another tracksuit. A dentist may decide to extract the tooth to prevent recurrent trouble. She is to go and have a tooth extracted at 3 o'clock today. In those days, dentistry was basic. Extractions were carried out without anaesthetic. ...the capitalist system, which extracts huge profits from arms production at the tax-payers' expense. He sought to extract the maximum political advantage from the cut in interest rates. His development policies have extracted cash from the city centre. He made the mistake of trying to extract further information from our director. He used her cash card, and the PIN number he had extracted from her, to take £500 from cashpoints. I've simply extracted a few figures. Britain's trade figures can no longer be extracted from export-and-import documentation at ports. ...files of data extracted from the departmental archives. This material has been extracted from 'Collins Good Wood Handbook'. Read this extract from an information booklet about the work of an airline cabin crew. Blend in the lemon extract, lemon peel and walnuts. ...fragrances taken from plant extracts.

def.en: An # extract# is the output from a liquid-liquid extraction process, mainly containing the solvent used to extract the solute.
def.exmp: About 80 percent of this #extract# could be redissolved in 100 ml of ethanol to have a stock solution of the antioxidant. Raffinates are combined in a dual-step process and the #extract# from the first step is used as the solvent in the second step. #An extract# is the output from a liquid-liquid extraction process, mainly containing the solvent used to extract the solute.

def.en: An # extract# is a solution of plant or animal tissue containing the active ingredient.
def.exmp: Plant #extracts# contain active ingredients that can be used for developing medicine. Animal and plant products provide many #extracts# used in the pharmaceutical industry. #An extract# is a solution of plant or animal tissue containing the active ingredient.

def.en: If you describe something or someone as #extraordinary#, you mean that they have some extremely good or special quality.
def.exmp: We've made extraordinary progress as a society in that regard. The task requires extraordinary patience and endurance. Rozhdestvensky is an extraordinary musician. She's extraordinarily disciplined. What an extraordinary thing to happen! His decision to hold talks is extraordinary because it could mean the real end of the war. Apart from the hair, he looked extraordinarily unchanged. Extraordinarily, the favourites for the title lie at the bottom of the table. ...at an extraordinary meeting of the sport's ruling body. Representatives of the colonies met in an extraordinary congress.

def.en: If you describe something as # extraordinary#, you mean that it is very unusual or infrequent.
Someone who is #extravagant# spends more money than they can afford or uses more of something than is reasonable.
def.exmp: We are not extravagant; restaurant meals are a luxury and designer clothes are out. I hope you don't think I'm extravagant but I've had the electric fire on for most of the day. Jeff had shopped extravagantly for presents for the whole family. Her Aunt Sallie gave her an uncharacteristically extravagant gift. Baking a whole cheese in pastry may seem extravagant. ...her extravagant lifestyle. By supercar standards, though, it is not extravagantly priced for a beautifully engineered machine. He was extravagant in his admiration of Hellas. They may make extravagant shows of generosity. She had on occasions praised him extravagantly. ...extravagantly bizarre clothes. They have to compete by adorning their products with ever more extravagant claims. Don't be afraid to consider apparently extravagant ideas. ...the wildest and most extravagant London parties. ...painting extravagant and bold designs onto wooden frames. The day before announcing his farewell to business, Sir James talked to me in his extravagantly elegant Paris home.

def.en: Your #eyesight# is your ability to see.
def.exmp: He suffered from poor eyesight and could no longer read properly.

def.en: A #fable# is a story which teaches a moral lesson.
def.exmp: ...the fable of the tortoise and the hare. Each tale has the timeless quality of fable. Is reincarnation fact or fable? ...little-known horticultural facts and fables.

def.en: #Fabric# is cloth or other material produced by weaving together cotton, nylon, wool, silk, or other threads.
def.exmp: ...small squares of red cotton fabric. Whatever your colour scheme, there's a fabric to match. The fabric of society has been deeply damaged by the previous regime. Years of civil war have wrecked the country's infrastructure and destroyed its social fabric. Condensation will eventually cause the fabric of the building to rot away.

def.en: If someone #fabricates# information, they invent it in order to deceive people.
def.exmp: All four claim that officers fabricated evidence against them. Eleven key officials were hanged on fabricated charges. She described the interview with her in an Italian magazine as a 'complete fabrication'. This story is total fabrication. All the tools are fabricated from high quality steel. ...a plant which fabricates airplane components. More than 200 improvements, many of them major, were made in the design and fabrication of the shuttle.

def.en: If you describe something as #fabulous#, you are emphasizing that you like it a lot or think that it is very good.
def.exmp: This is a fabulous album. It's fresh, varied, fun. The scenery and weather were fabulous. Despite his fabulous wealth, he is very much a man of the people. ...their fabulously rich parents.

def.en: To #facilitate# an action or process, especially one that you would like to happen, means to make it easier or more likely to happen.
def.exmp: The new airport will facilitate the development of tourism. He argued that the economic recovery had been facilitated by his tough stance.

def.en: #Facilities# are buildings, pieces of equipment, or services that are provided for a particular purpose.
def.exmp: What recreational facilities are now available? The problem lies in getting patients to a medical facility as soon as possible. It is very useful to have an overdraft facility. One of the new models has the facility to reproduce speech as well as text. He and Marcia shared a facility for languages. Smell is a very basic sense but humans have lost much of the facility to use it properly.

def.en: Your #faculties# are your physical and mental abilities.
def.exmp: He was drunk and not in control of his faculties. It is also a myth that the faculty of hearing is greatly increased in blind people. ...the Faculty of Social and Political Sciences. The faculty agreed on a change in the requirements. How can faculty improve their teaching so as to encourage creativity? ...eminent Stanford faculty members.

def.en: A #faint# sound, colour, mark, feeling, or quality has very little strength or intensity.
def.exmp: He became aware of the soft, faint sounds of water dripping. The room held the faint, sweet odour of pipe tobacco. He could see faint lines in her face. There was still the faint hope deep within him that she might never need to know. He was already asleep in the bed, which smelled faintly of mildew. She felt faintly ridiculous. Caroline made a faint attempt at a laugh. A faint smile crossed the Monsignor's face and faded quickly. Ten years ago today the U.S. Center for Disease Control published the first faint warnings of a worldwide epidemic. John smiled faintly and shook his head. She suddenly fell forward on to the table and fainted. I thought he'd faint when I kissed him. She slumped to the ground in a faint. Other signs of angina are nausea, sweating, feeling faint and shortness of breath. One patient suffered headaches, nausea, and faintness.

def.en: #Fairly# means to quite a large degree.
def.exmp: Both ships are fairly new. We did fairly well but only fairly well. Were you always fairly bright at school? You've got to be fairly single-minded about it. I'll have no income and no home and will need a job fairly badly. He fairly flew across the room. For him, the place is fairly boiling with humanity. It can no doubt be fairly argued that Sir John, whose pay is linked to performance, is entitled to every penny. After I had read the book I could fairly claim to be an expert.

def.en: A #fairy# is an imaginary creature with magical powers.
If you have #faith# #in# someone or something, you feel confident about their ability or goodness.
def.exmp: She had placed a great deal of faith in Mr Penleigh. People have lost faith in the British Parliament. England shifted officially from a Catholic to a Protestant faith in the 16th century. Umberto Eco's loss of his own religious faith is reflected in his novels.

def.en: Someone who is #faithful# #to# a person, organization, idea, or activity remains firm in their belief in them or support for them.
def.exmp: She had been faithful to her promise to guard this secret. Older Americans are among this country's most faithful voters. He spends his time making speeches at factories or gatherings of the Party faithful. He has since 1965 faithfully followed and supported every twist and turn of government policy. She insisted that she had remained faithful to her husband. I'm very faithful when I love someone. The faithful revered him then as a prophet. Colin Welland's screenplay is faithful to the novel. ...faithful copies of household items used in the mid-1800s. When I adapt something I translate from one meaning to another as faithfully as I can.

def.en: If you achieve #fame#, you become very well-known.
def.exmp: At the height of his fame, his every word was valued. The film earned him international fame. ...her rise to fame and fortune as a dramatist.

def.en: #Famine# is a situation in which large numbers of people have little or no food, and many of them die.
def.exmp: Thousands of refugees are trapped by war, drought and famine. The civil war is obstructing distribution of famine relief by aid agencies.

def.en: If you #fancy# something, you want to have it or to do it.
def.exmp: What do you fancy doing, anyway? Do you fancy going to see a movie sometime? I just fancied a drink. She did not suspect that his interest was just a passing fancy. The boys would tease you to death if they didn't fancy you. I think he thinks I fancy him or something. So you fancy yourself as the boss someday? I didn't fancy myself wearing a kilt. She fancies herself a bohemian. She knew Felix fancied himself as a connoisseur. ...a flighty young woman who really fancies herself. You have to fancy Bath because they are the most consistent team in England. I fancy England to win through. When Ferris looked up he fancied that he saw a shadow pass close to the window. She fancied he was trying to hide a smile. His last book is a bold, at times surrealistic mixture of fact and fancy. ...a childhood fancy. ...whims and fancies. It was very tasteless. Fancy talking like that so soon after his death. 'Fancy that!' smiled Conti.

def.en: If you describe something as #fancy#, you mean that it is special, unusual, or elaborate, for example because it has a lot of decoration.
def.exmp: It was packaged in a fancy plastic case with attractive graphics. ...fancy jewellery. He owned a fancy house out on Lake Agaway. ...a fancy private school.

def.en: #Farther# is a comparative form of far.
If something #fascinates# you, it interests and delights you so much that your thoughts tend to concentrate on it.
def.exmp: Politics fascinated Franklin's father. She fascinated him, both on and off stage.

def.en: When you #fasten# something, you close it by means of buttons or a strap, or some other device.
def.exmp: She got quickly into her Mini and fastened the seat-belt. Her long fair hair was fastened at the nape of her neck by an elastic band. ...the dress, which fastens with a long back zip. There were no instructions on how to fasten the carrying strap to the box. Mamma fastened the picture on the wall. More and more her memory and all her thoughts fastened on one event. The discovery has fastened public attention on the possibilities of DNA analysis for resolving mysteries. My mind attempted to calm itself by fastening on this trivial detail. It's a gross over-simplification to fasten on to the red deer as a threat to the environment. He's fastening on that poor girl like a leech.

def.en: #Fatigue# is a feeling of extreme physical or mental tiredness.
def.exmp: She continued to have severe stomach cramps, aches, fatigue, and depression. Clarke says his team could have lasted another 15 days before fatigue would have begun to take a toll. ...compassion fatigue caused by endless TV and celebrity appeals. ...the result of four months of battle fatigue. He never expected to return home wearing U.S. combat fatigues. The problem turned out to be metal fatigue in the fuselage.

def.en: If a material is subject to # fatigue#, it gradually cracks as stresses, especially vibrations, are repeatedly applied to it.
def.exmp: There have been problems with cracking, possibly due to metal #fatigue#. A part undergoing #fatigue# can eventually completely fracture into two parts. If a material is subject to #fatigue#, it gradually cracks as stresses, especially vibrations, are repeatedly applied to it.

def.en: If something # fatigues# a material or part, it cracks or breaks it by repeatedly putting stresses on it, or if a material or part # fatigues# it gradually cracks or breaks.
def.exmp: The bike's vibration #fatigued# the metal and eventually broke the frame. Each revolution flexes the blade to near the elastic limit of the steel, which causes the metal to #fatigue# and break quickly. If something #fatigues# a material or part, it cracks or breaks it by repeatedly putting stresses on it.

def.en: A #faulty# piece of equipment has something wrong with it and is not working properly.
def.exmp: The money will be used to repair faulty equipment. Their interpretation was faulty–they had misinterpreted things.

def.en: A #fax# or a #fax machine# is a piece of equipment used to copy documents by sending information electronically along a telephone line, and to receive copies that are sent in this way.
def.exmp: ...a modern reception desk with telephone and fax. These days, cartoonists send in their work by fax. I faxed a copy of the agreement to each of the investors. Did you fax him a reply? Pop it in the post, or get your secretary to fax it. I faxed 10 hotels in the area to check room size. I sent him a long fax, saying I didn't need any help. ...a 2,000 word fax message.

def.en: A # fax# is a copy of a document that is transmitted electronically along a telephone line by a fax machine.
def.exmp: You can book by phone or send a #fax#. Is there #a fax# machine to send faxes from this hotel? Any guest wishing to receive faxes will be given the business center #fax# number.

def.en: If you # fax# a document to someone, you send it from one fax machine to another.
def.exmp: I #faxed# a copy of the reservation to each of the guests. Did you mail or #fax# the guest a confirmation of her reservation? You can print, photocopy, and #fax# your documents from the business center.

def.en: If you are #fearful# #of# something, you are afraid of it.
def.exmp: Bankers were fearful of a world banking crisis. I had often been very fearful, very angry, and very isolated. 'What are you going to do to me?' Alex asked fearfully. The region is in a fearful recession. ...the fearful consequences which might flow from unilateral military moves. You gave me a fearful shock! 'It sounds the most fearful hard work,' Sybil said later. This is fearfully expensive compared with the last one I bought.

def.en: If something is #feasible#, it can be done, made, or achieved.
def.exmp: She questioned whether it was feasible to stimulate investment in these regions. That may be fine for the U.S., but it's not feasible for a mass European market. The committee will study the feasibility of setting up a national computer network.

def.en: A #feast# is a large and special meal.
def.exmp: Lunch was a feast of meat and vegetables, cheese, yoghurt and fruit, with unlimited wine. The fruit was often served at wedding feasts. On the following day a feast was given in King John's honour. They feasted well into the afternoon on mutton and corn stew. Starving dogs feasted on the human corpses. Only a few feet away, their captors feasted in the castle's banqueting hall. The feasting, drinking, dancing and revelry continued for several days. This new series promises a feast of special effects and set designs. Chicago provides a feast for the ears of any music lover. The Jewish feast of Passover began last night. At Christmas the visitors began their circuit of dropping in on the eve of the feast day.

def.en: If you refer to an action, or the result of an action, as a #feat#, you admire it because it is an impressive and difficult achievement.
def.exmp: A racing car is an extraordinary feat of engineering.

def.en: A bird's #feathers# are the soft covering on its body.
def.exmp: ...a hat that she had made herself from black ostrich feathers. ...a feather bed.

def.en: A #feature# #of# something is an interesting or important part or characteristic of it.
def.exmp: Patriotic songs have long been a feature of Kuwaiti life. The spacious gardens are a special feature of this property. Perhaps the most unusual feature in the room is an extraordinary pair of candles. His features seemed to change. Her features were strongly defined.
