It's a great movie and it features a Spanish actor who is going to be a world star within a year. The hour-long programme will be updated each week and feature highlights from recent games. This spectacular event, now in its 5th year, features a stunning catwalk show. Jon featured in one of the show's most thrilling episodes. We are delighted to see the Sunday Times running a long feature on breast cancer. ...a special feature on the fund-raising project. ...the first feature-length cartoon, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.

def.en: #February# is the second month of the year in the Western calendar.
def.exmp: He joined the Army in February 1943. His exhibition opens on 5 February. Last February the tribunal agreed he had been the victim of racial discrimination.

def.en: A #federal# country or system of government is one in which the different states or provinces of the country have important powers to make their own laws and decisions.
def.exmp: Five of the six provinces are to become autonomous regions in a new federal system of government. He does not believe in a federal Europe with centralising powers. The federal government controls just 6% of the education budget. ...a federal judge. ...residents of public housing and federally subsidized apartments.

def.en: A #federation# is a federal country.
def.exmp: ...the Russian Federation. ...the British Athletic Federation. The organization emerged from a federation of six national agencies.

def.en: If you describe someone or something as #feeble#, you mean that they are weak.
def.exmp: He told them he was old and feeble and was not able to walk so far. The feeble light of a tin lamp. His left hand moved feebly at his side. He said that the Government had been feeble. ...some rather feeble traditionalists. This is a particularly feeble argument. I said 'Sorry', very feebly, feeling rather embarrassed.

def.en: If you get #feedback# #on# your work or progress, someone tells you how well or badly you are doing, and how you could improve.
def.exmp: Continue to ask for feedback on your work. I was getting great feedback from my boss.

def.en: # Feedback# is a type of control in which the error is considered when deciding future control actions.
def.exmp: #Feedback# from measuring the car's speed has allowed the controller to compensate for changes to the car's speed. The #feedback# component of the control checks these predictions against real time data to make appropriate corrections. #Feedback# is a type of control in which the error is considered when deciding future control actions.

def.en: # Feedback# is the process of part of the signal coming out of a piece of electrical equipment going back into it to reduce or increase the amplification.
def.exmp: Negative #feedback# is used to stabilize a system by feeding back a proportion of the output to the input but in opposition to the input signal. When a sound system howls because the microphone is too near the speaker, this is an example of positive #feedback#. #Feedback# is the process of part of the signal coming out of a piece of electrical equipment going back into it to reduce or increase the amplification.

def.en: #Fell# is the past tense of fall.
def.exmp: Badly infected trees should be felled and burned. ...a blow on the forehead which felled him to the ground.

def.en: A #fellowship# is a group of people that join together for a common purpose or interest.
def.exmp: ...the National Schizophrenia Fellowship. At Merlin's instigation, Arthur founds the Fellowship of the Round Table. He was offered a research fellowship at Clare College. ...a sense of community and fellowship.

def.en: #Feminine# qualities and things relate to or are considered typical of women, in contrast to men.
def.exmp: ...male leaders worrying about their women abandoning traditional feminine roles. ...a manufactured ideal of feminine beauty. I've always been attracted to very feminine, delicate women. The bedroom has a light, feminine look.

def.en: A #fence# is a barrier between two areas of land, made of wood or wire supported by posts.
def.exmp: Villagers say the fence would restrict public access to the hills. The first task was to fence the wood to exclude sheep. Thomas was playing in a little fenced area full of sand. He originally acted as a fence for another gang before turning to burglary himself.

def.en: A #ferry# is a boat that transports passengers and sometimes also vehicles, usually across rivers or short stretches of sea.
def.exmp: They had recrossed the River Gambia by ferry. Every day, a plane arrives to ferry guests to and from Bird Island Lodge. It was still dark when five coaches started to ferry the miners the 140 miles from the Silverhill colliery. A helicopter ferried in more soldiers to help in the search.

def.en: Land or soil that is #fertile# is able to support the growth of a large number of strong healthy plants.
def.exmp: ...fertile soil. ...the rolling fertile countryside of East Cork. He was able to bring large sterile acreages back to fertility. ...a product of Flynn's fertile imagination. A chess player must have a fertile imagination and rich sense of fantasy. ...a fertile breeding ground for this kind of violent racism. The operation cannot be reversed to make her fertile again. Doctors will tell you that pregnancy is the only sure test for fertility.

def.en: #Fertilizer# is a substance such as solid animal waste or a chemical mixture that you spread on the ground in order to make plants grow more successfully.
def.exmp: ...farming without any purchased chemical, fertilizer or pesticide. Work in a balanced fertiliser before planting.

def.en: #Feudal# means relating to the system or the time of feudalism.
def.exmp: ...the emperor and his feudal barons.

def.en: If you have a #fever# when you are ill, your body temperature is higher than usual and your heart beats faster.
def.exmp: My Uncle Jim had a high fever. Symptoms of the disease include fever and weight loss. Angie waited in a fever of excitement.

def.en: #Fiction# refers to books and stories about imaginary people and events, rather than books about real people or events.
def.exmp: Immigrant tales have always been popular themes in fiction. Diana is a writer of historical fiction. The truth or fiction of this story has never been truly determined. The idea that the United States could harmoniously accommodate all was a fiction.

def.en: A #fierce# animal or person is very aggressive or angry.
def.exmp: They look like the teeth of some fierce animal. 'I don't know,' she said fiercely. Competition has been fierce to win a stake in Skoda. The town was captured after a fierce battle with rebels at the weekend. He inspires fierce loyalty in his friends. He has always been ambitious and fiercely competitive. The climbers were trapped by a fierce storm which went on for days. As I arrived a lorry had just been set on fire and was burning fiercely.

def.en: A #figure# is a particular amount expressed as a number, especially a statistic.
def.exmp: It would be very nice if we had a true figure of how many people in this country haven't got a job. It will not be long before the inflation figure starts to fall. New Government figures predict that one in two marriages will end in divorce. Alistair saw the dim figure of Rose in the chair. She waited, standing on the bridge, until his figure vanished against the grey backdrop of the Palace. A figure in a blue dress appeared in the doorway. ...a life-size bronze figure of a brooding, hooded woman. Take pride in your health and your figure. Janet was a natural blonde with a good figure. The movement is supported by key figures in the three main political parties. Sometimes young lads just need to turn to a mother figure for a bit of a chat and reassurance. Daniel Boone, the great hero figure of the frontier. Local police chiefs should re-emerge as figures of authority and reassurance in their areas. If you look at a world map (see Figure 1) you can identify the major wine-producing regions. Figure 1.15 shows which provinces lost populations between 1910 and 1920. Draw a pentagon, a regular five-sided figure. She figured that both she and Ned had learned a lot from the experience. When I finished, he said, 'Yeah. That figures'. Work it out and you'll find it figures. Human rights violations figured prominently in the report.

def.en: When someone #finances# something such as a project or a purchase, they provide the money that is needed to pay for them.
def.exmp: The fund has been used largely to finance the construction of federal prisons. Government expenditure is financed by taxation and by borrowing. A United States delegation is in Japan seeking finance for a major scientific project. ...a major player in the world of high finance. The report recommends an overhaul of public finances. A former Finance Minister and five senior civil servants are accused of fraud. Be prepared for unexpected news concerning your finances. In general, women manage the day-to-day finances but leave most longer-term decisions to men. Finance is usually the biggest problem for students.

def.en: #Financial# means relating to or involving money.
def.exmp: The company is in financial difficulties. ...the government's financial advisers. She would like to be more financially independent. She's been struggling financially for years. Financially, things are a bit tight.

def.en: Something that is #finite# has a definite fixed size or extent.
def.exmp: ...a finite set of elements. Only a finite number of situations can arise. The fossil fuels (coal and oil) are finite resources.

def.en: In a room, the #fireplace# is the place where a fire can be lit and the area on the wall and floor surrounding this place.
Your hand is referred to as your #fist# when you have bent your fingers in towards the palm in order to hit someone, to make an angry gesture, or to hold something.
def.exmp: Angry protestors with clenched fists shouted their defiance. Gary clutched a penny in his fist.

def.en: #Fixtures# are pieces of furniture or equipment, for example baths and sinks, which are fixed inside a house or other building and which stay there if you move.
def.exmp: ...a detailed list of what fixtures and fittings are included in the purchase price. City won this fixture 3-0 last season. She was a fixture in New York's nightclubs. The cordless kettle may now be a fixture in most kitchens.

def.en: A # fixture# is a device for holding and supporting a workpiece in a machine tool.
def.exmp: #Fixtures# must correctly locate a workpiece with respect to a cutting tool or measuring device. #Fixtures# are special work holding devices that are specifically designed to hold a particular workpiece. A #fixture# is a device for holding and supporting a workpiece in a machine tool.

def.en: The # fixtures# in a store or shop are the shelves or shelving units that products are displayed on.
def.exmp: Retail #fixtures# and displays include gridwall, slatwall, display cases, retail shelving, greeting card racks, clothing racks, mannequins, and hangers. Refurbishment of the store included getting rid of old #fixtures# and bringing in sleek modern ones. The #fixtures# in a store or shop are the shelves or shelving units that products are displayed on.

def.en: A #flag# is a piece of cloth which can be attached to a pole and which is used as a sign, signal, or symbol of something, especially of a particular country.
def.exmp: The Marines climbed to the roof of the embassy building to raise the American flag. They had raised the white flag in surrender. Joining John Whitaker will be his brother Michael also riding under the British flag. The airport was opened by Canadian troops operating under the flag of the United Nations. His enthusiasm was in no way flagging. By 4,000m he was beginning to flag.

def.en: A #flame# is a hot bright stream of burning gas that comes from something that is burning.
def.exmp: The heat from the flames was so intense that roads melted. ...a huge ball of flame. The best way to respond to a flame is to ignore it. Ever been flamed? Her cheeks flamed an angry red. Christopher's listening face flamed at the contempt. ...that burning flame of love.

def.en: A # flame# is the hot thing you can see when combustion takes place.
def.exmp: In a wood fire, the visible #flames# are not due to combustion of the wood itself, but rather of the gases released by its pyrolysis. The #flame# of a Bunsen burner consists of two cones: the inner one, in which heated but imperfectly burned gases exist, and the outer one, where oxygen is in excess on the outside edge. #A flame# is the hot thing you can see when combustion takes place.

def.en: If something such as a piece of cloth or paper #flaps# or if you #flap# it, it moves quickly up and down or from side to side.
def.exmp: Grey sheets flapped on the clothes line. They would flap bath towels from their balconies as they chatted. The bird flapped its wings furiously. A pigeon emerges, wings flapping noisily, from the tower. ...a kid running and flapping her arms. He drew back the tent flap and strode out into the blizzard. ...a loose flap of skin. ...the sudden slowing as the flaps were lowered. Nothing to be heard but the soft flap of a silk banner. Why did people get in a flap over nuclear energy? Wherever he goes there's always a flap.

def.en: A #flare# is a small device that produces a bright flame.
def.exmp: ...a ship which had fired a distress flare. Camp fires flared like beacons in the dark. Don't spill too much fat on the barbecue as it could flare up. Even as the President appealed for calm, trouble flared in several American cities. Dozens of people were injured as fighting flared up. Tempers flared and harsh words were exchanged. I turned to Jacky, my nostrils flaring in disgust. He stuck out his tongue and flared his nostrils. ...a simple black dress, cut to flare from the hips.

def.en: A # flare# is a flame used for burning flammable waste gases to get rid of them.
def.exmp: Gas which isn't burned in the turbine is burned in #a flare# to prevent its release. In many industrial operations, large volumes of combustible waste gases are produced which can be burned off in a #flare#. A #flare# is a flame used for burning flammable waste gases to get rid of them.

def.en: To # flare# unwanted gas at an oil well is to get rid of it by burning it.
def.exmp: Gas produced along with oil was usually just burned off, or #flared#. On a worldwide basis most unwanted gas produced as a result of oil production is #flared#. To #flare# unwanted gas at an oil well is to get rid of it by burning it.

def.en: A #flat# is a set of rooms for living in, usually on one floor and part of a larger building.
def.exmp: Sara lives with her husband and children in a flat in central London. …a block of flats Later on, Victor from flat 10 called. Tiles can be fixed to any surface as long as it's flat, firm and dry. After a moment his right hand moved across the cloth, smoothing it flat. ...windows which a thief can reach from a drainpipe or flat roof. The sea was calm, perfectly flat. Two men near him threw themselves flat. As heartburn is usually worse when you're lying down in bed, you should avoid lying flat. Ellen is walking down the drive with a square flat box balanced on one hand. To the north lie the flat and fertile farmlands of the Solway plain. The landscape became wider, flatter and very scenic. The highway stretched out flat and straight ahead. Notice the flatness and the rich, red earth. The salt marshes and mud flats attract large numbers of waterfowl. He slammed the counter with the flat of his hand. ...eight cloves of garlic crushed with the flat of a knife. People wear slacks, sweaters, flat shoes, and all manner of casual attire for travel. His mother looked ten years younger in jeans and flats. Then, after I finally got back on the highway, I developed a flat. Could this really stop the champagne from going flat? His car alarm had been going off for two days and, as a result, the battery was flat. The condition of flat feet runs in families. The Foreign Ministry has issued a flat denial of any involvement. She is likely to give you a flat refusal. Michael flatly denied virtually every rumour. He flatly refused to discuss it. I could use some money, Sarah told him flatly. You're sitting behind an engine that'll move you from 0 to 60mph in six seconds flat. I had it all explained to me in two minutes flat. Fees are charged at a flat rate, rather than on a percentage basis. Sometimes there's a flat fee for carrying out a particular task. Medicare is preparing to cut all payments by a flat 2%. During the first eight months of this year, sales of big pickups were up 14% while car sales stayed flat. For the country overall, house prices have remained flat. The past few days have seemed comparatively flat and empty. It is a long time since a party leader delivered such a dreadfully flat speech as he did yesterday. Kenworthy detected a certain flatness in the days that followed. 'Whatever you say,' he said in a deadly flat voice. 'I'll sit here and wait.' Her voice was flat, with no question or hope in it. I know you,' he said flatly, matter-of-fact, neutral in tone. ...Schubert's B flat Piano Trio (Opus 99). Her vocal range was, to say the least of it, limited, and she had a distressing tendency to sing flat. He had been fired because his singing was flat.

def.en: If someone #flatters# you, they praise you in an exaggerated way that is not sincere, because they want to please you or to persuade you to do something.
def.exmp: I knew she was just flattering me. ...a story of how the president flattered and feted him into taking his side. I flatter myself that this campaign will put an end to the war. I flatter myself I've done it all rather well. You flatter yourself. Why would we go to such ludicrous lengths? Orange and khaki flatter those with golden skin tones. My philosophy of fashion is that I like to make clothes that flatter.

def.en: A #flaw# #in# something such as a theory or argument is a mistake in it, which causes it to be less effective or valid.
def.exmp: There were, however, a number of crucial flaws in his monetary theory. Almost all of these studies have serious flaws. The only flaw in his character seems to be a short temper.

def.en: If you #flee# #from# something or someone, or #flee# a person or thing, you escape from them.
def.exmp: He slammed the bedroom door behind him and fled. He fled to Costa Rica to avoid military service. ...refugees who have fled from wars, famine and persecution. ...refugees fleeing persecution or torture. Thousands have been compelled to flee the country in makeshift boats.

def.en: A #fleet# is a group of ships organized to do something together, for example to fight battles or to catch fish.
def.exmp: The damage inflicted upon the British fleet was devastating. ...restaurants supplied by local fishing fleets. With its own fleet of trucks, the company delivers most orders overnight. A fleet of ambulances took the injured to hospital.

def.en: #Flesh# is the soft part of a person's or animal's body between the bones and the skin.
def.exmp: ...maggots which eat away dead flesh. ...the pale pink flesh of trout and salmon. ...the warmth of her flesh. ...the sins of the flesh. Cut the flesh from the olives and discard the stones.

def.en: A #flexible# object or material can be bent easily without breaking.
def.exmp: ...brushes with long, flexible bristles. The flexibility of the lens decreases with age. Look for software that's flexible enough for a range of abilities. ...flexible working hours. It would seem more sensible to apply standards flexibly rather than rigidly. The flexibility of distance learning would be particularly suited to busy managers.

def.en: If you #fling# something somewhere, you throw it there using a lot of force.
def.exmp: The woman flung the cup at him. He once seized my knitting, flinging it across the room. He flung himself to the floor. She flung her arms around my neck and kissed me. The youth got him by the front of his shirt and flung him to the ground. Peter flung his shoes into the corner. He flung it down on the desk. She flung herself into her career. I flung myself into poetry. She claims she had a brief fling with him 30 years ago. ...that last fling before you finally give up and take up a job.

def.en: #Flour# is a white or brown powder that is made by grinding grain.
def.exmp: Lightly flour a rolling pin. Remove the dough from the bowl and put it on a floured surface.

def.en: If something #flourishes#, it is successful, active, or common, and developing quickly and strongly.
def.exmp: Business flourished and within six months they were earning 18,000 roubles a day. Racism and crime still flourish in the ghetto. London quickly became a flourishing port. The plant flourishes particularly well in slightly harsher climes. Britain has the largest and most flourishing fox population in Europe. He flourished the glass to emphasize the point. He took his peaked cap from under his arm with a flourish and pulled it low over his eyes. She tended to finish dancing with a flourish. He scrawled his name across the bill, underlining it with a showy flourish.

def.en: #Flu# is an illness which is similar to a bad cold but more serious.
def.exmp: I got flu. He had come down with the flu.

def.en: If something #fluctuates#, it changes a lot in an irregular way.
def.exmp: Body temperature can fluctuate if you are ill. ...the fluctuating price of oil. Don't worry about tiny fluctuations in your weight. The calculations do not take into account any fluctuation in the share price.

def.en: A #fluid# is a liquid.
def.exmp: The blood vessels may leak fluid, which distorts vision. Make sure that you drink plenty of fluids. ...fluid retention. The forehand stroke should be fluid and well balanced. ...long, fluid dresses. She dances with an exquisite fluidity of movement. The situation is extremely fluid and it can be changing from day to day. ...the complexity and fluidity of the crisis.

def.en: A # fluid# is a liquid or gas.
def.exmp: The viscosity of a #fluid# is a measure of how easily it will flow. A #fluid# is a substance which undergoes continuous deformation when subjected to a shear stress. A #fluid# is a liquid or gas.

def.en: A # fluid# is a liquid or gas.
def.exmp: Heat can be carried by the flow of a #fluid# such as air or water. A #fluid# is a type of matter that flows. A #fluid# is a liquid or gas.

def.en: If you #flush#, your face goes red because you are hot or ill, or because you are feeling a strong emotion such as embarrassment or anger.
def.exmp: Do you sweat a lot or flush a lot? He turned away embarrassed, his face flushing red. There was a slight flush on his cheeks. Her face was flushed with anger. She flushed the toilet and went back in the bedroom. ...the sound of the toilet flushing. He heard the flush of a toilet. He was found trying to flush banknotes down the toilet. Flush the eye with clean cold water for at least 15 minutes. Water is ideal to flush the kidneys and the urinary tract. ...an 'alternative' therapy that gently flushes out the colon to remove toxins. That won't flush out all the sewage, but it should unclog some stinking drains. They flushed them out of their hiding places. The Guyana Defence Force is engaged in flushing out illegal Brazilian miners operating in the country. Make sure the tile is flush with the surrounding tiles. At that time, many developing countries were flush with dollars earned from exports. If we're feeling flush we'll probably give them champagne. ...the first flush of young love. ...in the flush of victory. ...the flush of recent victories. ...a flush of memories.

def.en: #Foam# consists of a mass of small bubbles that are formed when air and a liquid are mixed together.
def.exmp: The water curved round the rocks in great bursts of foam. ...shaving foam. ...modern three-piece suites filled with foam rubber. We had given him a large foam mattress to sleep on. I let the water run into it and we watched as it foamed and bubbled. ...ravines with foaming rivers rushing through them.

def.en: A # foam# is a suspension of a gas in a liquid or solid.
def.exmp: The #foam# is formed by mixing the aqueous solution containing the fluorochemical surfactant with a gas such as carbon dioxide or nitrogen. Air bubbles through the liquid and forms #a foam#. #A foam# is a suspension of a gas in a liquid or solid.

def.en: # Foam#, or a # foam#, is a drug delivery system consisting of a mass of small bubbles, usually applied to the skin.
def.exmp: A light #foam# can be applied to treat a variety of dry skin conditions. Apply the #foam# directly to the wound. Do not spray it on the hands or the bubbles will disappear too quickly. #Foam# is a drug delivery system consisting of a mass of small bubbles, usually applied to the skin.

def.en: If you #fold# something such as a piece of paper or cloth, you bend it so that one part covers another part, often pressing the edge so that it stays in place.
def.exmp: He folded the paper carefully. Fold the omelette in half. Fold the blanket back. ...a folded towel. Make another fold and turn the ends together. The priest fumbled in the folds of his gown. The back of the bench folds forward to make a table. This portable seat folds flat for easy storage. Check if you can fold the buggy without having to remove the raincover. ...a folding beach chair. When not in use it folds up out of the way. Fold the ironing board up so that it is flat. Meer folded his arms over his chest and turned his head away. Mrs Ringrose sat down and folded her hands in her lap. But as other shops fold, the march of the superstores continues. 2,500 small businesses were folding each week. The E.U. wanted to bring the U.S. back into the fold. He might find it difficult to return to the family fold when he realizes his mistake.

def.en: You can refer to people as #folk# or #folks#.
def.exmp: Country folk can tell you that there are certain places which animals avoid. These are the folks from the local TV station. ...old folks. I've been avoiding my folks lately. 'It's a question of money, folks,' I announced. This is it, folks: the best record guide in the business. ...South American folk art. ...traditional Chinese folk medicine. ...Irish folk music. ...a variety of music including classical, jazz, and folk. Jack was a folk hero in the Greenwich Village bars. Folk psychology comes closer to the obvious truth than the most sophisticated theories.

def.en: If you are #fond of# someone, you feel affection for them.
def.exmp: I am very fond of Michael. She was especially fond of a little girl named Betsy. ...a great fondness for children. ...a fond father. He gave him a fond smile. Liz saw their eyes meet fondly across the table. He was fond of marmalade. She is fond of collecting rare carpets. I've always had a fondness for jewels. ...his fondness for cooking. I have very fond memories of living in our village. My dad took us there when I was about four and I remembered it fondly. My fond hope is that we will be ready by Christmastime. I fondly imagined that surgery meant a few stitches and an overnight stay in hospital.

def.en: #Fore# is used to refer to parts at the front of an animal, ship, or aircraft.
def.exmp: There had been no direct damage in the fore part of the ship. ...a swelling appeared below his near fore knee. Our yacht was well equipped with two double cabins fore and aft. He loosened his very strong hold on the ship's rail and glanced fore and aft.

def.en: A #forecast# is a statement of what is expected to happen in the future, especially in relation to a particular event or situation.
def.exmp: ...a forecast of a 2.25 per cent growth in the economy. He delivered his election forecast. The weather forecast is better for today. They forecast a humiliating defeat for the Prime Minister. He forecasts that average salary increases will remain around 4 per cent.

def.en: A # forecast# is a prediction of future performance and financial position.
def.exmp: External sales #forecasts# are based on historical experience, statistical analysis, and consideration of various macroeconomic factors. The profit was in excess of the prospectus #forecast#. #A forecast# is a prediction of future performance and financial position.

def.en: The #foremost# thing or person in a group is the most important or best.
def.exmp: He was one of the world's foremost scholars of ancient Indian culture. The military government is waging a war of words against its supposed enemies. Foremost among these are the foreign media.

def.en: If you #foresee# something, you expect and believe that it will happen.
def.exmp: He did not foresee any problems. ...a dangerous situation which could have been foreseen. He could never have foreseen that one day his books would sell in millions.

def.en: If one person or institution #forges# an agreement or relationship with another, they create it with a lot of hard work, hoping that it will be strong or lasting.
def.exmp: The Prime Minister is determined to forge a good relationship with America's new leader. They agreed to forge closer economic ties. The programme aims to forge links between higher education and small businesses. The Community was trying to forge a common foreign and security policy. The project will help inmates forge new careers. Tito forged a unique model of communism after breaking with Stalin in 1948. He admitted seven charges including forging passports. She alleged that Taylor had forged her signature on the form. They used forged documents to leave the country. ...the most prolific art forger in the country. ...the blacksmith's forge. ...Woodbury Blacksmith & Forge Co. To forge a blade takes great skill.

def.en: A #fork# is a tool used for eating food which has a row of three or four long metal points at the end.
def.exmp: ...knives and forks. Ann forked some fish into her mouth. He forked an egg onto a piece of bread and folded it into a sandwich. They started me off in the gardens as a handyman. Digging, forking manure, that kind of thing. Farmers cut the hay, fork it on to a cart and then store it in barns. We arrived at a fork in the road. The road divides; you should take the right fork. ...the fork of the Delaware and Lehigh rivers. Beyond the village the road forked. The path dipped down to a sort of cove, and then it forked in two directions. Just before the town boundary fork left onto a minor road.

def.en: A # fork# is a tool used for eating food which has a row of three or four long metal points at the end.
def.exmp: Three #forks# were laid to go with the three knives. Bring a clean knife and #fork# for the next course. Place #forks# on the left side of the plate and knives and soup spoons on the right.

def.en: #The# #formation# #of# something is the starting or creation of it.
def.exmp: ...the formation of a new government. My profession had an important influence in the formation of my character and temperament. He was flying in formation with seven other jets. They saw a squadron of fifteen motorcycle policemen driving in V-formation. The dancers step into a formation which represents the human being. ...a vast rock formation shaped like a pillar. Enormous cloud formations formed a purple mass.

def.en: A # formation# is an area of rock that is of one type and is distinctive and continuous enough to be mapped.
def.exmp: Hydrochloric acid is pumped into the well under high pressure to reopen and enlarge the pores in the oil-bearing limestone #formations#. A fault trap is a geological #formation# in which oil or gas in a porous section of rock is sealed off by a displaced, nonporous layer. #A formation# is an area of rock that is of one type and is distinctive and continuous enough to be mapped.

def.en: #Former# is used to describe someone who used to have a particular job, position, or role, but no longer has it.
def.exmp: The unemployed executives include former sales managers, directors and accountants. ...former President Richard Nixon. He pleaded not guilty to murdering his former wife. ...the former Soviet Union. ...the former Yugoslavia. ...the former home of Sir Christopher Wren. ...a former monastery. He would want you to remember him as he was in former years. Given the choice between a pure white T-shirt and a more expensive, dirty cream one, most people can be forgiven for choosing the former. If the family home and joint pension rights are of equal value, the wife may choose the former and the husband the latter.

def.en: If you describe something or someone as #formidable#, you mean that you feel slightly frightened by them because they are very great or impressive.
def.exmp: We have a formidable task ahead of us. Marsalis has a formidable reputation in both jazz and classical music. She looked every bit as formidable as her mother. Sofia was attractive and formidably intelligent.

def.en: A #formula# is a plan that is invented in order to deal with a particular problem.
def.exmp: It is difficult to imagine how the North and South could ever agree on a formula to unify the divided peninsula. ...a peace formula. After he was officially pronounced the world's oldest man, he offered this simple formula for a long and happy life. Clever exploitation of the latest technology would be a sure formula for success. Socialism does not after all offer a magic formula for prosperity and human dignity. He developed a mathematical formula describing the distances of the planets from the Sun. ...Formula 1 racing cars. ...Formula 3000 racing. ...bottles of formula.

def.en: If you #formulate# something such as a plan or proposal, you invent it, thinking about the details carefully.
def.exmp: Little by little, he formulated his plan for escape. I was impressed by the way he could formulate his ideas.

def.en: When someone goes #forth# from a place, they leave it.
def.exmp: Go forth into the desert. I came forth to take the air. Nature herself brings forth new forms of life. My reflections brought forth no conclusion. Pilate ordered Jesus to be brought forth. He brought forth a small gold amulet from beneath his robe.

def.en: A #forthcoming# event is planned to happen soon.
def.exmp: ...his opponents in the forthcoming elections. They promised that the money would be forthcoming. We must first see some real evidence. So far it has not been forthcoming. One source predicts no major shift in policy will be forthcoming at the committee hearings.

def.en: A #fortnight# is a period of two weeks.
def.exmp: I hope to be back in a fortnight.

def.en: A #forum# is a place, situation, or group in which people exchange ideas and discuss issues, especially important public issues.
def.exmp: Members of the council agreed that it still had an important role as a forum for discussion. The organisation would provide a forum where problems could be discussed.

def.en: A #fossil# is the hard remains of a prehistoric animal or plant that are found inside a rock.
If you #foster# a child, you take it into your family for a period of time, without becoming its legal parent.
def.exmp: She has since gone on to find happiness by fostering more than 100 children. He said that developed countries had a responsibility to foster global economic growth to help new democracies. Its cash crisis has been fostered by declining property values.

def.en: If you describe something as #foul#, you mean it is dirty and smells or tastes unpleasant.
def.exmp: ...foul polluted water. The smell was quite foul. He was sent off for using foul language in a match last Sunday. He had a foul mouth. Collins was in a foul mood even before the interviews began. A village's entire beach and harbor can be fouled by a single rotting whale. Two oil-related accidents near Los Angeles have fouled the ocean and the skies there. It is an offence to let your dog foul a footpath. The freighter fouled its propeller in fishing nets. Middlesbrough's Jimmy Phillips was sent off for fouling Steve Tilson. He picked up his first booking for a 45th-minute foul on Bull. ...a foul tackle.

def.en: A #fraction# #of# something is a tiny amount or proportion of it.
def.exmp: She hesitated for a fraction of a second before responding. Here's how to eat like the stars, at a fraction of the cost. I opened my eyes just a fraction. The students had a grasp of decimals, percentages and fractions.

def.en: A #fracture# is a slight crack or break in something, especially a bone.
def.exmp: At least one-third of all women over ninety have sustained a hip fracture. You've fractured a rib, maybe more than one. One strut had fractured and been crudely repaired in several places. He suffered a fractured skull. His policy risks fracturing the coalition. It might be a society that could fracture along class lines. ...in a world of fractured cultures and global interdependence.

def.en: # Fracture# is the breaking up of a particle.
def.exmp: For a single particle, the extent of #fracture# will relate to the toughness of the particles. In areas of high gas velocity, greater rates of attrition will occur, and #fracture# of particles by impact. #Fracture# is the breaking up of a particle.

def.en: # Fracture# is the failure of a component or structure when a crack becomes larger.
def.exmp: Flaws in the metal can cause cracks which eventually lead to #fracture#. Taken to extreme, plastic deformation ends with the #fracture# of the material. #Fracture# is the failure of a component or structure when a crack becomes larger.

def.en: If you describe a situation as #fragile#, you mean that it is weak or uncertain, and unlikely to be able to resist strong pressure or attack.
def.exmp: The fragile economies of several southern African nations could be irreparably damaged. The Prime Minister's fragile government was on the brink of collapse. His overall condition remained fragile. By mid-1988 there were clear indications of the extreme fragility of the right-wing coalition. He leaned back in his fragile chair. Older drivers are more likely to be seriously injured because of the fragility of their bones. The haircut emphasised her fragile beauty. He felt irritated and strangely fragile, as if he were recovering from a severe bout of flu.

def.en: A #fragment# #of# something is a small piece or part of it.
def.exmp: ...fragments of metal in my shoulder. She read everything, digesting every fragment of news. ...glass fragments. The clouds fragmented and out came the sun. Fierce rivalries have traditionally fragmented the region. By the first century BC, Buddhism was in danger of fragmenting into small sects. ...the extraordinary fragmentation of styles on the music scene. Europe had become infinitely more unstable and fragmented.

def.en: A # fragment# is a solid piece of something which has broken off from a structure, component, or vessel.
def.exmp: In the preliminary stages of rock crushing, the #fragments# are large and angular. The clay particle is #a fragment# of the crushed rock with no particular crystalline form or shape. #A fragment# is a solid piece of something which has broken off from a structure, component, or vessel.

def.en: Something that is #fragrant# has a pleasant, sweet smell.
def.exmp: ...fragrant oils and perfumes. The air was fragrant with the smell of orange blossoms.

def.en: If someone is #frank#, they state or express things in an open and honest way.
def.exmp: 'It is clear that my client has been less than frank with me,' said his lawyer. They had a frank discussion about the issue. You can talk frankly to me. He now frankly admits that much of his former playboy lifestyle was superficial. The reaction to his frankness was hostile. The letter was franked in London on August 6. ...a self-addressed, franked envelope.

def.en: #Fraud# is the crime of gaining money or financial benefits by a trick or by lying.
def.exmp: He was jailed for two years for fraud and deception. Tax frauds are dealt with by the Inland Revenue. Unfortunately the portraits were frauds. He believes many 'psychics' are frauds who rely on perception and subtle deception. ...all those fashion frauds who think they are being original by raiding the tired old styles of the '60s.

def.en: Insurance # fraud# is the crime of gaining insurance benefits by being deliberately deceitful, dishonest, or untrue.
def.exmp: Insurance #fraud# ranges from completely fabricated claims, to inflation or padding of legitimate claims, to false statements on insurance applications. Common types of insurance #fraud# are staged accidents, exaggerated injuries, and inflated medical bills. Insurance #fraud# is the crime of gaining insurance benefits by being deliberately deceitful, dishonest, or untrue.

def.en: #Freight# is the movement of goods by lorries, trains, ships, or aeroplanes.
def.exmp: France derives 16% of revenue from air freight. ...26 tons of freight. 90% of managers wanted to see more freight carried by rail. From these ports the grain is freighted down to Addis Ababa.

def.en: If there is #friction# between people, there is disagreement and argument between them.
def.exmp: Sara sensed that there had been friction between her children. The plan is likely only to aggravate ethnic frictions. The pistons are graphite-coated to reduce friction. ...the friction of his leg against hers.

def.en: # Friction# is the force that stops two bodies or substances that are touching from moving against each other smoothly.
def.exmp: #Friction# between two metal parts can be reduced by using oil. #Friction# is created by the pads rubbing against the rotor. #Friction# is the force that stops two bodies or substances that are touching from moving against each other smoothly.

def.en: #Friday# is the day after Thursday and before Saturday.
def.exmp: Mr Cook is intending to go to the Middle East on Friday. The weekly series starts next Friday. I get home at half seven on Fridays. He left Heathrow airport on Friday morning.

def.en: A #fridge# is a large metal container which is kept cool, usually by electricity, so that food that is put in it stays fresh.
#Fright# is a sudden feeling of fear, especially the fear that you feel when something unpleasant surprises you.
def.exmp: The steam pipes rattled suddenly, and Franklin uttered a shriek and jumped with fright. The birds smashed into the top of their cages in fright. To hide my fright I asked a question. The snake picked up its head and stuck out its tongue which gave everyone a fright. The last time you had a real fright, you nearly crashed the car.

def.en: A #fringe# is hair which is cut so that it hangs over your forehead.
def.exmp: The jacket had leather fringes. ...black townships located on the fringes of the city. They lived together in a mixed household on the fringe of a campus. The party remained on the fringe of the political scene until last year. The monarchists are a small fringe group who quarrel fiercely among themselves. ...the numerous fringe meetings held during the party conference.

def.en: A #frog# is a small creature with smooth skin, big eyes, and long back legs which it uses for jumping.
A #frontier# is a border between two countries.
def.exmp: It wasn't difficult then to cross the frontier. ...a far-flung outpost on the frontier. ...pushing back the frontiers of science. ...technological frontiers.

def.en: When there is #frost# or a #frost#, the temperature outside falls below freezing point and the ground becomes covered in ice crystals.
def.exmp: There is frost on the ground and snow is forecast. The wind had veered to north, bringing clear skies and a keen frost.

def.en: When someone #frowns#, their eyebrows become drawn together, because they are annoyed, worried, or puzzled, or because they are concentrating.
def.exmp: Nancy shook her head, frowning. He frowned at her anxiously. ...a frowning man. There was a deep frown on the boy's face.

def.en: Something that is #fruitful# produces good and useful results.
def.exmp: We had a long, happy, fruitful relationship. The talks had been fruitful, but much remained to be done. ...taking their skills where they can be applied most fruitfully. ...a landscape that was fruitful and lush.

def.en: If something #frustrates# you, it upsets or angers you because you are unable to do anything about the problems it creates.
def.exmp: These questions frustrated me. Doesn't it frustrate you that audiences in the theatre are so restricted? Roberta felt frustrated and angry. ...voters who are frustrated with the council. The results show the level of frustration among hospital doctors. ...a man fed up with the frustrations of everyday life. The government has deliberately frustrated his efforts to gain work permits for his foreign staff. ...her frustrated attempt to become governor.

def.en: #Fumes# are the unpleasant and often unhealthy smoke and gases that are produced by fires or by things such as chemicals, fuel, or cooking.
def.exmp: ...car exhaust fumes. They have been protesting about fumes from a chlorine factory. He was still fuming over the remark. 'It's monstrous!' Jackie fumed. The old man fumed and threatened.

def.en: # Fume# is a fine suspension of particles, which can be seen in a gas.
def.exmp: #Fume# is the submicron particles formed by evaporation of the material and subsequent solidification in the gas stream. The dilution gives rise to large volumes of waste gas containing high concentrations of #fume#. #Fume# is a fine suspension of particles, which can be seen in a gas.

def.en: #Funds# are amounts of money that are available to be spent, especially money that is given to an organization or person for a particular purpose.
def.exmp: The concert will raise funds for research into Aids. ...government funds. ...a pension fund. ...a scholarship fund for undergraduate engineering students. The Bush Foundation has funded a variety of faculty development programs. The airport is being privately funded by a construction group. ...a new privately funded scheme. ...government-funded institutions. He is possessed of an extraordinary fund of energy.

def.en: A # fund# is money from many different investors combined and invested in many different types of securities.
def.exmp: Net asset value is the value of a #fund#'s investments. In order to sell shares, an investor generally sells the shares back to the #fund#. A #fund# is money from many different investors combined and invested in many different types of securities.

def.en: You use #fundamental# to describe things, activities, and principles that are very important or essential.
def.exmp: Our constitution embodies all the fundamental principles of democracy. A fundamental human right is being withheld from these people. Technical skill is a fundamental basis for most, if not all, great art. But on this question, the two leaders have very fundamental differences. Amnesty says there are fundamental flaws in their military justice system. He believes better relations with China are fundamental to the well-being of the area. The method they pioneered remains fundamental to research into the behaviour of nerve cells. The fundamental problem lies in their inability to distinguish between reality and invention. It was not simply a practical matter, but a fundamental question of principle. Industry leaders want scientists to engage in fundamental research, not applied research.

def.en: A #funeral# is the ceremony that is held when the body of someone who has died is buried or cremated.
def.exmp: His funeral will be on Thursday at Blackburn Cathedral. He was given a state funeral.

def.en: A # funeral# is the ceremony held when the body of someone who has died is buried or cremated.
def.exmp: This policy covers the costs of returning home to attend the #funeral# of a family member who has died. The benefit is designed to contribute towards the cost of #a funeral# on the death of the insured person, by providing the nominated beneficiary with a lump sum payment. #A funeral# is the ceremony held when the body of someone who has died is buried or cremated.

def.en: #Fur# is the thick and usually soft hair that grows on the bodies of many mammals.
def.exmp: This creature's fur is short, dense and silky. She had on a black coat with a fur collar. Women are also wearing fur again. ...the trading of furs from Canada. There were women in furs and men in comfortable overcoats.

def.en: Someone who is #furious# is extremely angry.
def.exmp: He is furious at the way his wife has been treated. I am furious that it has taken so long to uncover what really happened. He stormed out of the apartment, slamming the door furiously behind him. A furious gunbattle ensued. Officials worked furiously to repair the centre court.

def.en: A #furnace# is a container or enclosed space in which a very hot fire is made, for example to melt metal, burn rubbish, or produce steam.
def.exmp: How can we walk? It's a furnace out there.

def.en: A # furnace# is a vessel in which there is a very high temperature.
def.exmp: The temperature of the #furnace# was increased at 110°C per hour to the final temperature of 900°C and then held for one hour before the product was allowed to cool to room temperature. #Furnaces# heat up raw materials so that they can produce products such as gasoline, kerosene, chemicals, and plastic. A #furnace# is a vessel in which there is a very high temperature.

def.en: A # furnace# is an enclosed chamber in which heat is produced, for example to generate steam, burn waste, or produce molten metal.
def.exmp: The aluminum is melted in a #furnace# at a temperature of 1400 degrees. The iron ore is melted in huge #furnaces#. A #furnace# is an enclosed chamber in which heat is produced, for example to generate steam, burn waste, or produce molten metal.

def.en: If you #furnish# a room or building, you put furniture and furnishings into it.
def.exmp: Many proprietors try to furnish their hotels with antiques. They'll be able to furnish you with the rest of the details.

def.en: A #fuse# is a safety device in an electric plug or circuit.
def.exmp: The fuse blew as he pressed the button to start the motor. Remove the circuit fuse before beginning electrical work. The wire snapped at the wall plug and the light fused. Rainwater had fused the bulbs. A bomb was deactivated at the last moment, after the fuse had been lit. The skull bones fuse between the ages of fifteen and twenty-five. Conception occurs when a single sperm fuses with an egg. Manufactured glass is made by fusing various types of sand. Their solution was to isolate specific clones of B cells and fuse them with cancer cells. The flakes seem to fuse together and produce ice crystals. His music fused the rhythms of jazz with classical forms. What they have done is fuse two different types of entertainment, the circus and the rock concert. Past and present fuse.

def.en: A # fuse# is a safety device in an electric circuit.

A # fuse# is a protective device in an electric plug or circuit that contains a piece of wire designed to melt and break when there is a fault, and an excessive current flows along it for a particular time.
def.exmp: #Fuses# help protect your electronic equipment, and without them, any stray electrical surge - from lightning, large appliances, or the electric provider - could destroy your equipment. A #fuse# or a circuit breaker is normally used as a disconnector. A #fuse# is a protective device in an electric plug or circuit that contains a piece of wire designed to melt and break when there is a fault, and an excessive current flows along it.

def.en: #Fuss# is anxious or excited behaviour which serves no useful purpose.
def.exmp: I don't know what all the fuss is about. He just gets down to work without any fuss. Carol fussed about getting me a drink. My wife was fussing over the food and clothing we were going to take. She fussed with a wisp of hair over her ear. A team of waiters began fussing around the table. 'Stop fussing,' he snapped. Auntie Hilda and Uncle Jack couldn't fuss over them enough.

def.en: If you say that something is #futile#, you mean there is no point in doing it, usually because it has no chance of succeeding.
def.exmp: He brought his arm up in a futile attempt to ward off the blow. It would be futile to sustain his life when there is no chance of any improvement.

def.en: A #gallon# is a unit of measurement for liquids that is equal to eight pints.
def.exmp: ...80 million gallons of water a day. ...a gasoline tax of 4.3 cents a gallon.

def.en: When a horse #gallops#, it runs very fast so that all four legs are off the ground at the same time.
def.exmp: The horses galloped away. Staff officers galloped fine horses down the road. Major Winston galloped into the distance. I was forced to attempt a gallop. In spite of the recession, profits have galloped ahead. ...galloping inflation. They are galloping around the garden playing football.

def.en: A #gang# is a group of people, especially young people, who go around together and often deliberately cause trouble.
def.exmp: During the fight with a rival gang he lashed out with his flick knife. Gang members were behind a lot of the violence. He was attacked by a gang of youths. Police were hunting for a gang who had allegedly stolen fifty-five cars. ...an underworld gang. ...a gang of masked robbers. Come on over, we've got lots of the old gang here. ...a gang of labourers.

def.en:
jail
Exmp:
A #gap# is a space between two things or a hole in the middle of something solid.
def.exmp: He pulled the thick curtains together, leaving just a narrow gap. ...the wind tearing through gaps in the window frames. There followed a gap of four years, during which William joined the Army. We need more young scientists to fill the gap left by a wave of retirements expected over the next decade. Like a good businessman, Stewart identified a gap in the market. ...the gap between rich and poor. America's trade gap widened. Britain needs to bridge the technology gap between academia and industry.

def.en: A #garage# is a building in which you keep a car.
def.exmp: Nancy took her car to a local garage for a check-up. Nelson Garage has the used car you're after.

def.en: #Garlic# is the small, white, round bulb of a plant that is related to the onion plant.
def.exmp: ...a clove of garlic.

def.en: # Garlic# is the small, white, round bulb of a plant that is related to the onion plant.
A #garment# is a piece of clothing; used especially in contexts where you are talking about the manufacture or sale of clothes.
def.exmp: Many of the garments have the customers' name tags sewn into the linings.

def.en:
#Gasoline# is the same as petrol
Exmp:
# Gasoline# is the fuel which is used to drive motor vehicles.
def.exmp: #Gasoline# is drawn off from the gas tank by a fuel pump. The spark plugs produce sparks that cause the #gasoline# to burn. Hybrid cars have two propulsion systems: an electric motor and a #gasoline# engine.

def.en: A #gasp# is a short quick breath of air that you take in through your mouth, especially when you are surprised, shocked, or in pain.
def.exmp: An audible gasp went round the court as the jury announced the verdict. She gave a small gasp of pain. She gasped for air and drew in a lungful of water. I heard myself gasp and cry out.

def.en: If you #gauge# the speed or strength of something, or if you gauge an amount, you measure or calculate it, often by using a device of some kind.
def.exmp: He gauged the wind at over thirty knots. Distance is gauged by journey time rather than miles. ...temperature gauges. ...pressure gauges. ...as he gauged possible enemy moves and his own responses. His mood can be gauged by his reaction to the most trivial of incidents. The index is the government's chief gauge of future economic activity. ...a narrow gauge railway.

def.en: If you #gaze# #at# someone or something, you look steadily at them for a long time, for example because you find them attractive or interesting, or because you are thinking about something else.
def.exmp: She stood gazing at herself in the mirror. Sitting in his wicker chair, he gazed reflectively at the fire. The girls stood still, gazing around the building, trying to picture life there fifty years before. The Monsignor turned his gaze from the flames to meet the Colonel's. She felt increasingly uncomfortable under the woman's steady gaze. The interior was shielded from the curious gaze of passersby.

def.en: The #gears# on a machine or vehicle are a device for changing the rate at which energy is changed into motion.
def.exmp: On hills, he must use low gears. The car was in fourth gear. He put the truck in gear and drove on. About 100 officers in riot gear were needed to break up the fight. ...fishing gear. They helped us put our gear back into the van. I used to wear trendy gear but it just looked ridiculous. Are these people using gear and amphetamines at the same time? Colleges are not always geared to the needs of mature students. My training was geared towards winning gold in Munich.

def.en: A # gear# is a wheel with teeth that engage with the teeth of another wheel in order to change the speed or direction of transmitted rotational motion.
def.exmp: Neutral is the position when no #gears# are engaged and the engine is decoupled from the vehicle's drive wheels. The purpose of the #gears# is to allow the cyclist's legs to move at their optimum rate, no matter how fast the bicycle wheels are moving. A #gear# is a wheel with teeth that engage with the teeth of another wheel in order to change the speed or direction of transmitted rotational motion.

def.en: A person's #gender# is the fact that they are male or female.
def.exmp: Women are sometimes denied opportunities solely because of their gender. ...groups that are traditionally discriminated against on grounds of gender, colour, race, or age. While her observations may be true about some men, they could hardly apply to the entire gender. ...the different abilities and skills of the two genders. In both Welsh and Irish the word for 'moon' is of feminine gender.

def.en: # Gender# is the state of being male or female.
def.exmp: The three main variables in a mortality table are age, #gender#, and use of tobacco. For auto insurance, #gender# is taken into consideration, as statistically, males have more accidents than females. #Gender# is the state of being male or female.

def.en: A #general# is a senior officer in the armed forces, usually in the army.
def.exmp: The General's visit to Sarajevo is part of preparations for the deployment of extra troops. The figures represent a general decline in employment. ...the general deterioration of English society. £2,500 for software is soon swallowed up in general costs. His firm took over the planting and general maintenance of the park last March. The project should raise general awareness about bullying. ...a general ache radiating from the back of the neck. ...a general sense of well-being. ...raising the level of general physical fitness. They ran the general store and the farm dairy. He joined Sanders Roe, moving on later to become General Manager. The farm employed a tractor driver and two general labourers. This book is intended for the general reader rather than the student.

def.en: If you #generalize#, you say something that seems to be true in most situations or for most people, but that may not be completely true in all cases.
def.exmp: 'In my day, children were a lot better behaved'.—'It's not true, you're generalizing'. It's hard to generalize about Cole Porter because he wrote so many great songs that were so varied. A child first labels the household pet cat as a 'cat' and then generalises this label to other animals that look like it.

def.en: To #generate# something means to cause it to begin and develop.
def.exmp: The Employment Minister said the reforms would generate new jobs. ...the excitement generated by the changes in Eastern Europe. The company, New England Electric, burns coal to generate power.

def.en: If a system # generates# electricity, it produces it, especially in a power station.
def.exmp: The utility company will #generate#, transmit, and distribute supplies of electric energy to a specified area not being serviced by another utility. The network #generates# electricity in power stations and then distributes it to the end user through a network of overhead and underground lines. If a system #generates# electricity, it produces it, especially in a power station.

def.en: A #generation# is all the people in a group or country who are of a similar age, especially when they are considered as having the same experiences or attitudes.
def.exmp: ...the younger generation of Party members. David Mamet has long been considered the leading American playwright of his generation. Within a generation flight has become the method used by many travellers. ...a new generation of IBM/Apple computers. ...second generation Asians in Britain. She is a first generation American. Japan has announced plans for a sharp rise in its nuclear power generation.

def.en: # Generation# is the production of electrical or thermal energy by the combustion of a fuel.
def.exmp: A condensing turbine is a turbine used for electrical power #generation# from a minimum amount of steam. The #generation# of power from wind is being used on an increasing scale to boost clean electricity production. #Generation# is the production of electrical or thermal energy by the combustion of a fuel.

def.en: # Generation# of electricity is the process of producing electrical energy by transforming non electrical forms of energy.
def.exmp: Wind generators are ideal since they produce maximum power during a monsoon when solar power #generation# is minimum. A wave farm or wave power farm is a collection of machines in the same location and used for the #generation# of wave power electricity #Generation# of electricity is the process of producing electrical energy by transforming non electrical forms of energy.

def.en: A #generator# is a machine which produces electricity.
def.exmp: The U.S. economy is still an impressive generator of new jobs. The company has been a very good cash generator.

def.en: A # generator# is a machine for converting mechanical energy into electrical energy.
def.exmp: A hydroelectric plant is a plant in which the turbine #generators# are driven by falling water. The hydraulic motors drive electrical #generators# to produce electricity. A #generator# is a machine for converting mechanical energy into electrical energy.

def.en: A #generous# person gives more of something, especially money, than is usual or expected.
def.exmp: German banks are more generous in their lending. The gift is generous by any standards. We would like to thank all the judges who gave so generously of their time. He was always generous in sharing his enormous knowledge. He was generous enough to congratulate his successor on his decision. The students generously gave them instruction in social responsibility. ...a generous six weeks of annual holiday. He should be able to keep his room tidy with the generous amount of storage space. ...a generously sized sitting room. Season the steaks generously with salt and pepper.

def.en: You use #genetic# to describe something that is concerned with genetics or with genes.
def.exmp: Cystic fibrosis is the most common fatal genetic disease in the United States. Some people are genetically predisposed to diabetes. ...fetuses that are genetically abnormal.

def.en: #Genuine# is used to describe people and things that are exactly what they appear to be, and are not false or an imitation.
def.exmp: There was a risk of genuine refugees being returned to Vietnam. ...genuine leather. They're convinced the picture is genuine. There was genuine joy in this room. If this offer is genuine I will gladly accept it. He was genuinely surprised. He needed at least three days to assess the genuineness of their intentions. She is very caring and very genuine. I have no doubt about their genuineness.

def.en: #Geography# is the study of the countries of the world and of such things as the land, seas, climate, towns, and population.
def.exmp: ...policemen who knew the local geography. ...a pictorial journey through the history, geography and culture of the Caribbean.

def.en: #Geology# is the study of the Earth's structure, surface, and origins.
def.exmp: He was visiting professor of geology at the University of Jordan. Geologists have studied the way that heat flows from the earth. ...an expert on the geology of southeast Asia.

def.en: #Geometry# is the branch of mathematics concerned with the properties and relationships of lines, angles, curves, and shapes.
def.exmp: ...the very ordered way in which mathematics and geometry describe nature. They have tinkered with the geometry of the car's nose.

def.en: A #germ# is a very small organism that causes disease.
def.exmp: Chlorine is widely used to kill germs. ...a germ that destroyed hundreds of millions of lives. The germ of an idea took root in Rosemary's mind. This was the germ of a book.

def.en: Something that is described as #giant# is much larger or more important than most others of its kind.
def.exmp: ...Italy's giant car maker, Fiat. ...a giant oak table. ...a giant step towards unification with the introduction of monetary union. ...Japanese electronics giant Sony. ...one of Germany's industrial giants, Daimler-Benz. ...a Nordic saga of giants. He has enormous charisma. He is a giant of a man. The biggest man in the patrol, a giant of a man, lifted Mattie on to his shoulders. ...the giant of opera, Luciano Pavarotti. He was without question one of the giants of Japanese literature.

def.en: If you describe something as #gigantic#, you are emphasizing that it is extremely large in size, amount, or degree.
def.exmp: ...gigantic rocks. A gigantic task of national reconstruction awaits us.

def.en: If someone #giggles#, they laugh in a childlike way, because they are amused, nervous, or embarrassed.
def.exmp: Both girls began to giggle. 'I beg your pardon?' she giggled. ...a giggling little girl. She gave a little giggle. I was so nervous I got the giggles. She had a fit of the giggles. I might buy one for a friend's birthday as a giggle.

def.en: If you #glare# #at# someone, you look at them with an angry expression on your face.
def.exmp: The old woman glared at him. Jacob glared and muttered something. ...glaring eyes. His glasses magnified his irritable glare. The sunlight glared. ...glaring searchlight beams. ...the glare of a car's headlights. Special-purpose glasses reduce glare. Norma is said to dislike the glare of publicity. She attacked police in the full glare of TV cameras.

def.en: If you #glide# somewhere, you move silently and in a smooth and effortless way.
def.exmp: Waiters glide between tightly packed tables bearing trays of pasta. Our only companion is the wandering albatross, which glides effortlessly and gracefully behind the yacht.

def.en: If you get a #glimpse# #of# someone or something, you see them very briefly and not very well.
def.exmp: Some of the fans had waited 24 hours outside the Hyde Park Hotel to catch a glimpse of their heroine. She glimpsed a group of people standing on the bank of a river. As university campuses become increasingly multi-ethnic, they offer a glimpse of the conflicts society will face tomorrow. ...a glimpse into the future.

def.en: If something #glitters#, light comes from or is reflected off different parts of it.
def.exmp: The bay glittered in the sunshine. The Palace glittered with lights. His eyes glittered with a tense amusement. Decorate the tunic with sequins or glitter. She was blinded by the glitter and the glamour of her own life.

def.en: You can refer to the world as #the# #globe# when you are emphasizing how big it is or that something happens in many different parts of it.
def.exmp: ...bottles of beer from every corner of the globe. 70% of our globe's surface is water. ...a globe of the world. Three large globes stand on the floor. The overhead light was covered now with a white globe.

def.en: If a place is #gloomy#, it is almost dark so that you cannot see very well.
def.exmp: Inside it's gloomy after all that sunshine. ...this huge gloomy church. Miller is gloomy about the fate of the serious playwright in America. He tells me gloomily that he has been called up for army service. ...a gloomy picture of an economy sliding into recession. Officials say the outlook for next year is gloomy.

def.en: Something that is #glorious# is very beautiful and impressive.
def.exmp: ...a glorious rainbow in the air. She had missed the glorious blooms of the Mediterranean spring. ...a glorious Edwardian opera house. ...gloriously embroidered costumes. The win revived glorious memories of his championship-winning days. We opened the windows and let in the glorious evening air. ...her gloriously happy love life. Harrison had a glorious career spanning more than six decades. Her future could be more glorious even than her past. But the mission was successful, gloriously successful. I got dressed and emerged into glorious sunshine. The sun was out again, and it was a glorious day. For a change, it was a gloriously sunny day.

def.en: #Glory# is the fame and admiration that you gain by doing something impressive.
def.exmp: Walsham had his moment of glory when he won a 20km race. ...we were still basking in the glory of our Championship win. The album sees them re-living past glories but not really breaking any new ground. ...the military glories of Frederick the Great. The glory of the idea blossomed in his mind. ...a tour of Florence, to enjoy the artistic glories of the Italian Renaissance. One of the glories of the island has always been its bird population. The workers were glorying in their new-found freedom. He does not glory in his past successes and looks forward to achieving more.

def.en: A #glow# is a dull, steady light, for example the light produced by a fire when there are no flames.
def.exmp: ...the cigarette's red glow. The rising sun casts a golden glow over the fields. The moisturiser gave my face a healthy glow that lasted all day. Exercise will give you a glow of satisfaction at having achieved something. He felt a glow of pride in what she had accomplished. The night lantern glowed softly in the darkness. Even the mantel above the fire glowed white. Used together these colours will make your interiors glow with warmth and vitality. ...carved wood bathed in glowing colors and gold leaf. The instruments glowed in the bright orange light. The fall foliage glowed red and yellow in the morning sunlight. Her freckled skin glowed with health again. ...a glowing complexion. The expectant mothers that Amy had encountered positively glowed with pride.

def.en: #Glue# is a sticky substance used for joining things together, often for repairing broken things.
def.exmp: ...a tube of glue. ...high quality glues. Glue the fabric around the window. The material is cut and glued in place. They are glued together. They are all glued to the Olympic Games.

def.en: A #goat# is a farm animal or a wild animal that is about the size of a sheep.
People sometimes say '#goodness#' or '#my goodness#' to express surprise.
def.exmp: Goodness, I wonder if he knows. My goodness, he's earned millions in his career. He retains a faith in human goodness.

def.en: A #goose# is a large bird that has a long neck and webbed feet.
def.exmp: ...roast goose.

def.en: # Goose# is the flesh of a type of bird which is often kept on a farm for its meat, eaten as food.
def.exmp: The main dish that day was roast #goose#. #Goose# can be cooked in the same way as other poultry. If you like duck, you will probably enjoy the taste of #goose#.

def.en: If you say that something is #gorgeous#, you mean that it gives you a lot of pleasure or is very attractive.
def.exmp: ...gorgeous mountain scenery. It's a gorgeous day. Some of the Renaissance buildings are gorgeous. She has a gorgeously warm speaking voice. The cosmetics industry uses gorgeous women to sell its skincare products. All the girls in my house are mad about Ryan, they think he's gorgeous. ...a red-haired man in the gorgeous uniform of a Marshal of the Empire. ...gorgeously embroidered clothing.

def.en: #Gossip# is informal conversation, often about other people's private affairs.
def.exmp: He spent the first hour talking gossip. There has been much gossip about the possible reasons for his absence. Don't you like a good gossip? We spoke, debated, gossiped into the night. Eva gossiped with Sarah. Mrs Lilywhite never gossiped. He was a vicious gossip.

def.en: To #govern# a place such as a country, or its people, means to be officially in charge of the place, and to have responsibility for making laws, managing the economy, and controlling public services.
def.exmp: They go to the polls on Friday to choose the people they want to govern their country. Their citizens are very thankful they are not governed by a dictator. Marine insurance is governed by a strict series of rules and regulations. The government has altered the rules governing eligibility for unemployment benefit.

def.en: In some systems of government, a #governor# is a person who is in charge of the political administration of a region or state.
def.exmp: He was governor of the province in the late 1970s. Governor William Livingston addressed the New Jersey Assembly. Governors are using the increased powers given to them to act against incompetent headteachers. ...the chairman of the BBC board of governors. The incident was reported to the prison governor.

def.en: A # governor# is a device which limits the maximum speed of an engine, especially a diesel engine.
A # governor# is a device that controls the speed of an engine.
def.exmp: Fly-ball #governors# are used to maintain constant speed in a flywheel. Diesel engines with traditional mechanical injector systems have an integral #governor# which prevents over-speeding the engine. A #governor# is a device that controls the speed of an engine.

def.en: A #gown# is a dress, usually a long dress, which women wear on formal occasions.
def.exmp: The new ball gown was a great success. ...wedding gowns. ...an old headmaster in a flowing black gown.

def.en: If someone moves with #grace#, they move in a smooth, controlled, and attractive way.
def.exmp: He moved with the grace of a trained boxer. Ballet classes are important for poise and grace. The new King seemed to be carrying out his duties with grace and due decorum. The young woman had grace beyond her years. She didn't fit in and she had few social graces. She wanted a couple of days' grace to get the maisonette cleaned before she moved in. We have only a few hours' grace before the soldiers come. He went to the beautiful old Welsh dresser that graced this homely room. Her shoulders were graced with mink and her fingers sparkled with diamonds. He had been invited to grace a function at the evening college. It was only by the grace of God that no one died. Leo, will you say grace? ...a Latin grace. Your Grace, I have a great favour to ask of you.

def.en: Someone or something that is #graceful# moves in a smooth and controlled way which is attractive to watch.
def.exmp: His movements were so graceful they seemed effortless. ...graceful ballerinas. She stepped gracefully onto the stage. A graceful medieval cathedral. His handwriting, from earliest young manhood, was flowing and graceful. She loved the gracefully high ceiling, with its white-painted cornice. Aubrey could think of no graceful way to escape Corbet's company. He was charming, cheerful, and graceful under pressure. We managed to decline gracefully.

def.en: If you describe someone, especially someone you think is superior to you, as #gracious#, you mean that they are very well-mannered and pleasant.
def.exmp: She is a lovely and gracious woman. She closed with a gracious speech of thanks. Hospitality at the Presidential guest house was graciously declined. He drove through the gracious suburbs with the swimming pools and tennis courts.

def.en: A #grain# #of# wheat, rice, or other cereal crop is a seed from it.
def.exmp: ...a grain of wheat. ...rice grains. ...a bag of grain. ...the best grains. ...a grain of sand. ...coarse-grained salt. There's more than a grain of truth in that. Brush the paint generously over the wood in the direction of the grain. ...a hard, heavy, straight-grained wood.

def.en:
gram1
Exmp:
If you describe a building or a piece of scenery as #grand#, you mean that its size or appearance is very impressive.
def.exmp: ...this grand building in the center of town. The scenery of South Island is on a grand scale. Critics will point to other grand schemes that have gone less well, such as Sheffield's World Student Games disaster. The grand design of Europe's monetary union is already agreed. He is grander and even richer than the Prince of Wales. The Duke of Clarence will be there, and many of your grander friends. Few museums could rival the Old Royal Observatory at Greenwich for a grand day out. The dinner was a grand success. He was having a grand time meeting new sorts of people. He was a grand bloke. It came to a grand total of £220,329. They stayed at The Grand Hotel, Budapest. They're paying you ten grand now for those adaptations of old plays.

def.en: A #grant# is an amount of money that a government or other institution gives to an individual or to an organization for a particular purpose such as education or home improvements.
def.exmp: They'd got a special grant to encourage research. Unfortunately, my application for a grant was rejected. France has agreed to grant him political asylum. It was a Labour government which granted independence to India and Pakistan. Permission was granted a few weeks ago. The magistrates granted that the charity was justified in bringing the action.

def.en: #Grapes# are small green or dark purple fruit which grow in bunches.
# Grapes# are small green or purple fruit which grow in bunches.
A #graph# is a mathematical diagram which shows the relationship between two or more sets of numbers or measurements.
If you say that a description or account of something unpleasant is #graphic#, you are emphasizing that it is clear and detailed.
def.exmp: The descriptions of sexual abuse are graphic. ...graphic scenes of drug taking. Here, graphically displayed, was confirmation of the entire story. ...fine and graphic arts. ...a computer manufacturer which specialises in graphics. ...articles with strong headlines and graphics. The Agriculture Department today released a new graphic to replace the old symbol.

def.en: If you #grasp# something, you take it in your hand and hold it very firmly.
def.exmp: He grasped both my hands. She was trying to grasp at something. His hand was taken in a warm, firm grasp. The people in your grasp are not guests, they are hostages. She allowed victory to slip from her grasp. ...the task of liberating a number of states from the grasp of tyrants. The Government has not yet grasped the seriousness of the crisis. He instantly grasped that Stephen was talking about his wife. They have a good grasp of foreign languages.

def.en: #Grass# is a very common plant consisting of large numbers of thin, spiky, green leaves that cover the surface of the ground.
def.exmp: Small things stirred in the grass around the tent. The lawn contained a mixture of grasses. In the old days, there were strict fines for walking on the grass or missing a study period.
