I'm going to cut the grass. I started smoking grass when I was about sixteen. His wife wants him to grass on the members of his own gang. He was repeatedly attacked by other inmates, who accused him of grassing. How many of them are going to grass up their own kids to the police?

def.en: If you are #grateful# #for# something that someone has given you or done for you, you have warm, friendly feelings towards them and wish to thank them.
def.exmp: She was grateful to him for being so good to her. I should like to extend my grateful thanks to all the volunteers. 'That's kind of you, Sally,' Claire said gratefully.

def.en: #Gratitude# is the state of feeling grateful.
def.exmp: ...a sense of gratitude. I wish to express my gratitude to Kathy Davis for her immense practical help.

def.en: A #grave# is a place where a dead person is buried.
def.exmp: They used to visit her grave twice a year. ...drinking yourself to an early grave. Most men would rather go to the grave than own up to feelings of dependency. He said that the situation in his country is very grave. I have grave doubts that the documents tell the whole story. They had gravely impaired the credibility of the government. William was up on the roof for some time and when he came down he looked grave. Anxiously, she examined his unusually grave face. 'I think I've covered that business more than adequately,' he said gravely.

def.en: #Gravity# is the force which causes things to drop to the ground.
def.exmp: Arrows would continue to fly forward forever in a straight line were it not for gravity, which brings them down to earth. They deserve punishment which matches the gravity of their crime. Not all acts of vengeance are of equal gravity. There was an appealing gravity to everything she said.

def.en: When animals #graze# or #are grazed#, they eat the grass or other plants that are growing in a particular place.
def.exmp: Five cows graze serenely around a massive oak. The hills have been grazed by sheep because they were too steep to be ploughed. Several horses grazed the meadowland. ...a large herd of grazing animals. I had grazed my knees a little. ...grazed arms and legs. A bullet had grazed his arm. Wright managed a shot but it grazed the near post and rolled harmlessly across the goal.

def.en: #Grease# is a thick, oily substance which is put on the moving parts of cars and other machines in order to make them work smoothly.
def.exmp: ...grease-stained hands. I greased front and rear hubs and adjusted the brakes. His hair is thick with grease. He could smell the bacon grease. Grease two sturdy baking sheets and heat the oven to 400 degrees. Place the frozen rolls on a greased baking tray.

def.en: # Grease# is a thick, oily substance which is put on the moving parts of vehicles in order to make them work smoothly.
def.exmp: The amount of dust and #grease# on the engine indicated it had not been touched recently. #Grease# is an oil to which a thickening base has been added so that the end product is semi-solid. Oil and #grease# can deteriorate wires, belts, and hoses.

def.en: If you describe someone as #greedy#, you mean that they want to have more of something such as food or money than is necessary or fair.
def.exmp: He attacked greedy bosses for awarding themselves big rises. She is greedy and selfish. Livy ate the pasties greedily and with huge enjoyment.

def.en: A #greenhouse# is a glass building in which you grow plants that need to be protected from bad weather.
When you #greet# someone, you say 'Hello' or shake hands with them.
def.exmp: She liked to be home to greet Steve when he came in from school. The European Court's decision has been greeted with dismay by fishermen. It is unlikely that this suggestion will be greeted enthusiastically in the Baltic States. I was greeted by a shocking sight. The savoury smell greeted them as they went through the door.

def.en: A #greeting# is something friendly that you say or do when you meet someone.
def.exmp: His greeting was familiar and friendly. They exchanged greetings. He raised a hand in greeting.

def.en: #Grief# is a feeling of extreme sadness.
def.exmp: ...a huge outpouring of national grief for the victims of the shootings. Their grief soon gave way to anger.

def.en: If you #grieve# #over# something, especially someone's death, you feel very sad about it.
def.exmp: He's grieving over his dead wife and son. I didn't have any time to grieve. Margery's grieving family battled to come to terms with their loss. He was deeply grieved by the sufferings of the common people. I was grieved to hear of the suicide of James. It grieved me to see the poor man in such distress.

def.en: A situation or piece of information that is #grim# is unpleasant, depressing, and difficult to accept.
def.exmp: They painted a grim picture of growing crime. There was further grim economic news yesterday. The mood could not have been grimmer. ...an unrelenting grimness of tone. The city might be grim at first, but there is a vibrancy and excitement. ...the tower blocks on the city's grim edges. She was a grim woman with a turned-down mouth. Her expression was grim and unpleasant. 'It's too late now to stop him,' Harris said grimly. Things were pretty grim for a time.

def.en: When you #grin#, you smile broadly.
def.exmp: He grins, delighted at the memory. Sarah tried several times to catch Philip's eye, but he just grinned at her. ...a statue of a grinning old man cutting the throat of a deer. She came out of his office with a big grin on her face. Bobby looked at her with a sheepish grin.

def.en: If you #grind# a substance such as corn, you crush it between two hard surfaces or with a machine until it becomes a fine powder.
def.exmp: Store the peppercorns in an airtight container and grind the pepper as you need it. ...the odor of fresh ground coffee. He makes his own paint, grinding up the pigment with a little oil. 'Well,' I said, grinding my cigarette nervously into the granite step. ...a shop where they grind knives. The tip can be ground to a much sharper edge to cut smoother and faster. Tanks had crossed the border at five fifteen and were grinding south. The grind of heavy machines could get on their nerves. The daily grind of government is done by Her Majesty's Civil Service. Life continues to be a terrible grind for the ordinary person.

def.en: If you #grip# something, you take hold of it with your hand and continue to hold it firmly.
def.exmp: She gripped the rope. His strong hand eased the bag from her grip. The president maintains an iron grip on his country. Tony Blair last night tightened his grip on Labour mps with new powers to root out trouble-makers. Pain gripped him. The entire community has been gripped by fear. The nation is gripped by the dramatic story. The film turned out to be a gripping thriller. ...a new way of reinforcing rubber which gives car tyres better grip.

def.en: If you #groan#, you make a long, low sound because you are in pain, or because you are upset or unhappy about something.
def.exmp: Slowly, he opened his eyes. As he did so, he began to groan with pain. They glanced at the man on the floor, who began to groan. She was making small groaning noises. She heard him let out a pitiful, muffled groan. As his ball flew wide, there was a collective groan from the stands. 'My leg–I think it's broken,' Eric groaned. His parents were beginning to groan about the price of college tuition. Listen sympathetically to your child's moans and groans about what she can't do. The timbers groan and creak and the floorboards shift. The bar counter groans under the weight of huge plates of the freshest fish. ...a table groaning with food. Consumers were groaning under the weight of high interest rates. Bookshelves groan under the burden of books on threats to the environment.

def.en: A #grocer# is a shopkeeper who sells foods such as flour, sugar, and tinned foods.
A # grocer# is an individual, company, or chain selling foodstuffs.
def.exmp: This report ranks the top #grocers# based on free-range and eco-friendly products. Asian food #grocers# are good places to find more exotic ingredients not available in your local supermarket. A #grocer# is an individual, company, or chain selling foodstuffs.

def.en: If you #grope# #for# something that you cannot see, you try to find it by moving your hands around in order to feel it.
def.exmp: With his left hand he groped for the knob, turned it, and pulled the door open. Bunbury groped in his breast pocket for his wallet. I didn't turn on the light, but groped my way across the room. He groped for solutions to the problems facing the country. She groped for a simple word to express a simple idea. They continue their groping towards a constitutional settlement. He would try to grope her breasts and put his hand up her skirt. She even boasted of having a grope in a cupboard with a 13-year-old.

def.en: You use #gross# to describe something unacceptable or unpleasant to a very great amount, degree, or intensity.
def.exmp: The company were guilty of gross negligence. ...an act of gross injustice. Funding of education had been grossly inadequate for years. She was grossly overweight. He abused the Admiral in the grossest terms. I feel disgusted and wonder how I could ever have been so gross. They had a commercial on the other night for Drug Free America that was so gross I thought Daddy was going to faint. He wears really gross holiday outfits. I only resist things like chocolate if I feel really gross. ...a fixed rate account guaranteeing 10.4% gross interest or 7.8% net until October. Interest is paid gross, rather than having tax deducted. ...a father earning £20,000 gross a year. National Savings gross sales in June totalled £709 million. I'm a factory worker who grossed £9,900 last year. So far the films have grossed more than £590 million. He ordered twelve gross of the disks.

def.en: # Gross# refers to the total amount of something, especially money, before anything has been taken away.
If a person or a company # grosses# a particular amount of money, they earn it as total revenue, before deductions such as expenses and tax.
def.exmp: The popular brand #grossed# $65 million in sales last year. By her third year, she was #grossing# $6 million, thanks to a fortuitous contract with the superstore. If a person or a company #grosses# a particular amount of money, they earn it as total revenue, before deductions such as expenses and tax.

def.en: # Gross# refers to the total amount of something, especially money, before anything has been taken away.
If a person or a company # grosses# a particular amount of money, they earn it as total revenue, before deductions such as expenses and tax.
def.exmp: The popular brand #grossed# $65 million in sales last year. By her third year, she was #grossing# $6 million, thanks to a fortuitous contract with the superstore. If a person or a company #grosses# a particular amount of money, they earn it as total revenue, before deductions such as expenses and tax.

def.en: If an organization issues #guidelines# #on# something, it issues official advice about how to do it.
def.exmp: The government should issue clear guidelines on the content of religious education. The accord also lays down guidelines for the conduct of American drug enforcement agents. The effects of the sun can be significantly reduced if we follow certain guidelines. A written IQ test is merely a guideline.

def.en: #Guilt# is an unhappy feeling that you have because you have done something wrong or think that you have done something wrong.
def.exmp: Her emotions had ranged from anger to guilt in the space of a few seconds. Some cancer patients experience strong feelings of guilt. The trial is concerned only with the determination of guilt according to criminal law. You weren't convinced of Mr Matthews' guilt.

def.en: #The Gulf# is used to refer to the Arabian Gulf, the Persian Gulf and the surrounding countries.
def.exmp: ...the Gulf crisis. ...the Gulf War. ...the oil wells of the Gulf.

def.en: A #gulf# is an important or significant difference between two people, things, or groups.
def.exmp: Within society, there is a growing gulf between rich and poor. ...the gulf between rural and urban life. Hurricane Andrew was last night heading into the Gulf of Mexico.

def.en: #Gum# is a substance, usually tasting of mint, which you chew for a long time but do not swallow.
def.exmp: The toothbrush gently removes plaque without damaging the gums. ...gum disease. He was holding up a pound note that had been torn in half and stuck together with gum. ...gummed labels. It is a mild infection in which a baby's eyelashes can become gummed together.

def.en: A person's or animal's #guts# are all the organs inside them.
def.exmp: By the time they finish, the crewmen are standing ankle-deep in fish guts. It is not always necessary to gut the fish prior to freezing. The new Chancellor has the guts to push through unpopular tax increases. It takes more guts than I've usually got to go and see him. Let's have your gut reaction to the facts as we know them. His gut sagged out over his belt. She has a reputation for getting at the guts of a subject and never pulling her punches. The guts of the reactor have to be hauled out of the pressure vessel. Over the weekend, a firebomb gutted a building where 60 people lived. A factory stands gutted and deserted.

def.en: A #guy# is a man.
def.exmp: I was working with a guy from Manchester. Hi, guys. How are you doing? Mom wants to know if you guys still have that two-person tent.

def.en:
A #gymnasium# is the same as a gym
Exmp:
A #habit# is something that you do often or regularly.
def.exmp: He has an endearing habit of licking his lips when he's nervous. Many people add salt to their food out of habit, without even tasting it first. ...a survey on eating habits in the U.K.. A good way to break the habit of eating too quickly is to put your knife and fork down after each mouthful. After twenty years as a chain smoker Mr Nathe has given up the habit. She became a prostitute in order to pay for her cocaine habit.

def.en: The #habitat# of an animal or plant is the natural environment in which it normally lives or grows.
def.exmp: In its natural habitat, the hibiscus will grow up to 25ft. Few countries have as rich a diversity of habitat as South Africa.

def.en: If a person, event, or achievement #is hailed# #as# important or successful, they are praised publicly.
def.exmp: Faulkner has been hailed as the greatest American novelist of his generation. U.S. magazines hailed her as the greatest rock'n'roll singer in the world. The deal was hailed by the Defence Secretary. ...a sharp short-lived storm with heavy hail. It started to hail, huge great stones. The victim was hit by a hail of bullets. The riot police were met with a hail of stones and petrol bombs. I hail from Brighton. The band hail from Glasgow. He hails from an affluent background. This is a film which seems to hail from the hippie era. Jill saw him and hailed him. Suddenly, a voice hailed us and there was Miss Quigley. I hurried away to hail a taxi. Hail to the new champion Bengali D'Albret.

def.en: The #hall# in a house or flat is the area just inside the front door, into which some of the other rooms open.
def.exmp: The lights were on in the hall and in the bedroom. Its 300 inhabitants will be celebrating with a dance in the village hall. We picked up our conference materials and filed into the lecture hall. It was brilliant to hear George Harrison in concert at the Royal Albert Hall last week. He died at Holly Hall, his wife's family home. ...New York's Carnegie Hall.

def.en: A # hall# in a building is a long passage with doors into rooms on both sides of it.
def.exmp: There are ten rooms along each #hall#. The lights were on in the #hall# and in the guest bedrooms. Your room is the last door at the right side of the #hall#.

def.en: When a person or a vehicle #halts# or when something #halts# them, they stop moving in the direction they were going and stand still.
def.exmp: They halted at a short distance from the house. The engine note changed as the aircraft landed, taxied and halted. She held her hand out flat, to halt him. Striking workers halted production at the auto plant yesterday. He criticised the government for failing to halt economic decline. The flow of assistance to Vietnam's fragile economy from its ideological allies has virtually halted. The colonel ordered 'Halt!'

def.en: #Ham# is meat from the top of the back leg of a pig, specially treated so that it can be kept for a long period of time.
def.exmp: ...a huge baked ham. ...ham sandwiches. ...a dozen slices of ham. I became a ham radio operator at the age of eleven.

def.en: # Ham# is meat from the top of the back leg of a pig, specially treated so that it can be kept for a long period of time.
A #hammer# is a tool that consists of a heavy piece of metal at the end of a handle.
def.exmp: He used a hammer and chisel to chip away at the wall. To avoid damaging the tree, hammer a wooden peg into the hole. Builders were still hammering outside the window. The workers kneel on the ground and hammer the small stones in. The noise of hammering was dulled by the secondary glazing. We had to hammer and shout before they would open up. A crowd of reporters was hammering on the door. He hammered his two clenched fists on the table. As he said it, there was a hammering outside. He hammered it into me that I had not suddenly become a rotten goalkeeper. Recent advertising campaigns from the industry have hammered at these themes. The report hammers the private motorist. If we turned up late we would be hammered by everybody. Parents have taken a terrible hammering. Look at the numbers of small businesses that are being hammered unmercifully. The company has been hammered by the downturn in the construction and motor industries. He hammered the young Austrian player in four straight sets. Our cricketers are suffering their ritual hammering at the hands of the Aussies. My heart was hammering. The footsteps had stopped outside my door. Events like the hammer and the discus are not traditional crowd-pullers in the West.

def.en: If someone or something #hampers# you, they make it difficult for you to do what you are trying to do.
def.exmp: The bad weather hampered rescue operations. I was hampered by a lack of information. ...a luxury food hamper. ...a picnic hamper.

def.en: A #handful# #of# people or things is a small number of them.
def.exmp: He surveyed the handful of customers at the bar. One spring morning a handful of potential investors assembled in Quincy. She scooped up a handful of sand and let it trickle through her fingers. Zara can be a handful sometimes.

def.en: A #handicap# is a physical or mental disability.
def.exmp: He lost his leg when he was ten, but learnt to overcome his handicap. She was away from school for 15 weeks, a handicap she could have done without. Being a foreigner was not a handicap. Greater levels of stress may seriously handicap some students. The industrial injuries scheme takes into account the actual disability and whether it handicaps a person in working. I see your handicap is down from 16 to 12.

def.en: A #handkerchief# is a small square piece of fabric which you use for blowing your nose.
A #handle# is a small round object or a lever that is attached to a door and is used for opening and closing it.
def.exmp: I turned the handle and found the door was open. The handle of a cricket bat protruded from under his arm. ...a broom handle. To tell the truth, I don't know if I can handle the job. She cannot handle pressure. You must learn how to handle your feelings. I think I would handle a meeting with Mr. Siegel very badly. She admitted to herself she didn't know how to handle the problem. The family has criticized the military's handling of Robert's death. She handled travel arrangements for the press corps during the presidential campaign. The investigation is being handled by Scotland Yard's anti terrorist branch. I had never handled an automatic. His ship had handled like a dream! Wear rubber gloves when handling cat litter. When you have got a handle on your anxiety you can begin to control it.

def.en: Something that is #handy# is useful.
def.exmp: The book gives handy hints on looking after indoor plants. Credit cards can be handy–they mean you do not have to carry large sums of cash. It would be good to have a pencil and paper handy. Keep handy a lightweight sweater or cardigan. This lively town is handy for Londoners. If you're handy with a needle you could brighten up your sweater with giant daisies.

def.en: If something #hangs# in a high place or position, or if you #hang# it there, it is attached there so it does not touch the ground.
def.exmp: Notices painted on sheets hang at every entrance. A light-bulb hanging from the ceiling filled the room with a cold yellow light. The curtains will be hanging there for years. I was left hanging by my finger-tips over a drop of hundreds of feet. ...small hanging lanterns. They saw a young woman come out of the house to hang clothes on a line. I found his jacket, which was hanging up in the hallway. Some prisoners climbed onto the roof and hung up a banner. ...a ragged fur coat that hung down to her calves. Look for a suit made from good, sturdy cloth to ensure it hangs well. She was standing by the door, her blue robe hanging from her shoulders. ...her long golden hair which hung loose about her shoulders. The window sashes were missing, the doors hung open, or were gone altogether. She froze, her mouth hanging open. The walls were hung with huge modern paintings. ...a line of wall hooks hung with old anoraks and mud-stained overalls. The five were expected to be hanged at 7 am on Tuesday. It is right that their murderers should hang. He hanged himself two hours after arriving at a mental hospital. Four steamboat loads of spectators came to view a hanging in New Orleans. His breath was hanging in the air before him. A haze of expensive perfume hangs around her. A constant threat of unemployment hangs over thousands of university researchers. A question mark hangs over many of their futures. Once the Americans decide to do a thing, they do it well, and hang the cost.

def.en: #Harassment# is behaviour which is intended to trouble or annoy someone, for example repeated attacks on them or attempts to cause them problems.
def.exmp: Another survey found that 51 per cent of women had experienced some form of sexual harassment in their working lives. ...racial harassment. The party has accused the police of harassment.

def.en: When something #hardens# or when you #harden# it, it becomes stiff or firm.
def.exmp: Mould the mixture into shape while hot, before it hardens. Give the cardboard two or three coats of varnish to harden it. Their action can only serve to harden the attitude of landowners. The bitter split which has developed within Solidarity is likely to harden further into separation. ...a hardening of the government's attitude towards rebellious parts of the army. Property prices are just beginning to harden again. Her years of drunken bickering hardened my heart. She was hardened by the rigours of the Siberian steppes. All of a sudden my heart hardened against her. His smile died and the look in his face hardened.

def.en: If people are living #in# #harmony# #with# each other, they are living together peacefully rather than fighting or arguing.
def.exmp: We must try to live in peace and harmony with ourselves and those around us. He projected himself as the protector of national unity and harmony. ...complex vocal harmonies. ...singing in harmony. ...the ordered harmony of the universe. He looked more relaxed, as if some of the harmony from his surroundings had flowed into him.

def.en: If you #harness# something such as an emotion or natural source of energy, you bring it under your control and use it.
def.exmp: ...the movement's ability to harness the anger of all Ukrainians. Turkey plans to harness the waters of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers for big hydro-electric power projects. On Sunday the horses were harnessed to a heavy wagon for a day-long ride over the Border.

def.en: #Harsh# climates or conditions are very difficult for people, animals, and plants to live in.
def.exmp: The weather grew harsh, chilly and unpredictable. ...the harsh desert environment. ...after the harsh experience of the war. ...the harshness of their living conditions. ...the cold, harsh cruelty of her husband. He said many harsh and unkind things about his opponents. She's been told that her husband is being harshly treated in prison. 'Why didn't you tell me before?' asked Hunter harshly. ...treating him with great harshness. Tropical colours may look rather harsh in our dull northern light. ...harsher detergents that can leave hair brittle. ...as the wine ages, losing its bitter harshness. It's a pity she has such a loud harsh voice. Chris laughed harshly. Then in a tone of abrupt harshness, he added, 'Open these trunks!'. The harsh truth is that luck plays a big part in who will live or die.

def.en: #The harvest# is the gathering of a crop.
def.exmp: There were about 300 million tons of grain in the fields at the start of the harvest. ...a bumper potato harvest. Millions of people are threatened with starvation as a result of drought and poor harvests. Many farmers are refusing to harvest the cane. ...freshly harvested beetroot. ...war is hampering harvesting and the distribution of food aid. In his new career as a restaurateur he has blossomed and harvested many awards.

def.en: #Haste# is the quality of doing something quickly, sometimes too quickly so that you are careless and make mistakes.
def.exmp: In their haste to escape the rising water, they dropped some expensive equipment. The translations bear the signs of inaccuracy and haste.

def.en: A #hasty# movement, action, or statement is sudden, and often done in reaction to something that has just happened.
def.exmp: One company is giving its employees airplane tickets in the event they need to make a hasty escape. 'It may be satisfying, but it's not fun.' 'No, I'm sure it's not,' said Virginia hastily. 'I didn't mean that.' After the hasty meal, the men had moved forward to take up their positions. He said good night hastily, promising that he would phone Hans in the morning. The survivors were recovering in hastily erected tents. So let's not be hasty. After all, he can't run away. A number of the United States' allies had urged him not to take a hasty decision. I decided that nothing should be done hastily, that things had to be sorted out carefully.

def.en: When a baby bird, insect, or other animal #hatches#, or when it #is hatched#, it comes out of its egg by breaking the shell.
def.exmp: As soon as the two chicks hatch, they leave the nest burrow. The young disappeared soon after they were hatched. The eggs hatch after a week or ten days. During these periods the birds will lie on the cage floor as if trying to lay or hatch eggs. Seeing the eggs hatch out for the first time is a moment that I will never forget. He has accused opposition parties of hatching a plot to assassinate the Pope. He stuck his head up through the hatch. All deck fittings, windows, hatches and doors had been fastened.

def.en: #Hatred# is an extremely strong feeling of dislike for someone or something.
def.exmp: Her hatred of them would never lead her to murder. My hatred for her is so intense it seems to be destroying me. He has been accused of inciting racial hatred.

def.en: If you #haul# something which is heavy or difficult to move, you move it using a lot of effort.
def.exmp: A crane had to be used to haul the car out of the stream. He hauled himself to his feet. She hauled up her bedroom window and leaned out. She was hauled before magistrates for refusing to reveal her age to a policeman. He was hauled before the managing director and fired. He was hauled up before the Board of Trustees. She was late for the interview after being hauled up for speeding. The size of the drugs haul shows that the international trade in heroin is still flourishing. Another break-in yielded a £4,000 haul of jewellery.

def.en: A #hawk# is a large bird with a short, hooked beak, sharp claws, and very good eyesight.
def.exmp: Both hawks and doves have expanded their conditions for ending the war. ...vendors hawking trinkets. Developers will be hawking cut-price flats and houses. He is hawking around a 15-minute, £5,000 promotional video. Most of the women were hawking food around the various prisons. He hawked and spat.

def.en: #Hay# is grass which has been cut and dried so that it can be used to feed animals.
def.exmp: ...bales of hay. ...traditional hay making methods.

def.en: A #hazard# is something which could be dangerous to you, your health or safety, or your plans or reputation.
def.exmp: A new report suggests that chewing-gum may be a health hazard. Oil leaking from a barge in the Mississippi River poses a hazard to the drinking water of New Orleans. He could not believe that, had the Englishman known how much he was at risk, he would have hazarded his grandson. I would hazard a guess that they'll do fairly well in the next election. 'Fifteen or sixteen?' Mrs Dearden hazarded.

def.en: A # hazard# is anything which can harm or damage someone or something.
def.exmp: Safe work practices and the use of protective equipment may be needed for exposures to chemicals and other #hazards# such as noise and heat. Process #hazards# may cause major accidents involving the release of potentially dangerous materials. A #hazard# is anything which can harm or damage someone or something.

def.en: A # hazard# is something that increases the possibility or size of a loss.
def.exmp: The storing of explosives in a home basement is a #hazard# that increases the probability of an explosion. Coverage is provided for a wide range of #hazards# including theft, weather, fire, and collision. A #hazard# is something that increases the possibility or size of a loss.

def.en: You use #he# to refer to a man, boy, or male animal.
def.exmp: He could never quite remember all our names. He lives in Rapid City, South Dakota. Our dog Rex did all sorts of tricks. I cried when he died. The teacher should encourage the child to proceed as far as he can, and when he is stuck, ask for help.
...H.E. the Italian Ambassador.

def.en: A #heading# is the title of a piece of writing, which is written or printed at the top of the page.
def.exmp: ...helpful chapter headings.

def.en: A #headline# is the title of a newspaper story, printed in large letters at the top of the story, especially on the front page.
def.exmp: The Daily Mail has the headline 'The Voice of Conscience'. I'm sick of reading headlines involving the Kennedys in sex scandals. I'm Claudia Polley with the news headlines. The article was headlined 'Tell us the truth'. Sir Cliff Richard headlined the event.

def.en: The #headquarters# of an organization are its main offices.
def.exmp: ...fraud squad officers from London's police headquarters. The building is the headquarters of the family firm.

def.en: If you #heave# something heavy or difficult to move somewhere, you push, pull, or lift it using a lot of effort.
def.exmp: It took five strong men to heave the statue up a ramp and lower it into place. He heaved Barney to his feet. He heaved himself up off his stool. It took only one heave to hurl him into the river. His chest heaved, and he took a deep breath. ...the grey, heaving seas. He gasped and heaved and vomited again. My stomach heaved and I felt sick. Mr Collier heaved a sigh and got to his feet. The Happy Bunny club was heaving. Father Auberon's Academy Club positively heaved with dashing young men.

def.en: A #hedge# is a row of bushes or small trees, usually along the edge of a garden, field, or road.
def.exmp: You can hedge against redundancy or illness with insurance. Today's clever financial instruments make it possible for firms to hedge their risks. Gold is traditionally a hedge against inflation. They hedged in answering various questions about the operation. 'I can't give you an answer now,' he hedged.

def.en: If you # hedge#, you reduce risk when conducting a transaction by doing an opposite transaction.
def.exmp: Investors were plowing their funds into oil and other commodities to #hedge# against inflation. Private companies owe more than half of the country's foreign debt, much of it consisting of loans which were not #hedged# against currency risks. If you #hedge#, you reduce risk when conducting a transaction by doing an opposite transaction.

def.en: If you # hedge#, you reduce risk when conducting a transaction by doing an opposite transaction.
def.exmp: Investors were plowing their funds into oil and other commodities to #hedge# against inflation. Private companies owe more than half of the country's foreign debt, much of it consisting of loans which were not #hedged# against currency risks. If you #hedge#, you reduce risk when conducting a transaction by doing an opposite transaction.

def.en: Your #heel# is the back part of your foot, just below your ankle.
def.exmp: He kicked it shut with the heel of his boot. ...the shoes with the high heels. ...two well-dressed ladies in high heels. ...the old adage that you shouldn't wear heels with trousers. He shoved the heel of his hand against the side of my face.

def.en: If something #heightens# a feeling or if the feeling #heightens#, the feeling increases in degree or intensity.
def.exmp: The move has heightened tension in the state. These latest murders have heightened fears of further attacks. Cross's interest heightened. ...a heightened awareness of the dangers that they now face.

def.en: An #heir# is someone who has the right to inherit a person's money, property, or title when that person dies.
def.exmp: His heir, Lord Doune, cuts a bit of a dash in the city. ...the heir to the throne.

def.en: A #helmet# is a hat made of a strong material which you wear to protect your head.
A #hemisphere# is one half of the earth.
def.exmp: ...the northern hemisphere. In most people, the left hemisphere is bigger than the right.

def.en: A #hen# is a female chicken.
def.exmp: ...ostrich hens.

def.en: You use #hence# to indicate that the statement you are about to make is a consequence of what you have just said.
def.exmp: The trade imbalance is likely to rise again in 1990. Hence a new set of policy actions will be required soon. Whatever is hidden is harmful (hence revelation equals security). European music happens to use a scale of eight notes, hence the use of the term octave. The Socialist Party was profoundly divided and hence very weak. The gases that may be warming the planet will have their main effect many years hence. ...the much larger peacekeeping force that is meant to be fully deployed five months hence.

def.en: #Henceforth# means from this time onwards.
def.exmp: Henceforth, parties which fail to get 5% of the vote will not be represented in parliament. We were finally released with a formal warning that we were henceforth barred from the base.

def.en: A #herb# is a plant whose leaves are used in cooking to add flavour to food, or as a medicine.
A #herd# is a large group of animals of one kind that live together.
def.exmp: ...large herds of elephant and buffalo. ...dairy herds. They are individuals; they will not follow the herd. He began to herd the prisoners out. The group was herded into a bus. Stefano used a motor cycle to herd the sheep. A boy herded half a dozen camels down towards the water trough.

def.en: If you describe a person or their actions as #heroic#, you admire them because they show extreme bravery.
def.exmp: The heroic sergeant risked his life to rescue 29 fishermen from their blazing trawler. His heroic deeds were celebrated in every corner of India. He had acted heroically during the liner's evacuation. The company has made heroic efforts at cost reduction. He finally faltered in the last game of a heroic match. Their dogged single-mindedness is almost heroic. Single parents cope heroically in doing the job of two people. ...the book's central, heroic figure. ...the man whose aerial heroics helped save the helicopter pilot. England need heroics from the captain now. He said his advice was: 'No heroics, stay within the law'. Cut it out, Perry. You've performed your heroics. It's all over now.

def.en: The #heroine# of a book, play, film, or story is the main female character, who usually has good qualities.
def.exmp: The heroine is a senior TV executive. The national heroine of the day was Xing Fen, winner of the first Gold medal of the Games. My heroine was Elizabeth Taylor.

def.en: A #hierarchy# is a system of organizing people into different ranks or levels of importance, for example in society or in a company.
def.exmp: Like most other American companies with a rigid hierarchy, workers and managers had strictly defined duties. She rose up the Tory hierarchy by the local government route. Even in the desert there was a kind of social hierarchy. ...the notion of 'cultural imperialism' implies a hierarchy of cultures, some of which are stronger than others.

def.en: If someone or something #highlights# a point or problem, they emphasize it or make you think about it.
def.exmp: Last year Collins wrote a moving ballad which highlighted the plight of the homeless. Once again, the 'Free Press' prefers not to highlight these facts. Two events have highlighted the tensions in recent days. Highlight the chosen area by clicking and holding down the left mouse button. ...the relevant maps with the route highlighted in yellow. ...a match that is likely to prove one of the highlights of the tournament. The highlight of my day used to be cooking Meg a meal when she came in from work. I don't want to watch the game now. I'll just wait till the highlights come on later tonight.

def.en: A #highway# is a main road, especially one that connects towns or cities.
def.exmp: I crossed the highway, dodging the traffic.

def.en: If someone #hijacks# a plane or other vehicle, they illegally take control of it by force while it is travelling from one place to another.
def.exmp: Two men tried to hijack a plane on a flight from Riga to Murmansk. A Korean airliner was hijacked by two passengers and forced to fly to Tashkent. The hijacked plane exploded in a ball of fire. Every minute during the hijack seemed like a week. Car hijackings are running at a rate of nearly 50 a day. A peaceful demonstration had been hijacked by anarchists intent on causing trouble.

def.en: A #hike# is a long walk in the country, especially one that you go on for pleasure.
def.exmp: You could hike through the Fish River Canyon. We plan to hike the Samaria Gorge. ...some harder, more strenuous hiking on cliff pathways. ...heavy hiking boots. ...a sudden 1.75 per cent hike in Italian interest rates. His economic plan, with its tax hikes and spending cuts, will slow the economy. It has now been forced to hike its rates by 5.25 per cent. TSB's monthly credit card rate is now hiked from 1.95% to 2.05%. The federal government hiked the tax on hard liquor. The insurers have started hiking up premiums by huge amounts. Big banks were hiking their rates up.

def.en: If something #hinders# you, it makes it more difficult for you to do something or make progress.
def.exmp: Does the fact that your players are part-timers help or hinder you? Further investigation was hindered by the loss of all documentation on the case. A thigh injury increasingly hindered her mobility. Landslides and bad weather are continuing to hinder the arrival of relief supplies to the area.

def.en: A #hinge# is a piece of metal, wood, or plastic that is used to join a door to its frame or to join two things together so that one of them can swing freely.
def.exmp: The top swung open on well-oiled hinges.

def.en: A # hinge# is a device consisting of two interlocking metal pieces held by a pin around which they pivot.
def.exmp: One half of the #hinge# is welded to the door pillar, and the other half welded to the door, so that it does not come loose with repeated opening and closing of the door. The lid of the box is connected to the base by #hinges#. A #hinge# is a device consisting of two interlocking metal pieces held by a pin around which they pivot.

def.en: Your #hips# are the two areas at the sides of your body between the tops of your legs and your waist.
def.exmp: Tracey put her hands on her hips and sighed. He is broad-chested and narrow-hipped. ...a hip young character with tight-cropped blond hair and stylish glasses.

def.en: A #historian# is a person who specializes in the study of history, and who writes books and articles about it.
Something that is #historic# is important in history, or likely to be considered important at some time in the future.
def.exmp: ...the historic changes in Eastern Europe. ...a fourth historic election victory.

def.en: You use #hitherto# to indicate that something was true up until the time you are talking about, although it may no longer be the case.
def.exmp: The polytechnics have hitherto been at an unfair disadvantage in competing for pupils and money. Hitherto, the main emphasis has been on the need to resist aggression. The helicopter is the first in the world to be designed to serve three hitherto very distinct markets.

def.en: If you #hoist# something heavy somewhere, you lift it or pull it up there.
def.exmp: Hoisting my suitcase on to my shoulder, I turned and headed toward my hotel. Grabbing the side of the bunk, he hoisted himself to a sitting position. A twenty-foot steel pyramid is to be hoisted into position on top of the tower. Then a crane hoisted him on to the platform. A group of youths hoisted their flag on top of the disputed monument.

def.en: A #holder# is someone who owns or has something.
def.exmp: This season the club has had 73,500 season-ticket holders. ...Peter Koech, the record holder in the 3, 000 metres steeplechase. ...the holders of the European Football Championship. ...a toothbrush holder. ...a cigarette holder.

def.en: Something that is #hollow# has a space inside it, as opposed to being solid all the way through.
def.exmp: ...a hollow tree. ...a hollow cylinder. He looked young, dark and sharp-featured, with hollow cheeks. I made my home there, in the hollow of a dying elm. Below him the town lay warm in the hollow of the hill. ...where water gathers in a hollow and forms a pond. Any threat to bring in the police is a hollow one. ...a hollow man who's coasted on charm for far too long. One month before the deadline we see the hollowness of these promises. Murray Pick's hollow laugh had no mirth in it. ...the hollow sound of a gunshot. The mule's back was hollowed by the weight of its burden. ...her high, elegantly hollowed cheekbones.

def.en: #Homogeneous# is used to describe a group or thing which has members or parts that are all the same.
def.exmp: The unemployed are not a homogeneous group. Russia is ethnically relatively homogeneous.

def.en: If you describe people or actions as #honourable#, you mean that they are good and deserve to be respected and admired.
def.exmp: I believe he was an honourable man, dedicated to the people and his union. He argued that the only honorable course of action was death. However, their intentions are honourable. He also felt she had not behaved honorably in the leadership election. ...the Honourable Mr Justice Swinton Thomas. ...the Honourable Member for Billericay.

def.en: A #hook# is a bent piece of metal or plastic that is used for catching or holding things, or for hanging things up.
def.exmp: One of his jackets hung from a hook. ...curtain hooks. He felt a fish pull at his hook. Paul hooked his tractor to the car and pulled it to safety. ...one of those can openers that hooked onto the wall. She latched on to his arm, hooking her other arm around a tree. I hooked my left arm over the side of the dinghy. At the first cast I hooked a huge fish. Lewis desperately needs to keep clear of Ruddock's big left hook. I'm guessing again now because I'm not hooked into the political circles. Eager to hook into a career but can't find one right for you? ...an interactive media tent where people will be able to hook into the internet. ...a U.K. firm that lets Britons hook up to the Internet.

def.en: If you #hop#, you move along by jumping on one foot.
def.exmp: I hopped down three steps. Malcolm hopped rather than walked. 'This really is a catchy rhythm, huh?' he added, with a few little hops. A small brown fawn hopped across the trail in front of them. The rabbit got up, took four hops and turned round. My wife and I were the first to arrive and hopped on board. I hopped out of bed quickly. It is a three-hour drive from Geneva but can be reached by a 20-minute hop in a private helicopter. They were afraid of being turned down when they asked girls to dance at high school hops.

def.en: Something that is #horizontal# is flat and level with the ground, rather than at an angle to it.
def.exmp: The board consists of vertical and horizontal lines. Swing the club back until it is horizontal. Do not raise your left arm above the horizontal. The wind was cold and drove the snow at him almost horizontally. ...a horizontally striped tie. The undulating planes of the countryside provide relief from the hard horizontals and verticals of the urban scene.

def.en: On a vehicle such as a car, the #horn# is the device that makes a loud noise as a signal or warning.
def.exmp: He sounded the car horn. A mature cow has horns. ...a hunting horn. ...a wind-up gramophone with a big horn.

def.en: On a vehicle such as a car, the # horn# is the device that makes a loud noise as a signal or warning.
#Horror# is a feeling of great shock, fear, and worry caused by something extremely unpleasant.
def.exmp: I felt numb with horror. As I watched in horror the boat began to power away from me. ...his horror of death. ...the horror of this most bloody of civil wars. Can you possibly imagine all the horrors we have undergone since I last wrote you? Our host was arrogant and offensive. How his sweet wife could tolerate such a horror was baffling. ...a psychological horror film. ...a horror story about lost luggage while flying.

def.en: #Horsepower# is a unit of power used for measuring how powerful an engine is.
def.exmp: The engine has more than 4,000 horsepower. ...a 300-horsepower engine.

def.en: # Horsepower# is a unit of power used for measuring how powerful an engine is.
def.exmp: This vehicle has a 300-#horsepower# engine. The term #horsepower# describes how much power an engine can produce, and is directly related to how much speed a car can achieve. The 3-liter engine was meant to give 300 #horsepower# at 7500 rpm.

def.en: A #hose# is a long, flexible pipe made of rubber or plastic.
def.exmp: You've left the garden hose on. The firemen unwrapped their hoses and began dousing the scorched grain silos. Water in the engine compartment is sucked away by a hose. We wash our cars and hose our gardens without even thinking of the water that uses. If you have varicose veins, consider wearing elastic support hose.

def.en: A # hose# is a flexible pipe for carrying a liquid or gas.
def.exmp: The water is connected to the faucet by a length of rubber #hose#. Water sprays out like water from a garden #hose#. A #hose# is a flexible pipe for carrying a liquid or gas.

def.en: #Hospitality# is friendly, welcoming behaviour towards guests or people you have just met.
def.exmp: Every visitor to Georgia is overwhelmed by the kindness, charm and hospitality of the people. A few of us in the press were there, goggle-eyed at the lavish hospitality. ...corporate hospitality tents.

def.en: A #hostage# is someone who has been captured by a person or organization and who may be killed or injured if people do not do what that person or organization demands.
def.exmp: It is hopeful that two hostages will be freed in the next few days. With the reduction in foreign investments, the government will be even more a hostage to the whims of the international oil price. Wine growers say they've been held hostage to the interests of the cereal and soybean farmers.
